PREFACE 
This Code constitutes a complete recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Racine, Wisconsin. 
Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1973 Code, as supplemented through October 16, 1990, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the common council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1973 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CHARTER ORDINANCES 	CHT:1 
CHARTER ORDINANCES COMPARATIVE TABLE 	CHTCT:1 
CODE 	CD1:1 
CODE APPENDIX 	CDA:1 
CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES 	CCT:1 
STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE 	SLT:1 
CHARTER ORDINANCES INDEX 	CHTi:1 
CODE INDEX 	CDi:1 
 
Indexes 
The indexes have been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the indexes themselves which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
This publication was under the direct supervision of Alyce Whitson, Supervising Editor, and Charles Vignos, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
The publisher is most grateful to Dan Wright, Deputy City Attorney, Karen Norton, City Clerk, and the other members of the city staff, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs. 
	MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION 
Tallahassee, Florida 
 
ADOPTING ORDINANCE 
ORDINANCE NO. 28-94 
An Ordinance Adopting and Enacting a New Code for the City of Racine, Wisconsin; Providing for the Repeal of Certain Ordinances Not Included Therein; Providing a Penalty for the Violation Thereof; Providing for the Manner of Amending Such Code; and Providing When Such Code and This Ordinance Shall Become Effective. 
The Common Council of the City of Racine, do[es] ordain as follows: 
Section 1. The Code entitled "Municipal Code of the City of Racine, Wisconsin," published by Municipal Code Corporation consisting of Chapters 1 to 114, each inclusive, is adopted. 
Section 2. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before October 5, 1994, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. 
Section 3. The repeal provided for in Section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. 
Section 4. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provisions of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof, shall be subject to a forfeiture of not less than $1.00 and not more than $1,000.00, plus the cost of prosecution. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided shall apply to the amendment of any Code section whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the city may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief, and revocation of licenses or permits. 
Section 5. Additions or amendments to the Code when passed in the form as to indicate the intention of the common council to make the same a part of the Code shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
Section 6. Ordinances adopted after October 5, 1994 that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code, shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
Section 7. This ordinance shall take effect upon passage and the day after publication. 
Passed by the Common Council this 3rd day of January, 1995. 
Approved by the Common Council this 3rd day of January, 1995. 
	/s/ N. Owen Davies 
      Mayor 
 	 
ATTEST: 
/s/ Karen M. Norton 
      City Clerk

ARTICLE I. - COMMON COUNCIL 
 
Sec. 1-1. - One alderman for each aldermanic district. 
There shall be one alderman and no more from each aldermanic district in the City of Racine. 
(Ch. Ord. of 6-3-53, pt. 1) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 3.01.010. 
State Law reference— Charter ordinance providing one alderman from each aldermanic district, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(1)(b).  
Sec. 1-2. - Terms of aldermen. 
All aldermen shall be elected for terms of two years. 
(Ch. Ord. of 12-7-65; Ch. Ord. of 12-7-71; Ch. Ord. of 3-8-72) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 3.01.020. The reference to § 3.01.030 has been editorially deleted as that section was repealed by Charter Ordinance of 3-8-72. 
State Law reference— Two-year term of office unless established otherwise by charter ordinance, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(5)(b).  
Sec. 1-3. - Term of office of mayor. 
The mayor elected at the regular city election to be held in April, 1991, and subsequent elections shall be elected for a term of four years. 
(Ch. Ord. of 8-1-89, pt. 1) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 3.02.010.  
ARTICLE II. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Manner of choosing officers, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(3); method of choosing officers in effect on April 15, 1939 shall remain in effect until changed by charter ordinance, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(3)(b)6; oath and bond of certain persons required, Wis. Stats. §§ 19.01, 62.09(4)(a). 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-1. - Appointment of city officials. 
The offices of city clerk, city assessor, city attorney, city engineer, commissioner of public works, director of information systems, human resources director and traffic engineer, shall be filled by appointment by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the common council. 
(Ch. Ord. of 6-16-70(1), pt. 14(1); Ch. Ord. of 9-20-00, pt. 1; Ch. Ord. of 12-6-05, pt. 1; Ch. Ord. No. 0001-08, pt. 1, 6-23-09; Ord. No. 0001-19, pt. 1, 2-20-19) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as part of § 3.015.010. 
State Law reference— Officers, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(1)(a).  
Sec. 2-2. - Term of office. 
All appointments to the following offices shall be for an indefinite term, subject to removal by the common council for cause under the conditions prescribed by General Ordinance section 2-441: City clerk, assessor, city attorney, commissioner of public works, director of information systems, purchasing agent, human resources director, traffic engineer, chief building inspector, chief plumbing inspector, and chief electrical inspector. 
(Ch. Ord. of 6-16-70(1), pt. 14(2); Ch. Ord. of 9-20-00, pt. 2; Ord. of 9-2-03, pt. 1; Ch. Ord. of 12-6-05, pt. 1; Ch. Ord. No. 0001-08, pt. 2, 6-23-09; Ord. No. 0001-19, pt. 2, 2-20-19)  
Sec. 2-3. - Office of city comptroller abolished. 
The office of comptroller is hereby abolished, and the duties of such office shall be performed by the finance director. 
(Ch. Ord. of 1-18-21) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 3.03.010. 
State Law reference— Office of comptroller, duties, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(1)(a), (10).  
Sec. 2-4. - City departments, receipt of payments. 
Each city department shall keep an itemized and accurate account of all moneys received in its official capacity for fees, commissions and otherwise, and shall at the direction of the finance director, pay into the city treasury all such moneys and file a duly verified account in such form as approved by the finance director, together with a receipt from the city treasury showing that such moneys have been paid into the city treasury. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 6; Ch. Ord. of 6-16-70(2), pt. 8) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.12.010.  
Secs. 2-5—2-25. - Reserved.

DIVISION 3. - CITY ASSESSOR[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Assessor, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(1)(a). 
 
Sec. 2-51. - Office created; duties. 
There is hereby created and established for the city the office of assessor, whose duties shall be those defined and set forth in the statutes of the State of Wisconsin, and such other duties as may hereafter be imposed by the common council. Such assessor shall be appointed by the mayor and the appointment confirmed by the common council. 
(Ch. Ord. of 2-17-25, § 2) 
Editor's note— The date of appointment, terms and statement on salary of the assessor as prescribed in Charter Ordinance of 6-77-25, § 2, have not been codified as they are apparently obsolete. 
State Law reference— City assessor, duties, Wis. Stats. § 70.05.  
Sec. 2-52. - Appointment, term. 
The office of city assessor shall be filled by appointment. When a vacancy exists, notice shall be published by the human resources department in the official newspaper to the effect that applications for the position of city assessor will be accepted by the human resources department up to a specified date. The human resources department shall prepare a list of qualified applicants for the position of city assessor. From this list of applicants the mayor shall appoint an assessor, subject to confirmation by the common council. The appointee shall take office upon appointment and shall hold office until the office is vacated by retirement, death, removal or resignation. 
(Ch. Ord. of 6-16-70(1), pt. 2; Ch. Ord. of 9-20-00, pt. 3; Ch. Ord. No. 0001-08, pt. 3, 6-23-09; Ord. No. 4-12, pt. 3, 4-11-12) 
Editor's note— The reference to eligible list in this section, which was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 3.06.010, has been editorially deleted as apparently obsolete. 
State Law reference— Certification, etc., of assessment personnel, Wis. Stats. § 73.09.  
Sec. 2-53. - Removal. 
Whenever any charge of official misconduct or inefficiency shall be preferred against the city assessor, the common council shall proceed, within ten days after the charge so filed with the city clerk, to hear and determine the case upon its merits. The mayor may suspend such officer against whom charges have been preferred until the disposition of the charges and appoint an assessor to fill the vacancy temporarily until the charges have been disposed of. The common council for the purpose of such hearing may compel the attendance of witnesses and the production of all papers, books and records by subpoenas when necessary for the purpose of such hearing. A two-thirds vote of all the members of the common council shall have the power to dismiss such city assessor from office for malfeasance, misconduct or inefficiency in office, upon due hearing as provided in this section, provided that a City Assessor employed by the city after the effective date of General Ordinance section 2-441 shall be subject to the provisions thereof. 
(Ch. Ord. of 2-17-25, § 5; Ord. of 9-2-03, pt. 2) 
Editor's note— The procedure for removal of the city assessor as described in Charter Ordinance 2-17-25, § 5 was not included in this section which was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 3.06.040, as apparently it is obsolete. In addition, the bond and employment of personnel in Charter Ordinance of 2-17-25, §§ 3 and 4 were not included in the 1973 Code and were not codified in this division as they are apparently obsolete. 
State Law reference— Revocation of certification of assessor, removal, Wis. Stats. § 73.09(7).  
Secs. 2-54—2-75. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - CITY ATTORNEY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— City officers, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(1)(a). 
 
Sec. 2-76. - Office; duties; practice. 
The City of Racine shall provide and maintain adequate office room, office equipment and supplies and competent stenographic service to enable the city attorney to properly and efficiently perform the duties of his office. In addition to other duties, the city attorney shall have the responsibility for the conduct of all labor contract negotiations, with the assistance of the human resources department, and for the conduct of all labor grievance mediations and arbitrations. The city attorney shall be on duty at his office at such times as other city offices are open, except when attending court or otherwise engaged in city business, and shall devote his entire time to the performance of the duties of the office of city attorney as defined and set forth in the Wisconsin Statutes, and such other duties as may be imposed by the common council. The city attorney shall hire and manage all outside legal counsel engaged to represent and/or advise the city regarding all matters of any character. 
(Ch. Ord. of 9-6-27, § 3; Ch. Ord. No. 0001-08, pt. 4, 6-23-09) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 3.08.020.  
Sec. 2-77. - Suspension, removal. 
Whenever any charge of official misconduct or inefficiency shall be preferred against the city attorney, the common council shall proceed, within ten days after the charge so filed with the city clerk, to hear and determine the case upon its merits. The mayor may suspend such officer against whom charges have been preferred until the disposition of the charges and appoint an attorney to fill the vacancy temporarily until the charges have been disposed of. The common council may, for the purpose of such hearing, compel the attendance of witnesses and the production of all papers by subpoenas when necessary for the purpose of such hearing. A majority of all the members of the common council elect of this city shall have the power to dismiss such city attorney from office for malfeasance, misconduct or inefficiency in office, upon due hearing as provided in this section. 
(Ch. Ord. of 9-6-27, § 4) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 3.08.030. 
State Law reference— Duties of city attorney, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(12); city attorney may defend certain actions brought against officers or employees, Wis. Stats. § 62.115.  
Secs. 2-78—2-100. - Reserved.

(Ch. Ord. of 6-16-70(1), pt. 10)

Footnotes:

Sec. 2-121. - City treasurer. 
(a)  Designated. The finance director shall be the city treasurer. 
(b)  Duties. The city treasurer shall perform such duties as are provided by the Wisconsin Statutes, the ordinances of the City of Racine, and as may be assigned to him from time to time by the common council or the mayor. 
(Ch. Ord. of _____) 
Editor's note— Part of this section was formerly codified as a charter ordinance in the 1973 Code as § 3.04.040. 
State Law reference— City treasurer, duties, Wis. Stats. §§ 27.10, 62.09(9), 62.12, 66.23, 119.50, 778.14.  
Sec. 2-122. - Selection. 
The finance director shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the common council. 
(Ch. Ord. of 6-16-70(1), pt. 9) 
Editor's note— The section on eligible list which was referenced in this section which was formerly Code of 1973, § 6.02.040 has been editorially deleted as obsolete. This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.02.010.  
Sec. 2-123. - Oath of office; bond. 
The finance director shall, before entering upon the discharge of the duties of the office of city treasurer, take an oath of office to faithfully and impartially perform the duties of the office of city treasurer and shall execute a fidelity bond to the City of Racine in the sum of $100,000.00, to be approved by the mayor, conditioned upon his faithful performance of the duties of city treasurer. 
(Ch. Ord. of _____) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified as a charter ordinance in the 1973 Code as § 6.02.070. The city has elected to not give bond for the city treasurer, as provided in Wis. Stats. §§ 19.01, 70.67. 
State Law reference— Bond required of treasurer, Wis. Stats. §§ 62.09(4)(b), 70.67; surety company, Wis. Stats. § 632.17(2).  
Secs. 2-124—2-145. - Reserved.

ARTICLE III. - ELECTIONS 
 
Sec. 3-1. - Spring primaries. 
Whenever three or more candidates file nomination papers for a city office, a spring primary election shall be held for the nomination of candidates for such office. Such spring primary, when required, shall be held on the third Tuesday in February. 
(Ch. Ord. of 12-15-70; Ch. Ord. of 4-19-76) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 3.31.010. 
State Law reference— Spring primaries, Wis. Stats. § 5.58; spring primary ballots, Wis. Stats. § 5.60(3).  
ARTICLE IV. - FINANCE  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 4-1. - Payment of bills and accounts by city. 
Payment of claims other than tort claims may be made by the city treasurer after the finance director shall have audited and approved each such claim as a proper charge against the treasury and shall have endorsed his approval thereon after the following conditions have been complied with: 
(1)  That funds are available therefor pursuant to the budget approved by the governing body; 
(2)  That the item or service covered by such claim has been duly authorized by the proper official, department head or board or commission; 
(3)  That the item or service has been actually supplied or rendered in conformity with such authorization; and 
(4)  That the claim is just and valid pursuant to law. 
The finance director may require the submission of such proof and evidence to support the foregoing as in his discretion he may deem necessary. 
(Ch. Ord. of 2-2-26, §§ 1—4; Ch. Ord. of 4-6-64) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.16.010. 
State Law reference— Disbursements, Wis. Stats. § 66.042.  
Sec. 4-2. - Filing of claims with council. 
The finance director shall file with the common council monthly a list of the claims approved, showing the date paid, the name of the claimant, and amount. 
(Ch. Ord. of 4-6-64) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.16.020.  
Sec. 4-3. - Annual audit. 
There shall be an annual detailed audit of the financial transactions and accounts of the City of Racine, which audit shall be performed by public accountants licensed under the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 66.041. 
(Ch. Ord. of 4-6-64) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.16.030.  
Secs. 4-4—4-25. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BUDGET[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal budgets, Wis. Stats. § 65.01 et seq. 
 
Sec. 4-26. - Department budget estimates. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Department shall include any department, board, committee, commission or other body under the control of the common council which expends city funds or incurs obligations for the city, and unless otherwise expressed shall refer to the head of such department. 
Estimate shall include any written report of or the request of any department setting forth in detail the various sums and purposes it deems reasonably necessary to perform its functions. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of each department to file with the finance director not later than August 10 of each year on forms furnished by the finance director an estimate in detail of the department's needs for the ensuing calendar year. 
(c)  Any department whose funds are not subject to the control of the common council may include in its budget estimate such sum as it may deem reasonably necessary for a contingent fund for emergency purposes or other purposes which may arise during the year requiring the expenditure of money in addition to the sums provided for the several purposes or for purposes for which no express provision is made in the budget. 
(d)  The finance director shall, no later than September 10 of each year, file with the mayor the reports of estimates filed with him by the various departments, together with his statement of anticipated revenues for the ensuing year and comparisons with other years. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, §§ 1, 2; Ch. Ord. of 6-16-70(2), pts. 1, 2; Ch. Ord. of 8-2-04, pt. 1) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as §§ 6.03.010, 6.03.020, 6.04.010—6.04.030.  
Sec. 4-27. - Proposed executive budget. 
(a)  Proposals. From the budget estimates submitted by the departments, and after reviewing such estimates with representatives of the departments and the council committee assigned to the particular department, the mayor shall prepare and, by October 25 of each year, shall submit to the common council an executive budget, setting forth in detail a proposed budget for the ensuing year for the City of Racine, showing the amounts proposed to be spent by each department and the various purposes therefor, and the amounts of money for each purpose for which it is proposed shall be appropriated by the common council. If any department shall fail to file its estimates as provided in this section, the mayor shall make a proposed budget for such department, specifying the purposes for which the amount of funds such department may expend. 
(b)  Personnel. The executive budget shall include the number, title and classification or compensation range of each employee, officer and position in the city service and the proposed appropriation for the same for the ensuing year. 
(c)  Wage and benefit adjustments. The finance and personnel committee of the common council shall be responsible for reviewing the result of negotiations with employees and officers of the city, and it shall submit to the common council as soon as practicable each year, a report or reports showing the results of such negotiations and the adjustments recommended in the wages and benefits to be paid. 
(d)  Contingent fund. In addition to purposes required to be set forth in detail, the executive budget shall provide a contingent fund for such sum as the mayor may deem reasonably necessary for emergency and other purposes which may arise during the year requiring the expenditure of money in addition to the sums provided for the several purposes, and for purposes for which no provision is made in the budget. 
(e)  Debt service. The executive budget shall provide an appropriation sufficient to meet the required annual debt service. The executive budget shall provide an estimate and purpose for the issuance of any new fiscal year debt. 
(f)  Meetings public. All meetings of the mayor with representatives of the departments and committees of the common council during the preparation of the executive budget shall be public. 
(Ch. Ord. of 6-16-70(2), pt. 3) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as §§ 6.05.010—6.05.060.  
Sec. 4-28. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Section 4-28 was repealed by Ch. Ord. of 8-2-04, pt. 2. Former § 4-28 pertained to a report by the mayor on the capital improvement budget and was derived from Ch. Ord. of 6-16-70(2), pt. 10.  
Sec. 4-29. - Budget requirements. 
(a)  Contents. The budget shall provide a complete financial plan for the ensuing calendar year. It shall contain: 
(1)  A general summary; 
(2)  Detailed estimated revenues applicable to proposed expenditures; 
(3)  Detailed proposed appropriations; 
(4)  A compensation schedule setting forth rates of pay for offices and positions in the city service. 
The total of such appropriations shall not exceed the total of such estimated revenues. 
(b)  Budget summary. The budget summary shall itemize the principal sources of estimated revenues and shall state separately the amount to be raised by property taxes and the proposed appropriations for each department in such manner as to present to the public a simple and clear summary of the detailed budget. 
(c)  Estimated revenues. Estimated revenues shall be classified by the sources from which such revenues are to be derived. 
(d)  Proposed appropriations. Separate provisions shall be included in the proposed budget for at least: 
(1)  The administration, operation and maintenance of each department, itemized by kind and nature of the appropriation; 
(2)  The number, title and compensation range of each officer and of each position, and the proposed appropriation for the same shall be itemized according to the divisions in each department as submitted by the finance and personnel committee to the common council and shall be incorporated in and published with the rest of the budget as provided in this section; 
(3)  Appropriations proposed for improvements. 
(e)  Uniform compensation schedule. The compensation schedule shall provide for and establish uniform rates of pay for offices and positions in the city service to be in effect for the ensuing fiscal year. 
(f)  Proposed appropriations; comparison with other years. There shall be placed opposite the proposed appropriations for the ensuing year adequate comparisons with the appropriations and expenditures of prior years. 
(g)  Estimated revenues; comparison with other years. There shall be placed opposite the estimated revenues for the ensuing year adequate comparisons with the estimated revenues and receipts of prior years. 
(Ch. Ord. of 6-16-70(2), pt. 4) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as §§ 6.06.010—6.06.070.  
Sec. 4-30. - Council hearings on budget; notice. 
At the meeting of the common council at which the proposed budget is submitted by the mayor, the common council shall determine the place and time of a public hearing thereon, a summary of such budget and notice of the place where such budget in detail is available for public inspection, and notice of the time and place for holding the public hearing thereon shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least ten days prior to the time of such public hearing. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 5(11); Ch. Ord. of 6-16-70(2), pt. 5) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.07.010.  
Sec. 4-31. - Council adoption of budget. 
(a)  Changes. The common council, by vote of a majority of all the aldermen, may make such changes in the proposed budget submitted by the mayor, and the wages and benefit reports submitted by the finance and personnel committee, either as to purposes or amounts for which money may be expended and as to purposes or amounts for which bonds or mortgage certificates may be issued as it may deem best. 
(b)  Changes not permitted. The common council shall not change the proposed budget as submitted to it for the departments which by law are authorized to determine their appropriations and the taxes to be levied therefor, unless such department by formal resolution adopted by a majority of all its members shall authorize such change, nor shall the council change the purposes or amounts of the debt service which, by law, is required to be levied therefor. 
(c)  Changes authorized by departments. When any department authorized to determine its appropriations and the taxes to be levied therefor, shall authorize a change in its budget by the common council, it shall file its resolution authorizing the change with the city clerk at least two days prior to the time fixed by law for the adoption of such budget, and the common council shall then make the change in accordance therewith. 
(d)  Date of adoption. The common council, on or before November 20, shall adopt the proposed budget by a majority vote of all the aldermen, either as submitted or as changed by the common council. It shall not be necessary to refer the budget to a committee of the common council. 
(e)  Certification. The budget submitted by the mayor to the common council, as changed by the common council within the time therein provided, shall constitute the budget of the city for the following year, whether or not any formal resolution or motion adopting it has been passed by the common council. Within five days either after its formal adoption by the common council or by operation of law, it shall be certified by the city clerk to the mayor for his approval. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 4(1)—(5); Ch. Ord. of 6-16-70(2), pt. 7(1)—(5)) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as §§ 6.10.010—6.10.050.  
Sec. 4-32. - Approval or disapproval by mayor. 
(a)  Approval; disapproval of items. If the mayor approves the budget, he shall sign it. The mayor shall have power only to disapprove of any items therein under the control of the common council and, upon disapproving any such items, he shall return the budget to the city clerk with his objections to such items in writing and his reasons therefor. 
(b)  Action by council on items disapproved by mayor. The common council shall vote on each item disapproved by the mayor separately and, if the mayor's disapproval is sustained, it shall affect only the items so disapproved and sustained. The common council may thereupon proceed, by an affirmative vote of a majority of the aldermen, to adopt a substitute for the item rejected, which shall be separately submitted to the mayor, subject to his approval. All items not disapproved by the mayor and sustained by the common council shall constitute the budget and be in full force. The budget shall thereupon be filed in the office of the finance director, who shall forthwith have the budget printed and made available for general distribution. In case of an obvious error in authorizing any salary or position as provided in section 4-29(d) of this part I, the common council may, by a three-fourths vote of all of its members, correct such error in the period between the adoption of the budget and December 31, inclusive, of each year. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-21-27, § 4(6), (7); Ch. Ord. of 6-16-70(2), pt. 7(6), (7)) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as §§ 6.10.060, 6.10.070.  
Sec. 4-33. - Tax levy. 
The adoption of the budget shall determine the amount of money to be levied upon all taxable property in the city for the ensuing year. The tax levy shall be computed by deducting the estimated revenues available therefor from the appropriations for the ensuing year. The finance director shall then calculate the tax rate. Such tax rate shall be the rate of the ensuing tax levy. 
(Ch. Ord. of 6-16-70(2), pt. 7(8)) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.10.080.  
Sec. 4-34. - Compensation for city positions. 
The compensation rates of pay and the number of positions established in the budget shall determine the compensation to be paid and the number of positions for the ensuing calendar year, except that additional positions may be established where necessary during the year by resolution adopted by three-fourths vote of all the aldermen. 
(Ch. Ord. of 6-16-70(2), pt. 7(9)) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.10.090.  
Sec. 4-35. - Limitation to authorization. 
No money shall be expended and no liabilities incurred by the city or any department, unless otherwise specially authorized by law during the fiscal year, in excess of the amounts specified or except as provided in this article for any other purpose than as designated therein, provided, however, that whenever the waterworks department of the city desires to make a contract extending over a period of more than one year for additions to the plant in excess of the estimated revenue for the year, if in the opinion of the common council there will be money available to meet the payments on the contract as they may come due, then, by a majority vote of the common council, the finance director may be authorized to countersign such contract. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 5(1); Ch. Ord. of 6-16-70(2), pt. 8) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.11.010. 
State Law reference— Similar provision, Wis. Stats. §§ 65.06(1), 66.12.  
Sec. 4-36. - Monies received by departments. 
Whenever a department is reimbursed for materials or services furnished, and the funds so received are not by law credited to some particular fund, the department may spend the money so received for the same purpose for which the money was originally appropriated in the budget. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 5(2)) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.11.020. 
State Law reference— Similar provision, Wis. Stats. § 65.06(2).  
Sec. 4-37. - Transfer of funds. 
Whenever a department whose operating and outlay funds are subject to the control of the common council shall find it necessary to expend a sum greater than authorized by the budget for such specific purpose, and the department shall find it unnecessary to spend a sum as authorized for some other purpose, the administrative manager may request the finance director to authorize the funds unnecessary for one purpose to be transferred to the purpose for which the greater sum is needed, within their respective divisions and stating the reasons therefor in writing. The finance director shall make the changes in accordance with city policies and generally accepted accounting principles. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 5(3); Ch. Ord. of 6-16-70(2), pt. 8; Ord. No. 12-97, pt. 1, 6-17-97) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.11.030. 
State Law reference— Similar provision, Wis. Stats. §§ 62.12(6)(b), 65.06(3).  
Sec. 4-38. - Independent departments; transfer of funds. 
Any department authorized by law to fix its own tax levy may change at a regular meeting or one called for that purpose any appropriation specified in the budget for one purpose which is found unnecessary for that purpose to another purpose which the department shall find necessary to spend a sum greater than specified in the budget for that purpose. The department shall certify its action to the finance director and the change shall be made accordingly. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 5(4)) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.11.040. 
State Law reference— Similar provision, Wis. Stats. § 65.06(4).  
Sec. 4-39. - Expenditures over appropriation. 
No department shall spend a sum greater than is appropriated by the budget for that department, except: 
(1)  Unexpended balances from the proceeds of bonds or mortgage certificates carried over from the preceding year may be expended for the purposes for which the bonds or certificates were issued; and 
(2)  Any department whose funds are subject to the control of the common council may expend funds for the purpose appropriated by the common council from the contingent fund. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 5(5)) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.11.050. 
State Law reference— Similar provision, Wis. Stats. §§ 62.12(6)(b), 65.06(5).  
Sec. 4-40. - Contingent fund. 
(a)  The common council, by resolution adopted by a three-fourths vote of all the aldermen, may appropriate money from its contingent fund for any lawful purpose. 
(b)  The common council at any time after the adoption of the budget may, by resolution adopted by a majority vote of the members thereof, direct the proper officers of any department to expend such sum or sums of money as are specially appropriated out of any specific fund under its control for any of the several purposes enumerated therein. The adoption of such resolution shall be the authority for such department to proceed and expend such specified sum for the purpose as directed therein. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 5(6)) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.11.060. 
State Law reference— Similar provision, Wis. Stats. § 65.06(6).  
Sec. 4-41. - Independent departments; contingent fund. 
Any department whose funds are not subject to the common council may, by vote of three-fourths of all its members, appropriate money out of its contingent fund for any purpose for which it is authorized to spend money. Before the department shall spend any such funds, it shall certify to the finance director its action and the purpose for which such sum was appropriated. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 5(7)) 
Editor's note— Ordinance Number 29-74 adopted on August 20, 1974 which is codified in ch. 98 of the Municipal Code, Part II, which is apparently not a Charter Ordinance, provided in section 98-96 of the Municipal Code, Part III that this section apply to the wastewater utility and its operation. This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.11.070. 
State Law reference— Similar provision, Wis. Stats. § 65.06(7).  
Sec. 4-42. - Water utility and wastewater utility expenditures. 
The department charged by law with the construction, extension, operation and maintenance of the water utility or wastewater utility may spend money from the surplus revenue of such waterworks in addition to the sum specified in the budget when deemed necessary to maintain the service, upon being authorized so to do by a three-fourths vote of all the respective commission and aldermen of the common council, specifying by resolution the purpose for which and the sum appropriated. Before any money shall be so expended a copy of the resolution authorizing it shall be certified to the finance director. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 5(8); Ch. Ord. of 6-16-70(2), pt. 8) 
Editor's note— Ordinance Number 29-74 adopted on August 20, 1974 which is codified in ch. 98 of the Municipal Code, Part II, which is apparently not a Charter Ordinance, provided in section 98-96 of the Municipal Code, Part II, that this section apply to the wastewater utility and its operation. This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.11.080. 
State Law reference— Similar provision, Wis. Stats. § 65.06(8).  
Sec. 4-43. - Assessable expenditures. 
The city may expend any money or incur liabilities for any purposes which by law are assessable as benefits against parcels of land or are a legal charge against such parcels of land. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 5(9)) 
Editor's note— Ordinance Number 29-74 adopted on August 20, 1974 which is codified in ch. 98 of the Municipal Code, Part II, which is apparently not a Charter Ordinance, provided in section 98-96 of the Municipal Code, Part II, that this section apply to the wastewater utility and its operation. This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.11.100. 
State Law reference— Similar provision, Wis. Stats. § 65.06(10).  
Sec. 4-44. - City officers' liability. 
Every officer or employee who shall knowingly violate or participate in the violation of the provisions of this article shall be personally liable to the city for all loss or damage to the city occasioned thereby. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 5(10)) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.11.110. 
State Law reference— Similar provision, Wis. Stats. § 65.06(11).  
Sec. 4-45. - Budget authority. 
The adoption of the budget shall be authority for the expenditures by a department for the purposes therein provided and of the amounts assigned to the department thereby, and no further action by the common council shall be necessary to authorize any department to make such expenditures, except that as provided in this article it shall not authorize the expenditure of any money from the contingent fund of the common council. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 5(12)) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.11.120. 
State Law reference— Similar provision, Wis. Stats. § 65.06(12).  
Sec. 4-46. - Suspension of unexpended funds. 
The common council may at any time suspend the appropriation of any fund assigned to any department by the budget which has not been expended or encumbered for the payment of indebtedness incurred by the department. Such action by the common council shall be by a majority vote of all the aldermen, but shall not apply to the funds of a department which determines its own tax levy and whose funds are not subject to the control of the common council. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 5(13)) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.11.130. 
State Law reference— Similar provision, Wis. Stats. § 65.06(13).  
Sec. 4-47. - Budget carryover. 
The adoption of the budget for any year shall not authorize the expenditure of any funds for the succeeding year except for indebtedness incurred during the budget year. The common council may authorize funds not expended during the budget year to be carried over into the following year for the same purposes for which they were originally appropriated. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 5(14)) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as part of § 6.11.140.  
Sec. 4-48. - Reversion of unexpended and unencumbered funds. 
All funds subject to the control of the common council assigned by the budget to a department and not expended during the budget year, or not transferred to another account within the period specified in this article or not reserved for indebtedness incurred during the budget year, or not carried forward, shall revert to the general fund balance of the city. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 5(15)) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as part of § 6.11.150.  
Sec. 4-49. - Independent department revenues. 
All funds of a department not subject to the control of the common council and not expended or reserved for indebtedness shall become a part of the general fund balance of such department. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 5(16)) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.11.160.  
Sec. 4-50. - Exceptions, waterworks funds. 
Sections 4-46 through 4-49 of these Charter Ordinances shall not apply to the expenditures of funds, the proceeds of bonds or mortgage certificates, nor the surplus revenues of the waterworks. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 5(17)) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.11.170. 
State Law reference— Similar provision, Wis. Stats. § 65.06(17).  
Sec. 4-51. - Budget omissions. 
The omission from the budget of any of the following items shall not prohibit the placing of such items on the tax roll for the levy and collection of the tax and the payment of the money therefor: 
(1)  The payment of interest on or the principal of any bonded debt of the city when due; 
(2)  The payment of principal and interest on mortgage or mortgage certificates when due; and 
(3)  Funds required to be raised by any mandatory provision of law. 
(Ch. Ord. of 7-5-27, § 5(18)) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.11.180. 
State Law reference— Similar provision, Wis. Stats. § 65.06(18).  
ARTICLE V. - GASOLINE SERVICE STATIONS[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note— Charter Ordinance of March 6, 1928, §§ 9, 10, 12 and 14 through 16 regarding revocation of license, transfer of license, location frontage consents, penalty and severability were not included in the 1973 Code and are therefore not printed in this article as they are apparently obsolete or unnecessary to codify or have been repealed. 
 
Sec. 5-1. - Definition. 
The term "gasoline service station," as used in this article, means any building, structure or premises, enclosure or other place within the city where a container or containers, tank or tanks, either portable or stationary, and containing either gasoline, naphtha, benzole, lubricating oil or other flammable liquids having a flashpoint below 165 degrees Fahrenheit are kept or located for the purpose of selling, offering for sale or distributing any such liquids from such containers, tank or tanks at retail as a fuel or lubricant for motor vehicles or watercraft. 
(Ch. Ord. of 3-6-28, § 2) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 22.16.010.  
Sec. 5-2. - License required. 
No person, firm or corporation shall manage, conduct, operate, carry on or own a gasoline service station without a license therefor. If the person actually managing or in charge of the station is not the sole owner of the business, then he and the owner must each have a license. The license of the person actually managing or in charge of the business who is not the sole owner shall be known as a manager's license. Every other license shall be known as an owner's license. 
(Ch. Ord. of 3-6-28, § 3) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 22.16.020.  
Sec. 5-3. - License application. 
The application for an owner's license shall specify the location of the building, structure, premises, enclosure or other place in which it is proposed to keep such station and the capacity or capacities in gallons of the container or containers, tank or tanks; and shall be accompanied by a sketch showing such locations, the location of all pumps, pipes, hoses and conductors, drain pits, the location and use of all buildings on adjoining property, the location of all sidewalks abutting on such premises, the location of all driveways, and the dimensions of the premises. The application for either an owner's license or a manager's license shall be signed by the applicant and shall contain a statement setting forth the record of the applicant in business during the preceding ten years, specifying the location and the nature of his business during that period, the name of any employers during that period and any convictions of or penalties or forfeitures assessed against such applicant for violations of laws or ordinances governing the operation of gasoline service stations, the sale or traffic in any of the flammable liquids described in section 5-1 of these Charter Ordinances, or fraudulent practices of any nature. Any false statements in the application shall make the license issued thereon void. An application for an owner's license shall be filed with the city clerk at least 15 days prior to the granting of any such license. No place of business for which a license under Chapter 22.01 [chapter 6, Alcohol Beverages], permitting sale of fermented malt beverages, is held or for which an application is pending, shall be granted a gasoline service station license under this Chapter [sic], except that a place of business which operates as a convenient type grocery store or place of business which operates primarily as a boat or marine related retail store and meets the following conditions may hold both such licenses: 
Maintains on the premises a minimum inventory value of those goods customarily marketed by such businesses of not less than $15,000.00, at cost, excluding fermented malt beverages and gasoline. 
Upon receipt of an application for a new owner's license, the city clerk shall notify the commissioner of public works, the traffic engineer and the building inspector of the fact that the application is on file. It shall thereupon become the duty of said officers to review the application and in writing report their approval or disapproval of the same. If disapproved, reasons for so doing shall be set forth. Said reports shall be affixed by the city clerk to the application for such license. 
(Ch. Ord. of 3-6-28, § 4) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as part of § 22.16.030.  
Sec. 5-4. - Consideration of application. 
In the case of a new application for an owner's license, if the common council is satisfied that the location proposed is suitable in view of traffic, fire hazard, size and layout, relation to adjoining property and streets, health, safety and other conditions; that the premises, building, structure and equipment are safe and comply with all ordinances and laws applicable; and that the person applying for the license is a suitable person to have a license in view of character and record, it may, in the exercise of its reasonable discretion, grant the license; otherwise, the license shall be denied. In the case of an application for a manager's license, if the common council is satisfied that the applicant is a suitable person to have a license in view of his character and record, it may, in the exercise of its reasonable discretion, grant the license; otherwise, the license shall be denied. If the license is granted, it shall be issued by the city clerk after payment of the required fee. Every owner's license shall be issued only for the premises specified in the application. 
(Ch. Ord. of 3-6-28, § 5) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as part of § 22.16.040.  
Sec. 5-5. - License fee and period. 
The annual license fee for each owner's license and for each manager's license shall be established by the common council. After any license has been issued, the license may be renewed annually by the city clerk without action by the common council. All licenses expire on June 30 of the license year. 
(Ch. Ord. of 3-6-28, § 6; Ch. Ord. of 12-7-04, pt. 1) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 22.16.050.  
Sec. 5-6. - Change of location. 
No license issued under the provisions of this article shall authorize the maintenance or management of the business of a gasoline service station at any location except the location specified therein. 
(Ch. Ord. of 3-6-28, § 11) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 22.16.080.  
Sec. 5-7. - Locations prohibited. 
No gasoline service station shall be operated within 200 feet of any building used for the following purposes: 
(1)  Public theater, nursing home or hospital. 
(2)  School. 
(3)  Church, or any building used by any religious corporation for religious purposes. 
This restriction shall not apply to any building temporarily being used for religious purposes, nor to any gasoline service station which was operating prior to January 27, 1947. 
(Ch. Ord. of 3-6-28, § 13; Ch. Ord. of 2-1-37, § 1; Ch. Ord. of 9-3-68, pt. 1) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 22.16.100.  
Sec. 5-8. - Hours and conditions of operation. 
(1)  If any homicide, murder, battery, sexual assault, false imprisonment, kidnapping, reckless endangerment of safety, robbery, or disorderly conduct as identified and defined by Wisconsin Statutes, weapons crime in violation of secs. 941.20 through 941.299 of the Wisconsin Statutes, or act of prostitution in violation of secs. 944.30 through 944.34 of the Wisconsin Statutes occurs, after the effective date of this ordinance, upon the premises of any gasoline service station as defined by and licensed pursuant to Article V of the Charter Ordinances of the City of Racine and/or secs. 22-476 and 22-477 of the Municipal Code of the City of Racine, such gasoline service station shall be subject any or all of the provisions of subsection (2) by order of the Common Council. 
(2)  Such holder of a license for a gasoline service station, whether operated in connection with retailing of edible or non-edible commodities, or both, shall 
(a)  not sell or deliver any goods, wares, merchandise, or personal property of any kind and nature to the ultimate consumer nor take an order therein for delivery therein of any goods, wares, merchandise, and personal property of every kind and nature including any edible or non-edible commodities, including any sale or delivery for off-premises consumption, between the hours of midnight of any day of the week and 4:00 a.m. of that same day, anywhere in the City of Racine. If any provision of Chapter 22 or the Zoning Code is more stringent as to hours of operation of businesses that are subject to this section, then Chapter 22 or the Zoning Code provision shall be given effect. Gas stations may keep one or more pumps open that can be operated by credit card when such stations are closed; 
(b)  employ such additional staff as is necessary for the safe operation of such gasoline service station; 
(c)  employ such unarmed or armed private security person as defined by Chapter 22, Article XXVII of the Municipal Code of the City of Racine, as may be deemed useful and necessary to ensure the safe operation of such gasoline service station; 
(d)  install and operate such additional security measures as may be deemed useful and necessary to ensure the safe operation of such gasoline service station; 
(e)  have such premise's conditional use permit(s) revoked or modified; 
(f)  be subject to such additional and further sanctions as may be imposed by the Common Council. 
(Ord. No. 12-07, pt. 1, 7-3-07)  
ARTICLE VI. - RETIREMENT[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference— Wisconsin retirement system, Wis. Stats. § 40.20 et seq. 
 
Sec. 6-1. - Participation in system. 
Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 40.20 et seq., the City of Racine hereby elects to include eligible city personnel under the provisions of the Wisconsin municipal retirement fund [Wisconsin retirement system] in accordance with the terms thereof. 
(Ch. Ord. of 10-19-43, § 1) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.18.010.  
Sec. 6-2. - Prior service credits. 
Election is hereby made to provide prior service credits at rates equal to two times the rates of municipality credits for current service, to be applicable to employees as defined by Wis. Stats. § 66.90(1943) who are employed by the City of Racine on December 28, 1943. 
(Ch. Ord. of 10-19-43, § 2) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.18.020.  
Sec. 6-3. - Notice of election. 
The city clerk shall submit a certified notice of the election made under this article to the board of trustees of the Wisconsin municipal retirement fund [Wisconsin retirement system]. Such notice of election shall: 
(1)  Be in writing; 
(2)  Indicate the date and results of such election; 
(3)  Include a certification of the prior service contribution rate selected as being applicable to the employees of the municipality; 
(4)  Be officially certified by the clerk of the municipality. 
(Ch. Ord. of 10-19-43, § 3) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.18.030.  
Sec. 6-4. - Effective date of participation. 
The effective date of participation in the retirement system shall be January 1, 1944, unless the board of trustees of the Wisconsin municipal retirement fund [Wisconsin retirement system] shall defer such effective date pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.90(1943). 
(Ch. Ord. of 10-19-43, § 4) 
Editor's note— This section was formerly codified in the 1973 Code as § 6.18.040.
