DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF HEALTH[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Charter ordinance reference—Health officer, § 2-146 et seq. 
Cross reference— Policy on absenteeism of boards, committees, commissions, § 2-166; animals, ch. 10; property maintenance code, § 18-691 et seq.; bed and breakfast establishments, § 22-201 et seq.; commercial pesticide applicators, § 22-321 et seq.; lodging houses, apartments, hotels and lodging rooms, § 22-686 et seq.; massage establishments and massage therapists, § 22-766 et seq.; nuisances, § 42-26 et seq.; air pollution, § 42-86 et seq.; smoking, § 50-231 et seq.; health, ch. 54. 
State Law reference— Local board of health, Wis. Stats. § 141.015. 
 
Sec. 2-176. - Created; appointments, terms of members; secretary. 
There is hereby created a board of health consisting of nine members appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the common council. At least three of such members shall not be elected officials or city employees and shall be persons who have a demonstrated interest or competence in the field of public health or community health. A good faith effort shall be made to appoint a registered nurse and a physician. Appointments shall be made on the third Tuesday of April of each year and for the term beginning April, 1994, shall consist of four two-year terms and three one-year terms. Thereafter, terms shall be for two years. Members shall serve until their successors are appointed and confirmed. The health officer shall be the secretary of the board. 
(Code 1973, § 11.01.010; Ord. No. 32-93, pt. 1, 1-18-94; Ord. No. 21-03, pt. 1, 11-18-03; Ord. No. 21-09, pt. 1, 12-15-09)  
Sec. 2-177. - Election of officers; appointment of health officer. 
Within 30 days after their annual election, the members of the board of health shall complete their organization by the election of a president and vice-president. The board of health shall have the power to appoint a health officer for the city, fix his compensation, subject to the approval of the common council, and such health officer shall be the executive officer of the board and shall also act as secretary of the board and shall keep full minutes of the proceedings of such board. The board shall have power to authorize such health officer to exercise any or all of the powers conferred on it, and all directions and orders of the health officer made under such authority of the board shall have the same force and effect as if made by the board. 
(Code 1973, § 11.01.020)  
Sec. 2-178. - Powers. 
The board of health and health officers appointed by it shall have the powers given to boards of health and health officers by the laws of the state. 
(Code 1973, § 11.01.030; Ord. No. 32-93, pt. 2, 1-18-94)  
Sec. 2-179. - Rules and regulations. 
All rules and regulations prepared by the board of health shall be reported to the common council, and if such rules and regulations shall be approved by a majority of the members of the common council, such rules and regulations shall have the force and effect of ordinances, and the violation thereof may be prosecuted and punished as in the case of ordinances. 
(Code 1973, § 11.01.040)  
Secs. 2-180—2-190. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - BOARD OF REVIEW[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference— Policy on absenteeism of boards, committees, commissions, § 2-166; general property assessments, § 90-26 et seq. 
State Law reference— Board of review, Wis. Stats. § 70.46 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-191. - Created; appointments; filling of vacancies. 
In accordance with Wis. Stats. § 70.46, there is hereby created a board of review for the city consisting of the city clerk and four residents of the city. Such members shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation of the common council. Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner. 
(Code 1973, § 3.16.010; Ord. No. 3-00, pt. 1, 3-21-00)  
Sec. 2-192. - Terms of office. 
All appointments to the board of review shall be for a term of five years, and such appointments shall be made on the first Tuesday in March. The term of office shall begin upon appointment, confirmation and qualification, and shall continue until the qualification of a successor, excepting that the term of a city official listed in section 2-191 above shall expire upon cessation of office of any such member. 
(Code 1973, § 3.16.020; Ord. No. 3-00, pt. 2, 3-21-00)  
Sec. 2-193. - Compensation of members. 
Excepting full-time officers or employees of the city, members of the board of review shall receive no compensation for their service on such board. 
(Code 1973, § 3.16.030; Ord. No. 3-00, pt. 3, 3-21-00)  
Sec. 2-194. - Election of officers. 
Each year within 30 days after the time designated in this division for the beginning of terms, members of the board of review shall organize by the election, from among their number, of a president and such other officers as they deem necessary. The city clerk on the board shall be the clerk thereof and shall keep an accurate record of all its proceedings. 
(Code 1973, § 3.16.040; Ord. No. 3-00, pt. 4, 3-21-00)  
Sec. 2-195. - Meetings. 
The board of review shall meet annually as provided in Wis. Stats. ch. 70. The meeting place shall be determined by the city clerk, who shall provide notice of such place according to law. On the first meeting day for each year the board of review shall be in session at least two hours for taxpayers to appear and examine the assessment roll and other assessment data. 
(Code 1973, § 3.16.060; Ord. No. 13-99, pt. 2, 11-2-99; Ord. No. 3-00, pt. 5, 3-21-00) 
State Law reference— Board of review meetings, requirements, Wis. Stats. § 70.47(1)—(6).  
Secs. 2-196—2-205. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - CIVIC CENTRE COMMISSION[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference— Policy on absenteeism of boards, committees, commissions, § 2-166; civic centre, § 82-201 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-206. - Created; composition; filling of vacancies; chairman. 
There is hereby created a civic centre commission as provided in this section. The members thereof shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the common council. Members shall consist of one veteran of the U.S. Armed Forces who is a member of a veteran's organization, one aldermanic member, and seven citizen members. The mayor shall be authorized to appoint one member of the commission as commission chairman. 
(Ord. No. 9-91, pt. 1, § 3.23.020, 3-19-91; Ord. No. 5-93, pt. 1, § 3.23.020, 3-16-93; Ord. No. 1-96, pt.1, 3-5-96; Ord. No. 9-02, pt. 1, 6-18-02; Ord. No. 7-05, pt. 1, 5-3-05; Ord. No. 21-06, pt. 1, 6-28-06)  
Sec. 2-207. - Terms of office; residence requirement. 
(a)  The term of office of civic centre commission members shall be as follows: 
(1)  The term of the aldermanic member shall be one year and the term of citizen members shall be three years. Such terms shall commence on the first Tuesday in May of the year of their appointment. 
(2)  Vacancies on the commission shall be filled by appointment by the mayor subject to confirmation by the common council. Replacement members shall be appointed to fill the unexpired term of vacant positions. 
(b)  All members of the civic centre commission shall be residents of the city. 
(Ord. No. 9-91, pt. 1, § 3.23.020, 3-19-91; Ord. No. 5-93, pt. 1, § 3.23.020, 3-16-93; Ord. No. 1-96, pt. 2, 3-5-96; Ord. No. 9-02, pt. 2, 6-18-02; Ord. No. 7-05, pt. 1, 5-3-05)  
Sec. 2-208. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The civic centre commission shall have the powers and duties to: 
(1)  Advise on the contract management and operation of the land and structures comprising the civic centre. 
(2)  Advise on such policies and regulations as it deems necessary for the use of the civic centre, in cooperation with contract management of the civic centre. 
(3)  Advise on contract management's rental of the civic centre or its various parts for private and public functions and recommend to the common council rates to be charged for use of the civic centre and its various elements. 
(4)  Recommend to contract management a priority system for the allocation of dates for use of the civic centre and to develop a reservation system for securing those dates. 
(5)  Oversee contract management's responsibility for such services as building maintenance, custodial services, landscape maintenance and kitchen operations. 
(6)  Review annual budgets for operation of the civic centre as developed by contract management in cooperation with the commission, which budgets shall be submitted to the mayor in accordance with standard budgetary procedures. 
(7)  Utilize, as appropriate, in cooperation with contract management, coordination with the human resources department and with approval of the administrative manager, such city employees as may be agreed upon by the commission and the contract management to implement the operations of the civic centre. 
(8)  Report from time to time to the mayor and common council as the commission may deem appropriate or upon the request of the mayor and common council. 
(9)  The chairman of the commission shall have authority to appoint a subcommittee of the commission, which may be composed of commission members or noncommission members if the latter possess expertise in a particular field which the chairman deems useful in the accomplishment of subcommittee duties. 
(Ord. No. 9-91, pt. 1, § 3.23.030, 3-19-91; Ord. No. 7-05, pt. 1, 5-3-05; Ord. No. 08-08, pt. 1, 6-3-08)  
Sec. 2-209. - Budgets. 
In carrying out the provisions of section 2-208(6), the commission shall submit to the mayor an annual budget, which shall include financial projections for operating the civic centre formulated through the use of accepted accounting procedures and in accordance with the policies and procedures established by the city finance director. 
(Ord. No. 9-91, pt. 1, § 3.23.040, 3-19-91; Ord. No. 7-05, pt. 1, 5-3-05)  
Secs. 2-210—2-220. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT BLOCK GRANT BLOCK ADVISORY BOARD[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 0024-19, pts. 1—4, adopted November 12, 2019, repealed the former Div. 5, §§ 2-221—2-223, and enacted a new Div. 5 as set out herein. The former Div. 5 pertained to economic development committee and derived from Code 1973, § 3.45.010—3.45.030;Ord. No. 14-96, pt. 1, August 5, 1996; Ord. No. 2-11, pt. 1, June 27, 2011. 
Cross reference— Policy on absenteeism of boards, committees, commissions, § 2-166. 
 
Sec. 2-221. - Purpose and intent. 
The common council created the loan board of review, by Resolution 6609 of February 5, 1980, as modified by Resolution 10-2318 of December 21, 2010. The Loan Board of Review had the authority to approve to approve or reject housing rehabilitation loan applications relating to the programs administered by the department of housing; the authority to administer the Housing Rehabilitation Loan Program for properties with four or fewer dwelling units, including establishing administrative rules, procedures, and program policies; approval or disapproval of individual loan applications; and monitoring of existing loans to ensure compliance with the terms and conditions of the loans and collection of loan payments. Administration by the loan board pursuant to such authorization did not require further approval by the common council. In all other matters to come before the loan board, the loan board advised the common council, and the alderperson appointed to the loan board reported the loan board's recommendations for approval by the common council. 
The common council further created the community development committee by Resolution No. 2912 of November 6, 1974, as modified by Resolution No. 4541-A of December 18, 1990, Resolution 6393 of March 1, 2005, and Resolution 13-0091 of February 20, 2013. The community development committee reviewed legislative items pertaining to city activities that receive federal funding from U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development grant programs, including the Community Development Block Grant, HOME Investment Partnerships Program, and Emergency Solutions Grant. The community development committee also reviewed such HUD documents as Consolidated Plans, Annual Action Plans, and Consolidated Annual Performance and Evaluation Reports prior to providing recommendations to Common Council. 
The loan board of review and the community development committee are hereby dissolved and there is hereby created a community development block grant advisory board consisting of nine members. 
(Ord. No. 0024-19, pt. 2, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 2-222. - Membership; terms of office; appointments; compensation. 
(a)  The mayor shall make appointments to the community development block grant advisory board on the first Tuesday in June, subject to common council confirmation. The terms of the non-common council members shall commence on July 1 and shall expire on June 30 of the last year of the term. 
(b)  The members of the board shall be the mayor, who shall serve as chair, the president of the common council, who shall serve as vice-chair, the chairs of the three additional members of the common council, and four electors who by reason of their places of residence, occupations, or community activities have special interest in the application of community development funds. The elector members shall serve staggered three- year terms, except that immediately following passage of this resolution, the mayor shall designate members to serve such one or two year terms as necessary to establish the three-year staggered cycle. Thereafter, all successors will be appointed for three years and no elector member may serve two consecutive three-year terms. The director of city development shall serve as the board secretary. 
(c)  Members of the board shall receive no compensation for their services. 
(Ord. No. 0024-19, pt. 3, 11-12-19; Ord. No. 0005-20, pt. 1, 8-6-20)  
Sec. 2-223. - Duties. 
It shall be the duty of the community development block grant advisory board to perform all the duties previously performed by the loan board of review and the community development committee. 
(Ord. No. 0024-19, pt. 4, 11-12-19)  
Secs. 2-224—2-235. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - HEALTH AND SANITATION APPEAL BOARD[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference— Policy on absenteeism of boards, committees, commissions, § 2-166; health, ch. 54. 
 
Sec. 2-236. - Created; composition. 
There is hereby created the health and sanitation appeal board, consisting of five residents of the city, including at least one alderman, one property owner and one renter. Whenever any member of the appeal board shall lose the status which was a prerequisite to his appointment to the appeal board and such loss of status shall have the effect of loss of the minimum requirement of class of representation on the appeal board as provided for in this section, his term of office shall thereupon expire and his position shall be deemed vacant. 
(Code 1973, § 11.09.080(a))  
Sec. 2-237. - Appointment and terms; compensation; quorum. 
(a)  The members of the health and sanitation appeal board shall be appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation of the common council. Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner. The mayor shall appoint annually from the members a chairman of the board and a secretary. All appointments shall be made for terms of three years, except that the alderman member of the board shall be a member only as long as he continues to hold office as alderman. Board members shall receive no compensation for their services. 
(b)  The presence of at least three members of the health and sanitation appeal board at any meeting duly called shall constitute a quorum. 
(Code 1973, § 11.09.080(b), (d))  
Sec. 2-238. - Meetings; records. 
Meetings of the health and sanitation appeal board shall be held at the call of the chairman and at such times as the board may determine. The chairman may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. In the absence of the chairman, the members of the board shall elect one of its members to preside and exercise the functions of the chairman. All meetings of the board shall be open to the public. The board shall keep minutes of its meetings and shall keep records of its hearings and other official actions, all of which shall be immediately filed in the office of the board and shall be a public record. 
(Code 1973, § 11.09.080(c))  
Sec. 2-239. - Office of the board. 
The office of the health and sanitation appeal board shall be in the office of the administrator in the city hall. All documents and communications addressed to or required to be filed with the board shall be filed in the office of the board. The secretary shall have charge of all of the records and files of the board. 
(Code 1973, § 11.09.080(e))  
Sec. 2-240. - Functions, hearing procedures. 
The health and sanitation appeal board shall conduct a hearing on any appeal filed by any person affected by any declaration, notice or order issued in connection with the enforcement of the provisions of chapter 18, article V and chapter 78. After such hearing, the board shall sustain, modify or withdraw the declaration, notice or order, depending upon its findings as to whether the provisions of the applicable chapter have been complied with. The board may also modify any notice so as to authorize a variance from the provisions of the applicable chapter when, because of special conditions, a literal enforcement of the chapter will result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship; provided, that the spirit of the applicable chapter of this Code will be observed, public health and welfare secured, and substantial justice done. If the board sustains or modifies such declaration, notice or order, it shall be deemed an order, and the owner, operator or occupant, as the case may require, shall comply with all provisions of such order within a reasonable period of time, as determined by the board. After a hearing in the case of any notice revoking any permit required by the applicable chapter, when such notice has been sustained by the board, the permit shall be deemed to have been revoked. The concurring vote of a majority of a properly convened board shall be required to reverse or modify any declaration, notice or order of the administrator, or to decide in favor of the applicant on any matter upon which it is required to pass under this Code. 
(Code 1973, § 11.09.080(f))  
Secs. 2-241—2-250. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - PLANNING, HERITAGE, AND DESIGN COMMISSION[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 1, adopted November 12, 2019, changed the title of Division 7 to read as set out herein. Formerly, division 7 was entitled "Plan Commission." 
Cross reference— Policy on absenteeism of boards, committees, commissions, § 2-166; parks and recreation areas, § 70-76 et seq.; subdivision of land, ch. 86; zoning, ch. 114. 
State Law reference— Planning, heritage, and design commission, Wis. Stats. § 62.23. 
 
Sec. 2-251. - Created. 
(a)  The planning, heritage, and design commission is hereby created, which shall serve as, and have the authority of, a city plan commission created pursuant to the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 62.23 and shall have the powers set forth in section 114-33. The planning, heritage, and design commission shall have no authority to expend money except when specifically provided by the common council. 
(b)  All appointments to the planning, heritage, and design commission shall be made by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the common council. Membership of the planning, heritage, and design commission shall consist of seven members and shall include the mayor and an alderperson. The mayor may appoint other city elected or appointed officials, except that the commission shall always have at least three citizen members who are not city officials. Citizen members shall be persons of recognized experience and qualifications. Notwithstanding anything else contained herein, of the membership, one member shall be a registered architect or building professional, one member shall be a historian qualified in the field of historic preservation, and one member shall be a licensed real estate broker. 
(c)  All appointments to the planning, heritage, and design commission are for a term of three years, except that upon cessation of holding office or employment of a city elected or appointed official, the position shall be vacant. Appointments shall be made during the month of April for terms that expire in April or at any other time if a vacancy occurs during the middle of a term. 
(Code 1973, § 3.17.010; Ord. No. 13-91, pt. 1, § 3.17.010, 4-15-91; Ord. No. 2-00, § 1, 4-5-00; Ord. No. 24-05, pt. 1, 12-6-05; Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 2, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 2-252. - Adoption of plans. 
(a)  Recommendation by city planning, heritage, and design commission. The planning, heritage, and design commission shall prepare a comprehensive plan for the city and may, as the work of making the comprehensive plan progresses, recommend that part or parts of the comprehensive plan or amendments to the comprehensive plan be adopted. The planning, heritage, and design commission shall comply with the procedures described in Wis. Stats. § 66.1001 (4)(b) in submitting its recommendations to the common council. 
(b)  Adoption by common council. Upon receipt of a recommendation from the planning, heritage, and design commission that a comprehensive plan, part of a comprehensive plan, or amendment to a comprehensive plan be adopted, the common council shall schedule a public hearing and provide notice pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.1001 (4)(d). If the common council agrees with the recommendation of the planning, heritage, and design commission, the common council shall adopt the recommendation as an ordinance. When the adopted comprehensive plan, part of a comprehensive plan, or amendment to a comprehensive plan is in the form of a report, the ordinance shall identify the adopted report by title and date of planning, heritage, and design commission action. The director of city development shall maintain a master list of the reports adopted by the common council as a comprehensive plan, part of a comprehensive plan, or amendment to a comprehensive plan. 
(Ord. No. 13-02, pt. 1, 7-16-02; Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 2, 11-12-19)  
Secs. 2-253—2-260. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 8. - DUE PROCESS BOARD 
 
Sec. 2-261. - Created, appointments. 
There is hereby created a due process board consisting of four citizen members, one aldermen and one non-voting member of the Tavern League of Wisconsin. The aldermen member of the due process board shall not be a current standing member of the public safety and licensing committee. The non-voting member of the Tavern League of Wisconsin may be excused from participating in any meeting at his or her request and with approval of the chairman of the board. All members of the due process board shall be appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation by the common council; vacancies shall be filled in the same manner. The due process board shall elect a citizen member from among its membership to serve as the chairman of the board at its first meeting following the common council's annual organizational meeting. 
(Ord. No. 0016-17, pt. 1, 10-16-17)  
Sec. 2-262. - Terms; quorum. 
(a)  Terms. All appointments of members for the due process board shall be for a term of two years. The alderman member of the board shall serve during the time he or she holds his or her respective office and during the period that he or she has been appointed to the board. Appointments shall be made on the third Tuesday in May. The term of office shall begin upon appointment, confirmation and qualification and shall continue until the qualification of a successor. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term. 
(b)  Quorum and voting. The presence of at least three voting members of the due process board at any meeting duly called shall constitute a quorum. A concurring vote of a majority of a properly convened board shall be required on any matter upon which the board is required to consider under this article. 
(Ord. No. 0016-17, pt. 1, 10-16-17)  
Sec. 2-263. - Functions. 
(a)  Conduct hearings on an appeal filed by a person adversely affected as a result of a code enforcement officer's determination of a chronic nuisance premise under article XXX of chapter 66. After such hearing, the board shall either affirm or reverse the determination of the code enforcement officer, depending on its findings as to whether the criteria for declaring a chronic nuisance premise and assessing costs and forfeitures have been met under the ordinance. 
(b)  Conduct due process hearings regarding the nonrenewal, suspension and/or revocation of any licenses related to the sale of alcohol beverages pursuant to chapter 6 of the code and Wis. Stats. § 125.12. After such hearing and within five business days after it reaches a decision, the board shall file a report containing the findings of fact, conclusions of law and recommendation as to the license, with the city clerk. Upon majority vote, the common council shall either affirm or reverse the findings of the board. 
(c)  Conduct hearings on appeal filed by an owner of a tenant's authorization to deposit rental payments into an escrow account pursuant to section 18-904(4) of the Code. The board shall follow the procedures set forth in section 18-904(4) for such hearings. 
(Ord. No. 0016-17, pt. 1, 10-16-17; Ord. No. 0002-18, pt. 1, 5-15-18; Ord. No. 0022-19, pt. 8, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 2-264. - Hearing procedures. 
(a)  Procedures. Meetings of the due process board shall be held at the call of the chairman and at such time as may be required pursuant to the functions of the board. The chairman of the due process board shall be the presiding officer and may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses through subpoenas. The chairman shall ensure that an orderly hearing is conducted in accordance with the requirements of this subsection. The chairman shall rule on objections to the admissibility of evidence. Any ruling of the chairman shall be final unless appealed to the board, and the board shall reverse such ruling only upon the vote of a majority of its members present and voting. In the absence of the chairman, the members of the board shall elect one of its citizen members to preside and exercise the functions of the chairman. 
(b)  A member of the clerk's office shall be present at each meeting to take minutes and shall keep records of its hearings and other official actions. 
(c)  All meetings of the board shall be open to the public. 
(d)  At all stages of the proceedings before the board or before the common council, the licensee shall be entitled to appear both in person and by an attorney. 
(Ord. No. 0016-17, pt. 1, 10-16-17)  
Sec. 2-265. - Compensations. 
Excepting the alderman for his or her role as an elected official, members of the due process board shall receive no compensation for their services. 
(Ord. No. 0016-17, pt. 1, 10-16-17)  
Secs. 2-266—2-275. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 9. - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY 
 
Sec. 2-276. - Findings; declaration of necessity. 
The Common Council of the City of Racine finds and declares that there exists within the city the need for blight elimination, clearance of undesirable conditions, urban renewal and community development programs and projects, and housing projects. The city has in existence a redevelopment authority created by Resolution No. 2305, March 6, 1974, pursuant to Wis. Stat. § 66.1333, and has in existence an elderly housing authority, created by Resolution No. 2826-A, September 20, 1988, pursuant to Wis. Stat. § 66.1131, operating within the city, which have some but not all of the authority to carry out the needs stated herein. 
(Ord. No. 0025-19, pt. 1, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 2-277. - Creation of community development authority; termination of redevelopment authority and elderly housing authority. 
There is hereby created a housing and community development authority, which shall be known as the Community Development Authority of the City of Racine, pursuant to Wis. Stat. § 66.1335. The community development authority shall be a public body and a body corporate and politic exercising necessary public powers, and having all the powers, duties, and functions conferred on housing authorities, redevelopment authorities, and housing and community development authorities by applicable law. The community development authority is created for the purpose of carrying out all such blight elimination, clearance of undesirable conditions, urban renewal programs and projects and housing projects within the city. 
The redevelopment authority previously created in the city is terminated. The elderly housing authority previously created in the city is terminated. 
(1)  Any programs and projects which have been begun by the redevelopment authority or by the elderly housing authority shall be transferred to and completed by the community development authority. Any procedures, hearings, actions, or approvals taken or initiated by the redevelopment authority or by the elderly housing authority on pending projects are deemed to have been taken or initiated by the community development authority as if the community development authority had originally undertaken the procedures, hearings, actions, or approvals. 
(2)  Any form of indebtedness issued by the redevelopment authority or by the elderly housing authority shall be assumed by the community development authority. 
(3)  All contracts entered into between the federal government and the redevelopment authority or by the elderly housing authority, or between the redevelopment authority or the elderly housing authority and other parties, shall be assumed and discharged by the community development authority except for the termination of operations by the redevelopment authority. The redevelopment authority or the elderly housing authority may execute any agreements contemplated by this subsection. Contracts for disposition of real property entered into by the redevelopment authority or by the elderly housing authority with respect to any project are deemed contracts of the community development authority without the requirement of amendments to the contracts. Contracts entered into between the federal government and the redevelopment authority or the elderly housing authority bind the community development authority in the same manner as if originally entered into by the community development authority. 
(4)  The community development authority may execute appropriate documents to reflect its assumption of the obligations set forth in this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 0025-19, pt. 1, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 2-278. - Composition; powers; compensation. 
The community development authority shall consist of seven resident persons of the city ability and experience in the fields of urban renewal, community development and housing, as commissioners of the community development authority. The powers of the community development authority shall be vested in and exercised by the commissioners. The commissioners shall receive no compensation for their services. 
(Ord. No. 0025-19, pt. 1, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 2-279. - Appointment; vacancies. 
The commissioners of the community development authority shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the common council as follows: 
(a)  Two of the commissioners shall be members of the common council and shall serve during their term of office. 
(b)  The first appointments of the five non-common council members shall be for the following terms: two for one year, and one each for terms of two, three, and four years. Thereafter the terms of non-common council members shall be four years and until their successors are appointed and qualified. 
(c)  After the appointments of the original seven commissioners have been made and confirmed, vacancies occurring during any term shall be filled for the unexpired portion of the term and new appointments or reappointments of commissioners shall be made in the same manner in which the original appointments were made. 
(d)  One commissioner shall be appointed the chair for a one-year appointment. 
(e)  One commissioner shall be appointed the vice chair for a one-year appointment. 
The mayor shall make appointments to the community development authority on the third Tuesday in April, subject to common council confirmation. The terms of the non-common council members shall commence on May 1 and shall expire on April 30 of the last year of the term. 
(Ord. No. 0025-19, pt. 1, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 2-280. - Meetings; quorum; bylaws. 
Meetings of the community development authority shall be held in compliance with the provisions of the Wisconsin Open Meetings Law, Wis. Stats. §§ 19.81 to 19.98. Four commissioners shall constitute a quorum of the community development authority for the purpose of conducting its business and exercising its powers and for all other purposes. Action may be taken by the community development authority upon the affirmative vote of the majority of commissioners present at any meeting of the community development authority at which a quorum is present. No vacancy in the membership of the CDA shall impair the right of the quorum to exercise the powers and perform the functions of the community development authority. The community development authority may adopt, and from time to time amend or repeal, such bylaws and other rules and regulations not inconsistent with applicable law, as it deems necessary in the performance of its functions, subject to the approval of the common council. 
(Ord. No. 0025-19, pt. 1, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 2-281. - Powers and duties of community development authority. 
(a)  The community development authority shall have all the powers, duties, and functions of a housing authority as set forth in Wis. Stats. §§ 66.1201 to 66.1213 inclusive, and all housing projects initiated by the community development authority and approved by the common council shall be undertaken and carried out pursuant to such sections. 
(b)  The community development authority shall have all the powers, duties, and functions of the redevelopment authority as set forth in Wis. Stat. § 66.1333, and all projects relating to blight eliminations, clearance of undesirable conditions, urban renewal and redevelopment programs initiated by the community development authority and approved by the common council shall be undertaken and carried out pursuant to Wis. Stats. §§ 66.1105, 66.1301 to 66.1329, inclusive, Wis. Stats. §§ 66.1331, 66.1333, or Wis. Stat. § 66.1337 as determined appropriate by the common council on a project by project basis. 
(c)  The community development authority is authorized to act as agent for the city in planning and carrying out community development programs and activities approved by the common council under the Federal Housing and Community Development Act of 1974, as amended, 42 U.S.C. 5300 to 5320. 
(d)  The community development authority is further authorized to act as agent to perform all acts, except the development of the general plan of the city, which may be otherwise performed by the city plan commission under Wis. Stats. §§ 66.1105, 66.1301 to 66.1329, inclusive, Wis. Stat. § 66.1331, or Wis. Stat. § 66.1337. 
(e)  The community development authority may issue bonds or notes from time to time in furtherance of its power and duties and as authorized by state law and the city hereby declares that such community development authority bonds and notes are issued for an essential public and government purpose and are public instrumentalities. 
(f)  In addition to the foregoing powers, duties and functions, the community development authority shall have such other powers, duties and functions related to community development as conferred on it from time to time by the common council. 
(Ord. No. 0025-19, pt. 1, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 2-282. - Construction. 
The powers conferred upon the community development authority pursuant to this division and pursuant to Wis. Stat. § 66.1335, as amended from time to time, shall be in addition to and supplemental to the powers conferred upon a community development authority by any other law, provided that insofar as this division or Wis. Stat. § 66.1335 is inconsistent with any other law, this division and Wis. Stat. § 66.1335 shall control. 
(Ord. No. 0025-19, pt. 1, 11-12-19)  
Secs. 2-283—2-290. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 10. - TRANSIT COMMISSION[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 0005-18, pt. 4, adopted August 6, 2018, repealed the former Division 10, §§ 2-291—2-299, and enacted a new Division 10 as set out herein. The former Division 10 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1973, §§ 3.205.010—3.205.090; Ord. No. 16-94, pt. 1, September 6, 1994; Ord. No. 18-94, pt. 1, September 3, 1996; Ord. No. 2-97, pts. 2, 3, February 19, 1997; Ord. No. 22-06, pt. 1, June 28, 2006. Additionally, Ord. No. 0013-19, pt. 1, adopted 5-21-2019, changed the title of div. 10 to "Transit Commission". Formerly said article was entitled "Transit and Parking Commission". 
Cross reference— Policy on absenteeism of boards, committees, commissions, § 2-166; municipal parking facilities, § 94-276 et seq.; off-street parking and loading, § 114-1131 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-291. - Created; composition. 
(a)  There is hereby created a transit commission for the maintenance and operation of a comprehensive unified local transportation system within the meaning of, pursuant to the authority of, and subject to, Wis. Stat. § 66.1021. The transit commission shall consist of nine commissioners. Included in the membership of the transit commission shall be six City of Racine citizen members, one City of Racine alderman elected by the common council, and two members appointed by the Village of Mount Pleasant, Wisconsin. The City of Racine citizen members of the commission shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to the confirmation of the common council; vacancies shall be filled in the same manner. 
(b)  The first members of the transit commission shall be appointed for staggered three-year terms. The term of office of each member appointed after the first members of the transit commission shall be three years. The members of the transit commission shall be appointed effective the first day of June of the year of appointment. 
(Ord. No. 0005-18, pt. 4, 8-6-18; Ord. No. 0013-19, pt. 1, 5-21-19)  
Sec. 2-292. - Terms of office; compensation. 
All appointments of citizen members of the transit commission shall be for a term of three years. The other members of the commission shall serve during the period of time they hold their respective offices. Appointments shall be made on October 1. The term of office shall begin upon appointment, confirmation, and qualification, and shall continue until the qualification of a successor. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term. Members of the commission shall receive no compensation for their services. 
(Ord. No. 0005-18, pt. 4, 8-6-18)-  
Sec. 2-293. - Election of officers; secretary. 
Each year within 30 days after the time designated in this division for the beginning of terms, the members of the transit commission shall organize by the election of a citizen member as chairman of the commission and the selection of such other officers as they may deem necessary. The traffic engineer or his representative shall serve as secretary of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 0005-18, pt. 4, 8-6-18)  
Sec. 2-294. - Duties. 
It shall be the general duty of the transit commission to provide overall supervision of the assets and operation of the transit system to ensure that it functions as an integrated part of the overall transportation system. This supervision shall include, but is not limited to, recommendations to the common council relating to: the issuance of revenue bonds, service agreements and contracts, retention of professional transit management firms, routes, fares, hours of service, buildings and grounds, purchase and maintenance of transit vehicles and transit related items, personal recruitment and training, labor relations and negotiations, advertising and insurance, the general financial status of the transit system, and other items which concern the physical and operational aspects of bus transit management. 
(Ord. No. 0005-18, pt. 4, 8-6-18)  
Sec. 2-295. - Budget. 
The transit commission shall annually prepare operating and outlay budgets for the activities in which it is engaged, which budgets shall be approved by a majority of the members of the commission and shall be submitted to the common council for its approval. The commission shall be subject to the budget ordinance of the city and shall have no authority to expend funds other than those appropriated or approved by the common council. 
(Ord. No. 0005-18, pt. 4, 8-6-18)  
Sec. 2-296. - Finances. 
All accounts relating to the mass transit system shall be audited by the transit commission, and if approved by a majority of the commission, shall be paid by orders upon the city treasurer, signed by the mayor, city clerk, and finance director. The finance director shall keep, as separate funds, all income and revenue derived from the mass transportation system and any funds especially provided for either by the common council and pay therefrom all orders legally drawn upon such funds. 
(Ord. No. 0005-18, pt. 4, 8-6-18)  
Sec. 2-297. - Real estate purchases; construction work. 
The transit commission shall purchase no real estate to be used as part of the mass transit system without the prior approval of a majority of the members of the common council. Any construction work undertaken by the commission shall be under the immediate supervision of the commissioner of public works. 
(Ord. No. 0005-18, pt. 4, 8-6-18)  
Sec. 2-298. - Recommendations to the council. 
The common council and its committees shall refer to the transit commission for its recommendation all matters coming before them relating to mass transit. The common council shall vote upon any recommendation of the commission within 90 days after the filing of such recommendation with the city clerk. If any proposed ordinance, resolution, petition, or request referred to the commission is disapproved by the commission, such ordinance, resolution, petition or request shall not be adopted or granted, except by at least a majority vote of the full membership of the common council. 
(Ord. No. 0005-18, pt. 4, 8-6-18)  
Secs. 2-299—2-320. - Reserved.

(Code 1973, § 3.175.010)  
Sec. 2-332. - Duties.

(2)  Perform planning services set forth in Wis. Stats. ch. 236 and Wis. Stats. §§ 62.23 and 66.431. 
(3)  Administer the community development block grant program. 
(4)  Prepare applications for federal and state grants-in-aid relating to redevelopment plans, urban renewal plans and other programs as directed by the common council. 
(Code 1973, § 3.175.020; Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 4, 11-12-19)

DIVISION 5. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Cross reference— Bureau of fire prevention, § 50-61 et seq. 
State Law reference— Police and fire departments, Wis. Stats. § 62.13. 
 
Sec. 2-376. - Composition; fire chief. 
(a)  The fire department of the city shall consist of a chief appointed by the board of police and fire commissioners and such subordinate officers and members as the common council may from time to time provide. Appointments to the department shall be by the chief in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 62.13(4)(a). 
(b)  The chief of the fire department shall have sole and absolute command over all persons connected with the fire department and shall possess full power and authority over its organization, government and discipline, and to that end may prescribe and establish such rules and regulations as may be deemed advisable, subject to the provisions of this division and to any orders issued by the mayor. 
(c)  The fire chief shall have the custody, subject to the directions of the mayor, of all apparatus, property and equipment belonging to the fire department. 
(d)  The fire chief shall inquire into all fires in the city as soon after they occur as possible, and keep a record of such fires. 
(e)  The fire chief shall report to the common council, on or before May 1 each year, on the condition of the fire station, fire apparatus, etc., and also report all property damage losses and classes of buildings damaged by fire. 
(f)  The fire chief shall make suitable regulations under which the officers and members of the fire department will be required to wear an appropriate uniform. 
(g)  The fire chief shall keep a full and complete record of all transactions in the fire department, of all complaints against members thereof, of all property placed in the chief's charge, and of such other records as the business of the department may require. 
(h)  The fire chief or designee in command may prescribe limits in the vicinity of any fire within which no unauthorized person shall be permitted. 
(i)  The fire chief shall exercise all other powers granted to such office by law or ordinance. 
(Code 1973, §§ 5.01.010, 5.02.010—5.02.080) 
Cross reference— Residency requirement for certain administrative officers, § 2-437. 
State Law reference— Board of police and fire commissioners, Wis. Stats. § 62.13(1); appointment and removal of fire chief, Wis. Stats. § 62.13(3).  
Sec. 2-377. - Chief officer. 
(a)  The chief officer of the fire department in command shall have charge of all fire apparatus, station houses and members in the absence of the chief, and the responsibilities of the operation of the force devolves upon such officer. 
(b)  The chief officer in command of the fire department shall maintain good order and discipline of the members of such department, and when any offense under the rules has been committed shall immediately take appropriate action up to and including suspension. 
(Code 1973, §§ 5.03.010, 5.03.020)  
Sec. 2-378. - Recruitment and background investigations of applicants. 
(a)  Recruitment for the fire department will be done in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 62.13(4)(a) and (c), and other rules and policies governing recruitment, screening, testing and selection of applicants adopted by the board of police and fire commissioners. 
(b)  The chief of police, members of the municipal police department acting in his name, or his designated representatives, are authorized to conduct a field investigation and directed to conduct criminal records checks on each applicant for employment by the municipal fire department. 
(c)  The chief of police or a member of the police department acting in his behalf shall prepare a factual summary of the background investigation and criminal records check of each firefighter applicant, and transmit such summary to the fire chief and the board of police and fire commissioners for the purpose of determining the fitness of an applicant. The summary may contain recommendations to the fire chief concerning the suitability for employment of a firefighter applicant. 
(d)  Background investigations and records checks of applicants for the position of firefighter include records of all arrests and dispositions as an adult. Records of arrests and dispositions while such applicant was considered a juvenile shall be transmitted only when authorized by court order, court rule, court decision, federal regulation or state statute authorizing such dissemination. 
(e)  Criminal history records and information of applicants for the position of firefighter shall include arrest and disposition data on file in the National Crime Information Center, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Department of Defense, and all other federal, state and local law enforcement agencies. 
(f)  Any applicant to the municipal fire department may inspect its summary of such applicant for the purpose of clarifying, explaining or denying the accuracy of its contents. 
(g)  The chief of police and members of the police department shall make no other dissemination to the fire chief regarding the fitness of firefighter applicants, except in the official summary report referred to in this division. 
(Code 1973, § 5.01.020)  
Sec. 2-379. - Platoons. 
(a)  Generally. Fire department companies shall be divided into two or more platoons. Each platoon shall be on duty no longer than 24 continuous hours and on a work schedule designated by the fire chief. The battalion chiefs shall alternate in the same manner. Platoons shall go on duty at 7:00 a.m. 
(b)  Change of shift; procedure. 
(1)  Promptly at 7:00 a.m., the fire company officer shall ensure that there are sufficient firefighters on duty to staff the required apparatus. The commanding officer shall ready any special or general orders. Entry shall be made in the company journal of the condition of the company, noting any exceptions that may occur. 
(2)  The officer of the off-going platoon shall transmit to the officer of the on-coming platoon any orders received during the tour of duty, and make necessary explanations concerning quarters, apparatus and equipment. The names of absent members shall be noted and reported immediately to the chief or the chief officer on duty. This report must be made immediately by telephone, followed as soon as possible by a written report to the chief through the proper channels. 
(3)  If companies are working at a fire at the time of changing shift, they shall be required to remain until the fire is extinguished unless otherwise ordered by the chief officer in charge of the fire. 
(c)  Transfer. Members of the fire company may be transferred from one platoon to another platoon at the discretion of the fire chief or the battalion chief in charge for the efficiency of the service. Changes shall be made from one platoon to another. 
(d)  Vacancy. In case of a vacancy in any company caused by an absentee, the fire chief or battalion chief on duty shall draw a properly qualified firefighter from a company having more firefighters on duty than its minimum quota and cause such person to fill the vacancy. 
(Code 1973, §§ 5.12.010—5.12.040)  
Sec. 2-380. - Regulations. 
The fire department and all of its members shall be subject to the standard operating procedures manual promulgated from time to time by the fire chief. 
(Code 1973, § 5.13.010)  
Sec. 2-381. - Salaries and working hours. 
Subject to the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 62.13, the fire chief and all members of the fire department shall be paid such salaries and allowances and receive such fringe benefits and work such hours as the common council shall from time to time determine, or shall be agreed upon between the city and the collective bargaining units within the department. 
(Code 1973, § 5.18.010)  
Sec. 2-382. - Benefits. 
(a)  Sick leave. 
(1)  For all members of the fire department on 24-hour shifts, sick leave shall be accumulated at a rate of 11.2 hours per month. The sick leave account of each member of the fire department on 24-hour working shifts shall be charged with 24 hours' sick time for each work shift not worked because of illness. 
(2)  For all members of the fire department on other than 24-hour working shifts, a day of sick leave shall mean eight working hours. The sick leave account of each member of the fire department on other than 24-hour working shifts shall be charged with eight hours' sick time for each work shift not worked because of illness. 
(b)  Retirement gratuity. Upon retirement or upon death, a gratuity shall be given to those fire department employees having accrued sick leave to their credit, in such amounts and under such conditions as are from time to time prescribed by the common council or as are agreed upon between the city and the collective bargaining units within the fire department. 
(c)  Leaves of absence. The fire chief and all members of the fire department may be granted leaves of absence for such purposes and under such regulations as shall from time to time be prescribed by the board of police and fire commissioners or are agreed upon between the city and the collective bargaining units within the fire department. 
(Code 1973, §§ 5.14.010, 5.14.020, 5.15.010)  
Sec. 2-383. - Outside employment. 
(a)  When a fire department employee accepts employment in addition to his firefighting obligations, he shall within 24 hours of the acceptance of such employment notify the chief of the department in writing that he has accepted such employment, and shall include in such notice the name of the employer, business address of the employer, business telephone number of the employer and the normal hours of work. 
(b)  If the outside employment of any firefighter constitutes a conflict of interest or interferes with the employee's efficiency or availability for work, the chief of the fire department shall give the employee a written request to withdraw from the outside employment. The employee and union representative shall make and deliver to the chief of the department a written reply to such request within 24 hours of its receipt. Such reply shall inform the chief of the department either of the employee's acquiescence in the request or desire to place the matter in arbitration. 
(Code 1973, §§ 5.16.010—5.16.030)  
Sec. 2-384. - Emergency call to duty. 
If an emergency exists whereby the chief of the fire department calls a member to duty outside the normal shift, such member shall agree to report regardless of the fact that the firefighter may be engaged in gainful part-time employment as provided for in this division. 
(Code 1973, § 5.16.040)  
Sec. 2-385. - Outside work injury. 
If any member of the fire department suffers a major injury while engaged in part-time outside employment, thereby disqualifying such member temporarily to work in the fire department, the employee may receive a leave of absence, without pay, not to exceed one year to recover from such injury and return to work in the fire department. The employee shall have the option of taking sick leave during this period of time or of taking a leave of absence either immediately after the injury or upon the exhaustion of accrued sick leave. Such leave of absence shall be taken in accordance with the provisions of section 2-382(c). At the option of the city, employees shall submit to a physical examination by a physician chosen by the city prior to returning to employment in the fire department. 
(Code 1973, § 5.16.050)  
Sec. 2-386. - Suspension and removal of members. 
Any officer or member of the fire department who violates any provisions of this division or provision of Standard Operating Procedures may be suspended, reduced in rank, or removed in the manner provided by Wis. Stats. § 62.13. 
(Code 1973, § 5.17.010)  
Sec. 2-387. - Contract negotiations. 
Unless prohibited by law, the result of contract negotiations between the city and Local 321, International Association of Fire Fighters, AFL-CIO, and its staff officers' association shall automatically become a part of this division, and any provisions in conflict therewith shall be amended, deleted or revised to conform to the terms of such negotiated agreements. 
(Code 1973, § 5.21.010)  
Secs. 2-388—2-400. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[18] 

Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
Cross reference— Offenses, ch. 66; personnel, ch. 74; traffic and vehicles, ch. 94. 
State Law reference— Police, Wis. Stats. §§ 62.09(13), 62.13. 
 
Sec. 2-401. - Composition. 
(a)  The police department of the city shall consist of a chief of police appointed by the board of police and fire commissioners, and such subordinate officers and positions and such number of members as the common council from time to time shall provide. Subordinate officers shall be appointed by the chief subject to the approval of the board of police and fire commissioners. 
(b)  The police department shall consist of such divisions and ranks as may be deemed necessary by the chief of police consistent with departmental duties and size. These divisions shall be set forth in the department rules and regulations, which rules and regulations shall be subject to state statute and the approval of the board of police and fire commissioners. The number of commissioned and noncommissioned personnel shall be determined by the common council, except that any reduction in the personnel of the department shall be subject to the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 62.13. 
(Code 1973, §§ 4.01.010, 4.02.010) 
State Law reference— Board of police and fire commissioners, Wis. Stats. §§ 62.13(1).  
Sec. 2-402. - Chief of police. 
(a)  Responsibilities. The chief of police shall be the commanding officer of the police force and be responsible for the enforcement of law and order. He shall be responsible for the care and maintenance of all property and equipment of his department. 
(b)  Supervision of department; deputy chiefs. The chief of police shall have general supervision over the police department and be responsible for the efficiency thereof. In the event of a temporary absence of the chief of police, his duties shall be performed by the deputy chief of police designated by the chief of police, and in the event of the disability, death or suspension of the chief of police, his duties shall be performed by the deputy chief of police of the patrol division. 
(c)  Duty to keep record of receipts and turn over monies. When any money shall be paid to the chief of police for bail or on execution or for any fine, forfeiture or penalty, or for fees received by him or any police officer, it shall be his duty to make a record thereof in a book to be kept for that purpose and to pay such money over to the city treasurer or proper officer entitled thereto and take his receipt therefor. 
(d)  Reports to council. The chief of police shall report quarterly to the common council, or oftener if required, and account for all moneys received by him. He shall report to the common council during the month of February in each year the work done by the police department during the preceding year ending December 31; also the condition, needs and defects of the department; and shall make such recommendations as to him may seem necessary and proper. 
(e)  Supervision of emergency services and records. The chief of police shall have general supervision over the director of emergency services and records and be responsible for the efficiency of the emergency services and records operations. 
(Code 1973, §§ 4.01.020, 4.03.010, 4.11.010, 4.11.020; Ord. No. 20-92, pt. 1, § 4.03.010, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 6-05, pt. 1, 4-6-05; Ord. No. 24-05, pt. 3, 12-6-05; Ord. No. 14-06, pt. 1, 5-10-06) 
Cross reference— Residency requirement for certain administrative officers, § 2-437.  
Sec. 2-403. - Background investigation of applicants. 
(a)  The chief of police, and members of the police department acting in his name, are authorized to conduct a field investigation and directed to conduct criminal records checks on each applicant for employment by the police department. 
(b)  The chief of police or a member of the police department acting in his behalf shall prepare a factual summary of the background investigation and criminal records check of each police officer applicant, and transmit such summary to the police chief and the board of police and fire commissioners for the purpose of determining the fitness of an applicant. The summary may contain recommendations to the police chief concerning the suitability for employment of a police officer applicant. 
(c)  Background investigations and records checks of police officer applicants shall include records of all arrests and dispositions as an adult. Records of arrests and dispositions while an applicant was considered a juvenile shall be transmitted only when authorized by court order, court rule, court decision, federal regulation or state statute authorizing such dissemination. 
(d)  Criminal history records and information on police officer applicants shall include arrest and disposition data on file in the National Crime Information Center, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Department of Defense, and all other federal, state and local law enforcement agencies. 
(e)  Any applicant to the police department may inspect its summary of such applicant for the purpose of clarifying, explaining or denying the accuracy of its contents. 
(f)  The chief of police and members of the police department shall make no other dissemination to the police chief regarding the fitness of police officer applicants, except in the official summary report referred to in this division. 
(Code 1973, § 4.01.030)  
Sec. 2-404. - Powers and privileges. 
The police chief and all members of the police department shall possess the powers, enjoy the privileges and be subject to the liabilities provided in Wis. Stats. § 62.09(13), which section is hereby adopted by reference. 
(Code 1973, § 4.02.020)  
Sec. 2-405. - Preservation of public peace. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police and of all police officers to preserve the public peace and to suppress all riots, disruptions and breaches of the peace, and they shall, with or without process, apprehend all persons or disturbers of the peace and take them before the appropriate courts. 
(Code 1973, § 4.03.020)  
Sec. 2-406. - Enforcement of ordinances. 
The chief of police shall see that all ordinances of the city are enforced. Whenever any violation of any ordinance shall come to his knowledge or shall come to the knowledge of any member of the police department, whether by personal observation or by information from others, the chief of police or such member of the department shall make a complaint and cause the person so offending to be prosecuted. 
(Code 1973, § 4.03.030)  
Sec. 2-407. - Full-time employment. 
The chief of police and all full paid members of the police department shall devote all their time to the work of such department, and shall not engage in any other business except as provided in section 2-408. 
(Code 1973, § 4.04.010)  
Sec. 2-408. - Part-time outside employment. 
Members of the department may engage in gainful part-time employment subject to the following rules and regulations: 
(1)  Prior to accepting or undertaking any employment, a member shall furnish to the chief of police, upon forms prepared for that purpose, a statement setting forth name of employer or self-employed, hours of employment and type of work, and an acknowledgment that the member is familiar with and will abide by department policies and procedures regarding part-time outside employment. If not self-employed, the member shall also furnish a statement from his or her employer verifying the statement of the employee and agreeing to all of the terms and conditions of such part-time employment and provisions of this section. 
(2)  In the event any member suffers a major injury while engaged in part-time employment disqualifying him or her temporarily for work on the police department, he or she shall submit to a physical examination prior to being re-employed by the police department. In the event of disability or inability to work on the police department by reason of injury or illness occurring because of part-time employment, substitution by other members of the police department for such injured policeman or policewoman shall not be permitted. 
(3)  No member may engage in any part-time employment which will interfere with his or her efficiency or availability for duty, create a conflict of interest with the member's duties as a Racine police officer, or violate department policies and procedures. 
(4)  No member shall engage in any part-time employment, when such employment requires the securing of a license from the city, or shall any member engage in part-time employment for a private investigating agency licensed by the state and performing private investigating work in Wisconsin. 
(5)  In the event the chief of police has reasonable grounds to believe that any part-time employment is interfering with a member's efficiency or availability for duty, creating a conflict of interest, or violating department policies and procedures, the chief may order the member to terminate his or her employment, or reduce the number of hours engaged in his or her part-time employment. The member, upon receipt of such order, shall promptly terminate his or her employment, or reduce the number of hours as directed by the chief of police. 
(Code 1973, § 4.04.020; Ord. No. 20-94, pt. 1, 10-18-94)  
Sec. 2-409. - Suspension and removal of members. 
Any member of the police department violating any of the rules and regulations of the department may be suspended, reduced in rank, or removed in the manner provided in Wis. Stats. § 62.13. 
(Code 1973, § 4.05.010)  
Sec. 2-410. - Posting of bail; forfeiture. 
(a)  The chief of police, whenever in his opinion the circumstances may require, may receive of any person who may have been accused of violating any ordinance and who has been arrested therefor, a sum of money not exceeding the maximum amount of the penalty which may be imposed in such case, and release such person from arrest until the opening of county court on the next succeeding day when the court may be in session, or until a time for the hearing of the case. 
(b)  When any person so arrested and released pursuant to subsection (a) of this section shall fail to appear personally or by his attorney at the time fixed for the hearing of the case, and upon the order of the court forfeiting bail, the money deposited with the chief of police shall be retained and paid into the county court and disbursed in the same manner as for fines imposed for violation of city ordinances. 
(Code 1973, §§ 4.12.010, 4.12.020)  
Sec. 2-411. - Use of police dogs. 
(a)  Guidelines. The chief of police and the public safety and licensing committee of the common council shall be empowered to promulgate guidelines for the use of dogs in doing police work for the city. Upon establishment of such guidelines, it shall be the duty of the chief of police to use these dogs within the confines of such guidelines. If any major changes are desired in such guidelines, the changes shall be approved jointly by the chief of police and the public safety and licensing committee, with final approval by the common council. The general discretion for use of such police dogs within the policy guidelines shall be the sole responsibility of the chief of police. 
(b)  Harassment of police dogs. It shall be unlawful for anyone to intentionally or willfully harass, injure or interfere with dogs used by the police department while they are being used in carrying out the duties of the police department. 
(Code 1973, §§ 4.13.010, 4.13.020; Ord. No. 8-04, pt. 5, 4-7-04; Ord. No. 33-06, pt. 1, 9-5-06)  
Sec. 2-412. - Appointment of humane officers. 
(a)  The common council shall appoint one or more humane officers. Humane officers shall have all of the powers and duties established under Wis. Stats. ch. 173. 
(b)  The chief of police is hereby designated as the official who may modify or withdraw abatement orders issued pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 173.11. 
(Ord. No. 05-15, pt. 1, 5-5-15)  
Secs. 2-413—2-430. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - HUMAN RESOURCES DEPARTMENT 
 
Sec. 2-431. - Created. 
There is hereby created the human resources department. 
(Ord. No. 08-08, pt. 2, 6-3-08; Ord. No. 0002-19, pt. 1, 2-20-19)  
Sec. 2-432. - Duties. 
It shall be the duty of the human resources department to: 
(1)  Approve or disapprove the selection, employment, termination, promotion, demotion, layoff and suspension of all personnel, other than those whose appointment has been otherwise specifically provided either by state statute or city ordinance. 
If the human resources department disapproves of any of the aforementioned activities, the human resources department and the appropriate administrative manager shall exhaust all reasonable means at their disposal in an attempt to resolve or compromise the dispute. If settlement of the dispute is still not forthcoming, such dispute shall be referred to the finance and personnel committee for final resolution. 
(2)  Recruit applicants for the police and fire departments. 
(3)  Maintain the classification plan so that it reflects the current duties, responsibilities and nature of work of positions of the city service. 
(4)  Administer the compensation plan, in accordance with the provisions of the common council and this division. 
(5)  Develop and administer such recruiting and examination programs as may be necessary to obtain an adequate supply of competent applicants to meet the needs of the city services. 
(6)  Encourage and exercise leadership in the development of effective personnel administration within the several departments of the city government and make available the facilities of the department to this end. 
(7)  Foster and develop, in cooperation with department heads and others, programs for the improvement of employee effectiveness, including training, safety, health, counseling and welfare. 
(8)  Provide for the establishment and maintenance of a roster of all employees in the municipal service. 
(9)  Provide a system of checking payrolls to determine that all persons in the municipal service have been appointed and are being paid in accordance with the human resources regulations. 
(10)  Prepare and adopt such forms and procedures as it may consider necessary or desirable to carry out the city's human resources program. 
(11)  Assist the city attorney's office in conducting all negotiations of city labor contracts or conduct such negotiations at the direction of the city attorney. 
(12)  Administer the city health insurance program in accordance with the provisions of the common council. 
(13)  Investigate, from time to time, the operations and effects of the human resources rules and practices and report its findings and recommendations to the finance and personnel committee. 
(14)  Perform any other lawful acts that the human resources director may consider necessary and desirable to carry out the purposes and provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 08-08, pt. 2, 6-3-08; Ord. No. 0002-19, pt. 2, 2-20-19)  
Secs. 2-433—2-435. - Reserved.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-436. - Appointment of director of city development. 
The appointment and removal of the director of city development shall be made by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the common council. 
(Code 1973, § 3.015.010; Ord. No. 5-98, pt. 1, 3-18-98) 
Cross reference— Department of city development, § 2-331 et seq.; cemetery manager, § 30-56 et seq. 
State Law reference— Appointment of certain officers, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(1)(a).  
Sec. 2-437. - Administrative managers, residency requirement. 
(a)  The administrative managers of the city are the city assessor, human resources director, public health administrator, city attorney, finance director, commissioner of public works, director of city development, manager of the water and wastewater utilities, library director, chief of police, chief of the fire department, director of parks, recreation and cultural services and director of information systems. 
(b)  All administrative managers of the city shall within a period of 60 days after completion of their probationary period establish residence within the city limits of the city. Administrative managers who are not residents of the city as of the effective date of this section or as of the date of creation of their position as administrative manager may retain such nonresident status until their present term of employment ends. The common council shall have the right to waive the residency requirement for an administrative manager upon a showing of necessity and in keeping with the best interests of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 3.34.010; Ord. No. 19-91, pt. 1, § 3.34.020, 8-6-91; Ord. No. 12-95, pts. 1, 2, 7-18-95; Ord. No. 26-95, pt. 1, 11-7-95; Ord. No. 16-97, pt. 1, 10-9-97; Ord. No. 19-00, pt. 1, 9-20-00; Ord. No. 1-04, pt. 2, 1-20-04; Ord. No. 9-05, pt. 1, 6-7-05; Ord. No. 24-05, pt. 2, 12-6-05; Ord. No. 08-08, pt. 3, 6-3-08; Ord. No. 4-12, pt. 1, 4-11-12; Ord. No. 0002-19, pt. 3, 2-20-19) 
Cross reference— Chief of the fire department, § 2-376; chief of police, § 2-402; city clerk, § 2-451 et seq.; city assessor, § 2-466 et seq.; finance director, § 2-481 et seq.; personnel director, § 2-521 et seq.; commissioner of public works, § 2-531 et seq.  
Sec. 2-438. - Office of constable abolished. 
Pursuant to the authority granted in Wis. Stats. § 62.09(1)(b), the office of constable is abolished, effective midnight, April 30, 1994. 
(Code 1973, § 3.10.010; Ord. No. 13-93, pt. 1, 6-15-93) 
State Law reference— Abolishing office of constable, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(1)(b).  
Sec. 2-439. - Officers required to file bond. 
The officers required to file in the office of the city clerk a bond before entering upon the discharge of the duties of their respective offices shall file such bond in the amount required in state law or a fidelity bond in blanket policy may be provided. 
(Code 1973, § 3.14.010) 
State Law reference— Bonds, Wis. Stats. §§ 19.01, 66.14; bond for tax collectors, Wis. Stats. § 70.67.  
Sec. 2-440. - Attendance at national conventions; disbursements from travel expense account. 
(a)  The mayor is authorized to designate up to five administrative managers to attend national conventions or professional conferences in any calendar year at city expense. An administrative manager is eligible to attend such a convention or conference under this section no more than one time in two calendar years, except that: 
(1)  If an administrative manager is a member of a national board conducting the convention or conference, he shall be allowed to attend such convention or conference at city expense up to three consecutive years; and 
(2)  If such a convention or conference is held in the Chicago, Illinois area, the mayor may authorize any administrative manager to attend at city expense. 
(b)  Managerial employees below the classification of administrative manager may, upon a showing of special need, attend a national convention or conference at city expense upon approval of his administrative manager. 
(c)  Managerial and nonmanagerial employees may, upon approval of the administrative manager, attend, at city expense, a convention or conference held in this state. 
(d)  The limitations of this section shall not apply to city payment for attendance at professional conferences or conventions held in the state by an employee who is required by state law to attend such conferences or conventions. 
(e)  Disbursements for unbudgeted travel expenses may be made upon specific authorization by the common council. 
(Code 1973, § 6.11.190; Ord. No. 28-03, pt. 1, 12-16-03)  
Sec. 2-441. - Suspension, removal. 
Except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance, whenever any charge of official misconduct or inefficiency shall be preferred against an administrative manager employed by the city on or after the effective date of this section, the common council shall proceed within 30 days, or such other time as agreed between the parties, after the charge so filed with the city clerk, to hear and determine the case upon its merits. The mayor may suspend such officer against whom charges have been preferred until the disposition of the charges and appoint a person to fill the vacancy temporarily until the charges have been disposed of. The common council may, for the purpose of such hearing, compel the attendance of witnesses and the production of all papers by subpoena when necessary for the purpose of such hearing. Two-thirds of all the members of the common council elect shall have the power to dismiss such administrative manager from office for malfeasance, misconduct or inefficiency in office, upon due process hearing as provided in this section. Administrative managers employed prior to the effective date of this section shall be subject to the suspension and removal process prescribed for their position by ordinances in effect at the time of their employment by the city. 
(Ord. of 9-2-03, pt. 3)  
Secs. 2-442—2-450. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CITY CLERK[20]
