The fire limits of the city are hereby established as part of this article to include the following zoning districts: 
(1)  O, restricted office district. 
(2)  O/I, office/institutional district. 
(3)  B-1, neighborhood convenience district. 
(4)  B-2, community shopping district. 
(5)  B-3, general commercial district. 
(6)  B-4, central business district. 
(7)  B-5, central service district. 
(8)  I-1, restricted industrial district. 
(9)  I-2, general industrial district. 
The boundaries of these districts are defined in the zoning regulations and zoning districts map for the city, and shall be known as being embraced within the fire limits of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 30.07C.020) 
State Law reference— Power to establish fire limits, Wis. Stats. § 62.23(9)(b).  
Sec. 18-147. - Classes of construction. 
(a)  Number; scope. For the purpose of this article, construction shall be classified into eight different classes, which shall be limited as to height, ground floor area and location, and in other respects as required by this article, the state building code, and other ordinances of the city. 
(b)  Classes defined. The following classes of construction are created: 
Class 1: Fire-resistive type A. 
Class 2: Fire-resistive type B. 
Class 3: Metal frame—Protected. 
Class 4: Heavy timber. 
Class 5: Exterior masonry. 
Class 6: Metal frame—Unprotected. 
Class 7: Wood frame—Protected. 
Class 8: Wood frame—Unprotected. 
Class 1 shall be deemed the most fire-resistive, class 8 the least fire-resistive type of construction. When two or more types of construction occur in the same building and are not separated by four-hour fire-resistive construction as defined by the state building code, the entire building shall be subject to the restriction of such class. 
(c)  Fire-resistive type A. A building is of fire-resistive type A construction if all the walls, partitions, piers, columns, floors, ceilings, roof and stairs are built of noncombustible material, with a fire-resistive rating as specified by Wis. Admin. Code, Ind. 51.03(1). 
(d)  Fire-resistive type B. A building is of fire-resistive type B construction if all the walls, partitions, piers, columns, floors, ceilings, roof and stairs are built of noncombustible material, with a fire-resistive rating as specified by Wis. Admin. Code, Ind. 51.03(2). 
(e)  Metal frame—Protected. A building is of metal frame protected construction if the structural parts and enclosing walls are metal, or metal in combination with other noncombustible materials, with time rating as set forth by Wis. Admin. Code, Ind. 51.03(3). 
(f)  Heavy timber. A building is of heavy timber construction if the structural frame consists of heavy timber or heavy timber in combination with metal, reinforced concrete or masonry. The structural and enclosing walls shall be as set forth by Wis. Admin. Code, Ind. 51.03(4). 
(g)  Exterior masonry. A building is of exterior masonry construction if all enclosing walls are constructed of masonry or reinforced concrete with fire-resistive rating as set forth by Wis. Admin. Code, Ind. 51.03(5). 
(h)  Metal frame—Unprotected. A building is of metal frame unprotected construction if the enclosing walls are of unprotected metal or unprotected metal in combination with other noncombustible materials and all building elements are as set forth by Wis. Admin. Code, Ind. 51.03(6). 
(i)  Wood frame—Protected. A building is of wood frame protected construction if the structural parts and enclosing walls are of protected wood, or protected wood in combination with other materials, with fire-resistive rating as set forth by Wis. Admin. Code, Ind. 51.03(7). 
(j)  Wood frame—Unprotected. A building is of wood frame unprotected construction if the structural parts and enclosing walls are of unprotected wood, or unprotected wood in combination with other materials, with fire-resistive rating as set forth by Wis. Admin. Code, Ind. 51.03(8). 
(k)  Doubtful classifications. In case there is a doubt as to the classification within which a given building or other structure falls, the chief building inspector shall determine such classification. 
(l)  Partial compliance. This article does not require full compliance with a type of construction, if, under this article, a less restricted form of construction is permitted, but no building or other structure shall be deemed to be of a given type of construction unless it conforms with all specific provisions of this article applying to that type. 
(Code 1973, §§ 30.07B.010—30.07B.120)  
Sec. 18-148. - Limitations on wood frame construction. 
(a)  Except as provided in this section, no building or structure of wood frame construction shall be erected within the fire limits. 
(b)  Within the fire limits, wood shingle roofing is prohibited except for wood shingles that have a fire resistant rating as approved by Underwriters Laboratory or other nationally recognized testing service. 
(Code 1973, § 30.07C.030)  
Sec. 18-149. - Alterations. 
(a)  Within the fire limits, no building or structure of wood frame construction shall be increased in height. 
(b)  Within the fire limits, no building or structure of wood frame construction shall be extended on any side, unless the construction of such extension conforms to the requirements of this article for new construction, and provided that the area of the building as extended shall not exceed the allowable area for wood frame construction. 
(c)  Within the fire limits, no building or structure shall be extended on any side by wood frame construction. 
(d)  This section does not prohibit other alterations within the fire limits, provided there is no change of occupancy to a class otherwise prohibited. 
(Code 1973, § 30.07C.040)  
Sec. 18-150. - Moving buildings. 
No building of wood frame construction shall be moved from without to within the fire limits, except as provided under subsection 18-152(8). 
(Code 1973, § 30.07C.050)  
Sec. 18-151. - Location of buildings interpreted. 
A building or structure shall be deemed to be within the fire limits if more than one-third of the area of such building or structure is located therein. 
(Code 1973, § 30.07C.060)  
Sec. 18-152. - Exceptions. 
This subdivision does not prohibit within the fire limits, and subject to the specified limitation, the erection of new buildings or structures, nor the extension or enlargement of existing buildings or structures, of wood frame construction as follows: 
(1)  A building of wood frame construction or unprotected metal construction occupied exclusively as a private garage or stable, not more than one story in height nor more than 720 square feet in area, located on the same lot with a dwelling. 
(2)  Greenhouses not more than 15 feet in height erected on the same lot with and accessory to a dwelling or a store. 
(3)  Construction trailers not more than one story in height, for use only in connection with a duly authorized building operation and located on the same lot with such building operation, on a lot immediately adjoining, on an upper floor of the building under construction, or on a sidewalk shed. 
(4)  Piazzas or balconies on dwellings not exceeding ten feet in width nor extending more than three feet above the second story floor beams; provided that no such structure shall extend to a lot line or be joined to a similar structure of another building. 
(5)  Fences not exceeding ten feet in height. 
(6)  Display signs as elsewhere provided in this Code. 
(7)  Sheds erected in lumberyards and similar places used solely for the storage of lumber, finished millwork, etc., located not closer than 18 feet to the boundary or lot lines of adjoining property, and not exceeding 15,000 square feet in area nor more than 30 feet in height with roofs covered with incombustible or fire-retardant material. When such shed exceeds the above regulations, the walls shall be built with incombustible material or if of wood frame construction, standard fire-division walls extending through the roof to a height of three feet above the roof, and no compartment of the shed shall exceed the abovementioned area. 
(8)  One- and two-story wood frame residences occupied by not more than two families and accessory buildings on the same lot with residences; except in the I-1 and I-2 industrial districts. 
(9)  In B-2, B-4 and B-5 business districts, dwelling houses of not over two stories of wood frame construction for one and two families, provided that wire lath and cement stucco 1½ inches thick is used on the outside, or brick or stone veneer three inches thick or other approved fire-retardant material is used for outside walls, with roofs covered with incombustible or fire-retardant material. 
(Code 1973, § 30.07C.070)  
Sec. 18-153. - Mercantile buildings, restrictions on types of construction. 
(a)  All buildings and additions to existing buildings which are built for and to be used as mercantile establishments where commodities are bought or sold and used for the display, sale or storage of goods, wares or merchandise for the supplying of food, drink or other bodily needs or comforts shall have brick walls or the equal thereof in fire-resistance, and a fire-resistive roof covering. The first floor over the basement shall be not less than two-hour fire-resistive construction as defined by the state building code. 
(b)  In buildings of more than one story in height, the ceilings on the underside of the joists of the floor above shall be one-hour fire-resistive construction. 
(c)  The partition enclosures of all stairways shall be one-hour fire-resistive construction. 
(d)  The term "mercantile buildings" shall not be deemed to include factory buildings or warehouses and shops used in connection therewith. 
(Code 1973, § 30.07C.080)  
Sec. 18-154. - Street encroachments. 
(a)  Generally. Except as otherwise provided in this article, no part of a building hereafter erected or of an enlargement of a building heretofore erected shall project beyond a street line or a building line. 
(b)  Projections to be removable. A part of a building permitted to project beyond a street line or building line shall be so constructed that its removal may be made without causing the building to become structurally unsafe. 
(c)  Structural support. No part of a building or of an enlargement of a building that is necessary for structural safety shall project beyond the street line or building line, but this shall not prohibit the projection beyond the street line or beyond the building line within the street line, to the extent of not more than 12 inches, of the footings of street walls. 
(d)  Permissible projections. Under the conditions prescribed in this article and within the limitations specified in this section, the following projections shall be permissible: 
(1)  The main cornice, meaning a moulded projection at or near the top of the wall that faces on a street, may project beyond the building line not more than 15 inches, provided that such cornice is not less than 12 feet above curb level at all points. 
(2)  Cornices of show window and awning covers may project beyond the building line not more than 15 inches. 
(3)  Mouldings, belt courses, lintels, sills, architraves, pediments and similar projections of a decorative character may extend beyond the building line not more than four inches when they are less than ten feet above curb level and not more than ten inches when they are ten feet or more above curb level. 
(4)  No door shall be hung so as to project, when fully open, more than 12 inches beyond the building line. 
(5)  Fire escapes and balconies to fire towers or other required exits constructed of steel or other incombustible material, only when required, may project beyond the building line not more than five feet; but no part of such fire escapes or balconies shall be less than ten feet above the sidewalk; provided, that nothing in this section shall prevent the use, in connection with permissible fire escapes, of movable stairs to the sidewalk, so arranged that they are more than ten feet above the sidewalk when not in actual use. 
(6)  Marquees at entrances to buildings may extend beyond the building line not to exceed five feet; provided, that they are not less than ten feet above the curb level at all points and, within the fire limits, are constructed of incombustible materials. They shall be securely supported from the building and shall be properly drained. No marquees shall extend along the street wall of the building for more than 50 percent of the length of such wall, nor in any case more than 25 feet, and there shall be a clear distance of not less than four feet between any two marquees on the same building. Marquees extending beyond the limitations in this subsection and areas projecting beyond the building line and vaults entirely below the sidewalk level may be installed only by variance issued by the common council as provided in subsection (h) of this section. 
(e)  Limitations. This section does not authorize a projection beyond the street line or building line that is prohibited by the zoning regulations or by any other law or ordinance. 
(f)  Alterations. No change or enlargement shall be made to an existing part of a building not projecting beyond the street line or building line except in conformity with the provisions of this article for new construction. 
(g)  Existing encroachments. Parts of buildings which already project beyond the street line or building line may be maintained as constructed until their removal is directed by the city. 
(h)  A request for a variance to the provisions of this section may be filed with the common council, which shall be referred within 14 days to the public works and services committee. The committee, within 30 days from receipt of such request, shall recommend the granting or denial of the variance. 
(Code 1973, § 30.07C.090)  
Secs. 18-155—18-165. - Reserved.  
Subdivision III. - Design Requirements 
 
Sec. 18-166. - Applicability. 
All one- and two-family dwellings shall conform to the requirements of this subdivision. A building which contains a use or occupancy other than one- and two-family units shall follow the applicable requirements of the Wisconsin Administrative Building Code. 
(Code 1973, § 30.15.010)  
Sec. 18-167. - Maintenance. 
Every building and all parts thereof shall be kept in good repair and the roof shall be maintained to prevent leakage. All rainwater shall be so drained and conveyed therefrom to prevent dampness in the walls and ceilings. 
(Code 1973, § 30.15.020)  
Sec. 18-168. - Cleanliness. 
Every building shall be kept reasonably clean, and shall also be kept reasonably free from any accumulations of dirt, filth, rubbish, garbage, or other matter in or on such building, or in the yards, courts, passages, areas or alleys connected with or belonging to such building. 
(Code 1973, § 30.15.030)  
Sec. 18-169. - Street frontage. 
Every building shall front on at least one street, unless otherwise permitted by local regulations. Existing buildings not fronting on a street shall be provided with an unobstructed fire access lane not less than 15 feet in width from a public thoroughfare to the building. 
(Code 1973, § 30.15.040)  
Sec. 18-170. - Room areas. 
Room sizes for one- and two-family dwellings shall be equal to or greater than the following: 
(1)  Minimum dimension of living rooms shall be 11 feet, and minimum dimension of kitchens shall be six feet. Minimum room areas shall not include areas used for storage or closet purposes. 
(2)  Rooms and spaces not regulated in this subdivision as to area shall be connected to a living or other habitable room. Rooms and spaces not regulated in this subdivision and of areas less than the minimum areas required in this subdivision shall not be used for living, dining, sleeping or kitchen purposes. 
(3)  No habitable rooms shall be permitted in basements unless the ceiling line of the room is at least four feet above grade line. 
(4)  No additional dwelling units shall be created or maintained by rearranging room suites, by subdividing rooms, or by alterations in any existing building or structure unless such dwelling units have been authorized by permit and comply with this and other applicable regulations. 
(5)  Room areas, are in Table No. 2, section 18-441. 
(Code 1973, § 30.15.050)  
Sec. 18-171. - Ceiling heights. 
(a)  Except as otherwise permitted by local requirements, the minimum clear ceiling height of all habitable rooms in one- and two-family homes shall have a minimum ceiling height of seven feet. Basement ceiling height shall be a minimum of six feet ten inches under joists. 
(b)  Sloping roofs may penetrate rooms provided that any portion of any room under a sloping roof having a height of less than five feet shall not be considered as part of the floor area in computing required areas or volume of such rooms. Rooms under a sloping roof shall have a minimum ceiling height of seven feet for not less than one-half of the required area of the room. 
(c)  Rooms in any building or structure having ceiling heights or areas which do not conform to the regulations of this section shall not be used for human habitation. For ceiling heights of bath and toilet rooms, see section 18-174(d). 
(Code 1973, § 30.15.060)  
Sec. 18-172. - Light and ventilation. 
(a)  Every room in which one or more persons live, sleep, work or congregate shall have a window or windows with sash areas, which shall be at least eight percent of the floor area of the room. Such windows shall be constructed so as to permit a window area of at least 3.5 percent of the floor area of the room to be open to the outside, unless ventilation is provided by louvers, other openings, or artificial means. 
(b)  Windows shall be provided in all basements, and shall have a minimum openable total area of not less than one percent of the basement floor area, excluding crawl space area. 
(Code 1973, § 30.15.070)  
Sec. 18-173. - Stairways, landings, platforms and roof decks. 
(a)  Every exit stairway shall be not less than three feet in width, and not more than four inches on one side may be used for handrails. Every platform shall be at least as wide as the stairway, measured at right angles to the direction of travel. Whenever a door opens onto a stairway, a platform shall be provided extending at least the full width of the door in the direction of travel. 
(b)  If stairways are provided in addition to those required by this article, such additional stairways need not conform to the width requirements of this article. 
(c)  All stairway landings, platforms, roof decks, or similar elevations or depressions more than two feet above or below adjacent grade or floor level shall have a guardrail on the open sides thereof, at least 36 inches in height, with intermediate rails, balusters, or other construction such that a sphere with a diameter of six inches cannot pass through any opening. 
(d)  Handrails. All stairways and steps of more than three risers shall have at least one handrail. The handrail along stairways shall measure between 30 and 36 inches in height, measured above the stair nosing. Handrails must be installed on all open sides, if any, and this shall meet the minimum requirements. 
(e)  Risers and treads. All stairways and steps shall have a uniform rise of not more than eight inches, and a minimum tread width of nine inches. Risers shall be measured from tread to tread, and treads shall be measured from rise to rise. There shall be no more than 18 risers in any one run. 
(f)  The continuous clear head room measured perpendicularly from the nosing shall be not less than six feet eight inches, except that for basement stairways such head room may be six feet four inches. 
(g)  Winders may be used provided that such winders are designed so the tread width 18 inches from the converging end will not be less than nine inches. 
(Code 1973, § 30.15.080; Ord. No. 6-92, pt. 15, 3-3-92; Ord. No. 4-95, pts. 1, 2, 3-21-95)  
Sec. 18-174. - Kitchens, bathrooms and toilets. 
(a)  In every dwelling there shall be provided in each dwelling unit and connected to a plumbing system at least one kitchen sink; one water closet; one bathtub or shower; and one lavatory. 
(b)  Wherever a public water supply is not available, there shall be provided on the premises, for each dwelling unit, means for a sanitary disposal of sewage without health hazards or nuisance, and in conformity with generally accepted standards. 
(c)  Plumbing fixtures as required by this section shall be smooth, nonabsorbent, resistive to detrimental action of conveyed wastes and free from concealed fouling surfaces. 
(d)  Bathrooms for required toilets, tubs or showers, or lavatories, shall have a minimum floor area of not less than 12 square feet for each water closet and each tub, and ten square feet for each shower, lavatory, or other sanitary plumbing fixture or equipment installed therein. The ceiling height of the required bathroom shall be not less than seven feet. Powder rooms or second baths are not subject to this requirement, but shall have a minimum floor area of 14 square feet with a minimum dimension of three feet in one direction. 
(e)  Each bathroom or toilet room shall be provided with a door. No bathroom or toilet room shall open directly into a kitchen, nor shall such room provide sole access to any other room. 
(f)  Bathrooms and toilet rooms shall be provided with means of ventilation as required by this article for habitable rooms, or positive mechanical ventilation, providing one air change every five minutes. 
(g)  With the exception of exhaust fans with filters, all mechanical ventilation shall be directed directly to the outside. Exhaust fans with filters may be used without terminating to the outside if of a type approved by the state department of industry, labor and human relations. 
(Code 1973, § 30.15.090)  
Sec. 18-175. - Exits and openings. 
(a)  Exterior stairways other than to the first floor and basement shall not be allowed. Every residential home shall have two exits on the first floor. Duplexes shall have two separate stairways or one stairway and an outside porch. 
(b)  Access to each dwelling unit shall be provided without passing through any part of any other dwelling unit. In dwelling units, every habitable room shall have access to every other habitable room without passing through a bathroom or toilet room. 
(c)  Doors or openings. 
(1)  Exterior doors. The minimum size for at least one main entrance door to a residence shall be three feet wide by six feet four inches high. The rear or side door shall be two feet eight inches wide by six feet four inches high. 
(2)  Interior doors. The minimum size of doors serving as exits from any habitable rooms shall be two feet six inches wide by six feet four inches high. Bathrooms and closets other than linen and broom closets can be served by a door a minimum of two feet wide. 
(3)  An opening used without a door shall be the same size as the required door size. 
(d)  Corridors and hallways between rooms shall be not less than 36 inches wide. 
(Code 1973, § 30.15.100)  
Sec. 18-176. - Attics, access to. 
In every building and structure having an attic, there shall be provided permanent access thereto by means of a scuttle, disappearing or permanently installed stairway; the minimum size opening thereof shall be 24 inches by 20 inches. 
(Code 1973, § 30.15.110)  
Sec. 18-177. - Vents in attics. 
Unheated space above heated spaces must be ventilated. Such vents shall be located to provide proper circulation of air. The area of the clear opening of the vents shall total at least 1/500 of the projected ceiling area of the heated spaces below. 
(Code 1973, § 30.15.120)  
Sec. 18-178. - Insulation. 
(a)  Outside walls and sill boxes shall have a minimum of 3½ inches in thickness of insulation with a minimum rating of R-11. Ceilings shall have a minimum of six inches in thickness of insulation with a minimum rating of R-19. 
(b)  All windows must be double glazed, insulating glass, or have storm windows, and the frames thereof shall be caulked. All outside doors shall have storm doors, and the frames thereof shall be caulked. All openable windows and outside doors shall be weatherstripped. 
(c)  Crawl spaces vented to the outside shall have a minimum of six inches of insulation with a minimum rating of R-19 on floors above. 
(d)  Weather protection. When interior plastering work is in progress, adequate ventilation shall be provided, and in freezing weather the enclosure shall be heated. Plaster shall not be applied to surfaces that contain frost. 
(Code 1973, § 30.15.130)  
Sec. 18-179. - Door bells/chimes. 
(a)  All buildings having four or more dwelling units shall have an operable door bell or door chime for each unit not directly accessible to anyone wishing to make contact with the occupant of said dwelling units. "Directly accessible" shall mean the ability to physically knock on one of each dwelling unit's doors. The door bell/chime shall be maintained and accessible to the public. 
The owner shall be responsible for the installation and maintenance of any required door bell or chime. 
An intercom system may be used in lieu of a door bell or chime. 
(b)  Whenever the department is notified of or discovers any violation of this chapter, he or his agent shall notify the owner or agent allowing or permitting such violation, by means of a written notice. In such notice, the department shall order the owner or agent to correct the violation within 14 calendar days to provide an operable door bell or chime. 
(Ord. No. 4-98, pt. 1, 3-4-98)  
Secs. 18-180—18-190. - Reserved.  
Subdivision IV. - Soil Requirements 
 
Sec. 18-191. - Loads. 
The permissible loads in tons per square foot on natural earth shall not exceed the bearing capacity shown in the following table: 
TABLE A 
Type of soil or rock 	Bearing capacity 
(tons per sq. ft.) 
Quicksand, alluvial and filled soils, determined by test but not more than 	½ 
Soft clay, sandy loam, or silt 	1 
Ordinary clay 	2 
Clay or fine sand, firm and dry 	3 
Sand, compact and well cemented; dry hard clay 	4 
Gravel and coarse sand, well packed 	5 
Hard pan or shale 	6 
Rock 	Not more than 20 percent of the ultimate crushing strength of such rock. 
 
(Code 1973, § 30.16.010)  
Sec. 18-192. - Borings and tests. 
(a)  When required. In the absence of satisfactory data from immediately adjacent areas, the owner or applicant shall make borings, test pits, or other soil investigations at such locations and to sufficient depths of the bearing materials to the satisfaction of the chief building inspector. 
(b)  Soil samples. Samples of the strata penetrated in test borings or test pits, representing the natural disposition and conditions at the site, shall be available for examination of the chief building inspector. 
(c)  Varying soil values. When test borings indicate nonuniformity of bearing materials, a suffi- 
cient number of additional borings shall be made to establish strata levels of equal bearing capacity. 
(d)  Cost of tests. When the safe sustaining power of the soil is in doubt, the chief building inspector shall direct that the necessary borings or tests be made by and at the expense of the applicant and under the supervision of the chief building inspector to determine the safe value. 
(Code 1973, § 30.16.020)  
Sec. 18-193. - Soil test procedure. 
(a)  Soil test method. The test procedure and testing apparatus shall be approved by the chief building inspector before being used, and a complete record of the tests together with a record of the soil profile shall be filed by the licensed engineer or architect. 
(b)  Loaded area. If results of soil tests by boring are in doubt as to safe sustaining power, the chief building inspector may require tests by loaded area method. The loaded area shall be approximately four square feet for all bearing materials, except that when the footing overlies wet clay or other soft materials, the test load shall be applied to an area of not less than ten square feet. 
(c)  Recorded settlements. Loads shall be applied in continuous increments of not more than one-quarter of the proposed safe load. When the proposed load has been reached, it shall remain undisturbed and readings shall be recorded to determine the rate of settlement until the settlement in eight consecutive hours is less than 0.01 inch. A 50 percent excess load shall then be applied and allowed to remain in place until the rate of settlement is less than 0.01 inch in 24 hours. 
(d)  Accuracy of loading. Test loads applied by mechanical devices shall be automatically controlled so as to ensure not more than five percent variation in applied load. Such devices shall be calibrated prior to the test. 
(e)  Test acceptance. The load settlement shall be represented diagramatically, and no test shall be deemed satisfactory if the net settlement after removal of the test load exceeds 0.01 inch per ton of gross load applied. 
(Code 1973, § 30.16.030)  
Secs. 18-194—18-205. - Reserved.  
Subdivision V. - Excavation Requirements 
 
Sec. 18-206. - Barricades. 
All excavations for buildings and structures and parts thereof shall be protected and guarded against danger to life or injury to persons or property. 
(Code 1973, § 30.17.010(a))  
Sec. 18-207. - Distance from foundations. 
No trench for sewers or other excavations shall be made below any foundation wall nearer than three feet to any corner of such foundation. No trench for sewers or other excavations shall be made nearer to any column or pier footing than 1½ times the depth of the excavation below the footing. 
(Code 1973, § 30.17.010(b))  
Sec. 18-208. - Notice to adjoining lot owners. 
When the owner of any lot or plot of land or the city in making improvements is about to excavate or cause an excavation to be made, which excavation in any way affects any building or structure on any adjoining lot, a notice shall be given to all owners of adjoining lots at least ten days prior to commencing the excavation. Such notice shall describe the extent and character of the excavation work about to be done, and the adjoining owners shall thereafter be given a reasonable opportunity to protect their property in compliance with the regulations of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 30.17.010(c))  
Sec. 18-209. - Open excavations; order to backfill. 
Whenever an excavation for a building is left open and unprotected, or whenever a foundation has been constructed or partially constructed and not backfilled and has remained open for a period of 30 days or more with no further work progress, the chief building inspector, or his authorized agent, may serve upon the owner and upon the holder of any lien or encumbrance of record an order directing that the excavation and/or foundation be backfilled and graded to conform with the approved survey, and provide the necessary safeguards, as deemed necessary by the chief building inspector or his authorized agents, around the open foundation so as not to be dangerous to life, health or adjoining properties. This order shall be served in accordance with the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 66.05. Further, if work has ceased at other stages of progress of construction for a period exceeding 30 days and the building is left unsecured or the grade around the building is not in conformity with surrounding properties, an order may be served, as described in this section, directing the owner or holder of any encumbrances to secure the building and grade the lot to conform with the approved survey. If the owner fails or refuses to comply with such order within the time prescribed, the chief building inspector or his authorized agent shall cause the necessary work to be performed to correct the condition described in such order, through any available public agency or by contract or arrangement with private persons. The cost of such work shall be charged against the real estate upon which such building is located and shall be a lien upon such real estate and shall be assessed and collected as a special tax. 
(Code 1973, § 30.17.010(d))  
Secs. 18-210—18-220. - Reserved.  
Subdivision VI. - Brick, Masonry, Concrete and Similar Construction 
 
Sec. 18-221. - Footings. 
(a)  Generally. Concrete footings for load bearing walls shall be of adequate dimensions to distribute the load. Minimum thickness of such footings shall be eight inches. Footing width shall extend six inches on each side of the wall above. All footings shall be cast in forms upon undisturbed earth, unless the design of the footings and foundation is approved by the chief building inspector. Footings for any building or structure shall be constructed of concrete or reinforced concrete, and shall in all cases extend below the adjoining grade a minimum of four feet. Masonry units used in foundation walls shall be laid in Portland cement mortar. 
(b)  Pier and column footings. Concrete footings for piers and columns shall be a minimum of two feet square and a minimum thickness of 12 inches, and shall be designed to carry the superimposed load. Columns shall be centered on column footings. 
(c)  Chimney footings. Concrete chimney footings shall have a minimum projection six inches beyond the chimney foundation and a minimum thickness of 12 inches, and shall be designed to carry the superimposed load. 
(d)  Stepped footings. Where variations in the elevations of the bottom of wall footings are necessary, the vertical connection between the footings at the step shall be constructed of concrete eight inches thick and of the same width as the footing, if there is less than a two-foot difference in elevation; if over a two-foot difference in elevation, span with an approved lintel. 
(Code 1973, §§ 30.18.010, 30.18.030)  
Sec. 18-222. - Drain tiles. 
All foundation walls of basements, cellars or other occupied spaces shall have drain tiles on each side of such walls. (See section 18-224 for basementless spaces.) Bleeder tiles shall be placed in the foundation footing at not more than eight-foot centers. Tiles shall be connected to a sump pit provided with a pump to discharge the water at grade or be connected to the storm sewer house drain. Drain tiles shall be covered with 12 inches of no. 2 washed stone or other approved porous material. Tile and stone shall be in place prior to starting the fourth foundation block course. 
(Code 1973, § 30.18.020)  
Sec. 18-223. - Foundation walls. 
(a)  Generally. 
(1)  Foundation walls shall be continuous under habitable areas of principal buildings. Overhanging bays and projecting floors are permitted provided that such cantilevered floors are adequately supported to sustain such loads as they may carry. 
(2)  The top of foundation walls of any building or structure of wood frame construction shall be at least four inches above lot grade at all exterior walls, and no exterior wood construction shall be exposed less than three inches above grade. Where the eleva- 
tion of the lot grade adjoining the exterior walls of such building or structure varies and the four-inch requirement above such grade cannot be maintained, the joist skirt shall be protected with waterproof building paper or flashing. 
(3)  In no case shall joists be lower than the grade. All footings shall set at least 24 hours before the foundation wall or wall forms shall be built. 
(b)  Thickness. 
(1)  Foundation walls for one- and two-story frame buildings which are constructed of brick and solid or hollow concrete masonry units shall be of the following thicknesses: 
TABLE B 
Foundation 
  wall 
construction 	Maximum height 
unbalanced fill in feet* 	Frame 	Minimum thickness (inches) 
masonry 
or masonry 
veneer 
Masonry 	3 	10 	10 
	5 	10 	12 
	7½ 	10 	12 
Plain concrete 	3 	 8 	 8 
	5 	 8 	10 
	7½ 	 8 	10 
 
*When foundation wall is balanced with fill on both sides, foundation wall thickness may be reduced by two inches but shall not be less than eight inches in thickness. All masonry foundation walls shall be capped with solid masonry units. 
(2)  Foundation walls of poured monolithic concrete shall be eight inches thick whether reinforced or not. If the superstructure is to be of solid brick or masonry construction, the foundation wall shall be ten inches thick. 
(c)  Pilasters. 
(1)  When a girder whose span exceeds 12 feet frames into a masonry wall, pilasters of a minimum size of four inches by 12 inches built integrally with the wall shall be provided. 
(2)  Pilasters shall be required where the unsupported length of any foundation wall exceeds 30 T, where "T" is the thickness of the foundation wall. Such pilasters shall be not less than 16 inches wide and at least 1 1/3 times the thickness of the wall of which it is a part. Exception: Pilasters shall not be required in poured monolithic plain or reinforced concrete foundation walls of buildings. 
(d)  Girder bearing. Four inches of end bearing shall be provided for girders framing into foundation walls, and when wood girders are used an air space shall be provided between the foundation walls and the ends and sides of the girder. 
(e)  Dampproofing. Masonry foundation walls of basements and crawl spaces shall be made dampproof by the application to the exterior surfaces thereof of a continuous coat of three-eighths-inch-thick waterproof cement mortar or Portland cement mortar plus a coat of bituminous dampproofing material over the parging from top of stone to final grade. One coat of bituminous dampproofing material shall be applied to concrete foundation walls from top of stone to finish grade. 
(f)  Storage and materials. Cement and aggregates shall be stored in such a manner as to prevent deterioration or the intrusion of foreign matter. Any material which has deteriorated or which has been damaged shall be removed completely from the premises. 
(Code 1973, §§ 30.19.010—30.19.060)  
Sec. 18-224. - Basements, cellars, basementless spaces. 
(a)  Basement floor. All basements and cellars shall be provided with a minimum of three-inch concrete floor placed on a minimum of three inches of three-quarter-inch crushed road gravel. An inspection shall be called for and made prior to laying concrete to construct the basement floor. 
(b)  Basementless spaces. Basementless spaces may be used or constructed according to the following specifications: 
(1)  The ground level shall be at least two feet below any part of the wood construction. 
(2)  In such spaces, all debris, sod, tree stumps, and other organic materials shall be removed and a smooth surface free of pockets shall be provided. A minimum two-inch-thick concrete slab shall be installed. 
(3)  Where the floor level within the foundation walls is below the outside grade, drain tile shall be provided around the exterior of the walls and connected to the house tile. Special consideration shall be given by the chief building inspector if water conditions exist that would require interior drain tile. 
(4)  Foundation wall vents shall be provided, located near the corner of such space. Such vents shall have an aggregate free ventilating area equal to two square feet per 100 lineal feet of wall enclosing such space, or a minimum aggregate area of two square feet. All basementless spaces shall be provided with a minimum access opening of four square feet. If an access opening is in the basement wall and is kept clear and open except for screening which allows for air movement, this opening may be substituted for the above required ventilation area. 
(c)  Slab construction. The entire area shall consist of a base of three inches in thickness of gravel or other approved material well tamped in place, over which there shall be placed a vapor barrier covered with a layer consisting of four inches in thickness of concrete. 
(Code 1973, §§ 30.21.010—30.21.030)  
Sec. 18-225. - Building brick construction. 
(a)  As used in this section, "building brick" means a structural unit of burned clay or shale, sand lime or concrete. 
(b)  All building brick shall be free from cracks, laminations or other defects which may interfere with proper laying of the brick or impair the strength or permanence of the structure. 
(c)  Concrete building brick shall be manufactured from a mixture of Portland cement and approved aggregate, such as sand, gravel, crushed stone, bituminous or anthracite cinders, burned clay or shale, or blast furnace slag. 
(d)  All building brick shall be of a distinctive design or appearance, or marked so that the identity of the manufacturer may be known at any time. 
(e)  The strength and absorption of all building brick manufactured from burned clay or shale shall conform to the minimum requirements of Wis. Admin. Code Ind. § 53.05(5)(a). 
(Code 1973, § 30.20.010)  
Sec. 18-226. - Hollow building units. 
(a)  Hollow tile is the product of surface clay, shale, fireclay, or admixtures thereof, moulded to permanent hollow form for use as masonry units in building construction. 
(b)  Hollow concrete masonry units are the products of Portland cement and suitable aggregates such as sand, gravel, crushed stone, bituminous or anthracite cinders, burned clay or shale or blast furnace slag, moulded to permanent hollow form for use as masonry units in building construction. 
(c)  All hollow concrete masonry units and all hollow tile shall conform to the provisions of Wis. Admin. Code Ind. § 53.06. 
(Code 1973, § 30.20.020)  
Sec. 18-227. - Concrete construction. 
(a)  Generally. All building materials shall be of good quality conforming to generally accepted standards, including the following: 
(1)  Portland cement shall conform to the Standard Specifications for Portland Cement (A.S.T.M. designation C150-62). Air-entraining Portland cement shall conform to Standard Specifications for Air-Entraining Portland Cement (A.S.T.M. designation C175-61). 
(2)  Concrete aggregates, except lightweight aggregates, shall conform to the Tentative Specifications for Concrete Aggregates (A.S.T.M. designation C33-61T), including the methods of sampling and testing. 
(3)  Lightweight aggregate for concrete shall conform to the Tentative Specifications for Light Weight Aggregates for Concrete (A.S.T.M. designation C330-60T), including the methods of sampling and testing. 
(4)  The maximum size of concrete aggregates shall not be larger than one-fifth of the narrowest dimension between sides of the forms of the member for which the concrete is to be used, nor larger than three-fourths of the minimum clear spacing between reinforcing bars. 
(5)  Water used in mixing concrete shall be clean and free from injurious amounts of oil, acid, organic matter or other harmful substances. 
(6)  Metal reinforcements shall conform to the requirements of Tentative Specifications for Billet-Steel Bars for Concrete Reinforcement (A.S.T.M. designation A15-62T), or the requirements of Tentative Specifications for Rail-Steel Bars for Concrete Reinforcement (A.S.T.M. designation A16-62T). 
(b)  Standards. All A.S.T.M. designations or other standards mentioned in this section shall refer to that standard or to its current succeeding standards or designation. 
(c)  Air-entrained cement. Air-entrained cement shall be used when concrete is to be exposed to the elements. 
(d)  Mass concrete proportions. Concrete for all construction shall contain as a minimum five bags of cement per cubic yard of concrete mix or design to produce a minimum compressive strength of 3,000 pounds per square inch at 28 days. Concrete exposed to weathering elements shall be air-entrained. Concrete shall conform to the latest edition of Guide Specification for Ready-Mixed Concrete Section of Concrete Specifications, as developed by the Construction Specifications Institute, Inc., Milwaukee, Wisconsin. 
(Code 1973, §§ 30.22.010—30.22.030, 30.25.010)  
Sec. 18-228. - Masonry construction—Generally. 
(a)  All masonry walls above grade shall be of the type as specified in Wis. Admin. Code, Ind. §§ 53.03 through 53.07, inclusive. 
(b)  All masonry shall be laid up in mortar made of masonry cement of Portland cement with hydrated lime, combined with clean, well graded mason sand and potable water, proportioned by volume and thoroughly mixed to a workable consistency. 
(1)  All masonry foundations in contact with the earth on one or two sides, cavity walls and load bearing walls above grade shall be laid with type M mortar. 
To prepare type M mortar, use one part masonry cement and one part Portland cement (type I or III) with 4½ to six parts mason sand; or 2½ parts Portland cement (type I or III) and one-half part hydrated lime with seven to nine parts mason sand. 
(2)  All masonry veneer and non-load bearing walls above grade shall be laid with type N mortar. 
To prepare type N mortar, use one part masonry cement with 2¼ to three parts mason sand; or one part Portland cement (type I or III) and one part hydrated lime with 4½ to six parts of mason sand. 
(c)  All masonry shall be protected against freezing for not less than 48 hours after installation and shall not be constructed below 28 degrees Fahrenheit on rising temperatures or below 36 degrees Fahrenheit on falling temperatures without temporary heated enclosures or without heating materials or other approved precautions necessary to prevent freezing. No frozen materials shall be used nor shall frozen materials be built upon. In warm weather, all clay or shale units of high absorption characteristics shall be thoroughly wetted before laying in the wall. All other masonry units, except gypsum units, laid in other than lime mortar, shall be wetted before laying in the wall if the absorption resulting from partial immersion in one-eighth inch of water for one minute is less than one percent. All masonry construction shall be adequately braced and supported to ensure its stability during construction. 
(Code 1973, §§ 30.23.010, 30.24.010, 30.28.010)  
Sec. 18-229. - Same—Masonry veneers. 
(a)  Materials used for masonry veneering shall have minimum dimensions as shown in the following table: 
TABLE C 
Materials 	Minimum 
dimension 
in inches 
Stone ..... 	3 
Cellular architectural terra cotta ..... 	3 
Architectural terra cotta slabs ..... 	1¼ 
Brick (clay, concrete or sand-lime) ..... 	2¼ 
Cast stone ..... 	1½ 
Structural clay tile ..... 	1¾ 
Other approved masonry or thin veneers: As approved by the chief building inspector. 
 
(b)  In no case shall any type of veneering be considered a part of the required thickness of any masonry wall or be considered a part of the wall in computing the strength of bearing walls. Masonry veneer shall carry no weight except its own. Such veneering on masonry shall be bonded into the masonry backing by a full header for every 300 square inches of wall surfaces, or by approved substantial noncorrodible metal ties spaced no farther apart than 15 inches vertically and 32 inches horizontally. When sheathing, other than wood, is used, the ties shall be secured through to the studs. When veneering is used, special care shall be taken to fill all joints flush with mortar around all openings. 
(c)  No veneering in masonry walls shall exceed a height of 35 feet above foundation walls or other approved support. 
(Code 1973, § 30.23.020)  
Sec. 18-230. - Same—Lintels and arches. 
All openings in masonry walls shall be spanned by plain or reinforced arches, steel lintels or other approved noncombustible supports with not less than four-inch bearing on the wall at each end. Plain stone lintels shall not be used on spans greater than four feet nor to support load concentrations on the wall less than two feet above the top of the lintel unless supplemented by structural lintels or arches. All lintels shall be of sufficient strength to support the superimposed load with a deflection of not more than 1/360 of clear span, and arches shall be designed to support the load with provision to resist the lateral thrust. 
(Code 1973, § 30.26.010)  
Sec. 18-231. - Same—Corbeling; projecting masonry; pilasters and piers. 
(a)  Limiting projections. No masonry wall less than 12 inches thick shall be corbeled except to support firestopping around combustible door framing. The maximum horizontal projection of corbels shall be not more than one-third of the thickness of the wall, nor shall the projection of any single course of masonry exceed one-third of the height of the masonry unit. 
(b)  Hollow walls. Corbeling of hollow masonry or masonry built of hollow units shall be supported on one full course of solid masonry not less than 12 inches deep. 
(c)  Change in block size. In hollow masonry construction, if the size of the masonry unit is decreased as the wall is constructed, the block course supporting the smaller unit must be solid or filled with concrete. 
(d)  Pilasters and piers. All wall pilasters and piers shall be built into the wall with a masonry bond. 
(1)  Isolated piers shall be not less than 12 inches square nor more than 12 times the least dimension in height when of solid masonry construction nor more than four times the least dimension when of hollow masonry unless filled solidly with approved concrete. 
(2)  Isolated masonry piers shall be bonded as required for solid walls of the same thickness and shall be provided with a cap stone or bearing plate of the full dimension of the pier or with other adequate means for distributing the load on the top. 
(3)  Pilasters shall be not less than four inches thicker than the supported wall. 
(e)  Bearing and anchorage of structural members. All structural beams and girders producing concentrated loads shall have a bearing on solid masonry of not less than four inches thickness and shall project not less than four inches into masonry walls with adequate wall bearing plates provided. 
(Code 1973, §§ 30.27.010—30.27.050)  
Secs. 18-232—18-240. - Reserved.  
Subdivision VII. - Frame Construction 
 
Sec. 18-241. - Wood frame construction. 
Wood frame construction shall be of either balloon, post and beam, platform, or other approved system. 
(Code 1973, § 30.29.010) 
Cross reference— Illustration of a typical house section, § 18-448.  
Sec. 18-242. - Grades and sizes. 
All lumber and timber used in local bearing members shall be sound, free from rot and large or loose knots, and damaging diagonal or spiral grain; and shall be of the structural grade corresponding to the stresses used in design. When the grade of lumber is not identified in accordance with national design specifications for stress grade lumber, the maximum allowable working stress for the species of lumber used shall not exceed the lowest stress value given for that species. All lumber sizes specified in this subdivision are nominal sizes; the American Lumber Standards for dress sizes shall be accepted as the corresponding minimum net dimensions on which all structural design shall be based. Except as provided in this subdivision for composite or built-up integrated units, or when approved after test as specified in Wis. Admin. Code Ind. § 50.12, no wood floor beam, roof beam, joist, rafter or framing timber shall be less than two inches in nominal thickness. 
(Code 1973, § 30.29.020)  
Sec. 18-243. - Stress and loading requirements. 
For ordinary conditions of use and live loads, the spans of joists and rafters shall be limited by tables J-1, J-4, R-8 and R-10. See section 18-244. 
(1)  Allowable stresses. For lumber of a species other than that cited on Table No. 3, allow able stresses used in construction shall not exceed the allowable stresses as established by the state department of industry, labor and human relations. 
(2)  Live loads. The following live loads shall be used in the design of structural members for one- and two-family residential construction: 
Pounds
per sq. ft. 
Floor joists .....40   
Rafters, slope less than 6:12 .....30   
Slope of 6:12 or greater .....20   
(3)  Structural members. Structural members shall not be spliced between bearing points. Where structural strength is impaired by cutting, drilling or inherent defects, such members shall be reinforced in a manner acceptable to the chief building inspector. 
(4)  Girders. Girders may be of structural steel, reinforced concrete, solid wood, or built-up wood members. Joints of girders shall be made over pier or column supports only. Girder spans shall be not more than that allowed in Table No. 5, section 18-443. 
(Code 1973, § 30.29.030)  
Sec. 18-244. - Wood structural design data. 
The information contained in "Span Tables for Joists and Rafters," American Softwood Lumber Standard sizes PS 20—70, by National Forest Products Association, Washington, D.C., is an acceptable design authority under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 30.29.040)  
Sec. 18-245. - Stress, grade materials. 
(a)  Working stresses must conform to those established by the state department of industry, labor and human relations. 
(b)  Plywood. All plywood when used structurally, including among other uses siding, roof and walls sheathing, subflooring diaphragm and built-up members, shall conform to the performance standards PSI-66 for softwood plywood construction and industrial. Each panel member shall be identified for grade and the type of grade mark of an approved testing and grading agency. In addition, all plywood, when permanently exposed, shall be of the exterior type. 
(Code 1973, § 30.29.050)  
Sec. 18-246. - Bridging. 
In all ceilings, floors, attic, and flat roof joist framing, there shall be not less than one line of bridging for each eight feet of span and the bridging shall not be less than one-inch by three-inch lumber double-nailed at each end, or equivalent metal lateral bracing of equal rigidity secured at the intersections. A line of bridging shall also be required at supports where adequate lateral stiffness is not otherwise provided. Solid bridging is also acceptable. Where two-inch by six-inch ceiling joists are used, a minimum two-inch by four-inch stay-lathe may be substituted for required bridging. Such stay-lathe shall be spiked securely at each joist and at each end to either stud or rafter. 
(Code 1973, § 30.29.060)  
Sec. 18-247. - Cutting and notching. 
(a)  Bore holes in joists, girders or beams shall be no greater than 2½ inches in diameter, and shall be located in the end one-quarter of span, and shall not be more than one-quarter of the joist depth. The top or bottom edges of joists may be notched in the outer one-quarter of the length, not to exceed one-sixth of the joist depth. 
(b)  Notching the top or bottom edge of joists will not be permitted in the middle half of the length of any joist. In studs of walls or partitions, holes and notches made to receive piping or duct work, or for other fabrication purposes, shall be cut not more than one-half the depth of the stud. No more than two successive studs shall be so cut or bored unless they are doubled or otherwise reinforced as required by the chief building inspector. 
(Code 1973, § 30.29.070)  
Sec. 18-248. - Connections and fastenings. 
All structural members shall be connected and fastened at their junctions with connectors, bolts, lag screws, spikes, nails, straps, or other approved devices or by approved glueing and in accordance with the recommended nailing schedule in Table No. 4, section 18-442. 
(Code 1973, § 30.29.080)  
Sec. 18-249. - Plates and ribbon boards. 
All walls shall be provided with a single bottom plate and double top plate. Top plates shall be lapped no closer than 32 inches and at all intersecting walls and corners. Plates shall be of the same width as the supporting stud and each not less than two inches thick. Plates shall be spliced above studs. Ribbon boards which support floor or roof joists shall not be less than one inch by four inches in size, and shall be notched into the studs and nailed thereto as required by the nailing schedule. 
(Code 1973, § 30.29.090)  
Sec. 18-250. - Roof rafters. 
Roof rafters shall be vertically supported at the ridge when the slope of the roof is less than four inches per foot. When the slope is more than four inches per foot, roof rafters shall be vertically supported at the ridge or shall be adequately trussed or tied together with not less than one-inch by six-inch collar beams spaced not more than 32 inches on centers, and each rafter shall be fastened to the wall plate or special plate provided. Roof rafters shall be framed opposite each other at the ridge. 
(1)  When collar beams are above the lower third of the rafters and ties are not provided at the plate line provision shall be made for tying the lower end of the rafters to ceiling or wall construction. 
(2)  The depth of ridge boards shall not be less than the cut end of the rafter. 
(3)  The depth of valley or hip rafters shall not be less than the cut end of the rafter. The thickness of valley or hip rafters shall not be less than two inches. 
(4)  Where dormers or gables are over six feet in width, the valley rafters shall run through to the ridge of the main roof. Where the ridge of the dormer or gable is below the ridge of the main roof, one valley rafter shall run through to the ridge of the main roof. 
(5)  Factory constructed trusses approved by the state department of industry, labor and human relations may be used as an approved roof framing system. The building plans shall indicate the approval number assigned by the department of industry, labor and human relations. 
a.  The maximum spacing of trusses shall be two feet on centers. 
b.  Roof sheathing shall be as specified in sections 18-259 through 18-261. 
c.  Ceiling finish shall be as specified in subdivision XI. 
(Code 1973, § 30.29.100)  
Sec. 18-251. - Multiple joists and rafters. 
Floor joists under terrazza, tile, bathtubs, or other unusual loading conditions shall be doubled or otherwise reinforced to support the load. Floor joists under partitions running parallel thereto shall be doubled or formed of built-up sections or may be replaced by a solid section of adequate strength to support the loads. Dormer windows and other openings in roofs shall be framed with double rafters and headers. Valley rafters on spans over 12 feet, measured horizontally, shall be doubled. 
(Code 1973, § 30.29.110)  
Sec. 18-252. - Bearing and anchorage. 
Floor joists framing into walls or girders shall be anchored, tied or nailed to secure continuity. The ends of each joist or truss shall have not less than 1½ inches length of bearing on wood or metal nor less than three inches length on hollow of solid masonry units. The ends of beams or girders shall have not less than four inches length of bearing. Beams or joists framing from opposite sides shall lap not less than six inches nor more than 12 inches and be securely bolted or spiked together. When framing end to end, all joists, beams and girders shall be secured together by approved metal ties, straps or scabs. Anchorage of wood joists into masonry walls shall be in accordance with the state building code. 
(Code 1973, § 30.29.120)  
Sec. 18-253. - Joints in girders and beams. 
The joints of solid or built-up beams or girders shall be made over columns or pier supports. 
(Code 1973, § 30.29.130)  
Sec. 18-254. - Hung ceiling. 
Ceiling joists, when parallel to roof joists, shall be two inches by four inches at the same spacing as the joists above and hung by not less than one-inch by four-inch hangers spaced at not more than six feet. Ceiling joists, when at right angles to roof joist, shall be two inches by four inches spaced 16 inches on center and hung by not less than two-inch by two-inch hangers spaced at not more than six feet. 
(Code 1973, § 30.29.140)  
Sec. 18-255. - Joist headers and trimmers. 
All joist headers more than four feet in length and their trimmers shall be doubled. All tail beams or joists which are more than six feet in length shall be hung in approved joist or beam hangers, or shall be fastened by approved metal connectors. All double trimmer joists shall be spiked together. A minimum two-inch by two-inch ledger strip may be used in lieu of hangers or connectors. 
(Code 1973, § 30.29.150)  
Sec. 18-256. - Walls, partitions, posts and studs. 
(a)  The load-bearing value of the frame walls and partitions or isolated posts or struts shall be limited by Wood Structural Design Data, N.I.M.A. All wood posts used in basements or cellars shall have concrete bases which extend not less than three inches above the finished floor and bear directly on the post footing. In cellars or basements, all wall plates or stair stringers shall rest on top of the finished concrete floor. 
(b)  All walls and partitions shall be constructed using studs of continuous length. Such studs shall not be less than two inches by four inches in size, not more than 20 feet in length and not more than 16 inches on center, and a minimum two-inch firestopping shall be provided for every eight feet of height or at all floor levels. Nonbearing partitions only may be constructed with the smaller dimension perpendicular to the wall. Studs cut so as to impair their structural strength shall be reinforced as required by the chief building inspector. 
(Code 1973, § 30.29.160)  
Sec. 18-257. - Bracing. 
Corner posts shall be the equivalent of not less than three pieces of two-inch by four-inch studs braced with not less than one piece of one-inch by four-inch diagonal bracing let into studs. Diagonal bracing may be omitted when plywood meets the requirements of Table D in section 18-260, or when one-inch board sheathing is placed diagonally. 
(Code 1973, § 30.29.170)  
Sec. 18-258. - Framing of opening. 
(a)  All windows and door openings shall have double studs for the full height of the door opening at jambs, with double headers or truss construction over the opening, or by other approved methods or connection devices to support the superimposed loads. The jamb studs shall be minimum two-inch by four-inch studs double with the inner stud extending in one piece from header to bearing securely spiked to the outer stud. 
(b)  Lintels over openings in bearing walls or partitions shall consist of double joists on edge not less than specified in this article or truss construction bearing on jack studs or other approved construction affording adequate strength. 
(1)  Spans less than four feet: Two-inch by four-inch. 
(2)  Spans four feet to five feet six inches: Two-inch by six-inch. 
(3)  Spans five feet six inches to seven feet: Two-inch by eight-inch. 
(4)  Spans seven feet to eight feet six inches: Two-inch by ten-inch. 
(5)  Spans eight feet six inches to ten feet: Two-inch by 12 inches. 
Where headers support greater or lesser uniform or concentrated loads, or are subject to other unusual loading conditions, calculations shall be submitted to prove acceptable performance. 
(Code 1973, § 30.29.180)  
Sec. 18-259. - Wood boards. 
Except as otherwise regulated in this article, the outside of all exterior wall and roof structural framing of all buildings and structures shall be covered with wood board sheathing one inch in thickness and not more than eight inches wide, over studs and rafters spaced not more than 16 inches on centers. Wider sheathing may be used if triple nailed to studs and rafters. All joints of such wood sheathing shall be centered on studs and rafters unless end matched, tongue and groove wood sheathing is used, in which case no two vertical joints of adjoining boards shall occur in the same space between studs or rafters. All boards shall be applied with tight joints except that under wood shingles one-inch by three-inch or one-inch by four-inch board spaced center to center according to shingle exposure may be used. Boards shall be tongue and groove, shiplapped or square edge, with ends cut parallel to and over center of studs, rafters or roof joists with not more than two adjacent boards breaking joints over the same support except at ends and at openings. 
(Code 1973, § 30.30.010)  
Sec. 18-260. - Other sheathing. 
In lieu of wood board sheathing on exterior walls and roofs of buildings and structures as regulated in this subdivision, materials as shown in tables D and E may be used. 
TABLE D. WALLS

(Code 1973, § 30.30.020)  
Sec. 18-261. - Sheathing. 
Building paper shall be used on all sheathing not water resistant, including plywood, wood boards and gypsum. All water-resistant sheathing shall be identified with the manufacturer's label on each board and shall be approved by the chief building inspector. In all other cases sheathing papers, such as minimum 15-pound saturated felt or paper, or other approved water-resistant material, shall be applied over all exterior surfaces of exterior wall sheathing. Sheathing papers of high vapor resistance shall not be used as a covering on exterior walls unless a material of high vapor resistance is used on the inside of such exterior walls. Building papers shall be applied with a lap of four inches. 
(Code 1973, § 30.30.030)  
Secs. 18-262—18-270. - Reserved.  
Subdivision VIII. - Roof 
 
Sec. 18-271. - Wood roof decking. 
The following specifications shall be observed in the construction of wood roof decking: 
(1)  Planks shall be tongue and groove or splined; minimum thickness shall be two inches, maximum width shall be eight inches. 
(2)  Planks shall be continuous over at least two spans. All joints shall be cut parallel to and over center of roof beams with not more than two adjacent planks breaking joints over the same support except at ends and at openings. 
(3)  Maximum span of two-inch plank shall not exceed the following: 
a.  Planks continuous over two supports, eight feet. 
b.  Planks over single span, six feet. 
c.  Other spans or thicknesses may be used when calculated according to standard engineering practices. Deflection shall be limited to 1/240 of span. 
(4)  Tongue and groove planks having end matched end joints may be used to break joints between roof beams provided: 
a.  Each plank bears upon at least two supports. 
b.  End joints between supports shall not occur in adjacent planks. 
(5)  The roof deck shall be blind and face nailed to roof beams in accordance with the nailing schedule in Table No. 4, section 18-442. 
(6)  When the roof deck is also the finished ceiling surface, an approved vapor barrier shall be installed between deck and roof insulation. 
(Code 1973, § 30.31.010)  
Sec. 18-272. - Fiberboard roof deck. 
In fiberboard roof decks: 
(1)  Thickness and joist spacing shall comply with manufacturer's specifications and be designed in accordance with roof loads designated in this article. 
(2)  End joints shall be staggered and shall occur over supports at least three inches in width. Side joints shall be supported at eaves, ridge and openings. Nails shall penetrate supporting members at least 1½ inches and shall be spaced a maximum of five inches apart. 
(Code 1973, § 30.31.020)  
Secs. 18-273—18-285. - Reserved.  
Subdivision IX. - Flooring 
 
Sec. 18-286. - Boards supporting wood strip flooring. 
Boards supporting wood strip flooring shall comply with the following specifications: 
(1)  Minimum thickness, one inch (nominal) for joists spaced a maximum of 16 inches on centers. 
(2)  Maximum width shall be eight inches. 
(3)  Subfloor may be installed diagonal to or at right angles to joists. If installed at right angles to joists, finish floor shall be installed across subfloor. 
(4)  Boards shall have ends cut parallel to and over center of joists with not more than two adjacent boards breaking joints on the same joist except at ends and at openings. End matched T and G boards may break joints between joists provided two end joints do not occur in the same joist space in adjoining boards and each board bears on at least two joists. 
(5)  Where a header joist is not used, install blocking between ends of joists at wall for nailing ends of diagonal subfloor. Blocking shall also be provided where subfloor is cut away for plumbing and heating. 
(6)  Provide at least one-half-inch clearance between subflooring and masonry or concrete walls. 
(Code 1973, § 30.32.010)  
Sec. 18-287. - Boards supporting other than wood strip flooring. 
The following specifications applying to boards supporting flooring other than wood strip flooring shall be complied with: 
(1)  Subfloor used as a base for wood block flooring applied by nailing shall comply with section 18-286. 
(2)  Subfloor used as a base for ceramic tile applied over concrete setting bed shall comply with section 18-286. Floor joists may be beveled and ledger strips used to support subfloor as support for concrete setting bed. 
(3)  Resilient flooring, wood block flooring applied by adhesive and ceramic tile applied by adhesive shall be installed over an underlayment in compliance with section 18-289. Board subfloor when used shall comply with section 18-286. 
(Code 1973, § 30.32.020)  
Sec. 18-288. - Plywood. 
Plywood used as structural subflooring shall be applied continuously over two or more spans with the direction of the face grain perpendicular to supports. The allowable spans shall comply with those given in Table F.

(Code 1973, § 30.32.030)

Sec. 18-289. - Underlayment for resilient flooring. 
Underlayment for resilient flooring shall comply with the following: 
(1)  Underlayment shall be minimum one-half-inch structural-interior type or exterior type plywood, or hardboard. Other materials may be used as underlayment when determined suitable by the chief building inspector. 
(2)  Top ply of plywood shall be at least C-plugged type grade. 
(3)  Hardboard shall be installed with smooth surface up. 
(4)  Nail to subfloor using the type of nail and spacing recommended by the underlayment manufacturer. 
(Code 1973, § 30.32.040)  
Sec. 18-290. - Plank subfloor. 
Plank subflooring shall comply with the following specifications: 
(1)  Planks shall be T and G or splined; minimum thickness, two inches; maximum width, eight inches. Square edge planks may be used where strip flooring with T and G edges is installed at right angles to plank or where a separate underlayment is provided. 
(2)  Where practicable, planks shall be continuous over at least two spans. All joints shall be cut parallel to and over center of floor beams with not more than two adjacent planks breaking joints over the same support except at ends and at openings. 
(3)  Maximum span of two-inch plank deck shall not exceed the following: 
a.  Planks continuous over two spans, seven feet. 
b.  Planks over single span only, five feet. 
c.  Other spans may be used when calculated according to standard engineering practices. Deflection shall be limited to 1/360 of span. 
(4)  Plank deck shall be blind and face nailed to floor beams in accordance with the nailing schedule, Table No. 4, section 18-442. 
(5)  Loads from bearing partitions, interior columns, or other concentrated loads shall be supported independent from plank deck. 
(Code 1973, § 30.32.050)  
Sec. 18-291. - Finished floor. 
The subfloor of finished floors shall be covered with a minimum one-half-inch thick approved finished flooring material. 
(Code 1973, § 30.32.060)  
Sec. 18-292. - Combination subfloor-underlayment. 
Plywood designed for single floor systems shall comply with Table G.

Allowable uniform load based on deflection of 1/360 of span is 125 psf. Plywood edges shall have approved tongue-and-groove joints or shall be supported with blocking, unless one-fourth-inch minimum thickness underlayment is installed, or finish floor is 25/32 -inch wood strip. If wood strips are perpendicular to supports, thicknesses shown for 16-inch and 20-inch spans may be used on 24-inch spans. Except that one-half-inch underlayment grade and C-C plugged panels may be of nominal thickness 1/32 -inch thinner than the nominal thickness shown when marked with the reduced thickness. 
2. 
Panels 1 1/8 inches thick shall meet special construction requirements such as given in American Plywood Association 2-4-1 manufacturing specification. Supports spaced 32 inches on centers shall have a nominal width of two inches. Those supports spaced 48 inches on centers shall have a nominal width of four inches (single member, or two two-inch joists spiked together). Allowable load based on deflection of 1/360 of span is 60 psf. 
3. 
Field-glued plywood-lumber floor systems shall be constructed using adhesives meeting the requirements of AFG-O1, September 1974, as published by the American Plywood Association. Joist spans for field-glued floors using approved adhesives shall be those set forth in Glued Floor System 1975, as published by the American Plywood Association. Apply adhesives in accordance with manufacturer's recommendations and use 6d deformed-shank nails spaced 12 inches on centers at panel ends and intermediate bearings. 
(Code 1973, § 30.32.070)  
Secs. 18-293—18-305. - Reserved.  
Subdivision X. - Exterior Surfaces 
 
Sec. 18-306. - General requirements. 
(a)  All exterior wall coverings shall be of approved moisture and weather resisting materials of sufficient stiffness and properly attached to resist rain and wind. All exterior intersections between wood or metal and masonry veneer shall be caulked with elastic waterproofed material, except where metal flashed. 
(b)  The bottom edge of the exterior siding immediately over any exterior wall opening shall be so located as to permit the headflashing to extend under the siding and to be turned up behind the siding. 
(Code 1973, § 30.33.010)  
Sec. 18-307. - Types of weather wall coverings. 
The following materials shall be accepted as approved weather coverings of the nominal minimum thickness specified: 
Brick masonry veneers, four inches. 
Stone veneers, two inches. 
Clay tile veneers, three-eighths inch. 
Stucco or exterior plaster, three-fourths inch. 
Wood siding—Bevel, one-half inch at the butt. 
Wood siding—Board, one inch. 
Precast stone facing, five-eighths inch. 
Protected combustible siding, require approval. 
Wood shingles and shakes, three-eighths inch at the butt. 
Exterior plywood, three-eighths inch. 
Asbestos shingles, 5/32 inch. 
Asbestos cement boards, one-eighth inch. 
Formed metal siding, 28 gauge. 
(Code 1973, § 30.33.020)  
Sec. 18-308. - Aluminum siding. 
Aluminum siding shall be allowed subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  Such siding shall have a minimum thickness of 0.025 inch; provided however, that where insulation board is used as backing, the minimum thickness shall be 0.020 inch. Furthermore, the minimum thickness shall be 0.002 inch less to allow for rolling tolerance. 
(2)  All siding or material being covered by such aluminum siding shall be in sound condition. 
(3)  Horizontal aluminum siding shall not exceed nine inches in width. 
(4)  All aluminum siding not backed shall be coated on both sides. 
(Code 1973, § 30.33.030)  
Sec. 18-309. - Nailing weather boarding, wall and roof coverings. 
(a)  All weather boarding and wall and roof coverings shall be securely nailed with aluminum, copper, zinc, zinc coated or other approved corrosion-resistive nails into the supporting structure in accordance with the recommended nailing schedule or the approved manufacturer's standards. Shingles and other weather covering attached directly to sheathing less than one inch thick shall be secured with barbed or other mechanically-bonding nails of approved type; or other common nails on furring strips attached to studs. 
(b)  Combination wall sheathing - siding. In direct-to-stud applications, panels 5/16 -inch and 3/8 -inch nominal thickness or more may be used over studs spaced 16 inches on centers with face grain applied parallel to studs. Panels 5/16 -inch thick shall meet special crossband requirements such as those given in American Plywood Association manufacturing specifications for specialty siding. 
(Code 1973, § 30.33.040)  
Sec. 18-310. - Exterior stucco. 
All stucco work shall be reinforced with approved metal lath or wire fabric as specified in this section, except when applied directly to a masonry base. The reinforcing fabric shall be coated with zinc or other approved rust-resistive coating, or shall be manufactured from corrosion-resistive alloys. 
  Type of
