ARTICLE XV. - GASOLINE SERVICE STATIONS[15] 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Charter ordinance reference—Gasoline service stations, § 5-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 22-476. - Application for owners' license; investigation. 
An application for a gasoline service station owner's license shall be filed with the city clerk at least 15 days prior to the granting of any such license. Any false statement in the application shall make the license issued thereon void. 
(Code 1973, § 22.16.030; Ord. No. 7-91, pt. 2, 3-5-91; Ord. No. 15-06, pt. 1, 5-24-06)  
Sec. 22-477. - Limitations on issuance of license. 
No place of business for which a license under section 6-36 et seq., permitting the sale of fermented malt beverages or section 6-96 et seq., permitting the sale of intoxicating liquor, is held or for which an application is pending, shall be granted a gasoline service station license under this article, except that a place of business which operates as a convenience store or place of business which operates primarily as a boat or marine related retail store and maintains on the premises a minimum inventory value of those goods customarily marketed by such businesses of not less than $15,000.00, at cost, excluding fermented malt beverages, intoxicating liquor and gasoline, may be licensed with both licenses, excepting that such premises that are not licensed to sell intoxicating liquor on January 1, 2005, are not eligible to be licensed with an intoxicating liquor license, and excepting that such premises that are not licensed to sell fermented malt beverages on January 1, 2005, are not eligible to be licensed with a fermented malt beverage license. 
The city will not renew an existing "Class A" liquor license or Class "A" beer license for a gasoline service station, a boat and marine retail store or a convenience store whose premises are less than 3,000 square feet if application is not made within 30 days of the expiration of said license. 
(Code 1973, § 22.16.030; Ord. No. 7-91, pt. 2, 3-5-91; Ord. No. 11-99, pt. 2, 8-17-99; Ord. No. 47-04, pt. 4, 12-7-04; Ord. No. 49-04, pt. 2, 12-21-04; Ord. No. 44-06, pt. 1, 11-21-06)  
Secs. 22-478—22-500. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XVI. - GUN RANGES 
 
Sec. 22-501. - License—Required. 
(a)  No person or club shall use or permit to be used any property as a gun range, shooting gallery or place to practice target shooting where firearms are discharged, without a license therefor, except that no license shall be required for any range in a school or law enforcement facility which was in use on or before January 4, 1984, and each such range shall be considered to be in compliance with this article except for the requirements of range supervisors (section 22-505) and range procedures (section 22-506). 
(b)  Range licenses shall be issued in the following classes: 
(1)  Indoor ranges: 
a.  Class A—;hg;Regular indoor range, limited to .38 special and .45 ACP handgun as the most powerful firearms to be used. 
b.  Class B—;hg;Light ammunition indoor range, limited to .22 caliber long rifle rim fire ammunition of standard manufacture as the most powerful firearm to be used. 
c.  Class C—;hg;Air or pellet pneumatic indoor range (rifles or handguns). 
(2)  Outdoor ranges: 
a.  Class MP—Police/military range. 
b.  Class HP—High-powered rifle range. 
c.  Class AO—;hg;Regular range, limited to .38 and .45 caliber as the most powerful ammunition to be used. 
d.  Class BO—;hg;Light ammunition range, limited to .22 caliber long rifle rim fire ammunition as the most powerful to be used. 
e.  Class CO—;hg;Pneumatic range, limited to air or pneumatic handguns or rifles. 
f.  Class SG—;hg;Shotgun range. 
(Code 1973, § 22.28.010)  
Sec. 22-502. - Same—Application; fee; qualifications, investigation of applicant. 
(a)  Application for a gun range license shall be submitted to the common council for approval. Licenses shall expire on June 30 of the fourth year after issuance. Licenses issued after September 1 of any year shall carry a prorated fee for the balance of the unexpired portion of the license term. The license fee shall be set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council and valid for four years, except that no fee shall be required for military, law enforcement or educational institutions. A license issued under this article may be issued only to persons who do not have a felony conviction record, subject to Wis. Stats. §§ 111.321, 111.322 and 111.325, who are residents of this state, who are 18 years of age or older, and who can demonstrate knowledge of firearm safety. Firearm safety knowledge can be demonstrated by a state department of natural resources' safe hunters' instructor's certificate, or similar certificate. 
(b)  No gun range license may be issued to any corporation, association or club unless the agent of such body and the officers and directors thereof meet the qualifications set out in subsection (a) of this section. An agent of a corporation, firm, association or club which is granted a license under this article shall be personally responsible for compliance with all the terms and provisions of this article. 
(c)  The city clerk shall refer each application for a gun range license to the chief of police, the chief of the fire department and the chief building inspector to investigate the applicant's qualifications and the facility to be licensed as a gun range. 
(Code 1973, § 22.28.020; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 43, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 22-503. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction, forfeit an amount as provided in section 1-15 together with the cost of prosecution. Each violation and each day a violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offense. Such monetary penalties shall not preclude the denial or revocation of a license required to do business by the common council. 
(Code 1973, § 22.28.070)  
Sec. 22-504. - Change in personnel of licensee. 
Every corporation, firm, club or association holding a license under this article shall notify the city clerk of any change in the officers, directors or principal shareholders of such corporation or association within ten days of any change and shall furnish such further information as required by the city clerk in order to ascertain its continuing eligibility to hold a license under this article. 
(Code 1973, § 22.28.030)  
Sec. 22-505. - Range supervisor. 
There shall be present upon the gun range at all times during its use for shooting a range supervisor who has been issued a range supervisor license. Such person shall be responsible for the safe operation of the gun range. Application for a range supervisor license shall be made to the city clerk and shall be granted or denied by the public safety and licensing committee of the common council. The fee for such range supervisor license shall be set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council for four years or any portion thereof, except that no fee shall be required for range supervisors of military, law enforcement or educational institutions. Range supervisor licenses shall expire on June 30 of the fourth year. A range supervisor license may be issued only to persons who do not have a felony conviction record, subject to Wis. Stats. §§ 111.321, 111.322 and 111.325, who are residents of this state, and who are 18 years of age or older. A prerequisite for obtaining a range supervisor license shall be certification by the National Rifle Association as an instructor for the type of gun in use at the gun range. This section shall not apply to the training of military or law enforcement personnel by their own instructors. 
(Code 1973, § 22.28.040; Ord. No. 33-06, pt. 1, 9-5-06; Ord. No. 0028-19, pts. 44, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 22-506. - Range procedures. 
(a)  Range firing procedures shall be in accordance with the safety rules of the NRA range rules. The range supervisor, operators and instructors on duty shall be responsible for ascertaining that only proper firearms and ammunition are used. 
(b)  No person shall smoke any cigarette, cigar, pipe or other tobacco substance, or consume any fermented malt beverage or intoxicating liquor upon that part of the premises licensed as a gun range. 
(Code 1973, § 22.28.050)  
Sec. 22-507. - Gun range structure; safety requirements. 
No gun range structure shall be licensed as a gun range unless it meets or exceeds the following standards: 
(1)  Use and construction. The place to be licensed as a gun range shall be used only for the purpose of a gun range and not for any other purpose during any period that weapons are being fired or used. The construction shall meet or exceed the minimum recommendations of the United States Director of Civilian Markmanship and/or the recommended range construction of the National Rifle Association of America, for the class of range the license is to allow. 
(2)  Targets; firing line. There shall be provided a target carrier system or device for running the targets back and forth between the firing line and the bullet stop on indoor ranges. The licensee shall not permit any person to go in front of the firing line during the progress of firing for any purpose. No person shall go in front of the firing line during the progress of firing. 
(3)  Doors. All doors opening into the range, except those behind the firing line, shall be bolted from the inside at all times during which the gun range is in use. 
(4)  Sound quieting treatment. Licensed premises which are located adjacent to property used in whole or in part for residential purposes shall be constructed in such a manner as to prevent the emission of unreasonable noise from shooting from being conveyed outdoors. 
(5)  Range ventilation. An adequate exhaust ventilation system shall be installed on the range for the removal of smoke, lead dust, and gases from the combustion of powder. This standard can be met with the following basic characteristics in the ventilation system: 
a.  An evenly dispersed air flow of 50 to 75 feet per minute from the rear of the firing line past the shooter's upper body. 
b.  An even air flow across the firing line. 
c.  Exhaust from the target area. 
(Code 1973, § 22.28.060)  
Secs. 22-508—22-530. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XVII. - STREET VENDORS[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 12-17, pt. 1, adopted Sept. 20, 2017, changed the title of Art. XVII from "Hawkers and peddlers" to "Street vendors". 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate transient merchants, Wis. Stats. § 66.0423. 
 
Sec. 22-531. - Street vendor's license—Required. 
No person shall travel by foot or by vehicle from place to place within the city for the purpose of carrying to sell, or exposing for sale, any goods, wares or merchandise, or shall sell food, goods, wares or merchandise from a cart, tent, trailer, wagon, stand, motor vehicle or other substitute for a building on an intermittent but permanent basis at the same location weekly, monthly or seasonally, without first obtaining a street vendor license, otherwise known as a hawker or peddler license. Applicants shall provide proof of a valid Wisconsin seller's permit. 
Street vendors doing business on a permanent basis at the same location shall comply with the provisions of section 82-36. 
Any person conducting business under this article in a public street right-of-way shall engage in such business as close as practicable to the curbline, except as otherwise provided in this article. 
Any person conducting business under this article shall be required to have the street vendor license for each cart, tent, trailer, wagon, stand, motor vehicle or other substitute for a building, and a personal photo ID on their person or posted in a prominent place on their cart, tent, trailer, wagon, stand, motor vehicle or other substitute for a building. 
(Code 1973, § 22.02.010; Ord. No. 9-12, pt. 1, 9-18-12; Ord. No. 12-17, pts. 2, 3, 9-20-17) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 9-12, pt. 1, adopted Sept. 18, 2012, changed the title of § 22-531 from "License required" to "Street vendor's license—required".  
Sec. 22-532. - Same—Application. 
(a)  Application for such permit shall be made upon prescribed forms to the city clerk at least 14 days prior to the sale of any goods or services from a hawker or peddler. 
(b)  The application for a street vendor license shall include a description of the method of travel to be used, or the location at which sales are made intermittently but permanently, and the manner in which the applicant intends to carry on his trade within the city. No such license shall be issued unless the applicant presents to the city clerk the certificate of the sealer of weights and measures, and/or the appropriate permits or license(s) from the health, public works, parks, building, or fire department, if any is required for such activity. 
(Code 1973, § 22.02.020; Ord. No. 9-12, pt. 2, 9-18-12; Ord. No. 12-17, pt. 4, 9-20-17)  
Sec. 22-533. - Same—Fees. 
The annual* fees for hawkers and peddlers' licenses shall be as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council for the following: 
(1)  Every street vendor who sells or exhibits products by traveling on foot or bicycle for one to three consecutive days; 
(2)  Every street vendor who sells or exhibits products with a vehicle having a load capacity of: 
a.  Up to two tons; 
b.  More than two tons and up to three tons; 
c.  More than three tons and up to four tons; 
d.  Over four tons. 
(3)  Every street vendor who sells intermittently but permanently at the same location, subject to compliance with sections 82-36 and 18-42, or optional periods of three months or four consecutive days. 
(4)  Every business and registered nonprofit 501(c)(3) organization sponsoring a special event. 
(Code 1973, §§ 22.02.030, 30.07C.100; Ord. No. 44-04, pt. 10, 12-7-04; Ord. No. 9-12, pt. 3, 9-18-12; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 45, 11-12-19) 
* Fees are for licensing during a particular year.  
Sec. 22-534. - Identification badge required. 
No street vendor shall conduct any business as provided for in this article without displaying on his person in a prominent place an identification badge issued by the city to the licensee and employees thereof. Application for such badge shall be made by the licensee for him or herself and for any of his or her employees. The badge shall contain the photograph of the person to be performing business under the license, the person's name and address, the type of license issued, the date of issuance, and the date of expiration. The fee for each such badge shall be set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council. 
(Code 1973, § 22.02.040; Ord. No. 2-93, pt. 4, 2-2-93; Ord. No. 9-12, pt. 4, 9-18-12; Ord. No. 12-17, pts. 5, 6, 9-20-17; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 46, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 22-535. - No street sales during parades. 
No person shall, along the route of a parade authorized under section 82-39, during the period from the beginning of the parade to the end of the parade, hawk, peddle, vend or perform or engage in any other act specified in section 22-531 in that part of the street right-of-way between curblines or the extension thereof along the streets which constitute the parade route. 
(Code 1973, § 22.02.050)  
Sec. 22-536. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Upon conviction, any person found to be in violation of this article shall forfeit an amount as provided in section 1-15. 
(Code 1973, § 22.02.060)  
Sec. 22-537. - Exemptions from article. 
Street vendor licenses are not required for: 
(1)  Persons regularly engaged in the sale or exhibit for sale of goods, wares, food or merchandise to persons engaged in the business of buying, selling and dealing in such goods, wares, food or merchandise. 
(2)  Persons enrolled in a public, private or parochial elementary, middle or high school or members of a registered nonprofit 501(c)(3) youth groups, who are engaged in the sale of goods, wares, food or merchandise for fundraising activities sponsored by and benefitting such school or an organization officially affiliated with such school or the registered nonprofit 501(c)(3) organization. 
(3)  Persons who are members of a registered 501(c)(3) group engaged in selling at a fixed location, which is not on public property, for four or less consecutive days only, e.g., along a parade route or near a special event. 
(Ord. No. 9-12, pt. 5, 9-18-12)  
Sec. 22-538. - Special event license.* 
Special events sponsored by registered nonprofit 501(c)(3) organizations or businesses shall not be required to have an individual license for each vendor. A special event, for this article, is defined as a public event sponsored by a registered organization and held within a fixed perimeter, where one or more vendors assemble for the purpose of selling goods, services, food, or wares and/or providing entertainment or amusement. The event sponsor shall apply at least two weeks before the date of the event and provide a list of the participating vendors to acquire a special event license. 
Individual sellers shall not be required to purchase and wear an individual identification badge. Individual sellers are responsible to the acquire the appropriate permits or license(s) from the health, public works, parks, building, or fire department, if any is required for such activity. Responsibility for the conduct and integrity of the vendors shall rest with the sponsoring organization. The special event sponsor shall have the exclusive right to regulate the participation of vendors within the perimeter of the site and within 200 feet of the site. 
(Ord. No. 9-12, pt. 6, 9-18-12) 
* This will also require the addition of a fee for a special event license per section 22-533.  
Secs. 22-539—22-559. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XVIII. - HOTELS, MOTELS AND TOURISTS ROOMINGHOUSES[17] 
Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 0017-19, pt. 2, adopted July 16, 2019, amended the title of Article XVIII to read as set out herein. Formally, Article XVIII was entitled "Hotels and Tourist Roominghouses." 
Cross reference— Property maintenance standards, § 18-691 et seq.; transient lodging tax, § 90-51 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 22-560. - Definitions. 
Hotel means a place offering sleeping accommodations for pay exclusively to tourists or transient guests, all in a building or area that has a centralized means of ingress and egress and provides internal access to guest rooms, a lobby, front desk, and other amenities. 
Motel means a place offering sleeping accommodations for pay exclusively to tourists or transient guests, all in a building or area that allows direct access to guest rooms and other facilities and amenities via exterior ingress and egress. 
Tourist or transient guest means a person who travels to a location away from their permanent address and occupies a temporary living accommodation for a period of time which is less than 30 consecutive days for vacation, pleasure, recreation, culture, business or employment. 
(Ord. No. 0017-19, pt. 3, 7-16-19)  
Sec. 22-561. - Statutory provisions adopted. 
Chapter 72 ATCP of the Wisconsin Administrative Code and Ch. 97 of the Wisconsin Statutes are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this article as if fully set forth herein. Any future amendments, revisions or modifications of the sections incorporated herein are intended to be made a part of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 11.09.110; Ord. No. 0017-19, pt. 4, 7-16-19)  
Sec. 22-562. - Temporary order to cease operations. 
Whenever, as the result of an inspection, the city has reasonable cause to believe that any construction, sanitary condition, operation or method of operation of the premises or equipment used on the premises creates an immediate danger to health, the administrator may issue a temporary order and cause it to be delivered to the permittee, owner or operator under this article. The order may prohibit the continued operation or method of operation of specific equipment, require the premises to cease any other operation or method of operation which creates immediate danger to health, or set forth any combination thereof. The administrator may order the cessation of all operations authorized by the permit only if a more limited order does not remove the immediate danger to health. Except as provided in section 22-563, no temporary order shall be effective for more than 14 days from the time of its delivery, but a temporary order may be reissued for one additional 14-day period, if necessary, to complete the analysis or examination of evidence. 
(Code 1973, § 11.09.110(e))  
Sec. 22-563. - Resumption of operations after cessation order. 
No operation or method of operation prohibited by a temporary order issued under section 22-562 may be resumed without the approval of the city, until the order has terminated or the time period specified in section 22-562 has run out, whichever occurs first. If the city, upon completed analysis and examination, determines that the construction, sanitary condition, operation or method of operation of the premises or equipment does not constitute an immediate danger to health, the permittee, owner or operator of the premises shall be promptly notified in writing and the temporary order shall terminate upon his receipt of the written notice. 
(Code 1973, § 11.09.110(f))  
Sec. 22-564. - Continuance of temporary cessation order. 
If an analysis or examination shows that the construction, sanitary condition, operation or method of operation of the premises or equipment constitutes an immediate danger to health, the permittee, owner or operator shall be notified within the effective period of the temporary order issued under section 22-562. Upon receipt of such notice, the temporary order shall remain in effect until a final decision is issued, and no operation or method of operation prohibited by the order may be resumed without the approval of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 11.09.110(g))  
Sec. 22-565. - Hearings. 
A notice issued under section 22-562 shall be accompanied by notice of a hearing as provided in Wis. Stats. § 68.11(1). The city shall hold a hearing no later than 15 days after the service of the notice, unless both parties agree to a later date. Notwithstanding Wis. Stats. § 68.12, a final decision shall be issued under Wis. Stats. § 68.12 within ten days of the hearing. The decision may order changes to or replacement of equipment or construction, other changes in or cessations of any operation or method of operation of the equipment or premises, or any combination of these actions necessary to remove the danger to health. The decision may order the cessation of all operations authorized by the permit only if a more limited order will not remove the immediate danger to health. A final decision shall be issued within ten days after the hearing. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, such hearings shall be held by the board of health. 
(Code 1973, § 11.09.110(h))  
Sec. 22-566. - Violation of article; payment of forfeiture in lieu of court appearance. 
(a)  Any person charged with a violation of the offenses listed under subsection (b) of this section may pay the amount enumerated therein at the police department in lieu of a court appearance. Persons wishing to contest charges contained in subsection (b) of this section may contact the police department to arrange a court appearance date. 
(b)  The following forfeitures for the offenses listed herein may be paid at the police department: 
Code 
section 	Violation 	Forfeiture 
22-576 	Permit required 	$150.00 
22-561— 
22-565 	Violation of order 	150.00 
 
(Code 1973, § 11.26.020; Ord. No. 41-90, pt. 1, 11-20-90) 
State Law reference— Actions for violation of municipal regulations, forfeitures, stipulations, Wis. Stats. § 66.12(1)(b); citations for ordinance violations, Wis. Stats. § 66.119.  
Secs. 22-567—22-575. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 22-576. - Required. 
No person may conduct, maintain, manage or operate a hotel, motel or tourist roominghouse without first having obtained an annual permit from the administrator or his designee through application made upon a form furnished by the health department. 
(Code 1973, § 11.09.110(a); Ord. No. 0017-19, pt. 5, 7-16-19)  
Sec. 22-577. - Term; fee. 
All permits issued under this article shall expire on June 30 of each year. Fees for such permits shall be set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council. 
(Code 1973, § 11.09.110(b); Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 47, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 22-578. - Nontransferable; posting. 
Permits issued under this article shall not be transferred from one person or place to another. Permits must be posted in a conspicuous and easily accessible place in the premises for which the permit is issued. 
(Code 1973, § 11.09.110(c))  
Sec. 22-579. - Inspections. 
The administrator or his designees may enter, at reasonable hours, any premises for which the city has issued a permit under this article to inspect the premises, examine and copy relevant documents and records or obtain photographs or other evidence needed to enforce laws, ordinances, regulations and rules applicable to the premises licensed under this article. 
(Code 1973, § 11.09.110(d))  
Sec. 22-580. - Requirements for issuance of a hotel or motel permit. 
(a)  No permit shall be issued, nor shall any permit be renewed, for a hotel or motel within the city, unless the facility meets the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  The facility shall exclusively accommodate tourists or transients, and only for periods of occupancy less than 30 days, unless the hotel or motel has obtained a conditional use permit to operate as an extended stay facility as permitted by the zoning code pursuant to section 114-468(6). For purposes of calculating occupancy, any stays in excess of 29 days within a 90 day period violates this section, whether or not such occupancy was continuous. 
(2)  The facility shall not rent rooms on an hourly basis. 
(3)  The manager may live on site. 
(4)  The facility shall provide customary hotel or motel services and amenities, such as maid service, laundering, linens, furnishings, room upkeep and front desk services. 
(5)  The facility must comply with all local and state regulations, including all building, health and fire codes, and shall obtain all required permits, inspections and licenses. 
(6)  The facility shall not operate in such a way as to constitute a public nuisance in violation of city ordinance or state law. 
(b)  A violation of any of the above provisions shall constitute grounds for suspension, revocation or nonrenewal of such permit. 
(c)  The procedures under section 22-422 shall govern the suspension, revocation and/or nonrenewal of any permit issued under this article. 
(Ord. No. 0017-19, pt. 6, 7-16-19) 
State Law reference— Agent status for local health departments, Wis. Stat. § 97.615(2)(g); Powers of the department and local health departments, Wis. Stat. § 97.625(2).  
Secs. 22-581—22-600. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XIX. - JUKEBOX OPERATION[18] 
Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
Cross reference— Sale or consumption of intoxicating beverages or liquor in amusement centers and places of entertainment, § 6-3; noise regulations, § 42-111 et seq. 
State Law reference— Amusement places, license regulations, Wis. Stats. § 175.20 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 22-601. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Jukebox means any music vending machine or device which, upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate, currency, disc or key into any slot, crevice or other opening, or by the payment of any price, operates or may be operated for the emission of songs, music or similar amusement. 
Person means any person who owns any jukebox; the person in whose place of business any jukebox is placed for use by the public; and the person having control over a jukebox; provided, however, that the payment of a license fee by any one of the persons enumerated in this definition shall be deemed a compliance with this article. 
(Code 1973, § 22.25.010) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 22-602. - Hours of operation. 
No person holding a license under this article shall permit the playing of jukeboxes between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. of any day, except on New Year's Day, when playing such machine may be done at any time. 
(Code 1973, § 22.25.090)  
Secs. 22-603—22-615. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 22-616. - Required. 
No person shall display for public patronage or keep for operation any jukebox without obtaining a license therefor. 
(Code 1973, § 22.25.020)  
Sec. 22-617. - Application. 
(a)  The application for a license under this article shall set forth the name and address of the applicant, age, date and place of birth of the applicant, and the place where the jukebox is to be displayed or operated and the business conducted at that place. 
(b)  After an application for a license under this article has been made, the application shall be referred to the public safety and licensing committee of the common council, and the committee shall pass upon the question of whether such license shall be granted. Such committee shall refer the matter to the common council if denial is recommended. 
(Code 1973, §§ 22.25.030, 22.25.040; Ord. No. 33-06, pt. 1, 9-5-06)  
Sec. 22-618. - Renewal. 
Action by the common council shall only be necessary on the original application for each license under this article. Renewals thereof may be made by the city clerk without action by the common council. 
(Code 1973, § 22.25.050)  
Sec. 22-619. - Fee; term. 
(a)  The annual license fee for the privilege of operating or maintaining for operation each jukebox shall be set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council per machine for the license year from July 1 to June 30. When such license is issued at any time between January 1 and June 30, the fee shall be set forth in the fee schedule per machine for the balance of the license year. 
(b)  All licenses issued under this article shall expire on June 30 following the date of issue, unless revoked. 
(Code 1973, § 22.25.060; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 48, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 22-620. - Display of license. 
A license issued under this article shall be posted permanently and conspicuously in the place of business where the jukebox is to be operated or available for operation. 
(Code 1973, § 22.25.070)  
Sec. 22-621. - Transfer of license. 
A license issued under this article shall not be transferable from person to person or place to place, but shall be transferable from jukebox to jukebox. 
(Code 1973, § 22.25.080)  
Secs. 22-622—22-640. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XX. - JUNK DEALERS AND COLLECTORS[19] 
Footnotes: 
--- (19) --- 
Cross reference— Conditional use, § 114-136 et seq. 
State Law reference— Pawnbrokers and secondhand goods dealers, Wis. Stats. § 134.71; storage of junked automobiles, Wis. Stats. § 175.25; motor vehicle salvage business, Wis. Stats. § 218.20 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 22-641. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Junk means old iron, chain, brass, copper, tin, lead or other base metals, paper, wastepaper, paper clippings, rags, rubber, glass or bottles, and all articles and things discarded as manufactured articles composed of or consisting of any one or more of the articles or materials mentioned herein, or other material commonly included in the term "junk." 
Junk business means the business or occupation of buying, selling, gathering, delivering or storing of junk, except motor vehicle salvage businesses regulated under Wis. Stats. § 218.20 et seq. 
Junk collector means any person who collects, buys or gathers junk by means of a wagon, truck, cart or other vehicle. 
Junk dealer means a person who buys, sells, gathers, delivers or stores junk and maintains a yard or building therefor. 
Junkyard means any place where a junk business is conducted. 
(Code 1973, § 22.06.010) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 22-642. - Recordkeeping. 
Each junk dealer and junk collector shall in a bound book keep a daily record in the English language of articles purchased and the name and address of the seller when such person is known to the licensee. When the seller is unknown to the licensee, the licensee shall record the name, age and address, and indicate what identification card was inspected by the licensee, and the identifying number thereof, or if the card bears no number, the certifying officer. Any certified identification card issued by a public agency and giving a description of the person to whom it is issued shall be deemed sufficient to comply with the provisions of this section. When articles are purchased in bulk, they may be designated by a general description of the lot. 
(Code 1973, § 22.06.210) 
State Law reference— Records, Wis. Stats. §§ 134.71, 218.23.  
Sec. 22-643. - Purchase from minors and intoxicated persons prohibited. 
No purchase shall be made by a licensee under this article from any child under 18 years of age or from any intoxicated persons. 
(Code 1973, § 22.06.110) 
State Law reference— Purchases from minors, Wis. Stats. § 948.63.  
Sec. 22-644. - Sorting of materials, time of collection restricted. 
No materials shall be sorted in a public street, alley or sidewalk, and no licensee under this article shall collect junk between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., Monday through Saturday, and from 10:00 p.m. on Saturday to 9:00 a.m. on Sunday and legal holidays. 
(Code 1973, § 22.06.130)  
Sec. 22-645. - Chief of police may hold goods for identification. 
The chief of police may, in his discretion, cause any article in the possession of a licensee under this article which he shall have reason to believe was sold or exchanged by some person other than the lawful owner thereof to be held for the purpose of identification by its lawful owner, for such reasonable length of time as the chief of police shall deem necessary. 
(Code 1973, § 22.06.160) 
State Law reference— Secondhand goods, holding period, Wis. Stats. § 134.71(8)(d).  
Secs. 22-646—22-655. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 22-656. - Required; exception. 
(a)  A license shall be obtained by every person who engages in the business of a junk dealer, or the business of a junk collector. 
(b)  A separate license is required for each type of business under this article, but only one license is required from any person for each type of business, regardless of the number of locations on which such business is conducted. 
(c)  No license is required of any business, manufacturer or charitable organization which may as an incidental part of its business or operation buy, collect, gather, store or sell any junk. 
(Code 1973, § 22.06.020)  
Sec. 22-657. - Application, contents. 
Application for a license under this article shall be sworn to and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The full name and residence of the applicant; and, if a firm or association, the full names and residences of the members of the firm or association; and, if a corporation, the full names and residences of the officers thereof; whether the applicant or any of such persons has held a license or been a member of a partnership or association or an officer in a corporation which was licensed under this article; and whether such license was ever revoked or renewal thereof was ever refused, and if so, when. 
(2)  The address and legal description of the premises for which the license is desired, or, if the application is for a junk collector's license, the location of his office and of the premises on which the vehicle used in such collection business will be located when it is not being operated in connection with the business. 
(3)  The type of license for which the applicant is applying. 
(4)  Such other information as the city clerk may require. 
(Code 1973, § 22.06.030)  
Sec. 22-658. - Fees. 
License fees under this article are set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council. 
(Code 1973, § 22.06.070; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 49, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 22-659. - Reapplying after denial. 
No applicant to whom a license under this article has been refused shall directly or indirectly make further application for the same location or part thereof until a period of at least one year shall have elapsed since the last previous rejection. 
(Code 1973, § 22.06.060)  
Sec. 22-660. - License numbers; posting; identification of vehicles. 
All licenses issued under this article shall be numbered consecutively for each type of business licensed, and the city clerk shall furnish to each licensee a card setting forth his name, the number of such license, the type of business and a legal description of the premises for which it was issued. The license card shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises. The licensee shall cause his name and such license number to be printed in plain letters and figures at least three inches high and of such color as to be plainly read at a distance of at least 60 feet from both sides of each vehicle used in connection with the business licensed under this article. 
(Code 1973, § 22.06.080)  
Sec. 22-661. - Insurance. 
No license shall be issued under this article unless a current certificate of motor vehicle insurance covering each vehicle to be operated on public streets in connection with the licensed business is filed with the city clerk. Such certificate of insurance shall be in a minimum amount of $150,000.00 per person, $300,000.00 per occurrence and $50,000.00 property damage per occurrence. The certificate shall indicate that the insurer shall provide to the city clerk at least ten days' written notice of cancellation or termination of such coverage or any portion thereof. Such certificate shall be maintained current at all times. 
(Code 1973, § 22.06.270)  
Sec. 22-662. - Notice of change in personnel of licensee. 
Every partnership, association or corporation holding a license under this article shall notify the city clerk of any change in the members of such partnership or association or in the officers, directors or principal stockholders of such corporation within ten days of such change and shall furnish such further information as the city clerk may require in order to show its continuing eligibility to hold a license under this article. 
(Code 1973, § 22.06.260)  
Sec. 22-663. - Issuance in annexed areas. 
The common council may grant a license to any junk dealer in an annexed area who was licensed one year prior to the initiation of the annexation petition, on the same conditions as any licensee under this article may obtain a renewal of his license, and such license may be granted at any time during the year. 
(Code 1973, § 22.06.050)  
Sec. 22-664. - Liquidation of business. 
When renewal of a license issued under this article is denied or when such license is revoked or expires without renewal, such licensee shall have a period of three months in which to liquidate his business, during which time he shall be required to comply with all the regulations of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 22.06.090)  
Secs. 22-665—22-685. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XXI. - ROOMINGHOUSES[20] 

Footnotes: 
--- (20) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 16-01, adopted July 5, 2001 repealed art. XXI, lodginghouses, apartment hotels and lodging rooms, §§ 22-686—22-743, in its entirety, and enacted a new art. XXI, roominghouses, §§ 22-686—22-692, as set out herein. The former art. XXI pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Code 1973, §§ 11.09.060 et seq., 11.09.090, 11.09.100, 11.09.110(i), 11.26.020; Ord. No. 41-90, pt. 1, 11-20-90; Ord. No. 46-90, pt. 3, 12-18-90; Ord. No. 38-92, pt. 1, 2-17-93. 
Cross reference— Board of health, § 2-176 et seq.; property maintenance standards, § 18-691 et seq.; transient lodging tax, § 90-51 et seq. 
Cross reference— Property maintenance standards, § 18-691 et seq. 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; zoning, ch. 114. 
 
Sec. 22-686. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Approved. As applied to a material, device or method of construction, shall mean approved by the health officer under the provisions of this chapter, or approved by other authority designated by law to give approval in the matter in question. 
Basement. A portion of a building located partly underground, but having less than one-half the building's clear height below the average grade of the adjoining ground. 
Dead bolt lock. A lock with a single cylinder, minimum one-inch throw, case-hardened cylinder guard, all metal parts and tie screws facing the inside of the home only. 
Dwelling. Any building or structure, or part thereof, which is used or intended to be used for living or sleeping. 
Extermination. The control or elimination of insects, rodents or other pests by eliminating their harborage places, by removing or making inaccessible materials that may serve as their food, by blocking their access to a dwelling, by poisoning, spraying, fumigating or trapping, or by any other legal pest elimination method approved by the health officer. 
Habitable room. A room or enclosed floor space used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking or eating purposes, excluding bathrooms, water closets, hallways and closets. 
Health officer. The public health administrator of the city or his or her authorized representative. 
Infestation. The presence, within or around a dwelling of any insects, rodents or other pests. 
Operator. Any person who has charge, care or control of any dwelling as agent or representative of the owner, or as executor, administrator, trustee or guardian of the estate of the owner. 
Owner. Any person who, alone or jointly or severally with others, is the legal record holder of the title, with or without actual possession thereof. 
Person. Includes owners, their agents, tenants, operators, and any individual, firm, corporation, partnership or association. 
Properly. Properly shall mean as deemed proper by the health officer under the regulations of this chapter or deemed proper by an authority designated by law. 
Roominghouses. Any dwelling containing two or more rooming units, and in which persons either individually or as families are housed for compensation. 
Rooming unit. Any room or group of rooms forming a single habitable unit used or intended to be used for living and sleeping, but not for cooking purposes, except where section 22-687(d)(2) allows. 
Screen door. A durable, framed door with a self-closing device having at least 30 percent of its surface area being screen of not less than 16 mesh per inch to allow ventilation but prevent the entrance of pests into the dwelling unit. 
Screen window. A durable, framed window addition consisting of screen of not less than 16 mesh per inch to allow ventilation but prevent the entrance of pests into the dwelling unit. 
Storm door. A durable, framed, supplementary door with a self-closing device that tightly fits within the doorway and prevents the entrance of outside air and pests into the dwelling unit. At least ten percent of the surface area must be transparent and in a position to allow easy viewing of the outside. 
Storm window. A durable, framed, supplementary window that seals tightly against the window frame and prevents the entrance of outside air into the dwelling unit. 
Smoke detector. A device that detects the visible or invisible particles of combustion. 
Ventilation. The process of supplying and removing air by natural or mechanical means to or from any space. 
Workmanlike. Work of such character so as to meet manufacturer's specifications, accepted national standards or recognized trade practices, and to provide a durable result as intended to ensure public safety, health and welfare insofar as they are affected by building construction, use and occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 16-01, pt. 2, 7-5-01; Ord. No. 0017-19, pt. 1, 7-16-19)  
Sec. 22-687. - Roominghouses. 
(a)  Permit required. 
(1)  No person may conduct, maintain, manage or operate a roominghouse without first having obtained an annual permit from the health officer through application made upon a form furnished by the health department. 
(2)  All permits issued under this article shall expire on July 31 of each year. Fees for permits shall be set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council. 
(3)  Permits issued under this article shall not be transferred from one person or place to another. Permits must be conspicuously posted in the office or public hallway of the roominghouse. Every person holding such a permit shall give notice in writing to the health officer within 30 days after having sold, transferred, given away, or otherwise disposed of ownership, of interest in, or control of any roominghouse. Such notice shall include the name and address of the person succeeding to the ownership or control of such roominghouse. 
(4)  The issuance of a roominghouse permit shall not in any way signify or imply that a roominghouse conforms with the applicable state building code or the building and zoning codes of the city and the county. The issuance of a roominghouse permit shall not relieve the owner or operator of the responsibility for compliance with such building and zoning codes. 
(b)  Inspection required. 
(1)  Whenever an application is filed for a roominghouse, which does not have a prior valid permit, the health officer shall inspect the roominghouse within 30 days of such filing. Within 72 hours after the operator files an application for permit, the health officer shall transmit to the chief building inspector a duplicate copy of the application. The chief building inspector shall, within 30 days after the date on which such application was filed, report in writing to the health officer the maximum number of persons which may occupy the roominghouse in accordance with the provision of applicable zoning laws. No permit shall be issued to any operator which would authorize occupancy of the roominghouse by a larger number of persons than is permitted under the provisions of applicable zoning laws. 
(2)  The health officer shall inspect the roominghouse once per year. A written report based upon the requirements of this section shall be submitted. Failure by the operator or owner to appear on the scheduled time and day for the inspection without offering 24 hours notice to the health department may result in a re-inspection fee set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council issued to the operator of the roominghouse. 
(c)  Bath area. Every roominghouse shall have at least one flush toilet, lavatory basin and bathtub or shower for every six occupants. Such facilities shall be accessible from a common hallway or passageway and shall comply with sections 18-706(1-3). Roominghouses with valid permits at the time of adoption of this article shall be allowed to continue to operate within the previous requirements of one flush toilet, lavatory basin and bathtub or shower for every eight occupants until such time as the roominghouse changes ownership. 
(d)  Kitchen area. 
(1)  Cooking, food preparation, and storage of cooking utensils in rooming units of roominghouses is prohibited. Each owner or operator of a roominghouse shall be responsible for monitoring the sleeping rooms to ensure that cooking, food preparation, and storage of cooking utensils does not take place in rooms where cooking is prohibited. 
(2)  Cooking, food preparation and storage of cooking utensils shall be allowed in rooming units which have permanently installed cooking facilities which provide a minimum of 70 square feet of floor space. This area will not be included in the calculation of the habitable rooming unit area. These facilities must comply with section 18-706(4). 
(3)  Food preparation shall be allowed in the common kitchen area of roominghouses provided that the kitchen area is not located in the same room as the bathing or laundry facilities or in the basement. These facilities must comply with section 18-706(4). 
(e)  Heating facilities. Every roominghouse shall have heating facilities that are properly installed, safely maintained and in good working condition. Such heating facilities shall be capable of safely and adequately heating all habitable rooms, bathrooms and toilet rooms located therein to a temperature of at least 67° F. measured at three feet from the floor and at least three feet from an exterior wall with an outside temperature of -10° F. 
(f)  Electric service. All roominghouses and rooming units shall be supplied with electrical service that is adequate to safely meet the electrical needs of the roominghouse and the rooming units. Every outlet and fixture shall be properly installed, shall be maintained in a good and safe working condition, and shall be properly connected to the source of electric power in a safe manner and in compliance with the Racine Electrical Code. 
(g)  Interior walls, floors, ceilings, etc. 
(1)  Every interior partition wall, floor and ceiling shall be capable of affording privacy, and shall be kept in a workmanlike state of repair and maintained so as to permit them to be kept in a clean and sanitary manner. 
(2)  All woodwork and cabinets must be maintained in a sound condition and in a workmanlike state of repair and maintained so as to permit them to be kept in a clean and sanitary manner. 
(h)  Windows, doors and hatchways. Every window, exterior door and basement hatchway shall be substantially tight and shall be kept in a workmanlike state of repair. Every window, other than a fixed window, shall be capable of being easily opened. 
(1)  Window locks. Locking hardware shall be required on all basement windows, first floor windows and every other window that is accessible by an adjacent fire escape, stairway, etc. 
(2)  Screens. Every window opening or other outside opening used for ventilation purposes shall be supplied with a screen of not less than 16 mesh per inch. Every screen door shall have a self-closing device in a good working condition. Such screens and doors shall be in place from May 1 through October 15. Every basement or cellar window which is openable shall be supplied with a framed, heavy wire screen or hardware cloth of not less than four mesh per inch or other approved material affording equivalent protection against the entry of pests in addition to the screens required for ventilation. 
(3)  Storms. Every rooming unit shall be provided with storm windows for all windows that are not double-glazed and storm doors for all doors that are not provided with insulated doors. Every storm door shall have a self-closing device in a good working condition. Such storm windows and storm doors shall be in place from October 16 through April 30. 
(4)  Entry doors. Every entry door and its hardware shall be in a sound condition and fit tightly within its frame so as to prevent the entrance of pests and the weather. Every entry door to a rooming unit shall be substantially secure from illegal entry and shall be provided with a dead bolt lock. 
(5)  Basement hatchways. Every basement hatchway shall be so constructed and maintained as to prevent the entrance of rodents, rain and surface drainage water into the structure and shall be substantially secure from illegal entry. 
(6)  Common entries. Exterior doors used as a common means of egress for two or more rooming units shall be tight fitting and equipped with an automatic door-closing device in a good working condition in order to protect against the entry of pests and the weather. 
(7)  Exits. Every rooming unit shall have at least two safe, unobstructed means of exit leading directly to the outside. The requirements of section 18-175 of this Code shall be applicable to roominghouses. 
(i)  Lighting. Every public hallway and stairway in a multiple unit dwelling shall be adequately lighted by natural or artificial light at all times, providing in all parts thereof at least ten footcandles of light at each tread or floor level. 
(j)  Smoke detectors. Smoke detectors shall be installed in each rooming unit and in common areas including but not limited to: hallways, stairways, basements and kitchens. The owner and/or operator of a roominghouse shall keep all smoke detectors in a good operating condition and supplied with the proper type of batteries if such smoke detectors require batteries. 
(k)  Roof. The roof of every dwelling shall be tight, impervious to water and have no defects which admit water or dampness to the interior of the building. 
(l)  Occupancy. 
(1)  Every rooming unit shall contain at least 70 square feet of floor space for each occupant. No more than two people may occupy a single rooming unit. 
(2)  Floor area shall be calculated on the basis of total habitable room area, exclusive of any kitchen area allowed under subsection (d)(2) above. 
(3)  Every rooming unit shall have a ceiling height of at least seven feet. Any part of the rooming unit which does not have a ceiling height of seven feet will not be included in the calculation for habitable rooming unit area. 
(4)  Access to or egress from each rooming unit shall be provided without passing through any other rooming unit. 
(m)  Discontinuance of required services, facilities, equipment or utilities. No owner or operator shall cause or allow any service, facility, equipment or utility which is required to be supplied under the provisions of this Code to be removed, shut off, or discontinued in any roominghouse or rooming unit except for such temporary interruption as may be necessary while actual repairs, replacements, or alterations are in the process of being made. 
(n)  Hazardous conditions. Every roominghouse and rooming unit shall be structurally sound and shall be free of conditions which constitute a substantial hazard to the health and safety of the occupant(s) or which create an unreasonable risk of personal injury resulting from any reasonably foreseeable use of the dwelling other than negligent use of the dwelling by the occupant(s). Violations shall include, but are not limited to the following: 
(1)  Sewage in the basement. 
(2)  Excessive damage to interior, if it poses a health problem. 
(3)  Excessive solid waste accumulations inside, if such accumulations pose a health problem. 
(o)  Public areas. Every owner of a roominghouse shall be responsible for maintaining in a clean and sanitary condition the shared or public areas of the roominghouse and premises thereof. 
(Ord. No. 16-01, pt. 2, 7-5-01; Ord. No. 0028-19, pts. 50, 51, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 22-688. - Responsibilities of roominghouse occupants. 
(a)  Cleanliness. No occupant of a roominghouse and rooming unit shall fail to maintain, and upon departure, to leave that part of the roominghouse and rooming unit and premises thereof, including basement facilities, that the occupant occupies and controls and that is provided for the occupant's use, in a clean and sanitary condition, free of litter and debris. 
(b)  Solid waste disposal and containers. The occupant of a roominghouse and rooming unit shall dispose of all solid waste located in such roominghouse and rooming unit, in a clean and sanitary manner, by placing it in containers as specified in subsection 78-50(d). 
(c)  Animals. No occupant shall keep any animals or pets in a rooming unit, or on any premises in such a manner as to create unsanitary conditions, including without limitation, accumulation of excrement. 
(d)  Fixtures. Every occupant of a roominghouse shall keep all plumbing fixtures and heating facilities supplied by the owner or operator in good operating condition and free from damage, ordinary wear and tear excepted. 
(Ord. No. 16-01, pt. 2, 7-5-01)  
Sec. 22-689. - Notice of violation. 
Whenever the health officer finds, upon inspection, any violation of this article, he shall notify the owner or operator responsible therefor by means of a written notice of inspection. In such notification, the health officer shall set forth the specific condition found, the correction necessary to bring about compliance, and a specific and reasonable time for such correction and compliance. All corrections must be completed in a workmanlike manner. Each condition continued or repeated after the time specified in such notification shall constitute a separate violation of this article. 
At the end of such period, the health officer shall re-inspect the roominghouse and if they find that such conditions or practices have not been corrected, they shall give notice in writing to the operator that such operator's permit has been suspended. Upon receipt of notice of suspension, such operator shall immediately cease operation of such roominghouse and no person shall thereafter occupy for sleeping or living purposes any rooming unit therein. Such suspension shall be stayed if a timely petition for hearing is filed under section 22-690. 
(Ord. No. 16-01, pt. 2, 7-5-01)  
Sec. 22-690. - Appeal of suspension. 
Any roominghouse operator who has received notice from the health officer that their permit is to be suspended, or who has received notice from the health officer that their permit is to be suspended unless existing conditions or practices at their roominghouse are corrected, may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the health and sanitation appeal board, under the procedure provided by section 2-236 et seq. provided that if no petition for such hearing is filed within 30 days following the day on which such permit was suspended, such permit shall be deemed to have been automatically revoked. 
(Ord. No. 16-01, pt. 2, 7-5-01)  
Sec. 22-691. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Upon conviction, any person found to be in violation of this article or any order issued under this article shall forfeit an amount as provided in section 1-15. 
(Ord. No. 16-01, pt. 2, 7-5-01)  
Sec. 22-692. - Payment of forfeiture in lieu of court appearance. 
(a)  Any person charged with a violation of the offenses listed under subsection (b) of this section may pay the amount enumerated therein at the police department in lieu of a court appearance. Persons wishing to contest charges contained in subsection (b) of this section may contact the police department to arrange a court appearance date. 
(b)  The following forfeitures for the offenses listed herein may be paid at the police department:
