Sec. 22-1036. - Taxicab service; operation and rates. 
(a)  Operation. Each operator shall provide taxicab service as provided in this article. If such services cannot be rendered within a reasonable time, the operator shall notify the prospective passenger of the estimated time of service and give the reason therefor. No operator shall refuse to provide service within the city if taxicabs are available to respond thereto, except as otherwise provided in this article. 
(b)  Rates. 
(1)  Taximeter. A taxicab operated upon the streets of the city may be equipped with a taximeter. The sealer of weights and measures is authorized to test all taximeters periodically to ensure that such taximeters are operating properly, and if such inspection shows that such taximeter is not correctly registering, the taximeter shall be repaired or replaced so as to operate properly. 
(2)  Rates. Every person operating or controlling any motor vehicle operated as a taxicab operating with a taximeter within the limits of the city shall prominently display within the vehicle all applicable fares and tariffs, which shall be in plain sight of potential passengers. 
(c)  Exclusive permission granted. Subject to the conditions and limitations of this chapter, exclusive permission and authority are hereby granted to taxicab provider licensees hereunder to operate taxicabs under this chapter upon the public streets and other public ways within the corporate limits of the city, unless terminated or revoked. 
It shall be unlawful and the city will not permit any taxicab not licensed hereunder, or any person associated with such vehicle, to solicit business within the city or to accept for transportation, sightseeing tours or charter trips, any passengers within the city, excepting only passengers destined to the community in which such taxicab is licensed and then only when such transportation has been arranged for in advance by telephonic or written order. 
(d)  Number of available licenses. The public safety and licensing committee shall promulgate regulations to set forth procedures by which all available taxicab licenses shall be distributed periodically pursuant to open and competitive bidding procedures. The procedures shall be designed to produce the maximum amount of revenues to the city consistent with serving the public interest, and to ensure that the total number of licenses issued or to be issued depends on the public necessity for the designated level of service, and that only applicants that are qualified under this chapter are awarded licenses. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.170, 10-20-92; Ord. No. 4-99, pts. 1—4, 3-2-99; Ord. No. 52-04, pt. 1, 1-18-05; Ord. No. 3-06, pt. 1, 2-24-06)  
Secs. 22-1037—22-1045. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PROVIDER'S LICENSE 
 
Sec. 22-1046. - Required. 
No person shall operate or permit a public passenger vehicle owned or controlled by such person to be operated as a vehicle for hire upon the streets of the city without having first obtained a provider's license under this article, except as otherwise provided by Wis. Stats. § 349.24. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.030, 10-20-92; Ord. No. 12-94, pt. 2, 5-17-94; Ord. No. 52-04, pt. 2, 1-18-05)  
Sec. 22-1047. - Application. 
Application for a provider's license shall be filed with the city clerk upon a form provided by the city. Such application shall be verified upon oath, shall contain the following information and shall be accompanied by the license fee, excepting that providers providing public passenger services under contract with the city shall not be required to obtain a license under the provisions of this chapter: 
(1)  The name, address and business telephone number of the applicant except as otherwise provided herein. 
(2)  If a partnership or association, the names and addresses of all of the members of such partnership or association. 
(3)  If a corporation, the names and addresses of all officers, all directors and the managing agent or officer, and the place of incorporation. 
(4)  The financial status of the applicant, including the amount, nature and cause of any outstanding judgments against the applicant. 
(5)  Information relating to the applicant's conviction of any felonies or misdemeanors within the five years prior to application, including the place of conviction. Such information shall be provided for all officers, directors and managing agents of a corporation or association and all partners of a partnership. 
(6)  The experience of the applicant in the public passenger transportation business. 
(7)  The number, type, age and general description of vehicles to be operated or controlled by the applicant and the location of proposed business locations at which such vehicles will be kept. 
(8)  The name and address of the insurance company and its agent underwriting the insurance required by this article. 
(9)  The color scheme or insignia to be used, if appropriate, to designate the vehicles of the applicant. 
(10)  The rates which the applicant proposes to charge for such services. 
(11)  The names of any lienholders on the vehicles used or to be used under this article. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.040, 10-20-92; Ord. No. 12-94, pt. 4, 5-17-94; Ord. No. 52-04, pt. 3, 1-18-05)  
Sec. 22-1048. - Hearing on application. 
Upon the filing of an application, the city clerk shall refer such application to the committee, which shall fix a time and place for a public hearing thereon. Notice of such hearing shall be given to the applicant. In making its recommendation, the committee shall take into consideration the character, experience and responsibility of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.050, 10-20-92)  
Sec. 22-1049. - Issuance or denial. 
If the committee finds that the applicant is fit, willing and able to perform public passenger transportation services and to conform to the provisions of this article, then it shall recommend to the common council that a provider's license of the category applied for be granted. If the common council approves the report of the committee recommending the granting of such license, the city clerk shall issue the appropriate license stating the type of license, the name and address of the applicant, the number of vehicles authorized and the date of issuance. Otherwise, the application shall be denied. No license shall be issued by the city clerk unless the applicant has provided the city clerk with a valid vehicle inspection certificate for each vehicle to be operated under the license, proof of insurance and a city treasurer's receipt for the payment of the license fee. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.060, 10-20-92; Ord. No. 52-04, pt.4, 1-18-05)  
Sec. 22-1050. - Renewal. 
The committee shall, without a hearing, recommend to the common council the granting of applications for renewal of public passenger vehicle provider's licenses, provided that the city clerk has received a timely filed application for renewal, all applicable fees have been paid, the applicant has a current inspection certificate for each vehicle to be operated under the license, the applicant provides evidence of appropriate insurance coverage, and the information required by subsections 22-1047(1), (2), (3) and (5) has not changed. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.070, 10-20-92; Ord. No. 52-04, pt. 5, 1-18-05)  
Sec. 22-1051. - Insurance. 
(a)  No provider's license shall be issued unless satisfactory proof of liability insurance covering the operation of each public passenger vehicle to be used has been filed with the city clerk. The policy of insurance shall be with a company authorized to do business in the state, and placed with a carrier with an A.M. Best rating of no less than A-VII, or equivalent, insuring the owner of the vehicle against loss or damage that may result to any person or property from the operation or defective condition of the vehicle. The minimum policy limits shall be $100,000.00 per person/$300,000.00 per occurrence bodily injury and $50,000.00 per occurrence property damage. 
(b)  The insurance policy or certificate of insurance required by this section, and renewals thereof, shall be filed with the city clerk and reviewed by the city attorney, and all such policies shall contain a clause prohibiting cancellation or reduction in coverage except upon ten days' written notice to the city. If notice of cancellation is received and the vehicle owner fails within the period specified in the notice of cancellation to provide new coverage or reinstate such coverage and present evidence thereof to the city clerk, the provider's license as it applies to such vehicle or vehicles shall be terminated at 12:01 a.m. on the day the policy ceases to be in effect. In requiring such insurance, the city makes no representations or commitments whatsoever as to the sufficiency or adequacy with respect thereto and assumes no obligations to the public by virtue of having required such insurance to be submitted and filed with the city. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.090, 10-20-92; Ord. No. 24-93, pt. 1, 10-5-93; Ord. No. 14-94, pt. 1, 7-19-94; Ord. No. 18-97, pt. 1, 10-22-97; Ord. No. 52-04, pt. 6, 1-18-05)  
Sec. 22-1052. - Fee; term. 
(a)  The application for a provider's license under this article shall be accompanied by an operator's license fee and a fee for each vehicle to be operated under such license. Such fees shall be set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council and shall not be prorated and shall be issued for the following categories of license: 
(1)  Taxicab service. 
(2)  Shuttle vehicle service. 
(3)  Luxury limousine service. 
(4)  Handicapped-elderly vehicle service. 
(5)  Horse and surrey service. 
(b)  The term of a provider's license shall be from April 1 to March 31 of the following year. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.100, 10-20-92; Ord. No. 44-04, pt. 17, 12-7-04; Ord. No. 52-04, pt. 7, 1-18-05; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 63, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 22-1053. - Transfer. 
If an individual licensee under this division dies or becomes disabled, the provider's license may be transferred to the surviving spouse, and if there is no surviving spouse, to the legal representative of the permittee or the estate, who will then be eligible to operate under the license for the remainder of the license period. A provider's license may also be transferred with the licensee's consent to such licensee's spouse for good cause and upon approval of the committee. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.080, 10-20-92; Ord. No. 52-04, pt. 8, 1-18-05)  
Sec. 22-1054. - Suspension and revocation. 
A provider's license may be revoked or suspended by the common council when the public safety so requires. Prior to such suspension or revocation, the provider shall be given notice of a hearing on such matter, including therein the reasons for such hearing, the time and place the hearing shall be held, the right to be present at such hearing and to be represented by counsel, to call witnesses and examine and cross examine witnesses, and to have the proceedings recorded at the provider's own expense. Such hearing shall be held by the committee and if the committee recommends suspension or revocation of the provider's license, the recommendation shall be referred to the common council for its action. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.110, 10-20-92; Ord. No. 52-04, pt. 9, 1-18-05)  
Secs. 22-1055—22-1065. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 05-17, pt. 1, adopted May 16, 2017, repealed § 22-1055 in its entirety. Former § 22-1055 pertained to temporary license and derived from Ord. No. 12-94, pt. 5(22.17.115), adopted May 17 1994; Ord. No. 52-04, pt. 10, adopted Jan. 18, 2005.  
DIVISION 3. - DRIVERS 
 
Sec. 22-1066. - Driver's licenses—Required; application. 
(a)  Prohibition. No person shall operate a public passenger vehicle subject to licensing under this division upon the streets of the city without having in his or her possession a valid state driver's license and, unless otherwise provided herein, a valid city driver's license, excepting that drivers operating public passenger vehicles under a provider's contract with the city shall not be required to obtain a city driver's license under the provisions of this chapter if the person holds a current and valid State of Wisconsin Commercial Driver's License (CDL) with a passenger (P-2) endorsement. 
(b)  Application. Applications for a driver's license under this article shall be filed with the city clerk upon forms provided by the city. Applications shall be verified under oath and shall furnish the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant and the names and addresses of four persons who have known the applicant for a period of at least three years and who attest to the sobriety, honesty and general good character of the applicant. 
(2)  Applicant's experience in the transportation of passengers, if any. 
(3)  Applicant's educational background. 
(4)  Applicant's employment history. 
(5)  Two recent photographs of the applicant of a size which may be easily attached to the license, one of which shall be attached to the license if issued, and the other to be retained with the application. 
(6)  A certificate not more than two months old from a physician licensed to practice in the state certifying that, in his opinion, the applicant does not have any disease, infirmity or condition which would be reasonably likely to create an unsafe condition if the applicant were to engage in the transportation of passengers. 
(7)  The identification number of a valid Wisconsin motor vehicle operator's permit and a Wisconsin commercial driver's license, if applicable. 
(c)  Police investigation of applicant. The police department shall conduct an investigation of each applicant for a public passenger vehicle driver's license or a renewal thereof. A report of such investigation and a copy of that part of the police record which reasonably relates to employment under this article shall be attached to the application, returned to the city clerk and then referred to the committee for action. The police chief may authorize issuance of a temporary permit to an applicant upon preliminary approval of the application, which permit shall allow the applicant to drive a public passenger vehicle pending final action on the application. 
(d)  [License issuance prohibited.] No license shall be issued to any applicant who has an OWI conviction within the previous two years or two or more convictions within the previous five years. 
(e)  Action on application. The committee shall, upon consideration of the application, grant or recommend denial of the public passenger vehicle driver's license. A recommendation for denial shall be reported, along with the reasons therefor, to the common council for final action. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.130(a)—(d), 10-20-92; Ord. No. 12-94, pt. 3, 5-17-94; Ord. No. 52-04, pt. 11, 1-18-05; Ord. No. 06-15, pts. 1, 2, 5-5-15)  
Sec. 22-1067. - Same—Issuance; fee. 
(a)  After the committee grants a public passenger vehicle driver's license, the city clerk shall issue a license bearing the name, address, age, photograph and signature of the applicant. Each such license shall expire on December 31 of the year it is issued. 
(b)  The license fee for a new or renewal public passenger vehicle driver's license as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council shall be submitted with the application for such license. If the applicant is denied a license or withdraws the application during processing, $5.00 of such fee shall be refunded. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.130(e), (f), 10-20-92; Ord. No. 44-04, pt. 18, 12-7-04; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 64, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 22-1068. - Same—Suspension and revocation. 
If a person holding a driver's license issued under this division becomes unable to safely work in the field of public passenger transportation due to a physical condition or is charged with or convicted of an offense which reasonably relates to such employment, the committee may hold a hearing to determine whether such license should be suspended or revoked. Notice of such hearing shall be provided to the licensee, who shall be advised of the time and place of the hearing, the reason for the hearing, the licensee's right to call, examine and cross examine witnesses and to have the proceedings recorded at the licensee's own expense. Such license may be suspended for a period of not more than 60 days, or revoked if the committee determines that the public safety so requires. Pending such hearing, the license may be temporarily suspended for a period of up to 30 days if the committee deems such action necessary in the interest of public safety. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.130(g), 10-20-92)  
Sec. 22-1069. - Display of license. 
Any driver while operating a vehicle licensed under this article shall display his city driver's license in a location clearly visible to the passengers. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.140(a), 10-20-92)  
Sec. 22-1070. - Receipt and discharge of passengers. 
Drivers of public passenger vehicles shall not receive or discharge passengers in the roadway, but shall pull up to the righthand sidewalk as nearly as possible or, in the absence of a sidewalk, to the extreme righthand side of the road, and there receive or discharge passengers, except upon one-way streets, where passengers may be discharged at either the righthand or lefthand sidewalk or side of the roadway in the absence of a sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.140(b), 10-20-92)  
Sec. 22-1071. - Additional passengers; restriction on number of passengers. 
(a)  No driver shall permit any other person to occupy or ride in a taxicab, luxury limousine or horse and surrey unless the person first employing such vehicle shall consent to the acceptance of such additional passengers. 
(b)  No driver shall permit more persons to be carried in a public passenger vehicle than the rated seating capacity of such vehicle as stated in the license therefor. A child less than five years of age seated in the lap of an adult shall not be considered as a passenger. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.140(c), (d), 10-20-92)  
Sec. 22-1072. - Refusal to carry orderly passengers prohibited. 
No driver of a public passenger vehicle shall refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person upon [a] called-in request, unless previously engaged or unable or forbidden by the provisions of this article to do so, except that handicapped-elderly vehicles shall limit passengers based on such categories. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.140(e), 10-20-92; Ord. No. 3-06, pt. 3, 2-24-06)  
Sec. 22-1073. - Radio equipment. 
Every vehicle operating as a taxicab licensed under this article shall be equipped with two-way communication capable of maintaining continual communication with the operator's dispatcher. Such equipment shall be in proper working order at all times that the vehicle is in operation as a taxicab. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.140(f), 10-20-92; Ord. No. 3-06, pt. 4, 2-24-06)  
Sec. 22-1074. - Hours of drivers. 
No person may require any other person driving a public passenger vehicle upon the public streets to work more than 12 hours in every 24 hours. Such 12 hours of operation shall be split by an intermission of one to four hours off-duty. Every driver shall have at least 24 consecutive hours off each week. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.140(g), 10-20-92)  
Secs. 22-1075—22-1085. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - VEHICLES 
 
Sec. 22-1086. - Inspections. 
(a)  Certificate of inspection. No vehicle shall be operated as a public passenger vehicle under the provisions of this article unless the licensee has filed with the city clerk a certificate from a motor vehicle repair business which is legally engaged in such business in the state, or from state authorities, stating the seating capacity of the vehicle and certifying that the vehicle was inspected on the date indicated and that it complies with all applicable requirements of Wis. Stat. ch. 347, and Wis. Admin. Code ch. MVD 5, excepting that providers providing public passenger services under contract with the city shall not be required to obtain inspections under the provisions of this division. A copy of the certificate shall be carried in the vehicle at all times. The certificate shall be valid for one year from the date of inspection, subject to reinspection upon complaint or upon random inspection. Upon the filing of such certificate, the city clerk shall issue two decals for such vehicle, to be affixed in the manner provided herein. If the police department finds that any vehicle licensed under this article is unfit or unsuited for public use, the vehicle shall be immediately suspended from service. The licensee shall not use any vehicle under this article unless a valid certificate of inspection has been issued in accordance with this section and is present in such vehicle, and current decals issued by the city clerk for such vehicle have been affixed to the vehicle's bumpers at the left front and left rear, or the left front and left rear of a surrey. 
(b)  Random inspections. Any licensee under this article may be directed to present a licensed vehicle to the police department for inspection on a random selection basis or when identified by complaint. The licensee shall be notified by mail as to the inspection date and time at least two days prior to the inspection. Failure to submit a vehicle for inspection at the appointed time shall result in the immediate suspension of the license with respect to such vehicle. The licensee shall be notified of such suspension by certified mail and a special inspection fee as set forth in the fee schedule and established by the common council shall be charged for any rescheduled inspection for such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.120(a), (b), 10-20-92; Ord. No. 24-93, pt. 2, 10-5-93; Ord. No. 52-04, pt. 12, 1-18-05; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 65, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 22-1087. - Condition. 
Every vehicle operating under this article shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.120(c), 10-20-92)  
Sec. 22-1088. - Identification. 
(a)  Every vehicle licensed and operated as a taxicab under this article shall bear on the outside of either the front or rear doors, in letters not less than four inches in height, the word "taxi," "cab" or "taxicab." Also shown on the same doors, in letters not less than two inches in height and one-quarter-inch in stroke, shall be the name of the owner (company name). The company logo or identifying design may be contained on the same door. The telephone number of the taxicab company shall be provided in at least four-inch numerals and may be shown on either the vehicle doors or fenders. 
(b)  No vehicle operation under this article shall be licensed whose color scheme, identifying design, monogram or insignia to be used thereon shall conflict with or imitate those used on any other vehicle already operating under this article, in such a manner to be misleading or tend to deceive or defraud the public, nor shall the colors, monogram or identifying markings be such as to cause confusion with or imitate the markings used on police or other emergency vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.120(d), 10-20-92; Ord. No. 52-04, pt. 13, 1-18-05)  
Sec. 22-1089. - Taximeters. 
(a)  No taxicab operating with a taximeter shall be operated under this article until the city sealer of weights and measures has examined the taximeter attached to the vehicle and found it to meet the following requirements: 
(1)  The taximeter shall not be in error more than one percent in deficiency or more than four percent in excess of the interval under test. 
(2)  The face of the taximeter shall be capable of illumination by a suitable light, so arranged as to throw a continual steady light thereon, which light shall be illuminated after sundown. 
(3)  The taximeter case is sealed and its cover and gear are intact. 
(b)  Taximeters shall not be transferred between vehicles without permission of the city sealer of weights and measures. 
(c)  The certificate of the city sealer of weights and measures showing compliance with this section shall be carried in each taxicab at all times. A new certificate shall be required prior to licensing and renewal of any license under this article. 
(Ord. No. 33-92, pt. 1, § 22.17.120(e), 10-20-92; Ord. No. 4-99, pt. 5, 3-2-99; Ord. No. 52-04, pt. 14, 1-18-05)  
Secs. 22-1090—22-1110. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XXIX. - RACETRACKS 
 
Sec. 22-1111. - Prohibition. 
No person shall operate or sponsor a racetrack for vehicles propelled by internal combustion engines, or participate in or take part in the operation of such a racetrack or in any race involving any such vehicle, or race or operate any such vehicle on a racetrack within the city. The phrase "vehicles propelled by internal combustion engines" shall include, but shall not be limited to, vehicles commonly known as go-carts. 
(Code 1973, § 22.21.010)  
Secs. 22-1112—22-1130. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XXX. - STATIONARY ENGINEER  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 22-1131. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
ASME means the American Society of Mechanical Engineers' Boiler and Unfired Pressure Vessel Code. 
ASOPE means the American Society of Power Engineers. 
Automatically controlled boiler means a boiler equipped with the following safety devices: 
(1)  In the case of a low pressure boiler other than a hot water boiler: 
a.  An automatic low water fuel cutoff installed in compliance with COMM 41.30 or ASME section HG-605. 
b.  A pressure combustion regulator installed in compliance with ASME section HG-604. 
c.  Electrical wiring, circuitry and controls, installed in compliance with ASME sections HG-631, HG-632 and HG-633 and including a manually operated remote heating plant shutdown switch or circuit breaker installed outside the boiler room. 
d.  Controls and heat generating apparatus installed in compliance with ASME section HG-640. 
e.  Pressure gauges installed in compliance with ASME section HG-601. 
f.  Water level indicators and water level controls installed in compliance with ASME section HG-603. 
(2)  In the case of a hot water boiler: 
a.  An automatic low water fuel cutoff installed in compliance with COMM 41.30 or in compliance with ASME section HG-614. 
b.  A temperature combustion regulator installed in compliance with ASME section HG-613. 
c.  Electrical wiring, circuitry and controls installed in compliance with ASME sections HG-631, HG-632 and HG-633, including a manually operated remote heating shutdown switch or circuit breaker installed outside the boiler room. 
d.  Controls and heat generating apparatus installed in compliance with ASME section HG-640. 
e.  Pressure or altitude gauges installed in compliance with ASME section HG-611. 
f.  Thermometers installed in compliance with ASME section HG-612. 
(3)  In the case of a high pressure boiler: 
a.  An automatic low water fuel cutoff installed in compliance with COMM 41.30 or in compliance with ASME section C6.301(b). 
b.  A pressure combustion regulator installed in compliance with ASME section C6.301(a). 
c.  Electrical wiring, circuitry and controls for the operation of the boiler or boilers installed in compliance with the state and city electrical codes. 
d.  An automatic fuel-trip device installed in compliance with ASME section C6.201(13), C6.201(14) or C6.201(15). 
e.  Pressure gauges installed in compliance with ASME section PG-60(f). 
f.  Water level indicators installed in compliance with ASME section PG-60(a). 
Boiler means any device intended for use in heating water or other fluids, under pressure in order to generate steam or other vapors. 
Boiler horsepower means a unit equivalent to a maximum fuel input of 40,000 Btu's per hour, or a maximum electrical input of ten kilowatts per hour. 
COMM means the Wisconsin Administrative Code Rules of the Department of Commerce. 
High pressure boiler means a boiler on which the safety valves are set at a pressure of more than 15 psig and that exceeds the dimensions of a miniature boiler. 
Hot water heating boiler orhydronic boiler means a boiler in which no steam is generated from which hot water is circulated for heating purposes and then returned to the boiler and which operates at a pressure not exceeding 160 psig or a temperature of 250 degrees Fahrenheit at or near the boiler outlet. 
Low pressure boiler means a boiler on which the safety valves are set at pressures not exceeding 15 psig. 
Miniature boiler means a power boiler or high temperature water boiler which does not exceed any of the following limits: 
(1)  Sixteen inches inside diameter of shell; 
(2)  Twenty square feet of heating surface, except for electric boilers; 
(3)  Five cubic feet gross volume exclusive of casing and insulation; 
(4)  One hundred psig maximum allowable working pressure. 
(Ord. No. 31-92, pt. 1, § 22.18.010, 10-20-92; Ord. No. 33-03, pt. 1, 1-20-04; Ord. No. 28-09, pt. 1, 2-2-10) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 22-1132. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Upon conviction, any person found to be in violation of this article shall forfeit an amount as provided in section 1-15. 
(Ord. No. 31-92, pt. 1, § 22.18.130, 10-20-92; Ord. No. 33-03, pt. 1, 1-20-04)  
Sec. 22-1133. - Smoke indicating devices required. 
The stationary engineer shall ensure that the owner or operator of every power and heating plant, except those under ten horsepower which are not required to have a licensed operator, shall provide means whereby the stationary engineer may be able to know, without leaving the boiler or furnace room, whether or not prohibited smoke is issuing from the stack, so that possible necessary correction may be made at the time. Such means of observation shall be by either: 
(1)  A window or other opening through which an unobstructed view of the top of the stack may be had from the boiler or furnace room; 
(2)  A mirror so placed as to reflect the top of the stack and be visible from the boiler or furnace room; or 
(3)  A smoke indicator, alarm or recorder, approved by the examining board of stationary engineers; if such boiler exceeds 50 horsepower but is less than 300 horsepower, such means of observation shall be either a smoke indicator or alarm if such boiler exceeds 300 horsepower, a recorder shall be used. For the purpose of this section, 12 square feet of boiler heating surface shall be equivalent to one horsepower. 
(Code 1973, § 11.21.010; Ord. No. 33-03, pt. 1, 1-20-04)  
Secs. 22-1134—22-1145. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - RESERVED[28]

No. 28-09, pt. 2, adopted Feb. 2, 2010. 
 
Secs. 22-1146—22-1160. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - STATIONARY ENGINEERS PERMIT TO OPERATE[29] 

Footnotes: 
--- (29) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 5-11, pt. 1, adopted Aug. 1, 2011, amended Div. 3 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former Div. 3, §§ 22-1161—22-1168, pertained to license and derived from Ord. No. 31-92, pt. 1, §§ 22.18.020, 22.18.050, 22.18.060, 22.18.090, 22.18.110, adopted Oct. 20, 1992; Ord. No. 33-03, pt. 1, adopted Jan. 20, 2004; Ord. No. 28-09, pt. 3, adopted Feb. 2, 2010; Ord. No. 8-10, pt. 1, adopted May 18, 2010. 
 
Sec. 22-1161. - Required. 
No person shall operate, control, manage or commit to be operated any stationary boiler, engine or any portion of a steam plant or appliances connected therewith when working under pressure except those boilers exempt under COMM 41.18, and except as follows: 
(1)  An engineer or an assistant engineer with an appropriate valid stationary engineers permit to operate under this article who is in full-time attendance in the boiler room may operate a manually controlled boiler. 
(2)  An engineer or an assistant engineer holding an appropriate valid stationary engineers permit to operate under this article may operate an automatically controlled boiler provided that such person is periodically in attendance in the boiler room on at least a daily basis, except that for high pressure plants an engineer or assistant engineer shall be in constant attendance if any persons, other than boiler personnel, are present in the building in which the boiler is located. 
(Ord. No. 5-11, pt. 1, 8-1-11)  
Sec. 22-1162. - Application. 
A verified application for a permit to perform work as an engineer in the city shall be made on forms furnished by the city clerk. The applicant shall list education and work experience relating to the operation of boiler plants. Applications for stationary engineers permit to operate should contain the name of the engineer in charge of the plant where the applicant worked, whenever possible, or include two signed professional work references verifying experience as a stationary engineer. 
(Ord. No. 5-11, pt. 1, 8-1-11)  
Sec. 22-1163. - Qualifications; fees; temporary license. 
(a)  Application for a permit to operate under this article may be made by any person holding an American Society of Power Engineers (ASOPE) license. The city clerk shall determine applicants particular classification of permit based on the corresponding ASOPE classifications. The city's permit classifications shall correspond to the ASOPE classifications with the exceptions in paragraphs (b), (c) and (d) of this section. 
(b)  No permit under this article shall be granted to an applicant unless such person has held the next inferior license and has been actively employed in duties thereunder for a period of one year. The permit shall be prominently displayed in a conspicuous place in the boiler room or power plant at the engineers place of employment. 
(c)  An applicant for a second class facility operations engineer's permit shall present evidence of successful completion of a stationary engineer's course at an accredited technical school or training program and shall present evidence of successful completion of the ASOPE second class facility operations engineer's exam. 
(d)  A third class facility operations engineers permit may be applied for by any person who meets all qualifications under subsection (b) of this section, if the first ten-week phase of the accredited course has been successfully completed and the ASOPE examination has been passed. 
(Ord. No. 5-11, pt. 1, 8-1-11)  
Sec. 22-1164. - Classes of stationary engineer permits to operate. 
Six stationary engineer permits to operate classes are specified in this section. A permit shall authorize the holder to take charge of, operate and manage the equipment indicated, except that a holder of any class of permit may operate equipment one class in excess of such permit if such engineer is an assistant to an engineer holding the next superior permit. 
(1)  Chief power plant engineers permit: Low pressure steam or hydronic plant of any size; a high pressure plant of any size and a steam motive power plant of any size. 
(2)  First class power plant engineers permit: Low pressure steam or hydronic plant of any size; a high pressure plant not exceeding 1,500 BHP; and steam motive power plant not exceeding 7,500 HP. 
(3)  Second class power plant engineers permit: A low pressure steam or hydronic plant of any size; a high pressure plant not exceeding 500 BHP; a steam motive power plant not exceeding 2,500 HP. 
(4)  Third class power plant operations engineers permit: A low pressure steam or hydronic plant of any size; a high pressure plant not exceeding 300 HP; a steam motive power plant not exceeding 1,000 HP. 
(5)  Second class facility operations engineer permit: A low pressure steam plant or a hydronic plant of any size; a high pressure steam plant not exceeding 110 BHP or a steam motive power plant not exceeding 500 BHP. 
(6)  Third class facility operations engineer permit: A low pressure steam or hydronic plant not exceeding 150 BHP; a high pressure steam plant not exceeding 25 BHP. 
The city's permit classifications shall correspond to the following NIULPE or ASOPE classifications: 
Racine Stationary Engineers Permit 	ASOPE License 
Third Class Facility Operations Engineers Permit 	Facility Operating Engineer Third Class 
Second Class Facility Operations Engineers 
 Permit 	Facility Operating Engineer Second Class 
Third Class Power Plant Operations Engineers 
 Permit 	Power Plant Operating Engineer Third Class or 
 Facility Operating Engineer First Class 
Second Class Power Engineers Permit 	Power Plant Operating Engineer Second Class 
First Class Power Plant Engineers Permit 	Power Plant Operating Engineer First Class 
Chief Power Engineers Permit 	Power Plant Operating Engineer Chief or 
 Master Chief Operating Engineer 
 
(Ord. No. 5-11, pt. 1, 8-1-11)  
Sec. 22-1165. - Granting of license; renewal. 
An applicant shall be granted a stationary engineer permit by the city clerk if the applicant possess a valid nonexpired ASOPE license of the appropriate classification for the permit class being applied for, has submitted a fully completed application, verifies their identification using a picture identification and pays a fee as set forth in the fee schedule and established by the common council. A permit is valid for one year from date of issue. 
The stationary engineer's permit shall be annually renewed without further examination upon payment to the city clerk of a renewal fee as set forth in the fee schedule and showing the person possess a valid nonexpired ASOPE license of the appropriate classification for the permit class being renewed. 
The permit shall be prominently displayed in a conspicuous place in the boiler room or power plant an engineer's place of employment. 
(Ord. No. 5-11, pt. 1, 8-1-11; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 66, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 22-1166. - Reserved.  
Sec. 22-1167. - Temporary absence of a permitted engineer. 
In all cases of temporary absence(s), an engineer with a lower class permit may take charge of a plant requiring a higher permit classification not greater than one class under this article, provided that such engineer may not act in such capacity for a period of more than 30 days. 
(Ord. No. 5-11, pt. 1, 8-1-11)  
Sec. 22-1168. - Revocation. 
In order to provide for the public health, safety and welfare, the city clerk may have an investigation conducted to revoke or suspend any permit issued under this article if the engineer fails to implement proper maintenance and operating procedures in accordance with COMM 41 and 42; or for an unnecessary absence from the licensee's post of duty; or for any violation of the substantive provisions of this article, or for any other neglect or incapacity which impairs the licensee's abilities to perform the duties required by COMM 41 and 42 and this article. Within five days after such revocation, the engineer may petition the city clerk for a hearing on the matter, The city clerk may appoint a hearing panel of no more than three persons who hold an ASOPE Chief Power Plant Engineer or higher license. Which hearing shall be held within 30 days following such petition. At the hearing, testimony shall be given under oath and the city clerk's witnesses and the engineers witnesses shall testify under oath subject to cross-examination. The panel shall make findings and conclusions in writing and provide them to the city clerk for action within five business days following such hearing. The city clerk shall notify the engineer of said findings within five business days of receipt of the finding and conclusions. 
(Ord. No. 5-11, pt. 1, 8-1-11)  
Secs. 22-1169—22-1190. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XXXI. - REGULATION OF TATTOOING AND BODY PIERCING[30] 
Footnotes: 
--- (30) --- 
Editor's note— Prior to the reenactment of art. XIII by Ord. No. 5-04, part 2 of Ord. No. 17-97, adopted Oct. 22, 1997, repealed §§ 22-1191 and 22-1192 in their entirety. The former §§ 22-1191 and 22-1192 pertained to tattooing and derived from §§ 22.22.010 and 22.22.020 of the 1973 Code. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 22-1191. - Adoption by reference. 
Chapter HFS 173, Wis. Admin. Code and Wis. Stats. §§ 252.23(5) and 252.24(5), and all subsequent amendments, additions and recodifications thereto are hereby adopted by reference. It is the intent of the city that where there may be conflict between this subsection and the remainder of this section that the most stringent provision shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 5-04, pt. 1, 2-18-04)  
Sec. 22-1192. - Definitions. 
Words and phrases in this section have the meanings designated in Chapter HFS 173, Wis. Admin. Code, unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning with the following additions or modifications for use in this section only: 
Department means the city health department. 
Establishment means an entity comprised of one or more practitioners, organized as a corporation, limited liability company, partnership, sole practitioner or other association operating in a single building, structure, area or location at which tattoos are applied or body piercing is performed or all of the above. The establishment area shall be separately maintained from other business activities. 
Patron means a person receiving a tattoo or body piercing. 
Person means an individual, partnership, limited liability company, corporation, association, or other entity. 
Special event means a show, bazaar, fair or other occurrence lasting up to a maximum of seven consecutive days at which a collection of establishments practice their art in a single location, whether public or private premises. 
Tattoo means, as a noun, an indelible mark or design on a person created by inserting pigment under the surface of the person's skin by a needle prick or other means of puncture. 
Temporary combined establishment means a temporary establishment at which both tattooing and body piercing are performed. 
Temporary establishment means an establishment operating at a special event. 
(Ord. No. 5-04, pt. 1, 2-18-04)  
Sec. 22-1193. - Tattooing and piercing. 
When tattooing or body piercing with a needle, the tattooist or piercer must comply with the requirements found in Chapter HFS 173, Wis. Admin. Code. 
(1)  Environment. Floors shall be constructed of smooth, durable and non-porous material and shall be maintained in clean condition and in good repair. Carpeting is prohibited. The establishments shall provide access to public toilets and handwashing facilities. Easily cleanable waste containers with non-absorbent durable plastic liners shall be used for disposal of all tissues, towels and similar items used on patrons. Equipment shall be stored in closed cabinets exclusively used for that purpose. Establishments shall be maintained in a clean, sanitary and vermin-free condition. No smoking or consumption of food or drink is permitted in the area where the piercing or tattooing is performed. 
(2)  Personnel. No person with an exposed rash, skin lesion, boil or who is under the influence of alcohol or a mind-altering drug may engage in tattooing or body piercing. 
(Ord. No. 5-04, pt. 1, 2-18-04)  
Sec. 22-1194. - Enforcement. 
Enforcement procedures shall be in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 66.0417. The department's administrator of this article may utilize city health sanitarians to enforce any aspect of this article by appropriate inspections and the issuance of appropriate orders. 
(Ord. No. 5-04, pt. 1, 2-18-04)  
Sec. 22-1195. - Appeal. 
Any person affected by any notice or order which has been issued in connection with the enforcement of any of the provisions of this article may, within the time given for correction, request, and shall thereafter be granted, an informal review of the situation by the health officer. If the person is not satisfied with the health officer's review, within ten days of receiving written notice of the outcome of that review, a hearing before the health and sanitation appeal board created in section 2-236 et seq., may be requested, provided the request is submitted in writing on a form provided by the health officer. Enforcement of any order issued by the health officer shall be stayed pending decision on any appeal therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 5-04, pt. 1, 2-18-04)  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 22-1196. - Required. 
(a)  Establishment. No person may operate a tattoo or body-piercing establishment or combination thereof on an annual or temporary basis unless the person has obtained a license and paid fees as specified in this section: 
(1)  Licensing. Application for licensing shall be made 30 days prior to issuance. The licensing year shall be from July 1 through the following June 30. Renewal licenses shall be obtained on or before June 30 of each year or be subject to a late fee as set forth in the fee schedule and established by the common council. Payment of the late fee shall not relieve any person from any other penalties set forth in this section or in the ordinances for failure to possess or obtain a license. A license shall not be issued or renewed by the department unless the person or establishment is in full compliance with the terms of this article, HFS 173, Wis. Admin. Code, and any applicable board of health regulation, as may hereinafter be amended. A license issued under this section is not transferable. 
(2)  Temporary licensing. At special events every separate table or booth or area shall be considered a temporary establishment and must be licensed as such before the onset of the event. Every practitioner must possess a current and valid State of Wisconsin practitioner license issued by the state or other state municipality acting on behalf of the state before the practitioner can operate at a special event. An application for a temporary license shall be submitted to the city environmental health office 30 days prior to the special event to allow for processing. 
(b)  Practitioner. No person may tattoo or body pierce another person, use or assume the title of tattooist or body piercer unless the person has obtained a current and valid practitioner license from the state department of health and family services or other state municipality acting on behalf of the state. 
(Ord. No. 5-04, pt. 1, 2-18-04; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 67, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 22-1197. - Fees. 
(a)  Annual establishment fees. Annual establishment fees shall be set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council for the following: 
(1)  Tattoo or body piercing establishments; 
(2)  Combined tattoo and body-piercing establishments; 
(3)  Preinspection, one time only. 
(b)  Temporary establishment fees. Temporary establishment fees shall be set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council for the following: 
(1)  Tattoo or body-piercing establishments, or combined; first day; 
(2)  Tattoo or body-piercing establishments, or combined; each day after first day. 
(Ord. No. 5-04, pt. 1, 2-18-04; Ord. No. 44-04, pt. 19, 12-7-04; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 68, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 22-1198. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person who violates any provision of this article may be fined not less than $25.00, nor more than $500.00. Each day of violation and every violation of any provision of this article may constitute a separate offence. 
(b)  In addition to the above penalties, the department may order to suspend or revoke the license issued to a practitioner or an establishment under this section. 
(c)  Wis. Stats. § 66.0417(5)(b), regarding the impeding of city inspectors in the performance of their duties and the giving of false information to such inspectors, and all subsequent amendments, additions and recodifications thereto are hereby adopted by reference. 
(Ord. No. 5-04, pt. 1, 2-18-04)  
Secs. 22-1199—22-1220. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XXXII. - NEWS BOXES[31] 

Footnotes: 
--- (31) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 24-04, pt. 1, adopted Sept. 7, 2004, enacted provisions designated as Art. XXXI of Ch. 22. Inasmuch as Ch. 22 already contained an Art. XXXI, the editor has redesignated the provisions of Ord. No. 24-04 as Art. XXXII. 
 
Sec. 22-1221. - Generally. 
(a)  Purpose. To promote public health, safety, and welfare through the regulation of placement, appearance, maintenance, and insuring of news boxes in the public right-of-way. 
(b)  Applicability. The provisions of this article shall apply to all news boxes, whether installed and maintained prior to or after the effective date of any of the provisions of this article. Those news boxes installed prior to the effective date of this article shall be brought into compliance within 30 days of the effective date thereof. 
(c)  Definitions. For the purpose of this article, the following words shall have the meaning indicated: 
News box shall mean any coin-operated or self-service box, container, or other dispenser placed in the public right-of-way for the vending of, or free distribution of newspapers or other publications. 
Person shall mean any individual, corporation, company, association, firm, partnership, limited liability company or partnership, or other business entity and their lessors, transferees, and receivers. 
Public right-of-way shall mean the surface and space above and below an improved or unimproved public roadway, highway, street, bicycle lane and public sidewalk in which the city has an interest, including other dedicated right-of-way for travel purposes. 
(Ord. No. 24-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 22-1222. - Permit. 
(a)  Administration. This section is administered by the department of public works. 
(b)  Application. Application for a yearly permit shall be made to the commissioner of public works. A permit shall be issued within ten days of the receipt of complete application materials. A complete application shall include: 
(1)  The name, address, and telephone number of the applicant. 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number of local contact. 
(3)  A certificate of insurance showing general liability insurance, including property damage, in the amount of $1,000,000.00 per occurrence and naming the city as an additional insured. 
(4)  An agreement, in a form acceptable to the city, that the applicant will hold harmless, defend, and indemnify the city, its officers, boards, committees, commissions, elected officials, employees and agents from and against all liability, damages, and penalties resulting from the installation, use, maintenance, or presence of the applicant's news box(es) in the public right-of-way. 
(5)  Listing of location of all newspaper boxes. 
(6)  An annual permit fee as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council per box is due January 1 of each year. 
(Ord. No. 24-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 69, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 22-1223. - Standards. 
Every person shall install and maintain all news boxes as follows: 
(1)  No person may place a news box in the public right-of-way without having obtained a permit. 
(2)  No news box shall be placed at any location where the clear space for the passageway of pedestrians is reduced to less than five feet. 
(3)  No chaining, bolting, or other means shall be used to attach a news box to any property or facilities within the public right-of-way without prior express written permission of the owner. 
(4)  News boxes shall be maintained in a safe, clean, and neat condition and in good repair at all times. 
(5)  There shall be two or more feet of open area behind any curb face. 
(6)  There shall be three or more feet of open area behind the curb face at any loading zone or other place where parking is prohibited or where stopping, standing or parking is otherwise restricted, including metered parking areas. 
(7)  There shall be at least five feet between any news box and any driveway opening, fire hydrant, police or fire call box or other emergency facility. 
(8)  There shall be at least ten feet between any news box and any fire station driveway, railroad signal gate, intersecting property line at an intersection, and marked or unmarked crosswalks. 
(9)  A clear area shall be maintained at bus shelter openings and on the street side of bus shelters; in no case shall a news box be placed closer than five feet from a bus shelter. 
(10)  No news box shall be used for advertising signs or publicity purpose other than that dealing with the display, sale, or purchase of the material sold or available within, or of an activity sponsored by the publication. Allowable advertising, other than the name of the publication, shall appear only once, shall be on the side of the news box facing away from the street, and shall not exceed 18 inches by 18 inches. 
(11)  No news box may be attached to any sidewalk surface unless approved by the commissioner of public works. 
(12)  No news box may block any exit or entrance to a building. 
(13)  All news boxes in the following areas shall be constructed of sheet metal and shall be painted black: Washington Avenue from 13th Street to Phillips Avenue. 
(14)  No news box shall be placed within 125 feet of the Main Street right-of-way between State Street and 7th Street, with the exception of city-owned news boxes. 
(15)  No news box shall remain empty of current publications for more than 14 consecutive days. 
(16)  Any news box shall be removed upon ten days' written notice to the person named on the application for any lawful governmental purpose, including, but not limited to, right-of-way repair. 
(Ord. No. 24-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 22-1224. - Enforcement. 
The department of public works shall enforce this article. 
(1)  A notice of violation issued from the department of public works shall specify the nature of any violation and the location of the news box in violation. 
(2)  Any person aggrieved by orders from the department of public works may appeal to the public works and services committee within 15 days after the mailing of the notice of violation(s). Such appeal must be in writing and must inform the committee of the reasons why the person aggrieved believes the orders have been issued in error. Within 30 days after receipt of the request for appeal, the committee shall hold a hearing at which the parties may offer testimony and documents. Within 14 days of the hearing, the committee shall affirm, modify, or reverse the orders of the department of public works. A concurring vote of two-thirds of the voting members present shall be required to modify or reverse an order. No further enforcement action shall take place during the pendency of an appeal. 
(3)  Failure to correct a violation of section 22-1223 or request a hearing by filing an appeal under subsection (b) may result in a news box being removed. Thirty days after notice of removal is mailed, a news box is subject to disposal. 
(4)  Any person violating any provision of this article shall be subject to a forfeiture of not less than $25.00 nor more than $500.00. Each day such violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 24-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Secs. 22-1225—22-1250. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE XXXIII. - CHRISTMAS TREE LOTS AND STANDS[32] 

Footnotes: 
--- (32) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 39-04, pt. 1, adopted Nov. 3, 2004, set out provisions intended for use as Art. XXXII of Ch. 22. Inasmuch as the provisions of Ord. No. 24-04 were included as Art. XXXII of Ch. 22, the editor has included the provisions of Ord. No. 39-04 as Art. XXXIII. 
 
Sec. 22-1251. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the following meanings, except where the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
Christmas trees means those trees of the varieties and kinds used for decorative purposes, usually during the Christmas season, and which have been cut and are no longer attached to the soil. 
Public street means that property set aside for street purposes or street rights-of-way, including sidewalks, curbs, parkways, shoulders, parking strips and alleys. 
(Ord. No. 39-04, pt. 1, 11-3-04)  
Sec. 22-1252. - License required for storage, sale or display. 
No person shall operate any place in the city for the purpose of storing, selling or displaying for sale Christmas trees without first obtaining a license from the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 39-04, pt. 1, 11-3-04)  
Sec. 22-1253. - Application for license. 
Application for the license shall be made to the city clerk, and shall state the ordinary use to which the premises or location has been devoted immediately prior to and at the time of the making of application, the type and character of any business carried on at such premises or location, an accurate description of the premises or location to be licensed, and the name of the applicant, if an individual, or all of the partners, if a partnership, or, if a corporation, the names of its principal officers, and the name of one or more persons whom the corporation shall designate as manager or person in charge, together with their address or addresses. Each application shall state that the applicant consents to the entry of authorized representatives of the city upon the premises or location at all reasonable hours for the purpose of inspection. 
(Ord. No. 39-04, pt. 1, 11-3-04)  
Sec. 22-1254. - License fee; term; transfer. 
The fee for a license issued under this article shall be as established by the common council. The license shall expire at midnight on January 3 following the date of issuance. Each location at which Christmas trees are stored, displayed or sold requires a separate license. No license issued under this article shall be transferable either as to person or location. 
(Ord. No. 39-04, pt. 1, 11-3-04; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 70, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 22-1255. - Regulations. 
(a)  The license issued under this article shall be prominently displayed on the licensed premises or location at all times when such premises or location are being used for the purposes for which the license is issued. 
(b)  No Christmas tree shall be displayed, stored or sold on any public street, and all Christmas trees shall be stored and displayed in such manner that they will not fall upon the public sidewalk or street. 
(c)  No Christmas tree shall be stored or displayed inside any building or within 15 feet of any building, gasoline pump or dispenser, or any motor vehicle, unless otherwise permitted herein. 
(d)  All outside electric wiring used on the premises or location licensed under this article shall be installed to conform with Order No. 13-7321 of the National Electrical Code and when portable electric cords are used, they shall be hard service cords as specified in Table 31 of the National Electrical Code. 
(e)  At the expiration of the license, and by midnight of January 10 following the date of issue, the licensee under this article shall cause all trimmings, cuttings, trees and debris to be removed from the premises and disposed of in a lawful manner. Failure to comply with this provision shall be adequate reason to deny further license of the property for the purpose of Christmas tree sales, or of the offending licensee to secure such a license. 
(f)  All premises licensed under this article shall be maintained in such manner as to eliminate insofar as reasonably possible any fire hazard. 
(g)  Christmas trees which have become dried out shall not be kept on the licensed premises. 
(Ord. No. 39-04, pt. 1, 11-3-04)  
Sec. 22-1256. - Flocking of Christmas trees and decorations. 
(a)  If premises are to be used for flocking operations, the applicant for a license under this article must so state in the license application. 
(b)  Christmas trees and decorations may be flocked in a room or building separated from other occupancies so as not to create a fire or life hazard. Open flames and heating plants shall be separated from the areas where flocking operations are performed. No area may be used for flocking operations except upon prior written approval of the chief of the bureau of fire prevention. 
(c)  The use of wool or cotton flock, or adhesives that are not flame-retardant, is prohibited. No material shall be used for flocking of Christmas trees or decorations without prior approval of the chief of the bureau of fire prevention. 
(d)  Each tree or decoration that is flocked with flame-retarding flocking and flame-retarding adhesive shall have a tag affixed to it which shall bear the following: 
(1)  Name of applicator. 
(2)  Date of the application of the chemical. 
(3)  Kind of chemical used (trade name and symbol). 
(Ord. No. 39-04, pt. 1, 11-3-04)  
Sec. 22-1257. - Approval of premises; deposit. 
All premises to be licensed hereunder shall be inspected and approved by the chief building inspector or designee before a license under this article is granted by the city clerk. Every person at the time of making application for a license under this article shall pay the license fee, and in addition thereto shall post with the city clerk a certified check or cash in the sum of $50.00 payable to the city, which check shall be returned to the applicant on or before January 10 following, provided the chief building inspector shall have certified to the city clerk the fact that the licensee has fully complied with the provisions of section 22-1255. The city clerk shall on or before December 24 of such year prepare a list of premises or locations licensed under this article and forward such list to the chief building inspector who shall as soon as practicable after December 25 inspect all premises or locations licensed under this article and certify to the city clerk the names of those licensees who have fully complied with this article and are entitled to the return of the deposit referred to in this section. If the licensee fails to properly clean the premises upon removal or fails to maintain the premises in a manner as to eliminate any fire hazard, the chief building inspector is authorized to enter upon the premises and remove or destroy, or cause to be removed or destroyed, such Christmas trees or parts thereof which may create a fire hazard, and the cost of such removal shall be deducted from the amount placed on deposit with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 39-04, pt. 1, 11-3-04)  
ARTICLE XXXIV. - PRODUCE CARTS 
 
Sec. 22-1258. - Intent. 
It is the intent of the city in enacting this ordinance to promote residents' access to fresh produce by implementing a fresh produce cart program. 
(Ord. No. 07-14, pt. 1, 6-17-14)  
Sec. 22-1259. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to promote the health of the community by increasing access to fresh produce. 
(Ord. No. 07-14, pt. 1, 6-17-14)  
Sec. 22-1260. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, whenever used in this article, shall have the meanings defined in this section: 
(a)  Produce cart sales spot means one of the following designated public spaces where produce cart permit holders may sell fresh produce, subject to the regulations listed in section 22-1262. 
(1)  Vacant city-owned lots. 
(b)  Fresh produce means unprocessed, unfrozen, whole, raw fruits and vegetables that have not been combined with other ingredients. 
(c)  Produce cart permit means a permit for the selling of fresh produce or bottled water from a produce cart at a designated produce cart sales spot. 
(d)  Produce cart means any showcase, table, stand, bench, rack, handcart, pushcart, wagon, stall, or any other fixture, device, or other wheeled conveyance from which a produce cart permit holder sells fresh produce. Not to exceed three permitted vendors in any one lot. 
(e)  Produce cart vendor means an individual holding a produce cart permit. 
(Ord. No. 07-14, pt. 1, 6-17-14)  
Sec. 22-1261. - Permits. 
(a)  The city clerk shall issue fresh produce permits annually for a fee as set forth in the fee schedule and established by the common council, subject to the requirements and prohibitions listed below in section 22-1262. 
(b)  The city clerk is hereby authorized to issue all rules and regulations consistent with this article and shall have all necessary powers to carry out the purpose of this article, along with representatives from the city health department. 
(c)  The city clerk shall be responsible for designating locations for produce carts. The city health department shall be responsible for performing inspections resulting from complaints. 
(d)  The city clerk shall be responsible for issuing and accepting applications and permits while the city health department will be responsible for reviewing the applications for confirmation and vendor education. 
(Ord. No. 07-14, pt. 1, 6-17-14; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 71, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 22-1262. - Requirements and prohibited conduct. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to engage in the business of a produce cart permit holder without having first obtained a permit from the city clerk. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to sell any items other than fresh produce with a produce cart permit. 
(c)  Produce cart vendors shall keep their produce carts clean and free from paper, peelings, and refuse of any kind generated from the operation of their businesses. Produce cart vendors shall affix to their produce carts a marked receptacle for litter, which shall be maintained and emptied regularly. 
(d)  No produce cart vendor shall: 
(1)  Conduct business in such a way as to restrict or interfere with the ingress or egress of the abutting property owner or tenant, or in such a way as would create or become a nuisance or hazard to public health, safety, or welfare, or increase traffic congestion or delay, or constitute an obstruction to adequate access to fire, police, or sanitation vehicles; 
(2)  Leave any produce cart unattended at any time; 
(3)  Load or unload a produce cart for a period exceeding 20 minutes; 
(4)  Conduct business between 9:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
(5)  Conduct business within 900 feet of an established business that sells fresh produce or of any location previously established and currently being operated by a fresh produce vendor. 
(6)  Conduct business within ten feet of a crosswalk, fire hydrant, or the outer edge of any entranceway to any building or facility used by the public, including doors, driveways, and emergency exits. 
(Ord. No. 07-14, pt. 1, 6-17-14)  
Sec. 22-1263. - Penalties. 
(a)  A violation of this article shall be grounds for the city clerk to deny, refuse to renew, suspend, or revoke the permit to operate. 
(b)  Any person who violates any of the provisions herein shall be subject to a forfeiture of $303.00 for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 07-14, pt. 1, 6-17-14)  
Chapter 26 - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, professions and occupations, ch. 22; utilities, ch. 98. 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate, Wis. Stats. § 66.082. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 26-1—26-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CABLE TELEVISION FRANCHISE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 6-96, adopted April 16, 1996, added §§ 26-1—26-24 in their entirety. To keep in consistency with the Code, §§ 26-1—26-24 have been redesignated as §§ 26-21—26-44 and included herein as set out. 
 
Sec. 26-21. - Renewal created. 
There is hereby created a renewal franchise for the construction and operation of a cable television system within the city. Such renewal franchise shall constitute a contract between the city and the grantee thereof, which franchise contract shall be as follows. 
(Ord. No. 6-96, pt. 1, 4-16-96)  
Sec. 26-22. - Definitions. 
As used in this article the following words have the meaning indicated: 
Additional service means any communication service other than basic cable service provided on the system by grantee. 
Basic cable service or basic service means the level of service offered by grantee (on a primary outlet) that includes all television, broadcast stations (other than satellite superstations) plus all public, educational and governmental access channels. 
Cable system or CATV system or system means a system of antennas, cables, wires, lines, fiber optic cables, towers, waveguides or other conductors, converters, equipment or facilities, used for distributing video programming to subscribers, and/or producing, receiving, amplifying, storing, processing, or distributing audio, video, digital or other forms of electrical signals to, from and between subscribers and other users. 
Channel means a band of frequencies six megahertz wide capable of carrying one standard NTSC video signal or its high definition or digital equivalent. More than one video signal may be carried in the bandwidth by means of compression technology. Channels may be used for nonvideo digital purposes. 
City means the City of Racine, Wisconsin. 
Common council means the common council of the city. 
FCC means the Federal Communications Commission of the United States. 
Grantee means TCI of Racine, Inc., a Wisconsin Corporation and its lawful and permitted successors, assigns and transferees. 
Gross receipts means all revenue derived directly or indirectly from the operation or use of all or part of the cable television system in its provision of cable television service franchised pursuant to this article by the grantee, its affiliates, subsidiaries, and including, but not limited to, revenue from regular subscriber service fees, auxiliary service fees, installation and reconnection fees, leased channel fees, converter rentals, studio rental, production equipment and personnel fees, and advertising revenues; provided, however, that this shall not include any taxes or fees on services furnished by the grantee herein imposed directly upon any subscriber or user by the state, local or other governmental unit and collected by the grantee on behalf of said governmental unit, or bad debts. Gross receipts, for the purpose of this franchise agreement, shall not include any revenues received by grantee from any telephony services, common carrier services regulated by the authority of the state, or other noncable television services provided by the grantee. 
Subscriber means any person or entity who legally subscribes to a service provided by grantee by means of the system. 
(Ord. No. 6-96, pt. 1, 4-16-96)  
Sec. 26-23. - Commission created; duties and responsibilities. 
(a)  Creation. A cable television commission is hereby created, consisting of nine members. Two members shall be members of the common council and shall hold their term for one year; of the remaining members there shall be one representative of each of the following: organized labor, education, business, industry, churches and two representatives from the general public. The mayor shall appoint the commissioners subject to confirmation by the common council. Other than the members of the common council, the term of each member shall be three years. The commission shall receive assistance and administrative services through the human resources department. 
(b)  Duties and responsibilities. The general duties of the cable television commission shall be as follows: 
(1)  To review the public usage of the publicly available cable facilities and offer proposals for expansion of public service aspects of the system within the confines of the system's franchise obligations. 
(2)  To receive complaints from subscribers regarding service and technical problems, to investigate complaints, to act as mediator with the cable operator in efforts to resolve the complaints and to report to the city and the common council as to unresolved complaints. 
(3)  To provide periodic reports to the city and the common council as to franchisee's compliance with franchise obligations. 
(4)  To draw on city staff for advice and, when authorized by the common council, to retain outside expert technical assistance, the cost of which shall be borne out of the franchise fees of funds specially appropriated by the common council. 
(5)  To develop a plan for maximum community involvement and utilization of the public, educational and governmental channels. The plan will include regulations governing the operation and ensuring noncommercial usage by residents of the community and procedures for prohibition of obscene material and, to the extent permitted by law, indecent programming. 
(6)  To review and comment on the mayor's proposed annual cable communications operations budget prior to it being adopted by the common council. 
(7)  Grantee shall have full right of due process in the event of any recommendations for penalty or reduction in franchise benefits. Consideration of expansion of franchise obligations may be negotiated between the city and the grantee. Grantee shall be entitled to present evidence of the financial and technical impact on its operations and on subscriber rates. 
(Ord. No. 6-96, pt. 1, 4-16-96; Ord. No. 4-04, pt. 1, 2-3-04; Ord. No. 36-04, pt. 1, 11-16-04; Ord. No. 08-08, pt. 5, 6-3-08)  
Sec. 26-24. - Privileges granted. 
City hereby awards to grantee a nonexclusive franchise and privilege to construct, operate and maintain in, upon, along, across, above, over and under the streets, alleys, public ways, public places, and easements dedicated for use compatible with cable system operation, and all extensions thereof and additions thereto, in the city, poles, wires, cable underground conduits, and other television conductors and fixtures necessary for the operation and maintenance in the city of a CATV system, which shall be effective as provided herein and shall remain in effect until December 31, 2019. 
In the event the city enters into a franchise permit, or other agreement with any other person or entity to provide cable television service, the provisions thereof shall be reasonably comparable to those contained in the incumbent franchise agreement, in order that one operator not be granted an unfair competitive advantage over another, and to provide all parties equal protection under the law. Provided, however, that the reasonably comparable provisions shall apply to a franchise or agreement that is city wide. 
(1)  Conditions on street use—Utilization of existing facilities. Where feasible to do so, grantee will endeavor to obtain rights to use poles and conduits belonging to other franchise holders within the city. Approval of the assignment of such rights to grantee by such other franchise holders and such commission is hereby expressly given by city, it being the intention of city that grantee will utilize existing public utility poles and conduits where feasible. All poles and conduits installed within the city shall be made available for attachment or use by grantee, at just and reasonable rates applied to public utilities under the formula presently established in 47 U.S.C. § 224 even if the pole owner is not subject to pole attachment regulation. If such poles or facilities are not made so available, grantee may erect its own poles upon application to city. 
(2)  All transmission and distribution structures, lines and equipment erected by grantee within the city shall be located so as not to interfere with the proper use of streets, alleys and other public ways and places, and to cause minimum interference with the rights or reasonable convenience of property owners who adjoin any of the said streets, alleys or other public ways and places, and not to interfere with existing public utility installations. In all areas of the city where the cables, wires or other like facilities of all public utilities are placed underground, grantee shall place its cables, wires or other like facilities underground to the maximum extent technology and economic feasibility permit. 
(3)  If grantee disturbs any pavement, sidewalk, driveway or other surface or any other property, it shall, at its own expense and in the manner provided by city, replace and restore all such paving, sidewalk, driveway or other surface of any street or alley thus disturbed and return any and all property to its like condition immediately prior to being disturbed. 
(4)  If at any time during the period of the franchise, city shall lawfully elect to alter or change the grade or location of any street, alley or other public way, grantee shall, upon reasonable notice by city, remove, relay and relocate its poles, wires, cable, underground conduits, manholes and other fixtures at its own expense, and in each instance comply with city requirements. 
(5)  Grantee shall not place poles, conduits or other fixtures above or below ground where the same will unreasonably interfere with any gas, electric or telephone fixtures, water hydrant or other utility, and all such poles, conduits or other fixtures placed in any street shall be so placed so as to comply with all requirements of city, provided, however, that this section shall not act to restrict grantee's lawful use of appropriate easements and easements (public or private) dedicated or used for compatible uses. 
(6)  Grantee shall at all times employ reasonable care and shall install and maintain in use commonly accepted methods and devices for preventing failures and accidents which are likely to cause damage, injuries or nuisances to the public. Grantee shall, within ten days after receipt of notice thereof, notify city of any injury to person or damage to property caused by or claimed to have been caused by the system. 
(7)  On request of any person holding a moving permit issued by city, grantee shall temporarily move its wires or fixtures to permit the moving of buildings or other objects, the expense of such temporary removal to be paid in advance by the person requesting such removal. Grantee shall be given not less than 72 hours advance notice to arrange for such temporary changes. 
(8)  Grantee shall have the authority to trim any trees upon and overhanging the streets, alleys, sidewalks and public places of the city so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming into contact with grantee's wires and cables. 
(9)  Prior to the erection by grantee of poles or other wireholding structures, grantee shall secure city approval with regard to the location, height, type and other pertinent aspects of such facilities, such approval not to be unreasonably withheld. 
(Ord. No. 6-96, pt. 1, 4-16-96)  
Sec. 26-25. - Extension of service. 
Grantee shall serve any area within the city where the housing density is 30 housing units or more per mile of contiguous cable plant. Areas annexed to the city which meet the density standard shall be served within one year from the date of annexation unless to do so is technically or economically unfeasible. 
(Ord. No. 6-96, pt. 1, 4-16-96)  
Sec. 26-26. - Type and capacity of equipment and standard of service. 
Grantee shall engineer, install, maintain, operate and equip the CATV system herein provided so as to meet the technical standards of the FCC. 
(Ord. No. 6-96, pt. 1, 4-16-96)  
Sec. 26-27. - Subscriber rates. 
In accordance with the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992, city shall have the option, upon proper notice to grantee, including an opportunity for grantee to comment upon any proposed regulations, to regulate basic cable rates and equipment as expressly provided in FCC regulations. City shall also have the option, upon compliance with all lawful procedures, to rescind its regulation of rates. 
(Ord. No. 6-96, pt. 1, 4-16-96)
