(Ord. No. 4-04, pt. 2, 2-3-04)  
Chapter 50 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, adopted Sept. 7, 2004, repealed the former Ch. 50, §§ 50-1—50-6, 50-36, 50-46—50-51, 50-61—50-64, 50-86—50-97, 50-111—50-115, 50-126—50-131, 50-141—50-156, 50-166—50-169, 50-181—50-189, 50-201, 50-202, 50-216—50-218, 50-231—50-234, 50-246—50-250, 50-261—50-268, 50-281, 50-291, 50-292, 50-306—50-312, 50-326—50-329, 50-341—50-345, 50-376—50-381, 50-391—50-395, 50-400—50-414, 50-426—50-436, 50-446—50-451, 50-471—50-473, 50-496—50-508, and enacted a new Ch. 50 as set out herein. The former Ch. 50 pertained to similar subject matter and was derived from Code 1973, § 5.20.010; Ord. No. 16-93, pt. 1, adopted Aug. 3, 1993; Ord. No. 7-94, pt. 1, adopted April 18, 1994; Ord. No. 10-94, pt. 1, adopted May 3, 1994; Ord. No. 19-94, pt. 1, adopted Sept. 20, 1994; Ord. No. 13-95, pt. 5, adopted Aug. 15, 1995; Ord. No. 16-96, pt. 1, Aug. 20, 1996; Ord. No. 19-97, pts. 1, 2, Nov. 19, 1997; and Ord. No. 8-04, pt. 16, adopted April 7, 2004. 
Cross reference— Wagons, stands, other vehicles, carts, tents, trailers, sheds or other substitute for building used for sale of food, goods, wares or merchandise or business, commercial or residential purposed must meet certain standards, § 18-42; establishment of fire districts, § 18-146, et seq.; gas installation regulations, § 18-566 et seq.; electrical code, § 18-606 et seq.; fires in parks and recreation areas, § 70-78; regulations regarding fireworks in parks and recreation areas, § 70-80; burning of leaves or rubbish prohibited, § 82-33; parades, processions and open air meetings restricted and permit required, § 82-39; fire hydrants and other utilities located in streets restricted, § 82-40; gas company using streets, permit required, § 82-43. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 50-1. - Applicability. 
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all public buildings and places of employment as defined in the Wisconsin Commercial Building Code except as otherwise provided in this chapter; to hazardous conditions, the actions of persons regarding fire and fire safety, and to actions of persons relating to the prevention of fires. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 08-14, pt. 1, 7-15-14; Ord. No. 0013-17, pt. 1, 9-20-17)  
Sec. 50-2. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
Except as provided in subsection 50-125(d), any person who violates any provision of this chapter, or who fails to comply with an order issued by an officer authorized by the chief of the fire department under this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit an amount not less than $25.00, nor more than $500.00, together with applicable costs and assessments. The officer of the fire department may issue or cause a citation to be issued to the property owner or agent. If prima facie evidence exists that the occupant/tenant is causing the violation, the officer may cause the citation to be issued to the tenant or occupant. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-3. - Payment of forfeiture in lieu of court appearance. 
(a)  Any person charged with a violation of the offenses listed under subsection (b) of this section may pay the amount enumerated therein at the police department in lieu of a court appearance. Persons wishing to contest the charges contained in subsection (b) of this section may contact the police department to arrange a court appearance. 
(b)  The following base forfeitures, plus applicable costs and assessments, for the offenses listed herein may be paid at the police department: 
Section Number 	Violation 	Forfeiture 
50-4 	Negligent fire 	$250.00 
50-48 	Required appliances 	150.00 
50-86 	Adopted codes and standards 	150.00 
50-87 	Administrative code violation 	150.00 
50-88(b) 	Blocked exit 	 50.00 
50-88(c) 	Blocked aisle 	 50.00 
50-89 	Exit light out 	 25.00 
50-125 	Fireworks 	150.00 
50-264 	Open fire violations 	150.00 
50-377 	Access to fire hydrant 	150.00 
50-392 	Hood and duct permit 	150.00 
50-394(c) 	Hood and duct installation 	150.00 
50-394(e) 	Hood and duct maintenance 	150.00 
50-412 	Sprinkler maintenance 	150.00 
50-414 	Blocking sprinkler connection 	 50.00 
50-427 	Extinguisher installation 	150.00 
50-428 	Extinguisher maintenance 	 25.00 
50-430 	Permit to service 	150.00 
50-447 	Fire detection system installation/maintenance 	150.00 
50-447 	Detector not tested or maintained 	 50.00 
50-448 	Automatic dialers prohibited 	150.00 
50-471 	Fire lane violation 	 50.00 
 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-4. - Setting fire through negligence. 
No person shall, in any building or on any premises covered by this chapter, by any means whatsoever, through carelessness, neglect or negligence, set fire to, or cause the burning of, any property in such a manner as to endanger the safety of any person or property by fire or smoke. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-5. - Southeast emergency management region. 
The chief of the fire department or the officer in charge shall have the power to grant permission to any officer or member of the fire department to go with or without an engine or other fire apparatus to any town, city or village in the southeast emergency management region (Racine, Kenosha, Waukesha, Ozaukee, Walworth, Milwaukee, Washington, Dodge and Jefferson counties) for the purposes of civil defense disasters (manmade or natural), civil defense exercises, demonstrations, training, firefighting, or other appropriate purposes where the emergency has reached a point which is beyond the capabilities of the fire department which has requested aid, to be absent such length of time as may be directed. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Secs. 50-6—50-35. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 50-36. - Investigating undetermined fires. 
The city attorney and the police department, upon request of the fire chief, shall assist in the investigation of any fire which, in his opinion, is of undetermined origin. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 0013-17, pt. 2, 9-20-17)  
Secs. 50-37—50-45. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - FIRE DEPARTMENT  
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 50-46. - Right of entry; inspection/investigation; warrants. 
(a)  The fire chief, the chief of the bureau of fire prevention and officers of the fire department or any inspector may at all reasonable hours enter any building or premises within their jurisdiction for the purpose of making any inspection or investigation which, under the provisions of this chapter, any of them deems necessary. 
(b)  The fire chief or officers of the bureau of fire prevention may obtain an administrative inspection warrant or search warrant under Wisconsin Statutes when necessary in their opinion for the purpose of making an inspection or investigation of any building or premises where the owner has refused admission. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-47. - Order to remove hazards. 
(a)  Whenever any inspector shall find in or on any building or premises combustible material, explosive matter, hazardous, extremely hazardous or toxic materials which are so situated as to endanger property, or shall find obstructions to or on escapes, stairs, passageways, doors or windows liable to interfere with the operations of the fire department or egress of occupants in case of fire, he shall order the same to be removed or remedied. 
(b)  Where the public is exposed to immediate danger, the chief or designee is hereby empowered to order the immediate closing and vacating of the building or premises. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-48. - Order to install appliances. 
The fire chief or officers of the bureau of fire prevention shall survey inspectable buildings and order required fire appliances to be installed. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-49. - Service of orders. 
The service of orders under this article may be made upon the occupant of the premises to whom it is directed, whether by delivering a copy of such order to such occupant personally, or by delivering such order to and leaving it with an adult person in charge of the premises, or by placing such order in a conspicuous place on the door to the entrance of the premises. Whenever it may be necessary to serve such an order upon the owner of the premises, such order may be served either by delivering to and leaving a copy with such person, or, if such owner is absent from the jurisdiction by mailing a copy to the owner's last known post office address. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-50. - Compliance with orders; appeal. 
Any order made under this article shall forthwith be complied with by the owner or occupant of such premises or building. If such order is made by the chief of the bureau of fire prevention, or one of the inspectors, such owner or occupant may, within 24 hours, appeal to the fire chief in writing, who shall review such order and file his decision thereon. Unless by his authority the order is revoked or modified, it shall remain in full force and be complied with within the time fixed in the order or decision of the fire chief. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Secs. 50-51—50-60. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Bureau of Fire Prevention 
 
Sec. 50-61. - Created; supervision; personnel, appointments. 
A bureau of fire prevention in the fire department is hereby established. The bureau shall be operated under the supervision of the chief of the fire department. The fire chief shall designate an officer as division chief of the bureau of fire prevention, subject to confirmation by the board of police and fire commissioners. Such officer shall hold office and be removed by the fire chief only for cause. The fire chief may assign such other personnel as officers and inspectors to as shall from time to time be necessary. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-62. - Duties. 
It shall be the duty of the officers of the bureau of fire prevention to enforce all laws and ordinances covering the following: 
(1)  The prevention of fires. 
(2)  The storing and use of explosives, flammables, combustibles, hazardous materials, extremely hazardous substances or toxic gases. 
(3)  The installation and maintenance of automatic fire alarm systems, fire extinguishment equipment and smoke detection devices. 
(4)  Maintenance of exit ways, including hallways, stairways and aisles. 
(5)  The investigation of the cause, origin and circumstances of fires and explosions; the investigation of fire related deaths and injuries. 
(6)  The instruction of all firefighters in their inspection duties; making available public education to citizens and promoting sound fire prevention practices. 
(7)  The review of plans for automatic fire extinguishing equipment, fire suppression equipment, automatic sprinkler systems, fire alarm systems, hood and duct equipment, and fire lanes where required. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-63. - Annual reports. 
An annual report of the bureau of fire prevention shall be made, and shall be transmitted to the fire chief by May 1 each year. Such report shall contain all proceedings under this chapter with such statistics as the fire chief establishes. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-64. - Powers. 
The fire chief and the officers of the bureau of fire prevention are hereby empowered to order compliance, including the issuance of citations for violation of the Wisconsin Administrative Code, adopted codes and standards, the city building code, city ordinances, and Wisconsin Statutes in matters pertaining to fire prevention and protection within the city. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-65. - Annual fire prevention inspection. 
The officers of the bureau of fire prevention shall conduct annual fire prevention inspections for each building, structure, and premises in the city and charge the property owner a fee based on occupancy classification. This fee shall apply to taxable and tax exempt property alike. 
(Ord. No. 36-09, pt. 1, 11-21-06)  
Sec. 50-66. - Fire prevention inspection fee schedule and provisions. 
(a)  Fees, as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council, based on occupancy classification. 
(b)  The annual fire prevention inspection fee shall constitute a special charge against the property under Wis. Stats. § 66.0627(2) and shall be placed on the annual tax roll for collection as a special charge. All proceedings related to the collection of real estate taxes shall apply. 
(c)  Five percent of the total annual fire prevention inspection fees collected shall be used exclusively for the fire safety and education programs. 
(d)  All buildings, structures, and premises owned by the state and the United States government shall be exempt from the annual fire prevention inspection fee. 
(Ord. No. 39-06, pt. 1, 11-21-06; Ord. No. 13-10, pt. 1, 8-2-10; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 81, 11-12-19)  
Secs. 50-67—50-85. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - STANDARDS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 50-86. - Codes and standards adopted. 
Those portions of the latest version of the National Fire Codes published by the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) and adopted by the state that pertain directly to fire prevention measures are hereby adopted by reference as part of this article and herein referenced as NFPA. The chief of the fire department or designee may base approval for devices, materials, and procedures not covered by the Wisconsin Administrative Code or the municipal code on any applicable nationally recognized standards or published listings or nationally recognized testing laboratories. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 0013-17, pt. 3, 9-20-17)  
Sec. 50-87. - Statutory provisions adopted. 
Wisconsin Administrative Code, Department of Safety and Professional Services chapter 314 inclusive, are hereby adopted by reference as if fully set forth in this article. Any future amendments, revisions, or modifications of the provisions incorporated herein are intended to be a part of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 0013-17, pt. 4, 9-20-17)  
Sec. 50-88. - Obstructions to means of exit. 
(a)  No person shall place an encumbrance of any kind before or upon any fire escape, balcony or ladder intended as a means of escape from fire. 
(b)  No person shall place, store or keep, or permit to be placed, stored or kept, on or under or at the bottom of any exit stairway, inside or outside, exit hallway, fire escape, elevator or other means of egress, any materials the presence or the burning of which would obstruct or render hazardous the egress of persons from the building. 
(c)  No aisle, passageway or stairway in any store shall be obstructed with tables, show cases, or other obstructions. Aisle space must be maintained at 44 inches minimum width. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-89. - Exit lights. 
All required exit lights shall be on at all times that a building required to have exit lights is occupied. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Secs. 50-90—50-124. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - FIREWORKS 
 
Sec. 50-125. - Fireworks permit requirements. 
(a)  No person, retailer, wholesaler, jobbers or dealers shall sell, distribute or display fireworks or pyrotechnics without first obtaining the appropriate permit from the City of Racine Fire Department. No permit granted hereunder shall be transferable. 
(b)  No permit to sell, distribute, or display fireworks shall be issued to a person under the age of 18 years. 
(c)  Application to sell or distribute fireworks by retailer or wholesaler. Application for such permit shall be made in writing at least 30 days in advance of the sale or offer to sell. Such permits shall be valid from January 1 through December 31 of each year. The application shall include the following: 
(1)  Name and address of the permit holder. 
(2)  The kind and quantity of fireworks on site. 
(3)  The location for distribution or sales. 
(4)  A fee as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council. 
(5)  Approval of the fire chief and his or her designee. 
(6)  Any special conditions that may be in effect by ordinance or law at the time of issuance of the permit. 
(7)  Proof of a valid peddler's license must be presented, if required by chapter 22 hereof. 
(d)  Application to display fireworks or pyrotechnics. Application for such permit shall be made in writing at least 30 days in advance of the date of the display. Such permits shall be lawful only for the permitted purposes stated in the application. The application shall include the following: 
(1)  The qualifications, number of, and ages of the pyrotechnic operator and all assistants. 
(2)  The pyrotechnic experience of the operator. 
(3)  Confirmation of any applicable state and federal licenses held by the operator or assistant(s). 
(4)  Evidence of the permittee's insurance coverages with minimum limits of $1,000,000.00 bodily injury and property damage, combined single limit, naming the city, its officers, employees and agents as additional insureds. Said insurance shall indemnify and defend the city, its officers, employees and agents against all claims, liability, loss damages or expenses, whether caused by or contributed to by the negligence of the city, its officers, employees or agents. Said insurance shall provide that the city receive written notice 30 days prior to any cancellation, nonrenewal or material change in the policy. 
(5)  The number and types of pyrotechnic devices and materials to be used, the operator's experiences with those devices and effects, and a definition of the general responsibilities of the assistants. 
(6)  A diagram or site plan of the grounds or facilities where the production is to be held. This diagram shall show the point at which the pyrotechnic devices are to be fired, the fallout radius for each pyrotechnic device used in the performance, and the lines behind which the audience shall be restrained, which shall be not less than that required by NFPA 1126. 
(7)  The point of on-site assembly of pyrotechnic devices. 
(8)  Safety data sheets (SDS) for the pyrotechnic material(s) to be used. 
(9)  Certification that the set, scenery, and rigging materials are inherently flame retardant or have been treated to achieve flame retardancy. 
(10)  The manner and place of storage of the pyrotechnic materials and devices. 
(11)  Measures to provide crowd management security, fire protection, or emergency services for the event. 
(12)  Availability of pyrotechnician, upon demand, to demonstrate the pyrotechnic device(s) during a pre-event inspection by the fire prevention bureau. 
(13)  A fee of $50.00. 
(14)  Approval of the fire chief or his or her designee. 
(e)  A person convicted of a violation of this section shall be penalized as set forth in section 66-523, of the Racine Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 6-12, pt. 1, 6-28-12; Ord. No. 0013-17, pts. 5—13, 9-20-17; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 82, 11-12-19)  
Secs. 50-126—50-260. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - OPEN FLAMES AND BURNING 
 
Sec. 50-261. - Prohibition. 
No person shall kindle, start or maintain any rubbish fire or open fire for the burning of combustible materials without a permit from the fire department. This section shall not apply to fires set for training or instruction in firefighting, for testing of fire equipment, for cooking, unless such cooking is done in a manner which imposes a risk of personal injury or property damage, or for events of community interest where written permission has been granted by the fire chief. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-262. - Supervision. 
To ensure life safety and to prevent fires from endangering surrounding property, all open fires shall be under continuous supervision until they are completely extinguished and the remaining embers are cold or have been thoroughly wet down. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-263. - Notification of fire department; permit. 
(a)  No person shall kindle or start an open fire without first obtaining a permit from the fire department. 
(b)  The fire chief or his designee may prohibit fires when atmospheric conditions or legal circumstances make such fires hazardous or objectionable due to smoke or odor. 
(c)  A permit fee as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council shall be paid before issuance of a permit to burn. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 83, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 50-264. - Violation of division. 
Except as provided in section 18-369 of the Racine Municipal Code, no person shall kindle, start or maintain an outdoor fire in violation of this division. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Secs. 50-265—50-370. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - FIRE SUPPRESSION AND WARNING SYSTEMS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 50-371. - Conflict of article with other standards. 
The provisions of this article are enacted in addition to the Wisconsin Commercial Building Code and the most current standards of the National Fire Protection Association. Where conflicts in rules between the elements of this article and referenced standards are identified, the more restrictive rule shall be applied unless specifically excepted in this article. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 08-14, pt. 2, 7-15-14; Ord. No. 0013-17, pt. 14, 9-20-17)  
Secs. 50-372—50-375. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - FIRE HYDRANT REQUIREMENTS 
 
Sec. 50-376. - Intent. 
The intent of this division is to ensure adequate water supply for firefighting purposes to structures and premises. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-377. - Obstructing fire hydrants. 
No person shall park, stop or leave a vehicle standing within ten feet of any city fire hydrant. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Secs. 50-378—50-390. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - AUTOMATIC FIRE EXTINGUISHING EQUIPMENT 
 
Sec. 50-391. - Intent. 
The intent of this division is to require automatic fire extinguishing systems in vent hoods and duct systems, and includes protection of cooking equipment which may be a source of ignition, by providing for automatic fuel shutoff for all commercial type kitchens so as to effectively extinguish fire at its source and reduce the property damage and loss caused by kitchen fires. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-392. - Permit required; fee. 
Every person, whether self-employed or employed by another, who services or installs fire extinguishing systems in vent hoods and ducts within the city shall first obtain a permit as provided in this division. Permits shall expire on December 31 of the year for which it was issued. The permit process and fee shall be as follows: 
(1)  Initial permit to install and service. Every applicant for permit to service and or install automatic fire extinguishing systems shall make written application with the bureau of fire prevention including name, address, stated experience, copies of all factory authorized training certificates, and all other documents of relevant training, and shall include an application and permit fee as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council. Application shall include evidence of commercial general liability insurance coverage issued by an insurance carrier with the "Best" rating of "A-VII" or better and that is an admitted carrier in the State of Wisconsin, insuring the public in an amount of not less, $500,000.00 combined single limit bodily injury and property damage per occurrence for injury and damage caused by the negligence of such applicant in installing or servicing automatic extinguishing systems. 
(2)  Annual renewal permit. A permit issued under this section may be renewed upon filing a completed renewal application within 30 days prior to expiration of the current permit, with proof of the specified liability insurance coverage for the year for which the application is made, and shall include payment of a renewal and permit fee as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 84, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 50-393. - Where required; compliance. 
(a)  All hood and duct systems shall be equipped with approved automatic fire extinguishing systems designed for both manual and automatic operation. 
(b)  All hood and duct systems shall comply with the requirements of this division and NFPA 96. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-394. - Installation requirements. 
(a)  Plans. Where required, a complete drawing of the system installation, including the hood(s), exhaust duct(s), and appliances, along with the interface of the fire-extinguishing system detectors, piping, nozzles, fuel shutoff devices, agent storage container(s), and manual actuation device(s), shall be prepared. 
(b)  Review of plans; fee. All plans for automatic fire extinguishing equipment shall be submitted for review and approval by the fire prevention bureau prior to installation of the equipment. Two sets of plans and specifications shall be submitted to the bureau. One set shall be returned to the installer and if, sufficient, shall be stamped "approved by the bureau of fire prevention" with the date of such approval. The plan review fee shall be as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council. 
(c)  Installation. 
(1)  The system shall be installed by or under the direct supervision of a factory authorized representative. 
(2)  Package units or individually designed units shall be installed in conformance with the limitations of the designers' or manufacturers' specifications. 
(d)  Inspection; fee. A representative of the fire prevention bureau shall inspect all fire extinguishing systems installations prior to occupancy. The inspection fee shall be as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council. Occupancy shall not be approved until the installation is approved. 
(e)  Maintenance. 
(1)  All fire extinguishing systems shall be inspected semiannually by a factory authorized service person, except for occupancies open during no more than six months per year, which shall be inspected in their open season. A certificate of this inspection, of the work which has been performed, signed by the service person, shall be submitted to the fire prevention bureau within ten days of inspection. 
(2)  A service person who inspects a fire extinguishing system shall attach thereto a durable tag which clearly indicates the year of manufacture. The date of installation of the fusible links shall be marked on the system inspection tag, and the tag shall be signed or initialed and dated by the service person, indicating the date of completion or last inspection/service. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 85, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 50-395. - Permit revocation. 
Any violation of this division shall be cause for revocation of a permit issued under this section. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Secs. 50-396—50-405. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - AUTOMATIC SPRINKLER AND STANDPIPE SYSTEMS 
 
Sec. 50-406. - Intent. 
The intent of this division is to provide a means for the automatic extinguishment of fires in buildings or facilities and the access to firefighting standpipes where required as specified in the most recent version of the International Building Code (IBC). 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 08-14, pt. 3, 7-15-14)  
Sec. 50-407. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings given in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Area means the ground floor area of a building or, when a building is divided by an approved minimum four-hour fire-resistive wall, each section so divided. 
Other defined terms used in this division shall have the meaning given in this chapter and in the Wisconsin Commercial Building Code. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 08-14, pt. 4, 7-15-14; Ord. No. 0013-17, pt. 15, 9-20-17)  
Sec. 50-408. - Where required. 
New buildings or facilities shall have an approved automatic sprinkler system, standpipe system, and suitable access to supplementary water supply installed and maintained as required by the Wisconsin Commercial Building Code and/or the International Building Code (IBC), or at any time that the bureau of fire prevention determines that, based on the standards of the NFPA, a building or facility constitutes a fire hazard. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 08-14, pt. 5, 7-15-14; Ord. No. 0013-17, pt. 16, 9-20-17)  
Sec. 50-409. - Application to existing buildings or facilities; appeals. 
(a)  Where the bureau of fire prevention finds that an existing building or facility constitutes a fire hazard to occupants of the building or facility or to adjoining property as a result of size, occupancy or change of occupancy, compliance with the provisions of this division may be required. 
(b)  Appeals from the decision of the bureau of fire prevention may be made to the board of building appeals in the same manner as appeals from the decisions of the chief building inspector are made, and the board shall process such appeals in accordance with the same procedure set out in section 18-61 et seq., except that the chief of the fire prevention bureau shall attend all hearings on such appeal and fully disclose to the board information relevant to the inquiry being made. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 0013-17, pt. 17, 9-20-17)  
Sec. 50-410. - Type of system and approval of plans. 
Approved automatic sprinkler and standpipe equipment shall be installed in accordance with the standards of the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) and the Wisconsin Commercial Building Code. Automatic sprinkler or standpipe equipment shall not be installed or altered until plans have been submitted and approved by the bureau of fire prevention. Three copies of the plans and specifications shall be submitted for review. Approved plans shall be stamped, "Approved by the bureau of fire prevention" and the date of such approval shall be indicated thereon. Two copies of the plans shall be returned to the owner for submission to the chief building inspector, and one copy shall be kept on file by the bureau of fire prevention. Building sprinkler system alteration may be excepted from the requirements of this section provided the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The system alterations meet with prior approval of the fire prevention bureau. 
(2)  No more than 20 sprinkler heads are altered. 
(3)  As-built plans or narrative documents describing the alterations are submitted to the fire prevention bureau immediately following the alterations. 
(4)  The plan examination fee shall be as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council per set of plans, which shall be paid upon submission of the plans. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 08-14, pt. 6, 7-15-14; Ord. No. 0013-17, pt. 18, 9-20-17; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 86, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 50-411. - Inspection. 
(a)  Every automatic sprinkler or standpipe system required under this division shall be inspected upon installation and certified by the installer as meeting the requirements of NFPA at the time and date of installation. A copy of such certification shall be kept on file in the bureau of fire prevention. Final approval of such systems shall not be given until all testing has been completed and all fees have been paid. Final testing shall be witnessed by an inspector from the fire prevention bureau. 
(b)  Inspection fees under this division shall be as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 87, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 50-412. - Maintenance, testing, inspection. 
The owner or occupant of a building or facility having an automatic sprinkler or standpipe system required under this division shall maintain the system in an operative condition at all times and in accordance with the standards of NFPA 13, 14, and 25. The owner or owner's representative shall notify the fire department whenever the automatic fire sprinkler or standpipe system is shut down or impaired and also when it is placed back in service. The owner shall arrange for immediate and continual servicing or repair of the automatic fire sprinkler or standpipe system until it is placed back in operation. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-413. - Occupancy permit. 
An occupancy permit shall not be issued by the chief building inspector for a building to which this division applies until final approval of the automatic sprinkler and/or standpipe system has been given by the fire prevention bureau. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-414. - Obstructing exterior sprinkler or standpipe connection. 
No person shall park, stop or leave standing a vehicle within ten feet of any exterior sprinkler or standpipe connection which is required by this division. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Secs. 50-415—50-425. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - PORTABLE FIRE EXTINGUISHERS 
 
Sec. 50-426. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings given in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Inspect means the physical observation of an extinguisher and all appurtenances connected thereto to ensure that the extinguisher is properly sealed and pressurized and not damaged or corroded. 
Service means the inspection, repair, recharging or testing of fire extinguishers. 
Serviceperson means a person who holds a permit issued by the fire prevention bureau to inspect, repair, recharge or test fire extinguishers. 
Standard fire extinguisher means a portable fire extinguisher which bears the label of approval of a national testing laboratory acceptable to the fire chief 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-427. - Installation. 
Installation of all fire extinguishers required by section 50-48 shall be in the manner prescribed in NFPA, Portable Fire Extinguishers, published by the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA). 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 0013-17, pt. 19, 9-20-17)  
Sec. 50-428. - Inspections; maintenance; testing. 
Fire extinguishers shall be serviced annually by a serviceperson who holds a proper permit, and shall be inspected and maintained as specified in NFPA, Portable Fire Extinguishers, published by the National Fire Protection Association. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 0013-17, pt. 20, 9-20-17)  
Sec. 50-429. - Tags to be attached. 
A serviceperson who inspects, maintains, tests, or otherwise services a fire extinguisher shall attach thereto a durable tag which clearly indicates the information required by NFPA 10. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 0013-17, pt. 21, 9-20-17)  
Sec. 50-430. - Service—Permit required. 
Every person, whether self-employed or employed by another, who services a fire extinguisher within the city or services a fire extinguisher which is to be used within the city shall first obtain a permit to service fire extinguishers as provided by this division. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-431. - Same—Permit application. 
Permit to service extinguishers. Every applicant for a permit to service portable fire extinguishers shall file with the fire prevention bureau a written application signed by the applicant, stating his name, present occupation, documenting training and experience with the repair, recharging, testing and use of fire extinguishers, demonstrating knowledge of this division, knowledge of the standards and requirements of NFPA 10, and other information as may be deemed necessary and relevant by the bureau of fire prevention. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 0013-17, pt. 22, 9-20-17)  
Sec. 50-432. - Same—Issuance of permit; insurance requirement. 
A permit to service portable fire extinguishers shall be granted to all qualified applicants who possess a current certificate of factory authorized training or other documented proof of training and competency and who have delivered to the fire prevention bureau evidence of the existence of insurance as described in section 50-392(a) above [sic] for injury and damage caused by the negligence of such applicant in servicing fire extinguishers. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-433. - Permit fees; terms. 
Upon approval of the application for a permit under this division, the fire prevention bureau shall issue such permit upon receipt of a permit fee as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council. The permit shall expire on December 31 of the year for which it is issued. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 88, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 50-434. - Permit renewal fees. 
A service permit issued under this division may be renewed upon payment of an annual renewal fee as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council, a completed application, and proof of the specified liability insurance coverage for the year for which the application is made. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 89, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 50-435. - Suspension or revocation of permit. 
Any violation of this division shall be cause for suspension or revocation of a permit issued under this section. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Secs. 50-436—50-445. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - SMOKE AND FIRE DETECTION AND WARNING SYSTEMS 
 
Sec. 50-446. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this division is to require installation of smoke warning systems, fire detection systems, and other warning systems. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-447. - Required installation, testing, and maintenance. 
The owner of each building or facility covered by this division shall install, maintain, and test every alarm system and/or fire detection device in accordance with the most current requirements and standards of the National Fire Protection Association, Wisconsin Statutes and the Wisconsin Commercial Building Code. Additionally, the owner shall, on a monthly basis, test every alarm system in owner's buildings, make and retain records of such tests for one year, and make such records available for review upon request by fire code officials. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 08-14, pt. 7, 7-15-14; Ord. No. 0013-17, pt. 23, 9-20-17)  
Sec. 50-448. - Automatic dialers prohibited. 
No person shall use or cause to be used any telephone or electronic device or attachment that automatically selects a public telephone trunkline of the fire and/or police department, and then reproduces a recorded message to report a fire alarm or other emergency. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Sec. 50-449. - Penalty for violation of division. 
Any person who violates any provision of sections 50-447 and 50-448 shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit an amount as provided in section 50-2. Each day of violation constitutes a separate violation for offenses under this division. 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04)  
Secs. 50-450—50-470. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - FIRE LANES 
 
Sec. 50-471. - Establishment; prohibited parking. 
(a)  The fire chief or chief of the fire prevention bureau may require the establishment of fire lanes for any building, property, or other area within the city in which a potentially hazardous situation is created by parked vehicles or other obstructions to emergency operations. The fire prevention bureau shall maintain an accurate list of designated fire lanes and shall, through the building inspection process, order any required maintenance. 
(b)  Fire lanes shall be provided for at least two adjacent sides of every building or facility required to have fire lanes, and shall be parallel to the sides of the building or facility with the near edge of the fire lane within ten feet of the building or facility on the parallel sides. Fire lane construction shall conform to the standards provided by the current version of the Wisconsin Commercial Building Code, International Building Code (IBC), and NFPA standards. 
(c)  Upon establishment of fire lanes, the building owner shall prominently post and maintain signs indicating the fire lanes by installing the signs on sign posts or the building face no more than 75 feet apart and/or provide roadway surface marking as shall be determined by the bureau of fire prevention. The signs shall be constructed of durable material having a minimum size of 12 inches by 18 inches, having a white reflective background with a red line border, red three-inch minimum height letters stating "NO PARKING," "FIRE LANE" or the universal no parking symbol and the words "FIRE LANE," as shown below. Roadway surface marking shall consist of outlining or painting the fire lane area and curb line in yellow with the words "FIRE LANE" in yellow, at intervals of not more than 75 feet or as otherwise directed by the fire prevention bureau. The size of the lettering shall be not less than 24 inches in height and three inches in stroke. No person shall establish a fire lane on any property without the express authorization of the fire prevention bureau. Upon the establishment and posting of such fire lanes, no person shall park a vehicle, whether attended or unattended, in such fire lane, except commercially licensed vehicles actively engaged in delivery or pickup. 
(SAMPLES NOT TO SCALE) 
 
 
(Ord. No. 28-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 08-14, pt. 8, 7-15-14; Ord. No. 0013-17, pt. 24, 9-20-17) 

Chapter 54 - HEALTH[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter ordinance reference—Health officer, § 2-146. 
Cross reference— Board of health, § 2-176 et seq.; health and sanitation appeal board, § 2-236 et seq.; citation system for enforcement of ordinances, § 2-551 et seq.; rabies control regarding animals, § 10-96 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; property maintenance code, § 18-691 et seq.; private swimming pools, § 18-731 et seq.; businesses, professions and occupations, ch. 22; supplementary zoning district regulations, § 114-656 et seq. 
State Law reference— Special inspection warrants, Wis. Stats. § 66.122. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 54-1. - Enforcement of chapter. 
Except where otherwise provided in a particular article of this chapter, it shall be the duty of the health officer to enforce the provisions of this chapter and to see that all violations thereof are promptly abated and prosecuted, and it shall be the duty of the chief of police, the commissioner of public works, and all police officers to give attention throughout the city to any case of violation of this chapter and to promptly report to the health officer in writing every such violation which shall come to their knowledge. 
(Code 1973, § 11.24.010)  
Sec. 54-2. - Violations; payment of forfeiture in lieu of court appearance. 
(a)  Any person charged with a violation of the offenses listed under subsection (b) of this section may pay the amount enumerated therein at the police department in lieu of a court appearance. Persons wishing to contest the charge contained in subsection (b) of this section may contact the police department to arrange a court appearance date. 
(b)  The forfeitures for the offenses listed in this chapter may be paid at the police department. 
(Code 1973, § 11.26.020) 
State Law reference— Actions for violation of municipal regulations, forfeitures, stipulations, Wis. Stats. § 66.12(1)(b); citations for ordinance violations, Wis. Stats. § 66.119.  
Secs. 54-3—54-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - COMMUNICABLE DISEASES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Special inspection warrants, Wis. Stats. § 66.122; communicable diseases, Wis. Stats. § 143.01 et seq. 
 
Sec. 54-26. - Statutory definitions. 
Those diseases which are designated as communicable by HSS 145, appendix A, of the Wisconsin Administrative Code are hereby declared to be communicable within the meaning of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 11.02.010)  
Sec. 54-27. - State regulations apply. 
The provisions for the control and supervision of communicable diseases established by Wis. Stats. ch. 143, and the rules and regulations adopted by the state department of health and social services pursuant thereto are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this article as though fully set forth herein. Any future amendments, revisions or modifications of the sections incorporated herein are intended to be made a part of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 11.02.020)  
Sec. 54-28. - Hospitals and nursing homes. 
Whenever any person admitted or confined to a hospital or nursing home in the city has any communicable disease, it shall be the duty of the administrator, admitting clerk, or other authority of the hospital or nursing home to inform the health officer as speedily as possible. The health officer shall thereupon examine the case and take such action as is reasonable and necessary for the benefit of the other inmates to prevent the spread of infection. 
(Code 1973, § 11.02.030)  
Sec. 54-29. - School absences. 
Whenever any child has been absent from school for more than two consecutive days, it is the duty of the classroom teacher or principal of the school to establish the cause of the absence, and if a communicable disease is determined or suspected to be the cause of such absence, the teacher or principal shall inform the health officer or his authorized representative as speedily as possible. The health officer shall thereupon examine such case and take such action as is reasonable and necessary for the benefit of the pupils to prevent the spread of infection. 
(Code 1973, § 11.02.040)  
Sec. 54-30. - Exclusion from school; readmission. 
Where the rules of the state department of health and social services provide for the exclusion from school of persons afflicted with communicable disease, no such person shall be admitted to school until a written release from the health officer permitting attendance is presented. 
(Code 1973, § 11.02.060)  
Sec. 54-31. - Responsibility for minors. 
Parents, guardians, or other responsible persons having custody of children shall be responsible for the acts of minors under their charge in violation of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 11.02.070)  
Sec. 54-32. - Home quarantines. 
Where the rules of the state department of health and social services provide for the isolation, quarantine or other restrictions of persons who live in homes where communicable disease exists, no person shall leave or be removed from his home in the city for any reason without the approval of the health officer, nor unless the health officer deems it necessary for the health of such person or of the public. 
(Code 1973, § 11.02.050)  
Secs. 54-33, 54-34. - Reserved.  
Sec. 54-35. - Wear of face coverings. 
(1)  Definitions. As used in this section, the terms below shall have the following meanings: 
a.  Face covering means a uniform multi-layer piece of cloth, fabric, or other material that securely covers a person's nose and mouth and remains affixed in place without the use of one's hands. Face coverings include, but are not limited to, bandanas, medical masks, cloth masks, scarves, and gaiters, provided that they are worn such that they securely cover the person's nose and mouth. 
b.  Public space means any indoor or outdoor space that is open to the public. This does not include any private residence, private residential property, or private offices or workspaces that are not open to customers or to public visitors. 
(2)  Use of face coverings. 
a.  All persons in the City of Racine shall have possession of a face covering when the person leaves home or other place of residence and shall cover their mouths and noses with a face covering when: 
i.  In any indoor public space. 
ii.  In any outdoor public space and within six feet of any other person who is not a member of the person's family or household. 
iii.  Riding on public transportation or riding in a taxi, private car service, or ride-sharing vehicle. 
b.  All businesses, organizations, and non-profit entities within the City of Racine shall require all employees, customers, visitors, members, or members of the public to wear a face covering when any of the following apply: 
i.  Employees are working in any space visited by customers or members of the public, regardless of whether customers or members of the public are present at the time. 
ii.  Employees who are working in any space where food is prepared or packaged for sale or distribution to others. 
iii.  Customers, visitors, members, or members of the public are in a facility managed or operated by the business, organization, or entity. 
iv.  Employees are in any room or enclosed area where other people, except for members of the same family or household, are unable to maintain a six-foot distance except for infrequent or incidental moments of closer proximity. 
c.  Exemptions. Face coverings shall not be required: 
i.  For children aged four years or under 
ii.  Persons who fall into the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's guidance for those who should not wear face coverings due to a medical condition, mental health condition, developmental disability, or are otherwise covered under the Americans with Disabilities Act. 
iii.  Persons who have upper-respiratory chronic conditions. 
iv.  Persons who are hearing impaired, or communicating with a person who is hearing impaired, where the ability to view a person's mouth is essential for communication. 
v.  Persons who are obtaining a service involving the nose, mouth, or face for which temporary removal of the face covering is necessary to perform the service. 
vi.  Persons who are seated at a restaurant or other establishment that offers food or beverage service, while they are eating or drinking, provided they maintain a six-foot distance between individuals, not including individuals who are members of the same family or household or are seated together, with only infrequent or incidental moments of closer proximity, such as persons walking or passing by. 
vii.  Persons for whom wearing a face covering would create a risk to the person related to their work, as determined by local, state, or federal regulations or workplace safety guidelines. 
viii.  Whenever federal, state, or local law otherwise prohibit wearing a face mask or where it is necessary to evaluate or verify an individual's identity. 
ix.  Persons whose religious beliefs prevent them from wearing a face covering 
x.  While exclusively with members of a family or the same household, and no person other than such family or household is within the same enclosed area. 
xi.  In private, individual offices, when no other persons other than members of the same family or household are present. 
xii.  Persons present in government facilities closed to the public, institutions of higher education, public and private kindergarten through twelfth grade schools, and licensed childcare or youth facilities that are following Wisconsin Economic Development Corporation or Wisconsin Department of Children and Families guidelines as applicable. 
(3)  The owner or operator of any business or building has the right to refuse entry or service to any person who fails to comply with section 54-35(2). 
(4)  Penalties. 
a.  Upon conviction, any person found to be in violation of section 54-35(2)a. shall forfeit no more than $25.00 upon the first conviction, $50.00 upon the second conviction, and $100.00 upon the third or subsequent conviction. 
b.  Upon conviction, the owner or operator of any business, organization, and non-profit entity within the City of Racine found to be in violation of section 54-35(2)b. shall forfeit no less than $50.00 no more than $500.00. 
c.  The city attorney and city clerk are authorized to pursue license revocation for any business licensed by the City of Racine for failing to comply with section 54-35(2)b. 
(5)  Sunset. 
a.  This ordinance shall be effective July 27, 2020 at 8:00 a.m., and shall remain in effect until 11:59 p.m., December 31, 2020, unless extended or earlier terminated or modified by the common council. 
b.  Notwithstanding anything else contained herein, no later than October 20, 2020, the public health administrator shall provide a full report to the common council regarding the state of the COVID-19 pandemic in the City of Racine. The common council may take action to extend, modify, or terminate the application of this wear of face coverings ordinance upon receipt of the public health administrator's report hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 0006-20, pt. 1, 7-21-20)  
Secs. 54-36—54-55. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PUBLIC SWIMMING POOLS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Plumbing standards, § 18-466 et seq. 
 
Sec. 54-56. - Administrative authority; inspections. 
Authority for the control of public swimming pools and the administration of the provisions of this article relating thereto is vested in the health officer of the city. The health officer or his duly appointed agent is authorized to examine every public swimming pool during, or immediately prior to, all periods of operation. 
(Code 1973, § 11.25.020)  
Sec. 54-57. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Any person violating any provision of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a forfeiture in an amount as provided in section 1-15. Each day that a violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Code 1973, § 11.25.100)  
Sec. 54-58. - Violations; payment of forfeiture in lieu of court appearance. 
(a)  Any person charged with a violation of the offenses listed under subsection (b) of this section may pay the amount enumerated therein at the police department in lieu of a court appearance. Persons wishing to contest charges contained in subsection (b) of this section may contact the police department to arrange a court appearance date. 
(b)  The following forfeitures for the offenses listed herein may be paid at the police department: 
Section 
number 	Violation 	Forfeiture 
54-61 	Swimming pool permit required 	$75.00 
 
(Code 1973, § 11.26.020; Ord. No. 41-90, pt. 1, 11-20-90) 
State Law reference— Actions for violation of municipal regulations, forfeitures, stipulations, Wis. Stats. § 66.12(1)(b); citations for ordinance violations, Wis. Stats. § 66.119.  
Sec. 54-59. - Statutory provisions adopted. 
Chapters HSS 171 and 172 of the Wisconsin Administrative Code are hereby adopted and by reference made a part of this article as though fully set forth herein. Any future amendments, revisions or modifications of the sections incorporated in this article are intended to be made a part of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 11.25.040)  
Sec. 54-60. - Construction permit required; application; plans and specifications; issuance; records. 
(a)  No person shall construct, establish, maintain or make any major alteration to a public swimming pool without a written permit issued by the health officer. 
(b)  Any person wishing to obtain a permit as required by this article shall file a request for such permit with the health officer. The request shall be accompanied by a copy of a letter showing transmittal of plans and specifications for such public swimming pool as required by the state board of health, and shall also furnish the names and addresses of the owner and the architect or engineer and the location of the proposed swimming pool. 
(c)  If deemed necessary upon a preliminary survey, the health officer may demand, and the applicant shall furnish, the detailed plans and specifications of the public swimming pool so as to permit the health officer to cause to be made a comprehensive review of any of the following: the pumping and hydraulic details, servicing facilities and surrounding area, electrical layout, treatment equipment, operating data, and such other items as may be essential to enable the health officer to properly evaluate the public swimming pool within the purposes and provisions of this article. 
(d)  No actual construction or alteration of a public swimming pool shall be commenced unless and until a permit as is required by this article has been issued and a copy of a letter of approval of the plans and specifications from the state board of health has been filed with the health officer. 
(e)  The issuance of any permit under this article shall not prevent the health officer from thereafter revoking any such permit when issued in error. Upon revocation of such permit, all construction shall cease. 
(f)  Upon issuance of a permit under this article, construction shall be undertaken subject to any conditions of the permit and shall proceed in accordance with the plans as approved. No change or modification of any item governed by any section of this article shall be made without first obtaining the express written approval of the health officer. 
(g)  Except as regulated in this article, if any construction for which a permit under this article has been issued is not started within six months from the date of the issuance of the permit, or if construction ceases for more than six months, then such permit shall lapse and be void and no construction shall be begun or resumed until a new permit is obtained. 
(h)  No public swimming pool shall be permitted to operate until approved by the health officer in accordance with this article. 
(i)  All preexisting public swimming pools that have been constructed and are in operation on the effective date of this article shall comply with all pertinent sections of this article and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto by April 1, 1970. 
(j)  The public swimming pool operator shall maintain such daily records and furnish such monthly reports as may be required by the health officer. 
(Code 1973, § 11.25.050)  
Sec. 54-61. - Operating permit required; display. 
(a)  No person may conduct, maintain, manage or operate a public swimming pool without first having obtained from the health officer or his designee a permit therefor. 
(b)  The permit required by this section shall be publicly displayed in the pool area. Such permit may contain whatever limitations are deemed necessary by the health officer for the protection of the public. 
(Code 1973, § 11.25.060)  
Sec. 54-62. - Fees. 
(a)  No fee shall be required of an applicant seeking a permit to construct or alter a public swimming pool. 
(b)  The health officer shall issue an operating permit for a public swimming pool upon the payment of the annual fee which is established by the board of health and approved by the common council. Such permit shall expire on June 30 of each year. 
(Code 1973, § 11.25.080)  
Sec. 54-63. - Nontransferability of permit. 
No permit for a public swimming pool which has been issued under this article shall be transferable. Every owner or operator of a public swimming pool shall notify the health officer in writing within 24 hours after having relinquished ownership or having sold, transferred, given away, or otherwise disposed of such interest or control of any public swimming place. 
(Code 1973, § 11.25.090)  
Sec. 54-64. - Suspension of operating permit. 
The health officer shall have the authority to suspend the operating permit issued to any person upon evidence of the failure of such person to operate or maintain the swimming pool and maintain records and prepare reports in conformity with this article and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto. No permit shall be suspended by the health officer until written notice has first been given to the permittee advising him of the violations of the article or the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto and allowing him a reasonable period of time to correct such conditions. When in the opinion of the health officer such failure to operate or maintain the swimming place in conformity with this article and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto has resulted in a serious and immediate hazard to the health or safety of any person, the health officer shall have the right summarily to suspend the operating permit. Upon suspension of such permit, the swimming place shall remain closed until such time as compliance has been obtained and the permit reinstated. 
(Code 1973, § 11.25.070(a))  
Sec. 54-65. - Revocation of permit; hearing. 
The health officer may revoke any public swimming pool permit for failure to comply with the regulations referred to in this article or when the permit has been obtained through nondisclosure, misrepresentation or misstatement of a material fact. Before a public swimming pool permit is revoked, the person to whom such permit has been issued shall receive notice in writing from the health officer enumerating instances of failure to comply with the regulations. Any person affected by any notice which has been issued in connection with the enforcement of any provision of this article or of any rule or regulation adopted pursuant thereto may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the board of appeals as established by subsection 18-61 et seq., provided that such person shall file with the health officer a written petition requesting such hearing and setting forth a statement of the grounds therefor within 30 days after the day the notice was served. Within ten days of receipt of such petition, the board of appeals shall set a time and place for such hearing and shall give the petitioner written notice thereof. At such hearing, the petitioner shall be given an opportunity to be heard and to show cause why such notice should be modified or withdrawn. The hearing before the board of appeals shall be commenced not later than 30 days after the date on which the petition was filed, provided that upon written application of the petitioner to the health officer, the health officer may postpone the date of the hearing for a reasonable time beyond such 30-day period if in his judgment the petitioner has submitted a good and sufficient reason for such postponement. The board of appeals shall have the power to administer oaths and affirmations in connection with the conduct of any hearing held in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 11.25.070(b))  
Chapter 58 - HISTORIC PRESERVATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Adoption of a historic building code, § 18-32. 
State Law reference— Historic properties, Wis. Stats. § 66.037. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 58-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings given in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Certificate of appropriateness for properties within a designated H-Historic Properties district is an official ruling of the department of city development or planning, heritage, and design commission approving exterior treatment for activities such as additions, alterations, rehabilitation, restoration, construction, reconstruction or demolition of a landmark, landmark site or contributing property, or new construction on vacant or cleared lots or parcels. 
Commission means the planning, heritage, and design commission created under this Code of Ordinances. 
Contributing property is a designated property or structure that, in accordance with criteria in section 58-61, contributes to the character or understanding of the historical context of a defined geographic area. A contributing property is designated as one or a multiple of properties or structures that comprise the cohesive basis for the establishment of an H-Historic properties district. 
Historic district means a geographic area designated by this chapter which contains one or more landmarks or landmark sites and the abutting properties to which improvements affect the appearance and preservation of the landmark sites. 
Improvement means any building, structure, work of art or nature or other object constituting an addition to the real estate. 
Landmark means any improvement which has a special character or historic or cultural interest or value in the development and heritage of the city and has been designated by the common council as a landmark. 
Landmark site means any parcel of land of historic significance due to the presence of a landmark located thereon, or within the immediate vicinity thereof, the location of a historic event or property which provides a view of a landmark and has been designated by the common council as a landmark site. 
(Code 1973, § 29.02.010; Ord. No. 23-05, pt. 1, 12-6-05; Ord. No. 4-09, pt. 1, 2-18-09; Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 5, 11-12-19) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 58-2. - Purpose and intent. 
Whereas, historical, architectural, archeological and cultural heritage are among our most important assets, it is hereby declared to be the purpose of this chapter for the city to engage in a comprehensive program of historic preservation to promote the use and conservation of historic property for education, welfare, inspiration, pleasure and enrichment of the people and foster civic pride in the beauty and accomplishments of the past. 
(Code 1973, § 29.01.010; Ord. No. 23-05, pt. 1, 12-6-05)  
Secs. 58-3—58-25. - Reserved.

ARTICLE III. - SITES AND ZONING DISTRICTS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) ---

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 58-51—58-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - HISTORIC PROPERTIES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 23-05, adopted Dec. 6, 2005, repealed former §§ 58-61—58-63 and enacted §§ 58-61—58-65 to read as herein set out. The provisions of former §§ 58-61—58-63 derived from the 1973 Code and pertained to similar subject matter. 
 
Sec. 58-61. - Criteria for designation of landmarks, landmark sites and contributing properties. 
(a)  The criteria for the designation of properties to be landmarks, landmark sites, and contributing properties shall be that which: 
(1)  Exemplifies or reflects the cultural, archaeological, political, economic, social or religious history. 
(2)  Is identified with personages, events or periods of history. 
(3)  Embodies distinguishing characteristics of architecture, an architect or architectural materials, craftsmanship or works of nature. 
(4)  In its inherent historical nature provides the citizenry with educational or aesthetic enrichment. 
(5)  Contributes to the character or understanding of a district and is one property, or a multiple of properties or structures, that helps form the basis of a district. 
(Ord. No. 23-05, pt. 1, 12-6-05; Ord. No. 4-09, pt. 2, 2-18-09)  
Sec. 58-62. - Procedure for identification of landmarks, landmark sites or contributing properties for designation. 
(a)  Upon payment by the applicant of a processing fee as adopted by the common council and after due consideration and deliberation, the commission shall apply the criteria specified in this division to identify such properties as it may deem appropriate to be designated as a landmark, landmark site, or contributing property. 
(b)  The commission shall hold a public hearing before recommending any designation of a landmark or landmark site or contributing property. At least ten days prior to the hearing, the commission shall provide written notice to the following: 
(1)  The owners of record of the affected properties and the occupants thereof. 
(2)  Reserved. 
(3)  The chief building inspector. 
(4)  The mayor and alderpersons. 
(c)  After giving notice as provided in subsection (b), the commission shall conduct the public hearing. In addition to the notified persons and general public, the commission shall have the right to call such other witnesses and to examine such records as it deems necessary. 
(d)  Within 30 days after the close of the public hearing, the commission may recommend to the common council the designation of the property as either a landmark, landmark site, or contributing property or recommend the rescinding of such designation. The document of designation shall set forth the criteria required in section 58-61 which apply to the property so affected. After such recommendation of designation or rescission has been made, the commission shall provide written notice of its recommendation to the property owners of record and those persons who appeared at the public hearing. 
(e)  After making its findings and recommendation under subsection (d), the commission may petition the common council for the rezoning of the subject area or parcel to facilitate such a designation. If the common council determines to designate the landmark, landmark site or contributing property and appropriate adjacent lands, it may rezone it as "H." historic properties district, or rescind the "H." historic properties district, at city expense, in compliance with section 114-77. Only designations receiving affirmative common council action shall have the force and effect of this division. 
(f)  Following the rezoning, the commission shall cause such designation of a landmark or landmark site to be recorded at commission expense in the county register of deeds office. 
(Ord. No. 23-05, pt. 1, 12-6-05; Ord. No. 4-09, pt. 3, 2-18-09; Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 7, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 58-63. - Maintenance and repair of landmark, landmark site or contributing property and prevention of neglect. 
(a)  Subject to obtaining the required permits, ordinary maintenance and repair of designated landmarks, landmark sites or contributing properties may be undertaken without a finding of appropriateness by the department of city development (department) or commission if the activity involves maintenance and repair of existing features. Ordinary maintenance and repair shall include, but not be limited to, any activities which do not change the structural portions of the building or structure or irreversibly change the exterior appearance. Ordinary maintenance and repair shall not be considered either a minor or major change. If the activity does involve the substantial or irreversible change of the exterior appearance than commission review is required. All reviews shall be conducted as specified by sections 58-64, 58-64.5, and 114-619 of the Municipal Code. Subsection 58-63(a) shall not apply to properties designated as landmarks or landmark sites under this chapter prior to January 1, 2006, unless the landmark or landmark site is redesignated in accordance with section 58-66. 
(b)  No owner or occupant of a landmark or landmark site shall fail to keep such property in good repair. 
(c)  In the repair or replacement of a property that is designated as a historic landmark or included within a historic district or neighborhood conservation district under this section, the owner shall use the same materials, or materials which are similar in design, color, scale, architectural appearance, and other visual qualities to the original materials. 
(Ord. No. 23-05, pt. 1, 12-6-05; Ord. No. 7-07, pt. 1, 5-1-07; Ord. No. 4-09, pt. 4, 2-18-09; Ord. No. 0009-19, pt. 1, 5-21-19)  
Sec. 58-63.4. - Building permits required. 
Except as provided in section 58-63, for purposes of this chapter, the following exterior alterations to designated landmarks, landmark sites or contributing properties, or construction on vacant or cleared lots or parcels require a finding of appropriateness and a building permit: 
(a)  Porches and exterior stairs. 
(b)  Exterior doors. 
(c)  Front yard fencing. 
(d)  Siding. 
(e)  Windows. 
(f)  Roofs and chimneys. 
(g)  Decks, fire escapes, exit platforms, and other exterior structural elements. 
(h)  Building additions and exterior alterations. 
(i)  New construction on vacant or cleared lot or parcel. 
(j)  Accessory structures. 
(Ord. No. 4-09, pt. 5, 2-18-09)  
Sec. 58-63.5. - Preapplication conference for alterations to landmarks, landmark sites and contributing properties. 
Prior to making a formal application for a finding of appropriateness for alterations to a landmark, landmark site properties or contributing property, a preapplication conference is highly recommended. The purpose of the conference is to acquaint all pertinent city staff with the proposal and acquire the views and concerns of those participating. The preapplication conference occurs with the department at the conceptual stage of the project when plans are flexible and adjustments are possible. The preapplication conference is also intended to assist the applicant in bringing the project plan into conformance with this article and other applicable regulations. 
(Ord. No. 4-09, pt. 5, 2-18-08)  
Sec. 58-64. - Alterations and new construction. 
(a)  Within a designated H-Historic Properties district no owner or owner's agent shall receive a building permit to commence an activity resulting in a minor or major change to the exterior appearance of a designated landmark, landmark site, contributing property, or a vacant or cleared lot or parcel without first obtaining a finding of appropriateness. 
(b)  Repair or replacement activities shall be in conformance with section 58-63(c). 
(c)  Minor changes: for purposes of this chapter, the department may review an application and render a finding of appropriateness if an activity is determined by the department to be a minor change that does not alter the exterior appearance of a property, or vacant or cleared lot or parcel. The department shall conduct a review in accordance with subsection (f) below. 
(d)  Major changes: for purposes of this chapter, the commission shall review an application and render a finding of appropriateness if an activity is determined by the department to be a major change that will result in the substantial or irreversible alteration or demolition of, or the construction of any improvement upon a part or the entire exterior of such designated landmark, landmark site, or contributing property, or new construction on a vacant or cleared lot or parcel. The commission shall conduct a review in accordance with subsection (f) below, section 58-64.5, and section 114-619. 
(e)  The chief building inspector shall not accept applications for building permits for exterior modifications, new construction, or razing permits, nor issue such permits for properties for which the owner or its representative has a petition filed for the consideration of a rezoning to the "H" historic properties district designation. Subsections (a) through (g) shall not apply to properties designated under this chapter as landmarks or landmark sites prior to January 1, 2006, unless redesignated in accordance with section 58-66. 
(f)  Findings of appropriateness shall be rendered unless it is determined that: 
(1)  The activity will be detrimental to the maintenance and overall historic character of the landmark, landmark site, contributing property or district; 
(2)  The activity will impede the current or future preservation or restoration of the subject property or district; 
(3)  Adequate measures will not be taken to protect the integrity of distinctive features, finishes, construction techniques, or examples of craftsmanship of the subject or adjacent landmark, landmark sites or contributing property; 
(4)  The activity is contrary or detrimental to the findings of the original designation of the subject property or district; 
(5)  The activity will not stabilize the landmark, landmark site or contributing property for future preservation or restoration efforts; or 
(6)  The activity does not conform to criteria adopted by the common council to provide guidelines for the alteration and restoration of historic properties such as, but not limited to, those contained in section 58-64.5, H-Historic Properties district design guidelines and section 114-619, Architectural guidelines. 
(g)  The application for a finding of appropriateness, shall be accompanied by all information and applicable fees required for a finding with respect to the standards of subsection (f). Within ten days of submittal for the department, and 45 days of submittal for the commission, a review of the application shall be conducted and a written finding issued to the applicant, and the chief building inspector by the director of city development. 
(1)  Upon a finding of appropriateness, the applicant may request all necessary permits and, upon receiving such permits, proceed with the approved activity. 
(2)  Within 90 days after the date of denial or of a finding of appropriateness, the applicant may adjust the plans to address factors that resulted in the finding, and resubmit the adjusted plans for review as described in [subsections] (c) or (d) above. 
(h)  In instances of overlapping jurisdictions between the department and/or commission and a design or development review body established by chapter 114, the design or development review body shall conduct the application review, consult with the department and/or commission, and where substantiated, issue a finding of appropriateness following the standards provided in subsection (f), section 58-64.5 and section 114-619. 
(Ord. No. 23-05, pt. 1, 12-6-05; Ord. No. 7-07, pt. 2, 5-1-07; Ord. No. 4-09, pt. 6, 2-18-09; Ord. No. 0009-19, pts. 2, 3, 5-21-19; Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 8, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 58-64.5. - H-Historic Properties district design guidelines. 
(a)  General guidelines. The following general guidelines are based on 36 CFR Part 67, the Secretary of the Interior's Standard, and shall be applied to projects taking into consideration economic and technical feasibility. 
(1)  A property shall be used for its historic purpose or be placed in a new use that requires minimal change to the defining characteristics of the building and its site and environment. 
(2)  The historic character of a property shall be retained and preserved. The removal of historic materials or alteration of features and spaces that characterize a property shall be avoided. 
(3)  Each property shall be recognized as a physical record of its time, place, and use. Changes that create a false sense of historical development, such as adding conjectural features or architectural elements from other buildings, shall not be withdrawn. 
(4)  Most properties change over time; those changes that have acquired historic significance in their own right shall be retained and preserved. 
(5)  Distinctive features, finishes, and construction techniques or examples of craftsmanship that characterize a historic property shall be preserved. 
(6)  Deteriorated historic features shall be repaired rather than replaced. Where the severity of deterioration requires replacement of a distinctive feature, the new feature shall match the old in design, color, texture, and other visual qualities and, where possible, materials. Replacement of missing features shall be substantiated by documentary, physical, or pictorial evidence. 
(7)  Chemical or physical treatments, such as sandblasting, that causes damage to historic materials shall not be used. The surface cleaning of structures, if appropriate, shall be undertaken using the gentlest means possible. 
(8)  Significant archeological resources affected by a project shall be protected and preserved. If such resources must be disturbed, mitigation measures shall be undertaken.
