ARTICLE III. - DISCIPLINE AND GRIEVANCE PROCEDURE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 09-11, pt. 1, adopted Oct. 12, 2011, repealed Art. III in its entirety and enacted a new Art. III, § 74-66, 74-67. Former Art. III, § 74-66, 74-67, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1973, § 3.136.010; Ord. No. 19-00, pt. 1, adopted Sept. 20, 2000; Ord. No. 08-08, pt. 13, adopted June 3, 2008. 
 
Sec. 74-66. - Purpose; discipline; definitions. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this article is to provide guidance for employees and supervisors concerning discipline of covered city employees. In addition, the purpose of this article is to establish a procedure to provide those city employees who are not covered by a grievance procedure as part of a collective bargaining agreement to resolve grievances while in the employ of the city. 
This procedure is intended to comply with Wis. Stats. § 66.0509, and provides a grievance procedure addressing issues concerning workplace safety, discipline, and termination. This procedure applies to all employees covered under Wis. Stats. § 66.0509, and excepts all police and fire employees subject to Wis. Stats. § 62.13(5). A covered employee may appeal any level of discipline under this grievance procedure. Any grievance filed under the article shall be filed on behalf of an individual employee. No grievance may be filed on behalf of more than one employee, a group of employees, or any collective bargaining unit. 
Nothing in this article is intended to create a legally binding contact between the city and covered employees or to change the at-will nature of employment for covered employees with the city. Employment with the city is voluntarily entered into and employees are free to resign at any time with or without cause. Similarly, the city may terminate the employment of any covered employee, at any time with or without cause, subject to applicable federal, state, or local law. The city reserves its management rights to exclusively manage its operations. 
(b)  Discipline. To the extent possible, it is in the best interests of the employees and the city to ensure fair treatment of all employees and in making certain that disciplinary actions are prompt, uniform, and impartial. 
Discipline may result when an employee's actions do not conform with generally accepted standards of good behavior, when an employee violates a policy or rule, when an employee's performance is not acceptable, or when the employee's conduct is detrimental to the interests of the city. Disciplinary action may call for any of four steps - warning, reprimand, suspension (with or without pay) or termination of employment - depending on the problem and the number of occurrences. There may be circumstances when one or more steps are bypassed. Certain types of employee problems are serious enough to justify either a suspension or termination of employment without going through progressive discipline steps. The city reserves the right, in its sole discretion, to impose disciplinary action as may be appropriate to the particular circumstances. 
(c)  [Definitions.] For the purposes of this article, the following definitions apply: 
(1)  Discipline and disciplinary actions are actions taken to correct a problem or misbehavior, deter of further problems or misbehavior, prepare an employee for satisfactory service in the future, or separate an employee where an employee has demonstrated an inability or unwillingness to perform satisfactory service. Approved discipline and disciplinary actions are: 
a.  Warning. Written documentation given to an employee describing specific disciplinary infractions, such as inappropriate conduct, poor performance, or violation of work rules/policies. Such documentation may include information regarding past infractions and what action will be taken if the employee fails to improve. A warning is the first step of formal discipline. 
b.  Reprimand. Written documentation given to an employee describing continuing or more serious specific disciplinary infractions, such as inappropriate conduct, poor performance, or violation of work rules/policies. Such documentation may include information regarding past infractions and shall include what action will be taken if the employee fails to improve. A reprimand is more serious than a warning. 
c.  Suspension. A disciplinary measure, including written documentation, in which employees are suspended without pay for a specified period of time due to violations including continuing or serious specific disciplinary infractions, such as inappropriate conduct, poor performance, or violation of work rules/policies. Such documentation shall include what action will be taken if the employee fails to improve. 
(2)  Employee discipline includes all levels of progressive discipline, but shall not include the following personnel actions: 
a.  Placing an employee on paid administrative leave pending an internal investigation; 
b.  Counseling sessions, meetings, or other pre-disciplinary action, whether written or oral; 
c.  Actions taken to address work performance, including establishment and/or use of a performance improvement plan or job targets; 
d.  Demotion, transfer, or change in job assignment; or 
e.  Other personnel actions taken by the employer that are not a form of discipline. 
(3)  Employee termination shall include action taken by the employer to terminate an individual's employment for misconduct or performance reasons, but shall not include the following personnel actions: 
a.  Voluntary quit; 
b.  Layoff, furlough, or failure to be recalled from layoff at the expiration of the recall period; 
c.  Time lost because of a lack of work available to the employee; 
d.  Job abandonment, "no-call," "no-show," or other failure to report to work; 
f.  Termination of employment due to lack of qualification or license or other inability to perform job duties; or 
g.  Retirement. 
(3)  Workplace safety is defined as conditions of employment regarding employees' physical health or safety, and specifically including only: the safe operation of workplace equipment and tools, safety of the physical work environment, provision of personal protective equipment, workplace violence, and training related to same. 
(Ord. No. 09-11, pt. 1, 10-12-11)  
Sec. 74-67. - Filing of complaint; hearings; decisions. 
(a)  Procedure. Employees should first discuss complaints or questions with their immediate supervisor. Every reasonable effort should be made by supervisors and employees to resolve any questions, problems or misunderstandings that have arisen before filing a grievance. An employee whose complaint concerning the employee's discipline, termination, or workplace safety has not been resolved informally to the employee's satisfaction with the employee's immediate supervisor may obtain a review of the complaint under the following procedures: 
(1)  Step 1: Supervisor review. The employee shall reduce his complaint to writing, using the form prescribed by the human resources department, and submit it to the employee's immediate supervisor within 15 working days after the employee knew or should have known the cause of such grievance. Such complaint shall be referred to in this section as "the grievance." Any written grievance filed under this article must contain the following information: 
• The name and position of the employee filing it; 
• A statement of the issue involved; 
• A statement of the relief sought; 
• A detailed explanation of the facts supporting the grievance; 
• The specific date(s) the event(s) giving rise to the grievance took place; 
• The identity of the policy, procedure or rule that is being challenged; 
• The steps the employee has taken to review the matter, either orally or in writing, with the employee's supervisor; and 
• The employee's signature and the date. 
The supervisor shall answer the grievance within five working days. If the grievance is answered in a manner unsatisfactory to the employee, the employee may proceed to step 2. 
(2)  Step 2: Administrative manager review. If the grievance is not resolved at step 1, the employee may appeal the grievance to the employee's administrative manager within five working days of the receipt of the decision of the employee's supervisor at step 1. The administrative manager will review the matter and inform the employee of his/her decision, if possible, within ten working days of receipt of the grievance. 
(3)  Step 3: City administrator review. If the grievance is not resolved at step 2, the employee may appeal the grievance to the city administrator within five working days of the receipt of the decision of the administrative manager at step 2. The city administrator will review the matter and inform the employee of his/her decision, if possible, within ten working days of receipt of the grievance. 
(4)  Step 4: Impartial hearing officer. If the grievance is not resolved at step 3, the employee may request in writing, within five business days following receipt of the city administrator's decision, a request for review by an impartial hearing officer. 
a.  The parties shall, within ten business days, jointly request that the Wisconsin Employment Relations Commission appoint an impartial hearing officer. The parties shall equally share the cost of the independent hearing officer, which payment shall be made at the same time as the request therefor. 
b.  In all cases, the grievant shall have the burden of proof to support the grievance. The impartial hearing officer will determine whether the city acted in an arbitrary and capricious manner. This process does not involve a hearing equivalent to a hearing before a court of law. The rules of evidence will not be followed. 
c.  Depending on the issue involved, the impartial hearing officer will determine whether a hearing is necessary, or whether the case may be decided based on a submission of written documents. If the impartial hearing officer determines that a hearing is necessary, the parties shall attempt to agree in advance upon the issue involved and stipulate to facts to be used at the hearing. The independent hearing officer shall meet with the parties at the earliest possible date which can be set to review the evidence and hear testimony relating to the grievance. All such hearings shall be held at Racine City Hall. The impartial hearing officer shall prepare a written decision. 
d.  The impartial hearing officer may order either party to pay the entire amount of the independent hearing officer's fees upon such terms, and for such reasons, as the independent hearing officer finds appropriate and equitable. 
(5)  Step 5: Review by the common council. If the grievance is not resolved after step 4, the employee or the city administrator shall request, within five business days of receipt of the written decision from the hearing officer, a written review by the common council. The appeal shall be submitted as a communication to the common council, using a form prescribed by the human resources department, through the finance and personnel committee. The finance and personnel committee shall review the matter at its next regularly scheduled meeting, subject to the notice requirements of the open meetings law, and make a recommendation to the common council. The finance and personnel committee shall not take testimony or evidence; it may make a recommendation only upon a determination whether the hearing officer reached an arbitrary or incorrect result based on a review of the record before the hearing officer. The matter will be forwarded to the common council at its next regular meeting. The common council shall not take testimony or evidence; it may determine whether the hearing officer reached an arbitrary or incorrect result based on a review of the record before the hearing officer. The common council, through the city clerk, will inform the employee of its findings and decision in writing within ten working days of the common council meeting. A two-thirds vote of the common council shall be required to overturn the decision of the independent hearing officer. Absent such a supermajority vote, the decision of the independent hearing officer shall be affirmed. The decision of the common council shall be final and binding. 
(b)  An employee may not file a grievance outside of the time limits set forth above. If the employee fails to meet the deadlines set forth above, the grievance will be considered resolved. If it is impossible to comply with the deadlines due to meeting notice requirements or meeting preparation, the grievance will be reviewed at the next possible meeting date. An employee will conduct all activities related to preparing the grievance, other than delivering the grievance to the appropriate person as described in the various steps above, during nonworking hours and shall not otherwise be compensated for time spent in preparing his/her grievance. An employee shall not be permitted union representation at any stage in the grievance process. 
(c)  Administrative managers. Notwithstanding anything else contained herein any grievance by an administrative manager regarding discipline or workplace safety shall commence at step 3, using a form prescribed by the human resources department including the information required for step 1, above, within 15 working days after the employee knew or should have known the cause of such grievance. Notwithstanding anything else contained herein any grievance by an administrative manager regarding that administrative manager's termination based on a charge of official misconduct or inefficiency: 
(1)  Shall be initiated in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 17.16(3). 
(2)  Shall commence at step 4 as set forth above. 
(3)  If neither the employee nor the city appeals the decision of the impartial hearing officer, the common council shall affirm the decision of the impartial hearing office at its next regularly scheduled meeting after the time for appeal has expired, subject to the notice requirements of the open meetings law. 
(4)  If the employee or the city appeals the decision of the impartial hearing officer, such appeal shall be heard by the common council as follows: 
a.  Whenever any charge of official misconduct, malfeasance, or inefficiency shall be preferred against an administrative manager employed by the city, the common council shall proceed within 30 days, or such other time as agreed between the parties, after the charge so filed with the city clerk, to hear and determine the case upon its merits. 
b.  The mayor may suspend such officer against whom charges have been preferred until the disposition of the charges and appoint a person to fill the vacancy temporarily until the charges have been disposed of. 
c.  The common council may, for the purpose of such hearing, compel the attendance of witnesses and the production of all papers by subpoena when necessary for the purpose of such hearing. 
d.  Two-thirds of all the members of the common council elect shall have the power to dismiss such administrative manager from office for malfeasance, misconduct, or inefficiency in office, upon due process hearing as provided in this section. 
(Ord. No. 09-11, pt. 2, 10-12-11)  
Chapter 78 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Commissioner of public works, § 2-531 et seq.; citation system for enforcement of ordinances, § 2-551 et seq.; property maintenance code, § 18-691 et seq.; burning of leaves or rubbish prohibited, § 82-33; utilities, ch. 98. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 78-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Chief building inspector means the chief building inspector of the city or the authorized representative thereof. 
Collecting and transporting service means a municipal or privately operated agency, business or service for the collecting or transporting of solid waste for disposal purposes. 
Commercial or business premises means any public or private place, building and/or enterprise devoted in whole or in part to a business enterprise, whether nonprofit or profitmaking in nature, except for purposes of this chapter, where such place, building and/or enterprise constitutes a single-family premises or multiple-family premises. 
Dwelling unit means any habitable room or group of adjoining habitable rooms located within a building and forming a single unit with facilities which are used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking and eating of meals, and is interchangeable with the word "household." 
Health officer means the public health administrator of the city or the authorized representative thereof. 
Institutional premises means any institutional enterprise, including, but not limited to, hospitals, churches, schools, nursing homes, hotels, motels, and homes for the aging. 
Medical waste means isolation wastes, infectious agents, human blood and blood products, pathological wastes, sharps, body parts, contaminated bedding, surgical wastes, potentially contaminated laboratory wastes and dialysis wastes. 
Multiple-family premises means all housing buildings having five or more dwelling units. 
On-street business means a business which operates principally in a building which has one or more exterior sides abutting the public right-of-way. 
Premises means a plotted lot or part thereof or an unplotted lot or parcel of land or plot of land, either occupied or unoccupied by any dwelling or nondwelling structure. 
Salvageable materials means discarded material no longer of value as originally intended, but which is stored or retained for salvage, sale or future reuse. 
Sanitary landfill means a method of disposing of solid waste on land without creating nuisances or hazards to public health or safety, by utilizing the principles of engineering to confine the solid waste to the smallest practical volume, and to cover it with a layer of earth at the conclusion of each day's operation, or at such more frequent intervals as may be necessary. 
Single-family premises means any housing building containing a single-family dwelling unit. For the purposes of this chapter, any one- to four-dwelling unit housing building shall fall into this category. Each unit shall be regarded as a single-family dwelling unit. 
Solid waste means solid wastes consisting of garbage, refuse, and other discarded or salvageable material, including waste material resulting from domestic use, public service activities, and commercial and industrial operations, but not including solid or dissolved waste material in wastewater effluents or other common water pollutants. Solid wastes consist of the following categories: 
(1)  Domestic waste, meaning garbage, refuse, ashes and other waste, including, but not limited to, metal, glass, paper, wood, rags, plastic, rubber, cloth, cans, bottles, litter, leaves, shrubbery, tree trimmings, grass clippings, brush, small quantities of construction and/or demolition wastes, and limited nauseous and/or offensive wastes, with such wastes resulting from human habitation and the usual routine of housekeeping of residential units or incidental to their operation. 
(2)  Commercial waste, meaning wastes resulting from the operation of business enterprises, including but not limited to offices, stores, restaurants and similar businesses. 
(3)  Industrial waste, meaning wastes resulting from manufacturing or industrial processes and operations. 
(4)  Garbage, meaning wastes resulting from the handling, cooking, processing, preparation, serving, storage and consumption of food, including animal, fish, fowl, fruits, vegetables or other matter which is subject to decomposition, decay, putrefaction and the generation of offensive and noxious gases and odors. 
(5)  Refuse, meaning miscellaneous combustible and noncombustible waste material resulting from housekeeping activities, including but not limited to cans, bottles, plastic, paper, ashes, glass, lawn and garden waste, metals, rubber, street wastes, wood, cloth, litter, leaves, shrubbery, brush and cardboard. 
(6)  Bulky waste, meaning discarded articles of such dimension as are not normally collected with domestic waste, including but not limited to items of appliance, furniture, plumbing fixtures, windows and doors, such as would be considered household wastes. 
(7)  Construction or demolition waste, meaning waste resulting from building construction or demolition, alteration or repair, including excavated material, remodeling and waste such as concrete, stone, asphalt, sod, earth, dirt and brick. 
(8)  Vehicle waste, meaning waste resulting from discarded items of a vehicle, such as tires, mufflers, exhaust pipes, engine parts, and whole vehicles. 
(9)  Tree waste, meaning waste resulting from the care of trees, shrubs and bushes from pruning, wind and storm damage, or from trimming, including branches, limbs, trunks and stumps. 
(10)  Hazardous or toxic waste, meaning waste materials or substances which during normal storage or handling may be a potential cause of harm, sickness or death, such as explosives, petroleum products, medical or pharmaceutical materials, corrosive chemicals, and poisonous or pathogenic substances, whether in solid, liquid or gaseous form. 
(11)  Nauseous or offensive waste, meaning those wastes that are unwholesome in nature or have an unpleasant smell or which are otherwise nauseous or offensive, such as manure, filth, slops, carcasses, carrion, meat, fish, entrails, hides and hide scrapings, paint, kerosene, oily or greasy substances, and objects that may cause injury to any person or animal or damage to vehicles, such as barbed wire, briar thorns, or other similar materials or substances. 
Solid waste disposal operation means the site, facility, operating practices, and maintenance thereof, for the utilization, processing or final disposal of solid waste, including but not limited to sanitary landfill, incineration, composting, reduction, shredding, compression and salvage. 
(Code 1973, § 11.04.010; Ord. No. 28-95, pt. 1, 11-21-95; Ord. No. 18-03, pt. 18, 9-16-03; Ord. No. 31-06, pt. 1, 8-10-06) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 78-2. - Burning garbage in fireplaces prohibited. 
No person shall burn garbage or domestic waste in a fireplace or stove. 
(Ord. No. 7-92, pt. 2, § 11.20.030, 3-17-92)  
Sec. 78-3. - Promulgation of rules. 
The commissioner of public works is hereby authorized to make reasonable rules for the regulation and administration of solid waste collection, removal and disposal. Such rules shall be available to the public at the office of the commissioner of public works. 
(Code 1973, § 11.04.060)  
Sec. 78-4. - Enforcement. 
Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, it shall be the duty of the chief building inspector and the health officer to enforce the provisions of this chapter. It shall be the duty of the chief of police and the commissioner of public works to give attention throughout the city to any case of violation of this chapter and promptly report to the chief building inspector and the health officer, in writing, every violation within the city which shall come to their knowledge. 
(Code 1973, § 11.04.080; Ord. No. 18-03, pt. 19, 9-16-03)  
Sec. 78-5. - Citation. 
Whenever the chief building inspector or the health officer is notified of or discovers any violation of this chapter, he may issue a citation to the owner or agent causing, allowing or permitting such violation and request clean up by the department of public works. The property shall be assessed the cost for all work performed by the department of public works. 
If prima facie evidence exists that the occupant/tenant caused the violation, the chief building inspector or the health officer may issue a citation to the tenant or occupant. 
(Code 1973, § 11.04.070; Ord. No. 20-95, pt. 1, 9-19-95; Ord. No. 11-97, pt. 1, 7-1-97; Ord. No. 19-02, pt. 6, 12-17-02; Ord. No. 18-03, pt. 20, 9-16-03; Ord. No. 2-04, pt. 1, 2-3-04)  
Sec. 78-6. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be subject to forfeiture as provided in section 1-15. 
(Code 1973, § 11.04.090)  
Sec. 78-7. - Payment of forfeiture in lieu of court appearance. 
(a)  Any person charged with a violation of the offenses listed under subsection (b) of this section may pay the amount enumerated therein at the police department in lieu of a court appearance. Persons wishing to contest charges contained in subsection (b) of this section may contact the police department to arrange a court appearance date. 
(b)  The following forfeitures for the offenses listed herein may be paid at the police department:

Secs. 78-8—78-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 78-31. - Solid waste collection regulations generally. 
(a)  Solid waste shall be collected from single-family premises, churches, schools, except schools and buildings owned by the unified school district, service and filling stations, and on-street businesses, provided such waste is properly handled, prepared, contained, stored and located in conformance with this chapter and the rules and administrative regulations established by the commissioner of public works and the health officer. Solid waste shall also be collected under the above conditions from businesses which received collection from the city before December 1, 1995, but which would not qualify for collection as an on-street business. 
(b)  Solid waste shall not be collected by the department of public works from industrial property, off-street business property, or multiple-family premises. 
(c)  No person, unless granted a permit from the city allowing for the collection and removal of solid waste, or unless a city employee acting under the direction of the commissioner of public works, shall collect or remove any solid waste which has been deposited or placed by any person on the parkway or alleyway adjoining such person's premises for collection by the city. For purposes of this section, recyclable material deposited upon the parkway or alleyway for collection by the city shall be considered solid waste and shall be the sole property of the city. 
(Code 1973, §§ 11.04.020, 22.06.100; Ord. No. 28-95, pt. 2, 11-21-95)  
Sec. 78-32. - Transportation requirements. 
No person shall transport material of any kind whatsoever unless the means of transportation is so operated and of such construction that the contents shall not blow, fall, scatter, leak or spill upon streets or alleys, or otherwise create a nuisance. 
(Code 1973, § 11.04.030(a))  
Sec. 78-33. - Conveyance not to remain on streets. 
No public or private vehicle or other means of collecting or conveying solid waste shall be kept on any street, alley or public place, or upon any private premises within the city, longer than is reasonably necessary to collect the solid waste therefrom, except by permission of the commissioner of public works. 
(Code 1973, § 11.04.030(b))  
Sec. 78-34. - Collection by city. 
The expense of collection and removal of solid waste by the department of public works shall be paid for by the city from the solid waste collection budget as approved by the common council. To carry out the terms of this section, the commissioner of public works is empowered under terms approved by the common council to set regulations, employ all necessary labor, acquire and maintain the necessary equipment, or contract for collection. 
(Code 1973, § 11.04.040)  
Sec. 78-35. - Solid waste disposal. 
All solid waste collected by the department of public works shall be disposed of under the direction of the commissioner of public works in a manner approved by him with the concurrence of the health officer and in conformance with state department of natural resources, solid waste disposal standards, under terms approved by the common council. The expense of disposal of solid waste collected by the city shall be paid from the solid waste disposal budget. To carry out the terms of this section, the commissioner of public works is empowered under terms approved by the common council to employ necessary labor, acquire and maintain the necessary equipment or contract for disposal. 
(Code 1973, § 11.04.050)  
Sec. 78-36. - Medical waste and hazardous or toxic waste. 
(a)  No person shall place medical waste or hazardous or toxic waste out for collection by the city. 
(b)  If medical waste or hazardous or toxic waste is discovered to be placed out for collection, the commissioner of public works, in accordance with procedures approved by the health officer, and to protect the public health, safety and welfare, shall, attempt immediate contact with the occupant of the premises, who shall be requested to take custody of his/her medical waste or hazardous or toxic waste for proper disposal, and if such attempt fails, then, without prior notice to the owner or tenant, the commissioner shall take immediate action to barricade such waste and arrange for its prompt collection or disposal by an authorized entity. If the medical waste or hazardous or toxic waste is discovered after being placed in a garbage truck, the truck shall immediately be taken off its route and proper disposal of the medical waste or hazardous or toxic waste shall be made by an authorized agency. The costs of such actions and services resulting from the presence of medical waste and hazardous or toxic waste shall be billed to the owner of the property at which the waste was placed for collection, and if not paid shall be assessed against the real estate as a special charge. 
(Ord. No. 31-06, pt. 3, 8-10-06)  
Secs. 78-37—78-45. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CONTAINERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Fire hydrants and other utilities located in streets restricted, § 82-40. 
 
Sec. 78-46. - Storage and placement for collection. 
The owner and/or occupant of any premises shall be responsible for the proper and sanitary storage of all solid waste accumulated at that premises and placing the solid waste out for collection until solid waste is collected by the collecting and transporting service. Storage of solid waste shall conform with the rules and regulations concerning preparation, storage and collection set forth by the health officer and commissioner of public works of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 11.03.020(a))  
Sec. 78-47. - Preparation. 
(a)  Domestic solid waste may be mixed and placed in a common container. 
(b)  Domestic waste shall be drained of all free liquid, wrapped, packaged and/or bundled. 
(Code 1973, § 11.03.020(a)(1))  
Sec. 78-48. - Requirements; types permitted. 
Containers shall conform to regulations mutually established by the health officer and commissioner of public works of the city. In addition, they shall be regulated as follows: 
(1)  Containers that can be mutually emptied shall be durable, rust resistant, nonabsorbent, watertight, rodentproof, disposable or easily cleaned with close-fitted flytight covers. The containers shall be made of metal, plastic or other suitable materials having adequate handles or bails to facilitate handling. 
(2)  Containers may be capable of being emptied mechanically. 
(3)  All containers for the storage of solid wastes shall be maintained in such a manner as to prevent the creation of a nuisance or menace to public health. 
(4)  Containers may also be used with recommended plastic bag liners of at least two-mil weight. Plastic bags shall be kept in an acceptable container or protected areas until time of collection. 
(5)  Any and all containers deemed defective or otherwise inadequate by the commissioner of public works or health officer must be replaced within one week's time following proper notification by either official of the city. 
(6)  Any defective container not replaced subsequent to the proper notification shall be confiscated by the city. 
(7)  The occupants of each single-family dwelling and the owner or operator of each dwelling accommodating two or more families shall provide containers of an approved type sufficient to receive all solid wastes generated by that premises between the times of collection. No person shall dump or place any solid waste materials in any waterway flowing through or around the city nor on other public property or public right-of-way. 
(8)  Multiple-family premises or lodginghouses shall use mechanical means for storage and disposal. 
(Code 1973, § 11.03.020(a)(2); Ord. No. 21-90, pt. 1, 12-18-90; Ord. No. 19-02, pt. 7, 12-17-02)  
Sec. 78-49. - Mechanical dumpsters, placement of; use. 
(a)  No person shall place, or allow to be placed, a mechanical type dumpster in any public right-of-way. 
(b)  No person shall place, or allow to be placed, a mechanical dumpster at a distance closer than 15 feet from any dwelling unit, apartment, hotel, restaurant or roominghouse. 
(c)  No person shall place, or allow to be placed, a mechanical dumpster on any surface unless the surface is asphalt or concrete and well drained. 
(d)  No person shall place, leave, or dump any solid waste in or near a mechanical dumpster unless he has permission to use the dumpster or is a tenant of the building providing the dumpster facilities. 
(Code 1973, § 11.03.020(a)(2); Ord. No. 14-91, pt. 1, 5-21-91)  
Sec. 78-50. - Curb or alley line collection. 
(a)  Solid waste collection service will only be provided from within the street right-of-way, except that backdoor solid waste collection shall be provided to handicapped, disabled and elderly persons not reasonably able to place solid waste within the street right-of-way. The commissioner of public works shall establish regulations for implementation of such backdoor service. 
(b)  Solid waste material shall be placed at the curb or alley line for collection no later than 7:00 a.m. on the scheduled day of collection and no sooner than 15 hours before 7:00 a.m. of such day. 
(c)  Containers and equipment used to transport solid waste for curb or alley line collection shall be removed from the curb or alley line within 12 hours after collection. 
(d)  Containers of solid waste material placed out for curb or alley line collection shall conform to the following rules and regulations: 
(1)  All containers used for the collection of solid waste material shall be structurally sound and designed for the use of solid waste material. They shall be durable, rust resistant, nonabsorbent, watertight, rustproof and easily cleaned. Containers shall be made of metal, plastic or other suitable material, having adequate handles or bails to facilitate handling. 
(2)  One-way disposable bags made of polyethylene (minimum two-mil) or paper (minimum two-ply), properly secured, are acceptable containers for solid waste collection. 
(3)  Each container shall weigh no more than 50 pounds and shall be no greater than 32-gallon capacity. 
(4)  Any container used for collection of solid waste material shall be maintained in such a manner as to prevent the creation of a nuisance to public health and safety. 
(5)  Any container deemed defective by the commissioner of public works or health officer may be removed as refuse by the city following notification to the householder. 
(6)  Other types of containers conforming to the intent of this section and approved by the commissioner of public works may be used. 
(Code 1973, § 11.04.020(e), (f); Ord. No. 15-90, pt. 1, 4-16-90; Ord. No. 28-95, pt. 3, 11-21-95)  
Secs. 78-51—78-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PRIVATE COLLECTORS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, professions and occupations, ch. 22; license and permits generally, § 22-26 et seq. 
 
Sec. 78-61. - License required. 
(a)  No person shall engage in a waste collecting or transporting service on any street or alley in the city without a license in his own name. Each license shall bear a number corresponding to the license plate issued, which shall be prominently displayed on the vehicle used by such licensee in his business as provided in this section. Such license shall be used only by the person in whose name it is issued. Such license shall be issued by the city clerk upon approval of the commissioner of public works. The license fee for one year or fraction thereof shall be established by the common council. Each license shall automatically expire on January 1 following issuance. 
(b)  Any license issued under this section may be suspended or revoked, upon notice and hearing, by the commissioner of public works for violation of the provisions of this chapter or the rules and regulations established under the authority of the commissioner of public works. Appeal from such suspension or revocation may be made by filing an appeal, in writing, with the city clerk within five days after the decision of the commissioner of public works is issued. The appeal shall be heard and decided by the public works and services committee. 
(Code 1973, § 11.04.030(c); Ord. No. 2-93, pt. 1, 2-2-93; Ord. No. 44-04, pt. 20, 12-7-04)  
Secs. 78-62—78-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - GARBAGE DISPOSAL UNITS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Regulations regarding mechanical garbage disposers, § 18-535. 
 
Sec. 78-81. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Commercial food building means any building designed, equipped and used for storing or sheltering food or foodstuffs for human consumption, including fruits, vegetables and meats which are to be sold either at retail, at stores, clubs, hotels, restaurants, schools or other food establishments, or at wholesale, or which are prepared at food manufacturing or processing plants, whether such places of business are licensed under this Code or not; and any building where food for human consumption is prepared, sold, stored, or served; except, however, any business where packaged or canned foods are not opened on the premises; and except any business or food establishment which sells, prepares or handles food for human consumption and which provides for the disposal of all garbage and food processing wastes in connection with such business by daily incineration or by daily garbage collection. 
Dwelling unit means a single-family residence or a flat or apartment in a multiple-residence building. 
Garbage means every waste or refuse, animal, fruit or vegetable matter, liquid or otherwise, that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in or storage of meat, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetables. 
Mechanical garbage disposer means a motorized device suitable for installation under and in direct connection with a kitchen sink, that comminutes garbage to such a size as to be readily waterborne, and causes the discharge of such comminuted garbage to a sanitary sewerage system. 
(Code 1973, § 11.05.010) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 78-82. - Where required. 
Every dwelling unit of a building which contains four or more dwelling units, the construction of which is commenced after February 8, 1965, and every commercial food building shall be equipped with a properly installed mechanical garbage disposer which conforms to the specifications provided in section 78-83. 
(Code 1973, § 11.05.020)  
Sec. 78-83. - Specifications. 
The specifications for a mechanical garbage disposer are as follows: 
(1)  It shall shred garbage to a substantially uniform size, and discharge such shredded garbage particles at a reasonably uniform rate, in a waterborne or fluid form, which will flow readily through standard sink drains, approved traps, drain lines or soil lines in a manner and consistency which will not cause clogging or stoppage of the drain line or sewerage lines. 
(2)  It shall be self-scouring with no surfaces or pockets to harbor food wastes. 
(3)  It shall be of substantial construction, of adequate capacity for the intended use, and free from electrical or mechanical hazards. If activated electrically, it shall bear evidence of Underwriters' Laboratory approval. 
(4)  It shall be permanently connected to a drain to the sewerage system, and shall be free from any cross connection to a water supply. 
(Code 1973, § 11.05.030)  
Sec. 78-84. - Prerequisite to building permit. 
The chief building inspector shall not issue a permit for the construction of any commercial food building unless the plans and specifications and work to be performed include the installation of a mechanical garbage disposer. 
(Code 1973, § 11.05.040)  
Secs. 78-85—78-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - RECYCLING 
 
Sec. 78-101. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this chapter is to promote recycling, composting, and resource recovery through the administration of an effective recycling program, as provided in Wis. Stats. § 159.11, and ch. NR 544, Wisconsin Administrative Code. 
(Ord. No. 21-94, pt. 2(11.035.040), 10-4-94)  
Sec. 78-102. - Administration. 
This article shall be administered and enforced by the department of public works. 
(Ord. No. 21-94, pt. 2(11.035.020), 10-4-94)  
Sec. 78-103. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Bimetal container means a container for carbonated or malt beverages that is made primarily of a combination of steel and aluminum. 
Container board means corrugated paperboard used in the manufacture of shipping containers and related products. 
Foam polystyrene packaging means packaging made primarily from foam polystyrene that satisfies one of the following criteria: 
(1)  Is designed for serving food or beverages; 
(2)  Consists of loose particles intended to fill space and cushion the packaged article in a shipping container; or 
(3)  Consists of rigid materials shaped to hold and cushion the packaged article in a shipping container. 
HDPE means high density polyethylene, labeled by the SPI code #2. 
LDPE means low density polyethylene, labeled by the SPI code #4. 
Magazines means periodicals and other materials printed on similar paper. 
Major appliance means a residential or commercial air conditioner, clothes dryer, clothes washer, dishwasher, freezer, microwave oven, oven, refrigerator or stove. 
Multiple-family dwelling means a building containing five or more residential units, including those which are occupied seasonally. 
Newspaper means a publication that is printed on newsprint and that is published, printed or distributed at short, periodic intervals, for the dissemination of current news and general information, and includes shoppers guides which are printed on newsprint. 
Nonresidential facilities and properties means commercial, retail, industrial, institutional and governmental facilities and properties, excluding multiple-family dwellings. 
Office paper means high grade printing and writing papers from offices in nonresidential facilities and properties, such as printed white ledger and computer printout but excluding industrial process waste. 
Other resins or multiple resins means plastic resins labeled by the SPI code #7. 
Person means individual, corporation, partnership, association, local governmental unit as defined in Wis. Stats. § 66.299(1)(a), state agency or authority or federal agency. 
PETE means polyethylene terephyhalate, labeled by the SPI code #1. 
Plastic container means an individual, separate, rigid plastic bottle, can, jar or carton, except for a blister pack, that was used to contain a product that was the subject of a retail sale. 
Postconsumer waste means solid waste other than solid waste generated in the production of goods, hazardous waste, as defined in Wis. Stats. § 144.61(5), waste from construction and demolition of structures, scrap automobiles, or high-volume industrial waste, as defined in Wis. Stats. § 144.44(7)(1). 
PP means polypropylene, labeled by the SPI code #5. 
PS means polystyrene, labeled by the SPI code #6. 
PVC means polyvinyl chloride, labeled by the SPI code #3. 
Recyclable materials means lead acid batteries, major appliances, waste oil, yard waste, aluminum containers, corrugated paper or other container board, foam polystyrene packaging, glass containers, magazines, newspaper, office paper, rigid plastic containers, including those made of PETE, HDPE, PVC, LDPE, PP, PS, and other resins or multiple resins, steel containers, waste tires, and bimetal containers. 
Solid waste has the meaning specified in Wis. Stats. § 144.01(15). 
Solid waste facility has the meaning specified in Wis. Stats. § 144.43(5). 
Solid waste treatment means any method, technique or process which is designed to change the physical, chemical or biological character or composition of solid waste, including incineration. 
Waste tire means a tire that is no longer suitable for its usual purpose because of wear, damage or defect. 
Yard waste means leaves, grass clippings, yard and garden debris and brush, including clean woody vegetative material no greater than six inches in diameter excluding stumps, roots and shrubs with intact root balls. 
(Ord. No. 21-94, pt. 2(11.035.030), 10-4-94)  
Sec. 78-104. - Separation of recyclable materials. 
Occupants of single-family and two to four unit residences, multiple-family dwellings and nonresidential facilities and properties shall separate the following materials from postconsumer waste: 
(1)  Lead acid batteries. 
(2)  Major appliances. 
(3)  Waste oil. 
(4)  Yard waste. 
(5)  Aluminum containers. 
(6)  Bimetal containers. 
(7)  Corrugated paper or other container board. 
(8)  Foam polystyrene packaging. 
(9)  Glass containers. 
(10)  Magazines. 
(11)  Newspaper. 
(12)  Office paper. 
(13)  Rigid plastic containers made of PETE, HDPE, PVC, LDPE, PP, PS and other resins or multiple resins. 
(14)  Steel containers. 
(15)  Waste tires. 
(Ord. No. 21-94, pt. 2(11.035.040), 10-4-94)  
Sec. 78-105. - Separation requirements exempted. 
The separation requirements of section 78-104 do not apply to the following: 
(1)  Occupants of single-family and two to four unit residences, multiple-family dwellings and nonresidential facilities and properties who send their postconsumer waste to a processing facility licensed by the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources (DNR) that recovers the materials specified in section 78-104 from solid waste in as pure a form as is technically feasible. 
(2)  Solid waste which is burned as a supplemental fuel at a facility if less than 30 percent of the heat input to the facility is derived from the solid waste burned as supplemental fuel. 
(3)  A recyclable material specified in section 78-104(5) through (15) for which a variance has been granted by the DNR under Wis. Stats. § 159.11(m) or NR 544.14, Wisconsin Administrative Code. 
(Ord. No. 21-94, pt. 2(11.035.050), 10-4-94)  
Sec. 78-106. - Care of separated recycling materials. 
To the greatest extent practicable, the recyclable materials separated in accordance with section 78-104 shall be clean and kept free of contaminants such as food or product residue, oil or grease, or other nonrecyclable materials, including but not limited to household hazardous waste, medical waste, and agricultural chemical waste. Recyclable materials shall be stored in a manner which protects them from wind, rain, and other inclement weather conditions. 
(Ord. No. 21-94, pt. 2(11.035.060), 10-4-94)  
Sec. 78-107. - Management of lead acid batteries, major appliances, waste oil, yard waste, and waste tires. 
Occupants of single-family and two to four unit residences, multiple-family dwellings and nonresidential facilities and properties shall manage their lead acid batteries, major appliances, waste oil, and yard waste as follows: 
(1)  Lead acid batteries shall be taken for recycling to a retailer dealing in lead acid batteries or to a licensed scrap dealer. 
(2)  Major appliances which are not removed by a major appliance seller as a trade-in shall be taken for recycling to an appliance reclaimer or licensed scrap metal dealer. 
(3)  Yard waste shall be recycled in accordance with the department of public works rules and regulations governing the Green Racine Yardcare program. 
(4)  Waste oil shall be taken for recycling to an authorized waste oil dropoff location. 
(5)  Waste tires shall be recycled in accordance with the department of public works Recycle for a Green Racine policy governing waste tire disposal. 
(Ord. No. 21-94, pt. 2(11.035.070), 10-4-94)  
Sec. 78-108. - Preparation and collection of recyclable materials. 
Except as otherwise directed by the commissioner of public works, occupants of single family dwellings, two to four unit dwellings and nonresidential facilities and properties receiving solid waste collection from the city shall: 
(1)  Prepare their aluminum containers, bimetal containers, glass containers, magazines, newspaper, rigid plastic containers made of PETE, HDPE, PVC, LDPE, PP, PS, resins or multiple resins for collection at the curb/alley line as follows: 
a.  Aluminum containers shall be empty of product and rinsed clean. Cans may be flattened. 
b.  Steel and/or bimetal containers shall be empty of product and rinsed clean. Cans may be flattened. 
c.  Glass containers shall be empty of product and rinsed clean. Remove all caps, lids, and/or rings. 
d.  Rigid plastic containers shall be empty of product and rinsed clean. Remove all caps, lids and/or rings. 
e.  Magazines shall be placed flat in a paper grocery sack or tied into bundles not exceeding eight inches high. No other material may be placed together with magazines. 
f.  Newspapers shall be placed flat in a paper grocery sack or tied into bundles not exceeding eight inches high. No other material may be placed together with newspapers. The advertising inserts may remain with the newspaper. 
Items a through d of this subsection shall be placed in a designated blue plastic bag, as specified by the commissioner of public works, in a commingled (mixed) condition and placed on the curb/alley line for collection. Items e and f of this subsection shall be kept separate from each other and from other recyclable items and placed adjacent to the blue plastic bag for collection. 
(2)  Prepare their aluminum containers, bimetal containers, glass containers, magazines, newspapers, rigid plastic containers made of PETE, HDPE, PVC, LDPE, PP, PS resins or multiple resins, and corrugated paper (cardboard) for drop off at city recycling dropoff facilities as follows: 
a.  Aluminum containers shall be empty of product and rinsed clean. Cans may be flattened. 
b.  Steel and/or bimetal containers shall be empty of product and rinsed clean. Cans may be flattened. 
c.  Glass containers shall be empty of product and rinsed clean. Remove all caps, lids, and/or rings. 
d.  Rigid plastic containers shall be empty of product and rinsed clean. Remove and discard all caps, lids, and/or rings. 
e.  Magazines shall be placed flat in a paper grocery sack or tied into bundles not exceeding eight inches high. No other material may be placed together with magazines. 
f.  Newspapers shall be placed flat in a paper grocery sack or tied into bundles not exceeding eight inches high. No other material may be placed together with newspapers. The advertising inserts may remain with the newspaper. 
g.  Corrugated paper (cardboard) shall be clean, dry, and free of all foreign material packaging. All corrugated paper in the form of boxes shall be flattened. 
Items a through d of this subsection shall be deposited in the appropriate bins, located on the site, in a commingled (mixed) form. Items e through g of this subsection shall be placed in the designated location or container as indicated at the dropoff facility. 
(Ord. No. 21-94, pt. 2(11.035.080), 10-4-94)  
Sec. 78-109. - Responsibilities of owners or designated agents of multiple-family dwellings. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided, the owner or manager of a multiple-family dwelling shall do all of the following to recycle the materials specified in section 78-104(5) through (15): 
(1)  Provide adequate, separate containers for the recyclable materials. 
(2)  Notify tenants in writing about the established recycling program at the time of renting or leasing the dwelling and at least semiannually thereafter. 
(3)  Provide for collection and delivery to a private recycling facility of the recyclable materials separated from the solid waste by the tenants. 
(4)  Notify tenants of reasons to reduce and recycle solid waste, which materials are collected, how to prepare the materials in order to meet the processing requirements, collection methods or sites, locations and hours of operation, and a contact person or company, including a name, address and telephone number. 
(b)  The requirements specified in subsection (a) do not apply to owners or managers of multiple-family dwellings if the postconsumer waste generated within the dwelling is treated at a processing facility licensed by the DNR that recovers for recycling the materials specified in section 78-104(5) through (15) from solid waste in as pure a form as is technically feasible. 
(Ord. No. 21-94, pt. 2(11.035.090), 10-4-94)  
Sec. 78-110. - Responsibilities of owners or designated agents of nonresidential facilities or properties not receiving solid waste collection services from the city. 
(a)  The owner or a designated agent of a nonresidential facility or property shall do all of the following to recycle the materials specified in section 78-104(5) through (15). 
(1)  Provide adequate, separate containers for the recyclable materials. 
(2)  Notify in writing at least semiannually, all users, tenants and occupants of the facility or property about the established recycling program. 
(3)  Provide for the collection of the recyclable materials separated from the solid waste by the users, tenants and occupants and for delivery of the materials to a private recycling facility. 
(4)  Notify users, tenants and occupants of reasons to reduce and recycle, which recyclable materials are collected, how to prepare materials in order to meet the processing requirements, collection method or sites, locations and hours of operation, and a contact person or company, including a name, address and telephone number. 
(b)  The requirements specified in subsection (a) do not apply to the owners or designated agents of nonresidential facilities and properties if the postconsumer waste generated within the facility or property is treated at a processing facility licensed by the DNR that recovers for recycling the materials specified in section 78-104(5) through (15) from solid waste in as pure a form as is technically feasible. 
(Ord. No. 21-94, pt. 2(11.035.100), 10-4-94)  
Sec. 78-111. - Prohibitions on disposal of recyclable materials separated for recycling. 
No person shall dispose of in a solid waste disposal facility or burn in a solid waste treatment facility any of the materials specified in section 78-104(5) through (15) which have been separated for recycling, except waste tires may be burned with energy recovery in a solid waste treatment facility. 
(Ord. No. 21-94, pt. 2(11.035.110) 10-4-94)  
Sec. 78-112. - Hauler specifications. 
(a)  No hauler shall dispose in a landfill or burn in a solid waste facility any recyclable material generated in the city that has been separated for recycling. 
(b)  No hauler shall compact glass with newspaper during collection and transport of recyclables to a processing facility or market, and shall maintain recyclable materials in hauler's possession in a marketable condition. 
(c)  A hauler may reject or leave at the collection point: 
(1)  Any recyclable material that is not prepared according to the requirements of this chapter. 
(2)  Materials which are not separated from regular solid waste. 
(3)  Materials which are not placed in the proper container. 
(4)  Materials which are not designated recyclable materials. 
(Ord. No. 21-94, pt. 2(11.035.120), 10-4-94)  
Sec. 78-113. - Materials from outside the city. 
No person shall bring any refuse or recyclable material from outside the city limits into the city for the purpose of depositing any such material for recycling nor shall any person deposit any such material in the city for recycling at a location designated as a recycling dropoff or on any curb/alley line. 
(Ord. No. 21-94, pt. 2(11.035.130), 10-4-94)  
Sec. 78-114. - Ownership of recyclables. 
Properly prepared recyclable materials shall become the property of the city upon placement at the curb/alley line or at dropoff locations. 
(Ord. No. 21-94, pt. 2(11.035.140), 10-4-94)  
Sec. 78-115. - Antiscavenging or unlawful removal of recyclable materials. 
No person shall collect or remove any recyclable material that has been placed in any designated area for collection, unless under contract for such collection or removal with the city or the entity being serviced. 
(Ord. No. 21-94, pt. 2(11.035.150), 10-4-94)  
Sec. 78-116. - Inspection. 
(a)  The commissioner of public works or authorized designee may inspect recyclable materials separated for recycling, postconsumer waste intended for disposal, recycling collection sites and facilities, collection vehicles, collection areas of multiple-family dwellings and nonresidential facilities and properties and any records relating to recycling activities at any reasonable time for the purpose of ascertaining compliance with this chapter. 
(b)  No person shall refuse entry or access for purposes of inspection under this section to the commissioner of public works or authorized designee, upon presentation of official credentials. 
(c)  No person shall obstruct, hamper or interfere with any inspection under this section. 
(Ord. No. 21-94, pt. 2(11.035.160), 10-4-94)  
Sec. 78-117. - Penalties. 
Upon conviction, any person found to be in violation of sections 78-111 or 78-112 shall forfeit $50.00 for a first violation, $200.00 for a second violation and no more than $2,000.00 for a third or subsequent violation. Any person found to be in violation of sections 78-104, 78-106, 78-108, 78-109, 78-110, 78-113 or 78-115 shall forfeit not less than $10.00 nor more than $1,000.00 for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 21-94, pt. 2(11.035.170), 10-4-94)  
Chapter 82 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND CERTAIN OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Commissioner of public works, § 2-531 et seq.; city property, § 2-606 et seq.; sale, possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages in certain public places prohibited, § 6-4; cemeteries, ch. 30; hazardous spills and discharges upon any public streets, alley, groundwater or surface water, or other public property prohibited, § 42-1; skateboarding restricted, § 66-541 et seq.; parks and recreation areas, § 70-76 et seq.; Colonial Park is a bird sanctuary, § 70-103; municipal parking facilities, § 94-276 et seq.; trees in public areas, § 102-56 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 82-1. - Obstructions. 
(a)  No person shall permit any vegetation growing on premises owned or controlled by him to obstruct or impede, hinder or endanger travel upon any street, sidewalk or alley. 
(b)  No person shall cause or permit any stones, gravel, dirt, soil or debris, or any road material, to be placed, deposited or cast upon any public sidewalk or street located adjacent to, or abutting on, premises owned or controlled by him, nor suffer any such material to lie or remain upon any such sidewalk or street. 
(c)  No person shall throw or put snow or ice into any street, alley or sidewalk so as to impede, hinder or endanger travel upon such street, alley or sidewalk. This section does not apply to snow removal operations conducted by the city. 
(d)  In case any thing or substance shall be found remaining or lying upon any street, alley or sidewalk or public ground within the city without permission from the city, it shall be the duty of the chief of police or any police officer forthwith to notify and require, by either written or verbal notice, any person who may have placed or caused or permitted to be placed such thing or substance, or who may be the owner or have the control of such thing or substance, or who may suffer such thing or substance to lie or remain upon such street, alley, sidewalk or public ground, to immediately remove such thing or substance, or cause such thing or substance to be removed therefrom. If such person shall neglect or fail to remove or cause to be removed such substance or thing within 24 hours after being so notified, it shall be the duty of the police officer to remove such substance or thing or cause it to be removed from such street, alley, sidewalk or public ground to some convenient and safe place at the expense of such person to be recovered in an action against him in the name of the city. 
(e)  Every person who shall receive permission from the commissioner of public works to place any building materials or other obstructions upon any street in the city shall place and maintain upon or around such material or other obstruction each night from the time of sunset until sunrise sufficient lights to warn all persons of the presence of such material or obstruction. No person shall knock down, destroy or damage any barrier, light or other protection in and upon streets, alleys and public places under construction or improvement in the city. No person shall walk, drive upon, or in any way injure, disfigure or destroy any pavement upon any street, alley or public place not opened by the commissioner of public works for public use or travel. No person shall knock down, destroy or injure any manhole, water hydrant or catchbasin in or upon any of the public streets or alleys in the city. 
(Code 1973, §§ 9.01.030—9.01.060, 9.18.010, 9.19.010) 
State Law reference— Obstructions, Wis. Stats. § 66.045; warning lights, barricades, Wis. Stats. § 348.10.  
Sec. 82-2. - Maintenance of parkway. 
An abutting property owner shall maintain the area, commonly called the parkway, between the roadway and the lot line of the property, including the sidewalk, if any. 
(Ord. No. 18-90, pt. 1, § 9.01.070, 5-15-90)  
Sec. 82-3. - City datum established. 
The elevation of sea level as determined by the United States Coastal and Geodetic Survey is hereby established as the city datum. The city datum previously established is hereby repealed and all elevations and grades in and for the city shall be expressed with the city datum established by this section as the base elevation. 
(Code 1973, § 9.36.010)  
Sec. 82-4. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
Any person violating this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit the amount provided in section 1-15, together with the cost of prosecution. 
(Code 1973, § 9.35.010)  
Sec. 82-5. - Payment of forfeiture in lieu of court appearance. 
(a)  Any person charged with a violation of the offenses listed under subsection (b) of this section may pay the amount enumerated therein at the police department in lieu of a court appearance. Persons wishing to contest charges contained in subsection (b) of this section may contact the police department to arrange a court appearance date. 
(b)  The following forfeitures for the offenses listed herein may be paid at the police department:

ARTICLE II. - STREETS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Streets and alleys in subdivision of lands, § 86-126 et seq.; traffic regulations on specific streets, § 94-41 et seq.; stopping, standing and parking regulations, § 94-126 et seq.; truck and heavy traffic routes established, § 94-311 et seq.; bridges, § 106-31 et seq.; supplementary zoning district regulations regarding setbacks for major streets, § 114-806 et seq. 
State Law reference— Widening streets, Wis. Stats. § 62.23(10); street grades, service pipes, Wis. Stats. § 62.16. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 82-31. - Streets terminating at Lake Michigan and Root River. 
The ends of streets delineated in this section terminating on the lakeshore and those streets delineated in this section terminating at Root River within the city shall be maintained by the board of parks, recreation and cultural services commissioners: 
(1)  At Lake Michigan: 
Barker Street east of Michigan Boulevard. 
Eighth Street east of Lake Avenue. 
Kewaunee Street east of Michigan Boulevard. 
Main Street south of 16th Street. 
Melvin Avenue east of Michigan Boulevard. 
(2)  At Root River: 
Ehlert Street east of Luedtke Avenue. 
Glen Street west of North Memorial Drive. 
Glen Street east of Luedtke Avenue. 
Parkview Terrace north of West Sixth Street. 
Riverbrook Drive north of Willow Tree Circle. 
Delamere Avenue north of Ninth Street. 
Harbridge Avenue north of Ninth Street. 
Clayton Avenue west of Howland Avenue. 
West High Street west of Marie Street (entrance to Colonial Park). 
(Code 1973, § 7.14.010)  
Sec. 82-32. - Depositing rubbish. 
No person shall place, deposit or cast or cause to be placed, deposited or cast upon any street, alley, gutter, sidewalk or public ground within the city any timber, wood, lumber, ashes, rubbish, offal, vegetables, paper, shavings, carcass or earth, or anything or substance on any such street, alley, gutter, sidewalk or public ground, which may impede, hinder or endanger travel thereon, or which shall or may injure or disfigure the same, or tend to the injury or disfigurement thereof, or tend to render the same unclean or a nuisance, except for the period of October 1 through November 30 and as otherwise designated by the commissioner of public works, during which time leaves may be placed in the street along the curbline or except as otherwise provided for solid waste collection and for loading or unloading of any solid waste collection vehicle or conveyance and except as may be permitted by the chief building inspector under section 18-43. 
(Code 1973, § 9.01.010; Ord. No. 36-95, pt. 1, 12-19-95; Ord. No. 11-16, pt. 1, 12-20-16) 
Cross reference— Permit for placing certain materials on streets required, § 18-43.  
Sec. 82-33. - Burning of leaves or rubbish. 
No person shall burn any rubbish, leaves or other combustible material in any street or alley in the city. 
(Code 1973, § 9.03.010) 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 42; air pollution, § 42-86 et seq.; fire prevention and protection, ch. 50; open flames and burning, § 50-261 et seq.; solid waste, ch. 78.  
Sec. 82-34. - Constructing sewers or vaults in streets. 
No person shall construct or cause to be constructed or made any sewer, vault, cellar, cistern or well in any of the streets in the city without authority from the common council. 
(Code 1973, § 9.09.010)  
Sec. 82-35. - Playing games in streets. 
No person shall, within the city, take part in any amusement, sport or game on a public street or alley which impedes or endangers public travel thereon, or which may be dangerous to the safety of any person, or which may be contrary to the interests of public safety. 
(Code 1973, § 9.12.010)  
Sec. 82-36. - Sale of goods on streets. 
No person shall park, place or set up on any public street, sidewalk, parkway, street right-of-way or alley any wagon, stand, motor vehicle, cart, tent, trailer, shed or any other substitute for a building, used or to be used for the display, storage or sale of food, goods, wares or merchandise or used for any business, commercial or residential purpose, except that construction trailers or similar building substitutes may be used by contractors at construction sites during the progress of such work, and except as otherwise authorized by the common council and then only upon compliance with section 18-42. 
(Code 1973, § 9.10.010) 
Cross reference— Businesses, professions and occupations, ch. 22; nuisances, § 42-26 et seq.; public market, § 82-226 et seq.; business zoning district regulations, § 114-386 et seq.; supplementary zoning district regulations, § 114-656 et seq.  
Sec. 82-37. - Encroachments on streets. 
(a)  Generally. No person shall, within the city, erect any building, structure or fence which shall encroach upon or obstruct any public street, alley or ground. 
(b)  Stairways. No person shall erect or build any stairs or stairway leading into any building within the city where such stairs or stairway will encroach in whole or in part upon any public street, and it shall be the duty of the owner of every building where there is an open area or open cellarway leading to the basement of such building now constructed in any sidewalk, street or alley to place and maintain at all times a suitable iron fence or railing on the outer sides of such stairway not less than three feet high. The owner of such building shall also provide and locate and maintain an iron gate at the upper step of such stairway, and such gate shall be closed and fastened at nightfall or at such times as such basement shall not be tenanted and also during the hours the occupant thereof shall not carry on business therein or at such times when the occupancy thereof is such that the public is not admitted to such basement to transact business. 
(c)  Fences. Every owner or occupant of land within the city from whose premises any building or fence or other structure shall extend into or encroach upon any public street, alley or ground, who shall have been ordered or required by the common council or commissioner of public works to remove such encroachment, shall remove such encroachment within ten days after service of notice of such request or order. 
(Code 1973, §§ 9.07.010—9.07.030) 
Cross reference— Fences and walls, § 114-756 et seq. 
State Law reference— Encroachments, Wis. Stats. § 66.045.  
Sec. 82-38. - Shows and gatherings. 
No person shall upon any of the public streets or grounds in the city exhibit any show or performance of any kind which may obstruct public travel, or cause the gathering of a crowd of people upon any street or sidewalk, or injure any public park; nor shall any person call any public meeting upon any street or public ground, nor address any crowd of people upon any such street or ground, when the same may create a disturbance or cause any injury to public property or obstruct public travel. 
(Code 1973, § 9.11.010) 
Cross reference— Businesses, professions and occupations, ch. 22; carnivals and amusement rides, § 22-266 et seq.  
Sec. 82-39. - Parades, processions or open-air meetings. 
(a)  No parade or procession shall be allowed upon any street or public way in the city, nor shall any open-air meeting be held upon any street or public way in the city, until a permit in writing therefor shall first be obtained. Application to conduct a parade or procession or open-air meeting upon any street or public way shall be made in writing by the person in charge or control thereof, or responsible therefor, to the common council and shall be referred to the public works and services committee. Such application shall set forth the route along which such parade or procession is to proceed, the time of starting, and the name of the person or corporation or society in control thereof or responsible therefor, and the purpose of such parade or procession. If the application is approved by the committee it shall be referred to the chief of police who shall approve the application and establish the necessary conditions for the health, safety and general welfare of the city. If the application is denied by the public works and services committee, the denied application shall be presented to the common council in the committee report. If the applicant is aggrieved by the conditions established by the chief of police, the applicant may appeal such decision to the public works and services committee within 15 days of the chief of police's decision. 
(b)  In the case of an open-air meeting, the application therefor shall specify the place at which it is desired to hold such meeting, the purpose thereof, and the name of the person, corporation or society in control thereof or responsible therefor, the time at which such public meeting is to be held, and the probable duration thereof. 
(Code 1973, §§ 9.14.010, 9.14.020) 
Cross reference— Businesses, professions and occupations, ch. 22; environment, ch. 42; fire prevention and protection, ch. 50; offenses, ch. 66; parks, recreation and cultural services, ch. 70; traffic and vehicles, ch. 94; supplementary zoning district regulations, § 114-656 et seq.  
Sec. 82-40. - Hydrants, poles or shade trees, location. 
All hydrants, lampposts and telephone, telegraph and electric light poles permitted to be set in any street shall be set within the space adjacent to the curbline, and all ornamental or shade trees shall be set or planted inside such spaces. 
(Code 1973, § 9.15.010) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 50; fire hydrant requirements, § 50-376 et seq.; solid waste containers, § 78-46 et seq.; traffic and vehicles, ch. 94; utilities, ch. 98; trees, § 102-26 et seq.; supplementary zoning district regulations, § 114-656 et seq.  
Sec. 82-41. - Ornamental lighting. 
(a)  District of partial or single block. An ornamental lighting district composed of a partial block or single block of any length contiguous to an existing ornamental lighting district may be designated an ornamental lighting district by proceeding under this section regardless of the length of such block or partial block. 
(b)  Petitions. An ornamental lighting district may be applied for upon submission to the common council of a petition signed by the owners of two-thirds of the property fronting on any block or contiguous blocks of an aggregate length of at least 600 feet. "Block" means the frontage on both sides of any street between two intersecting streets. The petition shall request the establishment of ornamental lighting of a specified uniform type of pole and fixture for the entire block or blocks which, if such district is approved, shall be installed at locations as determined by the traffic engineer. The type of ornamental lighting fixture and pole shall be subject to the approval of the public works and services committee in the hearing process. Petitions shall be referred to the public works and services committee for a public hearing, which shall be held within 45 days after such referral. The traffic engineer shall cause notice of such hearing to be published in the official newspaper at least one week prior to the hearing. 
(c)  Hearing. The public works and services committee shall consider the petition and the comments made at the public hearing, which shall be recorded. The committee shall make its recommendations with the reasons therefor. The common council shall, by resolution, approve, deny or modify the proposed ornamental lighting district. The ornamental lighting district shall include only frontage which abuts upon the block or blocks included in the petition. The traffic engineer shall order the lighting installed as approved by the common council. 
(d)  Assessment of cost. Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.62, the cost of purchasing and installing the ornamental poles, fixtures and accessories shall be determined by the common council and assessed on a front footage basis to the property fronting on the ornamental lighting district. The assessments shall be made by the traffic engineer and reported to the city clerk who shall enter the tax upon the tax roll. Any person against whose land a special assessment is levied shall have the right to appeal therefrom in the manner prescribed in Wis. Stats. § 66.60(12), within 40 days of the date of the final determination of the common council. 
(Code 1973, §§ 9.32.010—9.32.040; Ord. No. 8-04, pts. 17, 18, 4-7-04) 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 98; supplementary zoning district regulations, § 114-656 et seq.  
Sec. 82-42. - Repair or storage of motor vehicles in streets prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall repair any motor vehicle, or do any body work or rebuilding of any motor vehicle while such vehicle is parked in any public street or alley. Minor emergency repairs and tire changes are excepted from this prohibition. 
(b)  No person engaged in the business of repairing, rebuilding, or dismantling of motor vehicles, or in the business of body repair or rebuilding of motor vehicles, shall park, locate or place or cause to be parked, located or placed, upon any public street or alley, any motor vehicle in his possession for such rebuilding, remodeling, dismantling, or for body repair or rebuilding. This subsection shall not be construed as prohibiting the temporary parking of such vehicle when being parked for delivery to the business premises for service, or being parked after service is complete for pickup by the patron, but such temporary parking shall not exceed 12 hours and shall be limited to the street or alley area adjacent to the business premises. 
(c)  Any vehicle found on the public street or alley in violation of this section is declared to be a public nuisance and such vehicle shall be forthwith removed from the street or alley to a safe location. The violator shall, in addition to any other penalty, be responsible for any towing and/or storage charges incurred. 
(Code 1973, §§ 9.33.010, 9.34.010) 
Cross reference— Abandoned, nuisance, or junked vehicles, § 42-181 et seq.; traffic and vehicles, ch. 94; stopping, standing, parking regulations, § 94-126 et seq.; supplementary zoning district regulations, § 114-656 et seq.  
Sec. 82-43. - Gas companies using streets. 
(a)  Permit required. No person, including public utility corporations, whether holding a franchise or permit from the city or the state or not, shall occupy the streets, highways or other public places within the city for the purpose of supplying or furnishing by pipes or mains, directly or indirectly, natural gas or a mixed gas containing natural gas to consumers within the city without a permit therefor from the common council. 
(b)  Permit application. Application for a permit under this section shall be made to the common council and filed with the city clerk. Such application shall set forth the standards, quality and character of the product or service to be furnished or rendered, including: 
(1)  The approximate cost to gas users in the city; 
(2)  The heating value of the gas to be furnished; 
(3)  The cost to all classes of users of any parts or equipment, or the cost of any changeover that will be required within the city, in detail; and 
(4)  Such other information as the common council or a committee thereof may require. 
(c)  Public hearing. Upon receiving an application under this section, the common council shall order a public hearing thereon either before it or a committee thereof. The common council may grant or refuse such permit or may refer the permit application to an advisory referendum vote for approval or disapproval by the voters of the city at a city election. The common council shall not grant such permit if it finds that the granting thereof is not in the best interest of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(d)  Issuance of permit.
