(b)  The retail alcohol beverage license includes the sidewalk cafe in the description of the licensed premises as an extended area. 
(c)  The retail alcohol beverage license permits the sale of the type of alcohol beverages to be served in the sidewalk cafe. 
(d)  Alcohol beverages are sold and served by the licensee or licensee's employees and sold or served only to patrons seated at tables in the sidewalk cafe. 
(e)  Alcohol beverages are served by the licensee or the licensee's employees in compliance with the alcohol beverage laws, ordinances and regulations. 
(f)  Alcohol beverages may only be served at the sidewalk cafe when food service is available through the licensed establishment. 
(g)  The permittee shall be responsible for policing the sidewalk cafe area to prevent underage persons from entering or remaining in the sidewalk cafe, except when underage persons are allowed to be present on the licensed premises under applicable laws. 
(h)  The permittee shall not allow patrons of the sidewalk cafe to bring alcohol beverages into the sidewalk cafe from another location, nor to carry open containers of alcohol beverages about in the sidewalk cafe area, nor to carry open containers of alcohol beverages served in the sidewalk cafe outside the sidewalk cafe area. 
(i)  The bar from which the alcohol beverages are dispensed shall be located indoors and shall not be located in the sidewalk cafe area. 
(j)  At times of closing or during times when consumption of alcohol beverages is prohibited, permittee shall remove from the sidewalk cafe area all containers used for or containing alcohol beverages. No container of alcohol beverages shall be present in the sidewalk cafe between 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 12-05, pt. 6, 6-7-05)  
Sec. 82-160. - Penalty. 
Any person who violates this division shall, upon conviction, forfeit not less than $50.00 nor more than $1,000.00. Each day of a violation is a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 12-05, pt. 6, 6-7-05)  
ARTICLE IV. - CURB CUTS AND DRIVEWAYS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; subdivision of land improvements required, § 86-91 et seq. 
 
Sec. 82-161. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Commissioner means the commissioner of public works. 
Curb return means that portion of a curb next to a driveway approach which includes the radius of curvature and which connects the driveway approach to the street curb. 
Driveway means a place on private property for the operation of motor vehicles. 
Driveway approach means an area, construction or facility between the roadway of a public street and private property intended to provide access for vehicles from the roadway of a public street to private property and which actually provides access to a definite objective on private property such as a parking area, a driveway, or a door at least seven feet wide intended and used for the entrance of vehicles. 
Outside sidewalk line means a line parallel to the property line lying along the edge of the sidewalk nearest the street roadway or curb. If the sidewalk width exceeds six feet, the outside sidewalk line shall be a line six feet from and parallel to the property line. 
Owner means the owner of the abutting land served by the driveway approach. 
Parcel of land means a lot or lots, or a tract officially recorded under one ownership. 
(Code 1973, § 9.06.010; Ord. No. 35-04, pt. 1, 10-19-04) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 82-162. - Permit required; fee. 
(a)  No person shall cut, break out or remove any curb along a street or alley, except to repair or replace an existing curb, without first obtaining a written permit therefor from the chief building inspector. The maximum width of a curb cut for a driveway approach in connection with a driveway or combination of driveways shall be 16 feet, excepting that an owner may request a curb cut for a driveway approach wider than 16 feet. Such request shall include supporting documentation under the standards provided in section 82-169. The chief building inspector shall submit the owner's plans along with a recommendation to the commissioner for review, and shall not issue a permit without the commissioner's approval. Approval shall be deemed granted if the commissioner has not provided written notice of denial to the chief building inspector within 21 days after commissioner's receipt of the request. 
(b)  The fee for breaking out or removal of any curb for the purpose of constructing a driveway approach shall be as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council. 
(Code 1973, § 9.06.020; Ord. No. 35-04, pt. 1, 10-19-04; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 94, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 82-163. - Width and location of driveway approach. 
(a)  No driveway approach shall exceed 30 feet in width as measured along the outside sidewalk line. Where more than one driveway approach on a street front serves a single parcel of land, there shall be at least ten feet between driveway approaches. 
(b)  No portion of the driveway approach may be constructed in front of the adjacent parcel of land, except as specifically authorized by the commissioner upon the owner's showing of necessity for a flared driveway approach due to insufficient land area necessary for reasonable ingress and egress and which does not result in obstruction of traffic or undue hardship upon the abutting property owner, and upon execution by the requesting property owners of a street privilege agreement pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.0425. The agreement shall be signed by the city if the commissioner approves the request and owner has submitted payment of an administrative fee as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council, which shall also cover the recording cost. 
(Code 1973, § 9.06.030; Ord. No. 35-04, pt. 1, 10-19-04; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 95, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 82-164. - Maximum width of curb cut. 
For the purpose of constructing a driveway approach, no curb cut, opening or section broken out or removed shall exceed 40 feet. 
(Code 1973, § 9.06.040; Ord. No. 35-04, pt. 1, 10-19-04)  
Sec. 82-165. - Distance between driveway approach and corner. 
No portion of a driveway approach, except the curb return, shall be constructed within 15 feet of a marked or unmarked crosswalk, and in all cases a tangent of at least three feet must be maintained between the point of tangency of the corner radius and the point of tangency of the curb return radius. 
(Code 1973, § 9.06.050; Ord. No. 35-04, pt. 1, 10-19-04)  
Sec. 82-166. - Curb return radius. 
The radius of the curb return shall not exceed the distance between the curb and the outside sidewalk line. 
(Code 1973, § 9.06.060; Ord. No. 35-04, pt. 1, 10-19-04)  
Sec. 82-167. - Control of vehicles from encroaching on sidewalk area. 
When more than one driveway serves a single parcel of land, there shall be a physical barrier constructed along the inside sidewalk line between driveways which shall be at least two-thirds of the length of the distance between the driveways. 
(Code 1973, § 9.06.070; Ord. No. 35-04, pt. 1, 10-19-04)  
Sec. 82-168. - Interference with street structures. 
No driveway approach shall interfere with facilities such as street lighting poles, traffic signal standards, poles, hydrants, underground pipes or ducts or other street structures. Owner shall pay, in advance, the cost of relocating any such facilities required to accommodate a request that is granted. 
(Code 1973, § 9.06.080; Ord. No. 35-04, pt. 1, 10-19-04)  
Sec. 82-169. - Unusual conditions. 
The commissioner is hereby authorized to issue a permit granting exceptions and variances from the strict application of sections 82-163, 82-165, 82-166 and 82-167, provided that the following conditions are present: 
(1)  The exception or variance request arises from physical conditions not ordinarily existing in similar districts in the city, or is due to the nature of the business or operation on the abutting property. 
(2)  Granting the permit will not adversely affect the rights of adjacent property owners or tenants. 
(3)  The exception or variance requested is not contrary to the public interest, particularly safety, convenience and general welfare. 
(4)  Strict application of the terms of this article will work unnecessary hardship on the owner. 
(Code 1973, § 9.06.090; Ord. No. 35-04, pt. 1, 10-19-04)  
Sec. 82-170. - Construction requirements. 
The permittee shall furnish all materials, do all work, and pay all costs in connection with the construction of the driveway and its appurtenances, including the replacement of curbs and gutters on the public right-of-way. All materials used shall meet the requirements of the city for construction of this type, which shall be as approved by the city. 
(Code 1973, § 9.06.100; Ord. No. 35-04, pt. 1, 10-19-04)  
Sec. 82-171. - Additions or revisions. 
No revisions or additions shall be made to a driveway or its appurtenances on the public right-of-way without written permission of the commissioner. 
(Code 1973, § 9.06.110; Ord. No. 35-04, pt. 1, 10-19-04)  
Sec. 82-172. - Construction by city. 
The city reserves the right to make such changes, additions, repairs and relocations to a driveway or its appurtenances on the public right-of-way as may at any time be considered reasonably necessary to permit the relocation, reconstruction, widening, channelization and/or maintaining of the street and/or to provide proper protection to life and property on or adjacent to the street. 
(Code 1973, § 9.06.120; Ord. No. 35-04, pt. 1, 10-19-04; Ord. No. 35-04, pt. 1, 10-19-04)  
Sec. 82-173. - Restoration of unused curb cuts. 
Whenever the use of property is changed so that a driveway approach no longer provides access for vehicles from the roadway of a public street to private property, the owner shall cause the driveway approach to be removed, the sidewalk area restored to grade and a standard curbing rebuilt along the curb line. 
(Code 1973, § 9.06.130; Ord. No. 35-04, pt. 1, 10-19-04)  
Sec. 82-174. - Repair of nonconforming approaches and curb cuts. 
When any driveway approach or curb cut existing prior to April 22, 1965 that does not conform to the provisions of this article is intended by the owner to be structurally changed, altered or rebuilt, the owner shall obtain a permit for the work and such change, alteration or reconstruction shall comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 9.06.140; Ord. No. 35-04, pt. 1, 10-19-04)  
Sec. 82-175. - Repair of defective approaches and curb cut returns. 
The commissioner may order an owner to repair, replace or remove any driveway approach or curb cut return that is unsafe, defective or insufficient and cause it to comply with this article. A copy of the order directing such work shall be served by registered mail, return receipt requested, or by personal service, or by publication as a Class 1 notice if the owner cannot reasonably be located. If the work is not done within 45 days after date of notice, the city may perform the work and the cost thereof shall be levied as a special charge against the abutting parcel of land. 
(Code 1973, § 9.06.150; Ord. No. 35-04, pt. 1, 10-19-04) 
State Law reference— Sidewalks, Wis. Stats. § 66.615.  
Sec. 82-176. - Filing of plans. 
Plans showing the minimum and maximum dimensions of driveways as prescribed by this article and showing construction details for driveway approaches and curb cuts shall be placed on file in the office of the commissioner and the traffic engineer. 
(Code 1973, § 9.06.160; Ord. No. 35-04, pt. 1, 10-19-04)  
Sec. 82-177. - Liability clause. 
The owner receiving a variance or exception hereunder, and heirs, successors or assigns, agree(s) to hold harmless the city, its departments, officers, employees, agents and authorized volunteers from and against any liability, loss, damage or expense of any nature whatsoever (no limitation) for any accident, bodily injury, including death, or property damage arising out of the exercise of any permit issued under this article, the work performed thereunder or the existence of the driveways and/or curbs constructed under the permit. 
(Code 1973, § 9.06.170; Ord. No. 35-04, pt. 1, 10-19-04)  
Secs. 82-178—82-200. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - CIVIC CENTRE[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference— Civic Centre commission, § 2-206 et seq. 
State Law reference— Cites for veteran's memorial halls, Wis. Stats. § 66.93. 
 
Sec. 82-201. - Findings and declarations. 
(a)  The city has established a Festival Park and Hall and Memorial Hall for use by the citizens of the city and surrounding communities. This usage encompasses serving the recreational and cultural needs of the community and the promotion of the community's commerce and industry. The Festival Park and Hall and Memorial Hall are dedicated to those uses. In addition, the Memorial Hall is dedicated to the memory and in honor of the deeds of the soldiers, sailors and marines, both men and women, of the city and county who served the nation during World War I and those soldiers, sailors and marines who have served, are serving and will serve our country. It is declared that Memorial Hall may be used free of charge for organization meetings of all honorably discharged veterans and members of the armed forces who have served the United States at any time. 
(b)  The Festival Park and Hall and Memorial Hall shall collectively be known as the Racine Civic Centre. The Festival Park and Hall and Memorial Hall shall retain their respective present names and be considered as elements of the Civic Centre. Those persons who are given the responsibility of administering the Civic Centre shall ensure that the purpose for its creation is carried out in keeping with the following philosophy and keeping in mind the veterans previously described in this section: 
(1)  The Civic Centre shall be open to the general public under such rules and regulations as will ensure access to all persons regardless of race, creed or national origin. 
(2)  The Civic Centre shall be operated in a manner which will enhance the recreational and cultural opportunities of the citizens of the community, and promote the community's commerce and industry. 
(3)  Since maximum use of the Civic Centre is a desirable goal, efforts shall be made to ensure that it competes successfully with similar facilities. 
(Code 1973, § 3.23.010; Ord. No. 9-91, pt. 1, 3-19-91; Ord. No. 11-96, pt. 1, 6-18-96)  
Sec. 82-202. - Skateboards, rollerskates and bicycles at Festival Park. 
(a)  Prohibition. No person shall ride a skateboard or bicycle or rollerskate within the limits of Festival Park during any outdoor event at Festival Park, except if the sponsor of such event authorizes a demonstration of the use of such equipment, and except when operated by police officers or law enforcement officers in the course of their duties. 
(b)  Definition. For purposes of this section, "event" means any approved use of an outdoor area within the limits of Festival Park by a renter of such area, and shall include the time that such event is in operation, is being set up and is being taken down. 
(c)  Penalty for violation. 
(1)  Any person found to be in violation of this section shall, upon conviction, forfeit an amount as provided in section 1-15. 
(2)  Any person charged with a violation of this section may pay the amount enumerated herein at the police department in lieu of a court appearance. Persons wishing to contest charges contained in this section may contact the police department to arrange a court appearance date. The forfeiture for skateboarding, bicycling or rollerskating at Festival Park events is $20.00. 
(Code 1973, §§ 25.23.010—25.23.030; Ord. No. 23-93, pt. 2, 10-5-93; Ord. No. 13-95, pt. 9, 8-15-95; Ord. No. 7-05, pt. 2, 5-3-05) 
Cross reference— Skateboarding, § 66-541 et seq.  
Secs. 82-203—82-225. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - PUBLIC MARKET[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference— Wagons, stands, other vehicles, carts, tents, trailers, sheds or other substitute for building used for sale of food, goods, wares or merchandise or business, commercial or residential purposes must meet certain standards, § 18-42; sale of goods on streets restricted, § 82-36 et seq. 
 
Sec. 82-226. - Market committee. 
The public safety and licensing committee of the common council shall constitute the market committee referred to in this article. 
(Code 1973, § 23.29.010; Ord. No. 33-06, pt. 1, 9-5-06) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 33-06, pt. 1, adopted Sept. 5, 2006, changed the phrase license and welfare to public safety and license. The term is being changed to public safety and licensing at the city's instruction. 
Cross reference— Policy on absenteeism for boards, committees, commissions, § 2-166; boards, committees, commissions, § 2-166 et seq.  
Sec. 82-227. - Superintendent. 
The sealer of weights and measures shall be ex officio superintendent of the public markets and shall account for and pay over weekly or more often all moneys received by him to the city treasurer, and shall take his receipt therefor. The superintendent shall cause books to be kept in proper form and shall report annually to the common council at the same time that his report as sealer of weights and measures is presented to the common council. The superintendent, together with the market committee, shall have authority to designate the necessary help for the purpose of carrying on the market and keeping the market in proper condition, subject, however, to the approval and fixing of compensation of help by the common council. 
(Code 1973, § 23.31.010) 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-436 et seq.; personnel, ch. 74; sealer of weights and measures, § 110-3.  
Sec. 82-228. - Operation; fees. 
(a)  Public markets for the city are hereby established at such place or places in the city as may be determined upon by the market committee, subject to the approval of the common council. 
(b)  The public markets established pursuant to this article shall be open on such days and for such hours as the market committee shall, from time to time, determine. 
(c)  The market committee shall, from time to time, establish the fees and/or rents to be paid by those who use the public markets for the sale of their merchandise. 
(Code 1973, §§ 23.30.010—23.30.030)  
Sec. 82-229. - Regulations. 
(a)  The littering of the grounds at public markets is prohibited and the owner or seller of each load shall pick up and remove from the ground all paper, refuse or anything lying upon the ground as the result of his use thereof before he leaves the market. The superintendent of the public markets shall have the right to expel anyone from a market if he finds that such person is attempting to sell produce which is not fit for use or is trying to wrongfully influence prices while in the market. 
(b)  The market committee, together with the superintendent, shall from time to time make such necessary rules and regulations for the daily working and care of the markets as in its judgment may be necessary, subject to the approval of the common council. 
(Code 1973, §§ 23.32.010, 23.33.010)  
Sec. 82-230. - Use of markets and streets. 
No person shall sublet or transfer his space or stall rented in any public market, and no person shall use any stall or space except the person leasing the space. No person shall use any of the public streets, alleys or other public places in the city as standing places for vehicles for the sale of fruits, vegetables, or other products usually disposed of in market places, except those portions of streets or alleys that the market committee may designate. This does not prohibit licensed hucksters from peddling from house to house within the city. No person shall have a right to use any market without complying with the provisions of this article and with the rules and regulations that may be made under the authority of this article. 
(Code 1973, § 23.34.010)  
Chapter 86 - SUBDIVISION OF LAND[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— City planning, heritage, and design commission, § 2-251 et seq.; development standards, § 114-731 et seq.; mobile homes and parks, § 114-786 et seq.; flood regulations, § 114-841 et seq.; shoreland and wetland regulations, § 114-916 et seq.; sign regulations in the zoning districts, § 114-1026 et seq. 
State Law reference— City planning, Wis. Stats. § 62.23; subdivisions, Wis. Stats. § 236.01 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 86-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alleys means those streets which are a secondary means of access for vehicular service to the back or side of properties otherwise abutting on a street. 
Collector streets means those streets which carry traffic from minor streets to the major system of arterial streets and highways and includes the principal entrance streets to residential developments and streets for circulation within such developments. 
Lot division means the division of a parcel of land into two lots or parcels, any one of which is less than three acres in area, for the purpose of transfer of ownership or building development. 
Major streets and highways means those streets which are primarily for fast or heavy through traffic. 
Marginal access streets means those streets which are parallel and adjacent to arterial streets and highways and which provide access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. 
Master plan means the comprehensive plan for building and shaping the growth and development of the community, including all of its component parts, as set forth in the various maps, plats, charts and descriptive and explanatory matter prepared by the planning department and adopted and certified by the planning, heritage, and design commission. 
Minor streets means those streets which are used primarily for access to abutting properties. 
Street means a public way for pedestrian and vehicular traffic, whether designated as a street, highway, thoroughfare, parkway, throughway, road, avenue, boulevard, lane, place, or however otherwise designated. 
Subdivision means the division of a lot, parcel or tract of land by the owners thereof or their agents for the purpose of transfer of ownership or building development, where: 
(1)  The act of division creates three or more parcels or building sites of three acres each or less in area; or 
(2)  The act of division creates three or more parcels or building sites of three acres each or less in area by successive divisions within a period of three years. 
The term includes resubdivision and, when appropriate to the context, shall relate to the process of subdividing or to the land subdivided. 
(b)  Other terms. All other pertinent terms not defined in this section shall be as defined in the zoning ordinances of the city (chapter 114) and Wis. Stats. ch. 236, excluding extraterritorial plat review. 
(Code 1973, §§ 17.02.010—17.02.100; Ord. No. 6-02, pt. 1, 4-3-02; Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 15, 11-12-19) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Definitions, Wis. Stats. § 236.02.  
Sec. 86-2. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this chapter is to regulate and control the subdivision of land within the corporate limits of the city in order to promote the public health, safety and general welfare of the community. It is designed to lessen congestion in the streets and highways; to further the orderly layout and use of land; to ensure proper legal description and proper monumenting of subdivided land; to secure safety from fire, panic, and other dangers; to provide for adequate light and air; to prevent the overcrowding of land and avoid undue concentrations of population; to facilitate adequate provision for transportation, water, sewerage, schools, parks, playgrounds, and other public requirements; to facilitate and further the resubdivision of larger tracts into smaller parcels of land. The regulations in this chapter are formulated to facilitate the enforcement of development standards as outlined in the zoning ordinances and the master plan of the city. 
(Code 1973, § 17.01.020; Ord. No. 6-02, pt. 2, 4-3-02)  
Sec. 86-3. - Compliance required. 
(a)  No person shall divide any land located within the corporate limits of the city thereof which shall result in a subdivision without complying with the provisions of Wis. Stats. ch. 236, excluding extraterritorial plat review, and the requirements of this chapter. The proposed subdivision shall also conform to: 
(1)  All applicable ordinances of the appropriate jurisdictions. 
(2)  The master plan or any portion thereof. 
(3)  The rules of the state department of industry, labor and human relations relating to lot size and lot elevation if the subdivision is not served by a public sewer and provisions for such service have not been made. 
(4)  The rules of the state department of transportation relating to safety of access and the preservation of the public interest and investment on the streets if the subdivision or any lot contained therein abuts on a state trunk highway or connecting street. 
(b)  Whenever a tract to be subdivided embraces any part of a major thoroughfare, parkway or boulevard designated in the master plan, such part of such proposed public way shall be platted and dedicated by the subdivider in the location and at the width indicated. 
(c)  Where a proposed park or other recreation area, school site, drainageway, or other public ground shown on the master plan of the city is located in whole or in part within a proposed subdivision, such proposed public ground or park may be dedicated to the public or reserved for acquisition within a period of one year by the city, the township, or the school district in which it is located. 
(d)  No dedication under subsections (b) and (c) of this section can be required in a total amount of more than one-third of the area to be platted. 
(e)  No land shall be subdivided for residential use which is held by the planning, heritage, and design commission to be unsuitable for such use by reason of flooding or bad drainage, adverse earth or rock formation or topography, or any other feature likely to be harmful to the health, safety or welfare of the future residents in the proposed subdivision or of the community. 
(f)  Both in the case of lot divisions and in the case of platted subdivisions, lot sizes shall conform to the area and width requirements prescribed for the zoning district in which the property is located, provided that in commercial and industrial districts lotting shall be to the widths and areas deemed by the planning, heritage, and design commission to be appropriate for the prescribed use. 
(Code 1973, § 17.03.010; Ord. No. 6-02, pt. 3, 4-3-02; Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 16, 11-12-19) 
State Law reference— Extraterritorial jurisdiction, Wis. Stats. § 236.02(5).  
Sec. 86-4. - Lot divisions and consolidations (splits and joiners). 
(b)  No person shall perform a consolidation or reconfiguration of lots of record unless the assessor, in consultation with the zoning administrator, finds that the consolidation or reconfiguration does not cause a nonconformity or result in a greater degree of nonconformity under this chapter or other applicable laws or ordinances. This section shall apply to all platted and unplatted lands within the city. 
(Code 1973, § 17.03.020; Ord. No. 6-06, pt. 1, 4-5-06) 
Cross reference— Supplementary zoning district regulation regarding lots, § 114-771 et seq.  
Sec. 86-5. - Exceptions from chapter provisions. 
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to: 
(1)  Transfer of interests in land by will or pursuant to court order; 
(2)  Leases for a term not to exceed ten years, mortgages or easements; 
(3)  The sale or exchange of parcels of land between owners of adjoining property if additional lots are not thereby created and the lots resulting are not reduced below the minimum sizes required by this chapter, the zoning ordinances, or other applicable laws or ordinances. 
(4)  Extraterritorial plat reviews. 
(Code 1973, § 17.03.040; Ord. No. 6-02, pt. 4, 4-3-02)  
Sec. 86-6. - Remedies. 
Failure to comply with the requirements of this chapter shall invalidate purported transfers of titles at the option of the purchaser in accordance with the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 236.31(3). Building permits shall also be refused for construction on sites created in violation of these requirements. 
(Code 1973, § 17.03.030)  
Secs. 86-7—86-35. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PLATS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 86-36. - Preapplication procedure. 
Previous to the filing of an application for approval of the preliminary plat, the subdivider may consult with the planning, heritage, and design commission and its staff for advice and assistance. This step does not require formal application or filing of a plat, but is intended to inform the subdivider of the objectives of this chapter and of the master plan; to otherwise assist him in planning his development; and in so doing to informally reach mutual conclusions regarding the general program and objectives of the development. 
(Code 1973, § 17.04.010; Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 17, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 86-37. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Part 5 of Ord. No. 6-02, adopted April 3, 2002, repealed in its entirety § 86-37, plats within extraterritorial jurisdiction. Said section pertained to subdivision of land with extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city and derived from Code 1973, §§ 17.05.010—17.05.030.  
Secs. 86-38—86-50. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PRELIMINARY PLAT 
 
Sec. 86-51. - Contents. 
The preliminary plat of a proposed subdivision shall be based upon a survey by a registered land surveyor and the plat prepared on tracing cloth or paper of good quality at a scale of not more than 100 feet to one inch, and shall show correctly on its face: 
(1)  Date, scale and north point. 
(2)  The title under which the proposed subdivision is to be recorded. 
(3)  The name and address of the owner, the subdivider and the surveyor or engineer preparing the plat. If a professional land planner has prepared the subdivision design, his name and address shall also appear on the plat. 
(4)  Location of the proposed subdivision by government lot, quarter section, township, range and county. 
(5)  Exact length and bearing of the exterior boundaries of the proposed subdivision referenced to a corner established in the U.S. public land survey and the total acreage encompassed thereby. 
(6)  Location and names of adjacent subdivisions, parks and cemeteries. 
(7)  Location, right-of-way width and names of any adjacent existing streets, alleys or other public ways, easements, and railroad and utility rights-of-way. 
(8)  Type, width and elevation of any adjacent existing street pavements together with any legally established centerline elevations. 
(9)  Location, size and invert elevations of any existing sanitary or storm sewers, culverts or drain pipes and the location and size of any existing water and gas mains on and adjacent to the tract and proposed to be used in the development. If sewers and water mains are not on or adjacent to the tract, the direction and distance to and size of the nearest sewers and water mains, showing invert elevations of sewers, shall be indicated. 
(10)  Location of existing property lines, buildings, drives, streams and watercourses, marshes, rock outcrops, wooded areas, railroad tracts and other similar significant features within the tract being subdivided or immediately adjacent thereto. 
(11)  Water elevations of adjoining lakes or streams at the date of survey, and approximately high and low water elevations, all referred to city datum. 
(12)  Contours at vertical intervals of not more than five feet where the slope is greater than ten percent, and not more than two feet where the slope is less than ten percent. Elevations shall be marked on such contours based on city datum. 
(13)  The preliminary plat shall be accompanied by proposed street profiles and typical cross sections showing existing ground surface and proposed street grades, including extensions for a reasonable distance beyond the limits of the proposed subdivision when requested. All elevations shall be based on city datum, and profile sheets shall meet the approval of the engineering department. 
(14)  When conditions indicate an unsatisfactory soil condition, the planning, heritage, and design commission may request location and results of tests made to ascertain subsurface soil, rock and water conditions including depth to bedrocks and depth to groundwater table. Where public services are not available for immediate service, the applicable provisions of the Wisconsin Administrative Code shall be complied with and the appropriate data submitted with the preliminary data. 
(15)  Location, width and names of all proposed streets and public rights-of-way such as alleys and easements. 
(16)  Location and approximate dimensions of any sites to be reserved or dedicated for parks, playgrounds, drainageways or other public use or which are to be used for group housing, shopping centers, church sites or other nonpublic uses not requiring lotting. 
(17)  Approximate dimensions of all lots together with proposed lot and block numbers. 
(18)  Approximate radii of all curves. 
(19)  When requested by the planning, heritage, and design commission, a draft of a protective covenant whereby the subdivider proposes to regulate land use in the subdivision and otherwise protect the proposed development. 
(Code 1973, § 17.07.010; Ord. No. 6-02, pt. 6, 4-3-02; Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 18, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 86-52. - Procedure for approval. 
(a)  Before submitting a final plat for approval, the subdivider shall cause to be prepared a preliminary plat and supplementary material and shall file with the secretary of the planning, heritage, and design commission a written application for approval of such plat, accompanied by ten blueprints, or other acceptable reproductions thereof, at least 21 days prior to the meeting of the planning, heritage, and design commission at which action is desired. The preliminary plat shall cover the entire area owned or controlled by the subdivider even though only a small portion thereof is proposed for development at the time. The planning, heritage, and design commission may waive this requirement where it is unnecessary to fulfill the purpose of this chapter and undue hardship would result from strict application thereof. 
(b)  The preliminary plat shall be reviewed by the planning department for conformity with all ordinances, administrative rules and regulations and plans which affect subdivisions; and the planning department shall transmit a copy of the preliminary plat to the city engineering department and the traffic engineering department, the health department, the commissioner of public works, the wastewater utility and the water department for review and report concerning matters within their jurisdiction. Their recommendations in respect thereto shall be transmitted to the planning, heritage, and design commission not later than 14 days from the date the plat is filed. 
(c)  The planning, heritage, and design commission shall, within 60 days of the filing of the plat, approve, approve conditionally, or reject the plat. One copy of the plat shall be returned to the subdivider with the date and action endorsed thereon and, if approved conditionally or rejected, the conditions or reasons for rejection endorsed thereon or attached thereto. 
(d)  Approval or conditional approval of a preliminary plat shall not constitute approval of the final plat. Rather, it shall be deemed an expression of approval or conditional approval of the layout submitted as a guide to the preparation of the final plat, which will be subject to further consideration by the planning, heritage, and design commission. 
(e)  Whenever it is proposed to replat a recorded subdivision or subdivisions, or any part of a recorded subdivision or subdivisions, the planning, heritage, and design commission shall hold a public hearing on the proposed preliminary plat of the replat before taking final action; provided however, where such replatting establishes larger lots than required by the zoning regulations, such replatting need not be submitted for approval. 
(Code 1973, § 17.04.020; Ord. No. 13-97, pt. 1, 8-4-97; Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 19, 11-12-19)  
Secs. 86-53—86-65. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - FINAL PLAT 
 
Sec. 86-66. - Procedure for approval. 
(a)  The final plat, a written application for approval, and such copies thereof as shall be required under the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 236.12, shall be submitted to the city clerk within six months of the approval of the preliminary plat and at least seven days prior to the meeting of the planning, heritage, and design commission at which action thereon is desired. However, if approval of the preliminary plat must be obtained from another approving authority subsequent to the preliminary plat approval by the planning, heritage, and design commission, the final plat shall be submitted within six months of such approval. The planning, heritage, and design commission may, however, waive compliance with the six months' time limit in either case. 
(b)  The city clerk shall forthwith forward the plat to the planning, heritage, and design commission and shall within 20 days of such submission forward such copies of the plat to the director of regional planning as may be required by Wis. Stats. § 236.12. The planning, heritage, and design commission shall examine the final plat as to its conformance with the preliminary plat, the requirements set forth in this chapter, and with any other ordinances, administrative rules and regulations, and plans which may affect it; and shall recommend approval, conditional approval, or rejection of the plat. The final plat may, if permitted by the planning, heritage, and design commission, constitute only that portion of the approved preliminary plat which the subdivider proposed to record at that time. 
(c)  The planning, heritage, and design commission shall transmit the plat, together with the recommendations of the commission, to the mayor and common council within 40 days of its submission to the city clerk, for necessary action. The common council shall approve or reject the final plat within 60 days of its submission to the city clerk, unless the time is extended by agreement with the subdivider. Reasons for rejection shall be forwarded to the subdivider in writing. 
(d)  After the final plat has been approved by the common council, and improvements either installed or a suitable contract acceptable by the city is entered into, or a performance bond insuring their installation is filed in accordance with section 86-91, the city clerk shall cause the certificate inscribed upon the plat attesting to such approval to be duly executed and the plat returned to the subdivider for recording. 
(Code 1973, § 17.04.030; Ord. No. 13-97, pt. 2, 8-4-97; Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 20, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 86-67. - Statutory requirements. 
The final plat of the subdivision shall comply with the requirements of Wis. Stats. § 236.20. Where the plat is located within a section or quarter section the corners of which have been relocated and monumented by the city, the plat shall be tied directly to one of such corners. The exact length and bearing of such tie shall be determined by field measurement and the material and state plane coordinates of the monument marking the relocated section or quarter section corner to which the plat is tied shall be indicated on the plat. 
(Code 1973, § 17.07.020)  
Sec. 86-68. - Additional procedures. 
(a)  The final plat or a true copy thereof, a written application for approval, and such additional copies as shall be required under the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 236.12, shall be submitted to the city clerk within six months of the approval of the preliminary plat and at least seven days prior to the meeting of the planning, heritage, and design commission at which action thereon is desired. However, if approval must be obtained from another approving authority subsequent to the preliminary plat approval by the planning, heritage, and design commission, the final plat shall be submitted within six months of such approval. The planning, heritage, and design commission may, however, waive compliance with the six months' time limit in either case. Where more than one approval is required, the letter of application shall indicate to which approving authority the plat is being first submitted in order to facilitate compliance with Wis. Stats. § 236.12(5). All of the requirements relating to improvements specified by the town board and various sanitary districts, or the city, in matters over which they have jurisdiction shall be met before filing of the final plat. 
(b)  State and city review of the final plat shall be as specified in section 86-66(b). 
(c)  Common council action on the final plat shall be as specified in section 86-66(c). 
(d)  Certification and recording of the final plat shall be as specified in section 86-66(d). 
(Code 1973, § 17.05.040; Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 21, 11-12-19)  
Secs. 86-69—86-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - IMPROVEMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Fire hydrant requirements, § 50-376 et seq.; excavations in streets, § 82-71 et seq.; sidewalk construction requirements, § 82-121 et seq.; curbcuts and driveways, § 82-161 et seq. 
 
Sec. 86-91. - Placing of monuments. 
Before final approval of any plat within the corporate limits of the city, the subdivider shall install monuments placed in accordance with the requirements of Wis. Stats. ch. 236 or as may be required by the city engineer. The planning, heritage, and design commission may waive the placing of monuments for a reasonable time on condition that the subdivider executes a surety bond to insure the placing of such monuments within the time required. 
(Code 1973, § 17.06.010; Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 22, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 86-92. - Required improvements. 
(a)  Generally. After final approval of any residential, B-1 neighborhood convenience district, B-2 community shopping district and B-3 general commercial district plats located within the city and before any building permits are issued, the subdivider shall install street and utility improvements as provided in this section. The subdivider shall before recording of his plat enter into a contract with the city agreeing to install the required improvements and shall file with such contract a bond meeting the approval of the city attorney, or a certified check in an amount equal to the estimate of cost prepared by the city engineer, as a guarantee that such improvements will be completed by the subdivider or his subcontractors not later than one year from the date of recording of the plat, or one construction season. If the subdivider desires to avail himself of special assessment financing, he shall submit a petition to the city clerk in accordance with the applicable special assessment improvements policy of the city, requesting installation of such improvements and expressly waiving all legal requirements, including right to notice and hearing, with respect to the special assessments to be levied in connection therewith. The contractor and/or subcontractors who are to be engaged in the construction of utilities or street improvements on dedicated street rights-of-way shall be listed as qualified for such work by the department of public works. Governmental units to which these bond and contract provisions apply may file, in lieu of such contract or bond, a letter from officers authorized to act in its behalf, agreeing to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Water. The subdivider shall either install adequate water facilities, including laterals to the street lines, subject to the specifications and inspections of the water department, or shall have filed after approval of the final plat, and prior to recording, a petition with the city clerk for installation of water mains in the plat. If performed by the city, the cost of engineering and supervision shall be charged to the developer at the rate of five percent of that portion of the final cost of the improvement, plus the cost of construction inspection. 
(c)  Sewer. The subdivider shall either install adequate sewer facilities, including laterals to the street lines, subject to the specifications and inspections of the city engineering department and/or the wastewater utility, or shall have filed, after approval of the final plat, a petition with the city clerk and prior to recording for installation of sewers in the plat. If performed by the city, the cost of engineering and supervision shall be charged to the developer at the rate of five percent of that portion of the final cost of the improvements to be paid by the subdivider, plus cost of construction inspection. If public sewer facilities are not available, lot sizes shall be such that effective private disposal systems can be provided on the individual premises, and shall be determined on the basis of recommendations of the boards of health of the city and the state. 
(d)  Street grading. The subdivider shall furnish drawings which indicate the existing and proposed grades of streets shown upon the plat and, after approval of street grades by the city engineer and the common council, shall grade or cause to be graded the full width of right-of-way of the dedicated streets. The bed for the roadways in the street rights-of-way shall be graded to subgrade, which is six inches below established grade. The city engineer shall approve the work prior to the time any building permit is issued. 
(e)  Street surfacing. After sewer and water utilities have been installed either by the developer at his option or by the city, with the cost to be special assessed to benefited properties, when requested by the city the subdivider shall surface roadways to a width of 36 feet. The surfacing shall consist of not less than six inches of crushed limestone, conforming to department of public works specifications. 
(f)  Sidewalks in public way. Dedicated walkways through blocks shall be improved by the subdivider with a city standard sidewalk to a grade established by the city engineer. Such work shall be inspected by the city engineer. Engineering and inspection costs shall be paid by the subdivider at the rate of five percent of the final cost of improvements. 
(g)  Filing of final plat. After the subdivider has entered into a contract, guaranteed by a performance bond or a suitable contract acceptable by the city, by which he agrees to provide utilities and street improvements required in this article, such subdivider shall file with the city clerk the final plat as required under section 86-66. 
(Code 1973, § 17.06.020) 
Cross reference— Residential zoning district regulations, § 114-251 et seq.; B-1 neighborhood convenience district, § 114-446 et seq.; B-2 community shopping district, § 114-466 et seq.; B-3 general commercial district, § 114-486 et seq.  
Secs. 86-93—86-115. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - DESIGN STANDARDS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 86-116. - Variances. 
When in the judgment of the planning, heritage, and design commission it would be inappropriate to apply literally the provisions of this article because extraordinary hardship would result, it may waive or vary such provisions so that substantial justice may be done and the public interest secured. 
(Code 1973, § 17.10.010; Ord. No. 6-02, pt. 7, 4-3-02; Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 23, 11-12-19)  
Secs. 86-117—86-125. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - STREETS AND ALLEYS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Streets, § 82-31 et seq. 
 
Sec. 86-126. - Layout generally. 
In any new subdivision, the street layout shall conform to the arrangement, width and location indicated on the master plan, or component neighborhood unit development plan. In areas for which such plans have not been completed, the streets shall be designed and located in proper relation to existing and proposed streets, to the topography, to such natural features as streams and tree growth, to public convenience and safety, to the proposed use of the land to be served by such streets, and to the most advantageous development of adjoining areas. The subdivision shall provide each lot access to a public street which is acceptable to the city. 
(Code 1973, § 17.08.010(a)) 
Cross reference— Supplementary zoning district regulations regarding lots, § 114-771.  
Sec. 86-127. - Arrangement. 
(a)  Major streets and highways shall be properly integrated with the existing and proposed system of major streets and highways and insofar as practicable shall be continuous and in alignment with existing, planned or platted streets with which they are to connect. 
(b)  Collector streets shall be properly located to the mass transportation system, to special traffic generators such as schools, churches and shopping centers, to concentrations of population, and to the major streets into which they feed. 
(c)  Minor streets shall be designated to conform to the topography; to discourage use by through traffic; to permit the design of efficient storm and sanitary sewerage systems; and to require the minimum street area necessary to provide safe and convenient access to abutting property. 
(d)  Proposed streets shall extend to the boundary lines of the tract being subdivided unless prevented by topography or other physical conditions, or unless in the opinion of the planning, heritage, and design commission such extension is not necessary or desirable for the coordination of the layout of the subdivision or for the advantageous development of the adjacent tracts. 
(Code 1973, § 17.08.010(b); Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 24, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 86-128. - Treatment of railroad rights-of-way and limited access highways. 
Wherever the proposed subdivision contains or is adjacent to a railroad right-of-way or limited access highway, the subdivision shall provide the following treatment: 
(1)  In residential districts the minimum depth of a lot shall be 130 feet, of which the rear ten feet shall be reserved for a buffer strip, when adjacent to the railroad right-of-way or limited access highway. This strip shall be part of the platted lots, but shall have the following restriction lettered on the face of the plat: "This strip reserved for the planting of trees or shrubs by the owner; the building of structures hereon is prohibited." 
(2)  In commercial and manufacturing districts provision shall be made on each side of the railroad right-of-way or limited access highway for streets approximately parallel to and at a distance from such right-of-way or highway suitable for the appropriate use of the land between such streets and rights-of-way, but not less than 150 feet. 
(3)  Streets parallel to the railroad right-of-way or limited access highway shall, when intersecting a major street and highway or a collector street, be located at a minimum distance of 250 feet from the right-of-way or highway. Such distance, where desirable and practicable, shall be determined with due consideration of the minimum distance required for the future separation of grades by means of appropriate approach gradients. 
(4)  Location of minor streets immediately adjacent and parallel to railroad rights-of-way shall be avoided. 
(Code 1973, § 17.08.010(c))  
Sec. 86-129. - Protection of major streets and highways. 
Whenever the proposed subdivision contains or is adjacent to a major street or highway, adequate protection of residential properties, limitation of access and the separation of through and local traffic shall be provided by: 
(1)  Reversed frontage with screen planting contained in a nonaccess reservation along the rear property line. 
(2)  Marginal access street. 
(Code 1973, § 17.08.010(d))  
Sec. 86-130. - Alleys. 
Alleys shall be required in commercial, business and industrial districts for off-street loading and service access unless otherwise eliminated by the planning, heritage, and design commission, but shall not be approved in residential districts. Roads and alleys shall not be approved; and alleys shall not have their points of connection on a major thoroughfare. 
(Code 1973, § 17.08.010(e); Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 25, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 86-131. - Reserve strips. 
There shall be no reserve strips controlling access to streets except where control of such strips is definitely placed in the city under conditions approved by the planning, heritage, and design commission. 
(Code 1973, § 17.08.010(f); Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 26, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 86-132. - Intersections. 
(a)  Streets shall intersect each other at as nearly right angles as topography and other limiting factors of good design permit. 
(b)  The number of streets converging at one intersection shall be reduced to a minimum, preferably not more than two. 
(c)  The number of intersections along major streets shall be held to a minimum; wherever practicable, the distance between such intersections shall not be less than 1,000 feet. 
(d)  Property lines at street intersections shall be rounded with a minimum radius of ten feet or of a greater radius when required by the planning, heritage, and design commission. 
(e)  Minor streets shall not necessarily continue across major or collector streets, but if centerlines of such minor streets approach the major streets from opposite sides thereof within 300 feet of each other measured along the centerline of the major or collector street, their location shall be adjusted so that the alignment across the major or collector street is continuous and a jog is avoided. 
(Code 1973, § 17.08.010(g); Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 27, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 86-133. - Widths of streets and pavements, parkways and drainageways. 
(a)  The minimum right-of-way and roadway of all proposed streets shall be of the width specified by the master plan, neighborhood development study or planned development plan, or, if no width is specified therein, the minimum widths shall be as follows: 
Type of street 	Right-of-way 
width 
(feet) 	Roadway width 
(face of curb to 
face of curb) 
Boulevards and parkways 	120 	Dual 36 feet 
(24-foot median) 
Major streets 	110 	Dual 36 feet 
(14-foot median residential area); 
(24-foot median business area) 
Collector streets 	 90 	70 feet 
Minor streets 	 60 	36 feet 
 
(b)  All cul-de-sac streets shall terminate in a circular turnaround having a minimum right-of-way diameter of 120 feet and a minimum outside curb diameter of 90 feet. 
(c)  If parkways or drainageways influenced by topographical features such as streams or ponds are to be provided within the proposed plat, their width and location shall be determined as may be deemed necessary to preserve such features. Generally, parkways and drainageways shall have a width of 200 feet, but they shall not in any case be less than 100 feet in width. 
(Code 1973, § 17.08.010(h))  
Sec. 86-134. - Grades. 
(a)  Unless necessitated by exceptional topography and subject to the approval of the planning, heritage, and design commission, the maximum street grades shall not exceed the following: 
(1)  Major streets and collector streets: Six percent. 
(2)  Minor streets and alleys: Eight percent. 
The grade of any street shall in no case exceed ten percent or be less than one-half of one percent. 
(b)  All changes in street grades of over two percent shall be connected by vertical curves of a minimum length equivalent in feet to 15 times the algebraic difference in the rates of grade for major and collector streets, and one-half this minimum for all other streets. Street grades shall be established wherever practicable in such a manner as to avoid excessive grading, the promiscuous removal of ground cover and tree growth and the general leveling of the topography. 
(Code 1973, § 17.08.010(i); Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 28, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 86-135. - Radii of curvature. 
When a continuous street centerline deflects at any one point by more than ten degrees, a circular curve shall be introduced having a radius of curvature on such centerline of not less than the following: 
(1)  Major streets, 300 feet. 
(2)  Collector streets, 200 feet. 
(3)  Minor streets, 100 feet. 
A tangent of at least 100 feet in length shall be provided between reverse curves on major and collector streets. 
(Code 1973, § 17.08.010(j))  
Sec. 86-136. - Half-streets. 
Where an existing dedicated or platted half-street is adjacent to the tract being subdivided, the other half of the street shall be dedicated by the subdivider. Plats with half-streets of less than 49 feet in width on the borders of the subdivision will not be approved unless the owner will place on record an agreement which will state in effect that lots which are dependent upon the half-street of less than 49 feet for ingress and egress purposes shall not be sold, and stating further that no structures shall be erected on such lots with ingress and egress facilities facing such half-street until the full width of the street of at least 60 feet shall have been opened and accepted by the planning, heritage, and design commission and the common council. 
(Code 1973, § 17.08.010(k); Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 29, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 86-137. - Street names. 
New street names shall not duplicate or be similar to existing street names, and existing street names shall be projected wherever possible. 
(Code 1973, § 17.08.010(l))  
Sec. 86-138. - Drainage. 
All plats shall comply with the drainage and erosion control requirements of Wis. Stats. § 236.13(2)(m).  
Secs. 86-139—86-150. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - LOTS AND BLOCKS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Zoning lot regulations, § 114-771 et seq. 
 
Sec. 86-151. - Blocks. 
(a)  The lengths, widths and shapes of blocks shall be suited to the planned use of the land, zoning requirements, need for convenient access, control and safety of street traffic, and the limitations and opportunities of topography. Block lengths in residential areas shall not as a general rule be less than 600 feet in length between street lines unless dictated by exceptional topography or other limiting factors of good design. 
(b)  Blocks shall have sufficient width to provide for two tiers of lots and appropriate depth except where otherwise required to separate residential development from through traffic. 
(Code 1973, § 17.08.030)  
Sec. 86-152. - Lots. 
(a)  The size, shape and orientation of the lots shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision and for the type of development and use contemplated. The lots should be designed to provide an aesthetically pleasing building site, and a proper architectural setting for the building contemplated. 
(b)  Every lot shall front or abut on a public street. In the case of a subdivision which is part of a planned development, every lot shall front or abut on a public street or other means of access approved by the city. 
(c)  Lot dimensions shall conform to the zoning regulations and shall have a minimum average depth of 120 feet. 
(d)  Side lot lines shall be at right angles to straight street lines or radial to curved street lines on which the lots face. 
(e)  Corner lots shall have an extra width of ten feet to permit adequate building setbacks from side streets. 
(f)  If a tract is subdivided into large parcels, such parcels shall be arranged so as to allow for the resubdivision of any such parcels into normal lots in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(g)  Excessive depth in relation to lot width shall be avoided and a proportion of two to one shall normally be considered as a desirable ratio. 
(h)  Lot lines shall follow municipal boundary lines rather than across them. 
(i)  Double frontage and reverse frontage lots shall be prohibited except where necessary to provide separation of residential development from through traffic or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. 
(j)  Residential lots fronting or backing on major streets shall be platted with extra depth to permit generous distances between the buildings and such trafficways. 
(k)  Depth and width of properties reserved or laid out for commercial or industrial use shall be adequate to provide for the off-street service and parking facilities required by the type of use and development contemplated. 
(l)  All plats in the city shall contain a prominent note stating that "No lot or parcel shall be hereafter created which has less area or frontage than the average of all lots along that block frontage as originally subdivided." 
(Code 1973, § 17.08.040)  
Secs. 86-153—86-165. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - EASEMENTS AND PUBLIC SITES AND OPEN SPACES 
 
Sec. 86-166. - Easements. 
(a)  The planning, heritage, and design commission may require easements of widths deemed adequate by the commission for the intended purpose on each side of all rear lot lines and on side lot lines or across lots where necessary or advisable for poles, wires, conduits, storm and sanitary sewers, gas, water and heat mains or other utility lines. A minimum easement width of six feet inside the lot on each side of the lot line shall be required, making a minimum total easement of 12 feet. 
(b)  Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream, any adequate drainageway or easement shall be provided as required by the planning, heritage, and design commission. The location, width, alignment and improvement of such drainageway or easement shall be subject to the approval of the planning, heritage, and design commission and parallel streets or parkways may be required in connection therewith. Wherever possible, the stormwater drainage shall be maintained by landscaped open channels of adequate size and grade to hydraulically accommodate maximum potential volumes of flow, and these sizes and design details shall be subject to review and approval by the engineering department and the park department. 
(Code 1973, § 17.08.020; Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 30, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 86-167. - Public sites and open spaces. 
In the design of the plat, due consideration shall be given to the reservation of suitable sites of adequate area for future schools, parks, playgrounds, drainageways and other public purposes. In the location of such sites, consideration shall be given to the preservation of scenic and historic sites, stands of fine trees, marshes, lakes and ponds, watercourses, watersheds and ravines. 
(Code 1973, § 17.08.050)  
Secs. 86-168—86-190. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - LAND DIVISIONS OTHER THAN SUBDIVISIONS 
 
Sec. 86-191. - Application of article. 
For land divisions other than subdivisions, the regulations of this article apply. This article does not apply to lots in a recorded subdivision other than out-lots. 
(Code 1973, § 17.09.010) 
Cross reference— Zoning regulations, ch. 114.  
Sec. 86-192. - Procedures. 
(a)  The subdivider shall file a certified survey map accompanied by six blueprints or other acceptable reproductions thereof and written application for approval with the secretary of the planning, heritage, and design commission at least 14 days prior to the meeting of the planning, heritage, and design commission at which action is desired. 
(b)  The map shall be reviewed by the planning department for conformity with the provisions of city ordinances and for the possible effect of the proposed division on any plans as set forth in the master plan, or neighborhood unit development studies, and it shall transmit a copy of the map to the building inspection department, which shall review the proposed division for compliance with all existing zoning regulations. Their recommendations in respect thereto shall be transmitted to the planning, heritage, and design commission not later than seven days from the date the map is received by the building inspection department. 
(c)  The planning, heritage, and design commission shall within 21 days of the filing of the plat approve, approve conditionally or reject the division. The original and one copy of the map shall be returned to the divider with the date and action endorsed thereon for recording. The divider shall be notified in writing of any conditions of approval or the reasons for rejection. 
(Code 1973, § 17.09.020; Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 31, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 86-193. - Requirements; certificate of approval. 
(a)  The division shall comply with the provisions of this chapter relating to the general requirements and design standards for subdivisions. 
(b)  The survey shall be performed and the map prepared by a registered land surveyor, and the map shall comply with Wis. Stats. § 236.34 and section 86-51. In addition, the plat shall show all existing buildings, watercourses, drainage ditches and other features pertinent to proper division. 
(c)  The certificate of approval of the planning, heritage, and design commission shall be typed, lettered or otherwise reproduced legibly on the face of the map with nonfading black ink. 
(d)  Except in those cases when the proposed division lies within a duly recorded subdivision, the map shall be filed by the divider for recording with the county register of deeds. 
(Code 1973, § 17.09.030; Ord. No. 0026-19, pt. 32, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 86-194. - Fees. 
Review fees as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council shall be charged by the city. 
(Ord. No. 6-06, pt. 2, 4-5-06; Ord. No. 9-07, pt. 1, 4-16-07; Ord. No. 01-14, pt. 1, 2-4-14; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 96, 11-12-19)  
Chapter 90 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Department of finance, § 2-361 et seq.; finance director/city treasurer, § 2-481 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 90-1—90-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - GENERAL PROPERTY; ASSESSMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Board of review, § 2-191 et seq.; city assessor, § 2-466 et seq. 
State Law reference— Levy of taxes, Wis. Stats. § 65.07; property taxes, Wis. Stats. ch. 70; property tax collection, Wis. Stats. ch. 74; property tax sales, Wis. Stats. ch. 75. 
 
Sec. 90-26. - Due date; installment tax payments. 
All taxes upon real estate in the city shall be paid on or before January 31 of each year, except that where the tax on a particular parcel amounts to $100.00 or more, it may be paid in four equal installments, each of which shall become successively due and payable on or before January 31, March 31, May 31 and July 31. On any installment date, the taxpayer may pay the balance of the tax due. 
(Code 1973, § 6.14.010) 
State Law reference— Payment of taxes, Wis. Stats. § 74.11; installment payment option, Wis. Stats. § 74.12.  
Sec. 90-27. - Delinquent installments; interest and penalty. 
(a)  When the first installment of the real estate taxes is not paid on or before January 31, the whole amount of such real estate taxes shall become delinquent as of February 1. All such taxes remaining unpaid on February 1 shall be collected by the city treasurer with interest at the rate of one percent per month or fraction thereof, and penalty of 0.5 percent per month or fraction thereof from February 1. 
(b)  If the second or any subsequent installment payment of real property taxes is not paid by the due date specified, the entire amount of the remaining unpaid taxes on that parcel is delinquent on the first day of the month after the payment is due. Such taxes shall be collected together with interest of one percent per month or fraction thereof and penalty of 0.5 percent per month or fraction thereof from February 1. 
(Code 1973, §§ 6.14.020, 6.14.030) 
State Law reference— Delinquent payments, Wis. Stats. § 74.12(7)—(9).  
Sec. 90-28. - Special assessments and special charges. 
(a)  Special charges. Special charges for current services which shall include, without limitation because of enumeration, snow and ice removal, weed elimination, street sprinkling, oiling and tarring, subgrading and stoning, tree care and water mains, shall not be payable in installments. If not paid within the period fixed by the common council, such charges shall be deemed a delinquent charge and shall become a lien on the property against which it is levied, and shall automatically be extended on the current or next tax roll as a delinquent tax against the property, and all procedures relating to the collection, and return and sale of property for delinquent real estate taxes, shall apply to such charge. Any such delinquent charges shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month or fraction thereof and penalty of 0.5 percent per month or fraction thereof from the preceding February 1. If any such special charge is not paid when due, the whole remaining real estate tax and special charges shall become delinquent on February 1. 
(b)  Special assessments. Special assessments shall be due upon determination of the amount of such assessment and may be paid without interest up to and including the due date. Any balance remaining unpaid after the due date shall be collected with interest from and after the due date at the annual interest rate specified in subsection (3), below. All unpaid balances will be collected in the following manner: 
(1)  Any balance of less than $200.00 shall be entered on the first tax roll prepared after such assessment shall have been determined, as a special tax on the property upon which such assessment was levied, and thereafter this tax shall be treated in all respects as any other municipal tax. 
(2)  Whenever the unpaid balance of the following special assessments is in excess of $200.00, it may be paid in ten annual installments: 
a.  Portland cement concrete pavement. 
b.  Portland cement concrete combined curb and gutter. 
c.  Sewer and water services. 
d.  Sanitary sewer. 
e.  New sidewalk construction. 
f.  Sidewalk repair or replacement. 
g.  Bituminous concrete pavement. 
(3)  The annual interest rate for all unpaid special assessment balances failing under subsections (1) and (2), above, will be adjusted every five years (beginning in 2012), as follows: 
a.  First, the average bank prime loan interest rate percentage for the preceding ten-year period shall be calculated. Next, a 0.5 percent administrative charge shall be added to this rate. Finally, this total interest rate percentage shall be rounded up to the nearest 0.5 percent. 
For example, if the average bank prime loan interest rate percentage for 2002—2011 is 5.017%, then the 2012—2016 interest rate for all unpaid special assessment balances falling under subsections (1) and (2), above, are as follows: 
 
b.  No adjustment to the special assessment interest rate shall exceed the previous rate by more than + 2.0 percent. 
c.  The bank prime loan interest rate percentage will be calculated from the annual figures released by the Federal Reserve System available at http://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/h15/data.htm. 
(c)  Payment in installments. 
(1)  The first installment of any special assessment shall include a proportionate part of the principal of the special assessment determined by the number of installments, together with interest at the rate of eight percent per annum computed for a period of one year from the due date, and each subsequent installment shall include a like proportion of the principal and one year's interest on the unpaid balance of the assessment. 
(2)  The first installment shall be entered in the first tax roll prepared after such installments shall have been determined, as a special tax on the property upon which the special assessment was levied, and thereafter this tax shall be treated in all respects as any other municipal tax. One of the subsequent installments shall be entered in a like manner and with like effect in each of the annual tax rolls thereafter until all are levied. 
(3)  If any installment so entered in the tax roll shall not be paid with the other taxes when due, it shall be returned to the county as delinquent and collected by the county in the same manner as delinquent general taxes on real estate. 
(Code 1973, § 6.14.040; Ord. No. 14-12, §§ 1, 2, 12-18-2012) 
State Law reference— Special assessment, Wis. Stats. §§ 66.0701; 66.0715; 74.43.  
Sec. 90-29. - Personal property taxes. 
Personal property taxes shall be paid on or before January 31 of each year. The city treasurer shall charge back to each taxing jurisdiction its proportionate share of those personal property taxes for which the city settled in full the previous February, which were delinquent at the time of settlement and remain delinquent. Any delinquent personal property taxes charged back under this section which are subsequently collected by the city shall be proportionately distributed on May 15, August 15, November 15 and February 15 to each taxing jurisdiction to which the delinquent taxes were charged back. 
(Code 1973, § 6.14.050)  
Sec. 90-30. - Penalty on delinquent taxes. 
Pursuant to the authority of Wis. Stats. § 74.47(2), the county imposed a penalty of 0.5 percent per month or fraction of a month, in addition to the interest prescribed by Wis. Stats. § 74.47(1), on all overdue and delinquent general property taxes, special assessments, special charges and special taxes included in the tax roll. This penalty of 0.5 percent per month or fraction of a month shall apply to any such taxes or charges which are overdue or delinquent on the effective date of this section, or which subsequently become overdue or delinquent. 
(Code 1973, § 6.14.060)  
Sec. 90-31. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 13-01, adopted April 17, 2001, repealed § 90-31, notice of increase in assessed valuation, which pertained to property assessments and derived from Code 1973, § 6.15.010.  
Sec. 90-32. - Income and expense information. 
Whenever the assessor in the performance of the assessor's duties requests or obtains income and expense information pursuant to, Wis. Stats. § 70.47(7)(af), then such income and expense information that is provided to the assessor shall be held on a confidential basis, excepting that such information may be revealed to and used by persons in the discharge of duties imposed by law; in the discharge of duties imposed by office, including, but not limited to, use by the assessor in performance of official duties of the assessor's office; use by the board of review in performance of its official duties, or pursuant to order of a court. Income and expense information provided to the assessor under Wis. Stats. § 70.47(7)(af), unless a court determines that it is inaccurate, is not subject to the right of inspection and copying under Wisconsin open records law or City of Racine open records ordinances, pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 70.47(7)(af), Wis. Stats. 
(Ord. No. 13-99, pt. 1, 11-2-99)  
Sec. 90-33. - Special charges for repayment of energy efficiency improvement loans. 
(a)  The common council may establish by resolution a program for making loans for improvements to resident's residential property for energy efficiency or renewable energy projects pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.0627(8). 
(b)  Loans made under this program shall be repaid through a special charge against the residential real property. The special charge shall equal the principal and interest due on the loan for the period specified in the loan agreement between the property owner and the city. The loan agreement may specify more frequent payments than the time established by the city for the billing and collection of special charges; in which case, the loan payment shall not be billed as a special charge unless the property owner becomes delinquent in payments. A penalty charge shall be added to delinquent payments. 
(Ord. No. 17-09, pt. 1, 8-18-09)  
Secs. 90-34—90-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - TRANSIENT LODGING TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Bed and breakfast establishments, § 22-201 et seq.; roominghouses, § 22-686 et seq.; hotels and tourist roominghouses, § 22-561 et seq. 
State Law reference— Room tax authorized, Wis. Stats. § 66.75. 
 
Sec. 90-51. - Authority and purpose. 
Wis. Stats. § 66.0615 authorizes the imposition of a tax on the privilege of furnishing, at retail, lodging for transients by hotelkeepers, motel operators, owners of short-term rentals and certain other persons. The common council finds that such a tax is in the best interest of the public under the condition that the proceeds be used for the promotion of tourism, hospitality and convention facilities, and recreation facilities in the greater Racine area. 
(Code 1973, § 22.27.010; Ord. No. 0012-18, 9-4-18)  
Sec. 90-52. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Gross receipts means the total amount of the rental price, with the conditions and exceptions provided in Wis. Stats. § 77.51(4)(a), (b) and (c). 
Innkeeper means the owner of a lodging facility. 
Lodging facility means a building or group of buildings in which the public may obtain accommodations for a consideration, including, without limitation, such establishments as inns, motels, bed and breakfast establishments, tourist homes, tourist rooming houses, lodging houses, rooming houses, hotels, resort lodges, cabins, short-term rentals, and any other building or group of buildings in which accommodations are available to the public, except accommodations rented for a continuous period of more than one month and accommodations furnished by any hospital, sanitarium, nursing home, or by corporations or associations organized and operated exclusively for religious, charitable or educational purposes, provided that no part of the net earnings of such corporations or associations inures to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual. 
Lodging marketplace has the meaning as defined in Wis. Stats. § 66.0615(1)(bs). 
Transient means any person residing for a period of less than 29 days continuously in a lodging facility. 
Treasurer means the treasurer of the city or their designated representative. 
(Code 1973, § 22.27.020; Ord. No. 0012-18, 9-4-18; Ord. No. 0018-19, pt. 4, 8-7-19) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 90-53. - Imposed. 
Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.0615, there is hereby imposed a tax on the privilege and service of furnishing, at retail, rooms or lodging to transients by innkeepers, whether or not membership is required for the use of such accommodations. The tax shall be at the rate of eight percent of the gross receipts from such retail furnishing of rooms or lodging and shall be payable by innkeepers of lodging facilities in the city. From the proceeds of such tax, five percent will be allocated to the innkeeper filing the return.
