(Code 1973, § 22.27.030; Ord. No. 11-94, pt. 1, 5-3-94; Ord. No. 32-01, pt. 1, 12-4-01; Ord. No. 27-05, pt. 1, 12-6-05; Ord. No. 0012-18, 9-4-18)  
Sec. 90-54. - Collection and remittance. 
The tax imposed under this article is due and payable on a monthly basis not later than the 20th day of the month following that for which the tax is due. Not later than the 20th of each month or quarter that the lodging facility has overnight guests, every innkeeper shall file a return with the treasurer on a form provided by the treasurer and shall remit to the treasurer the tax as provided in such return. 
(Code 1973, § 22.27.040; Ord. No. 0012-18, 9-4-18)  
Sec. 90-55. - Room tax permit. 
(a)  No innkeeper shall operate a lodging facility without first obtaining a room tax permit for each lodging facility. Application for such permit shall be made to the treasurer on forms provided by the Treasurer. The Treasurer shall issue a permit to the innkeeper for each lodging facility for which application is made upon payment of a one-time fee as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council for each lodging facility. Lodging facilities that are current on all inspections and which have paid and are current on payment of room taxes prior to September 4, 2018, shall not be required to pay the permit fee and shall be issued a room tax permit. The permit is nontransferable and is valid only for the named lodging facility and the innkeeper named in such permit. The permit shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the lodging facility for which it is issued. 
(b)  If the innkeeper ceases to do business at the lodging facility for which the room tax permit was issued, or conveys or transfers the business or his interest in it, or assigns his interest to another person, the innkeeper shall, within ten days of such event, notify the treasurer of such change and turn into the treasurer any such permit issued for the lodging facility. 
(Code 1973, § 22.27.050; Ord. No. 0012-18, 9-4-18; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 97, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 90-56. - Violations; penalty. 
(a)  Whenever any person fails to comply with this section the treasurer may, upon ten days notification and after affording such person the opportunity to show cause why his or her permit should not be revoked, revoke or suspend any or all of the permits held by such person. The treasurer shall give to such person written notice of the suspension or revocation of any of his or her permits. The treasurer shall not issue a new permit after the revocation of a permit unless he or she is satisfied that the former holder of the permit will comply with the provisions of this section. A fee as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council shall be imposed for the renewal or issuance of a permit that has been previously suspended or revoked. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided, in addition to the remedy in section (a) above, any innkeeper who is subject to the tax imposed by this article who fails to obtain a permit as required or who fails or refuses to permit the inspection of such innkeeper's state sales tax records by the treasurer after such inspection has been duly requested, or who fails to file a return as required in this article, or who violates any other provision of this article, shall be subject to a forfeiture as provided in section 1-15. Each violation and each day a violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1973, § 22.27.100; Ord. No. 0012-18, 9-4-18; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 98, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 90-57. - Liability. 
If an innkeeper who is liable for any tax under this article sells, conveys, assigns or transfers his lodging facility business or stock of goods or quits such business, the innkeeper's successors or assigns shall be responsible for the payment of any unpaid tax due under this article. 
(Code 1973, § 22.27.060; Ord. No. 0012-18, 9-4-18)  
Sec. 90-58. - Records; determination of tax by treasurer; appeal. 
Every innkeeper holding a permit under this article shall, for a period of three full calendar years, maintain available for inspection by the treasurer the account books, records, receipts, invoices, property, and similar records relating to the rental of rooms and lodging in the lodging facility. The treasurer may, upon audit of returns, records, memoranda, and other information received, determine the tax to be paid or refunded. An appeal from any additional tax imposed may be made by the innkeeper upon written notice to the treasurer within 20 days following the date that notice of the assessment is mailed to such innkeeper. The finance and personnel committee of the common council shall hold a hearing on such appeal within 30 days after the treasurer receives the notice of appeal, and shall recommend to the common council whether such appeal should be granted or denied. The common council shall grant or deny such appeal within 30 days of its receipt of such recommendation. 
(Code 1973, § 22.27.070; Ord. No. 0012-18, 9-4-18)  
Sec. 90-59. - Assessment of unpaid taxes. 
If an innkeeper fails to file a return as required by this article, the treasurer shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts for such lodging facility. The estimate shall be made for the period for which the innkeeper failed to make a return and shall be based upon state sales tax records and records described in section 90-58. On the basis of such estimate, the treasurer shall compute and determine the amount of the tax. In addition to the tax, a penalty in the amount of ten percent of the amount owed shall be assessed. 
(Code 1973, § 22.27.080; Ord. No. 0012-18, 9-4-18)  
Sec. 90-60. - Delinquent returns. 
A penalty of 25 percent of the room tax due for the previous year or $5,000.00, whichever is less, of the tax imposed, is hereby established and due and owing in the event that the room tax is not paid within ten days after the due date of the return. In addition to this penalty, all unpaid taxes assessed or imposed under this article shall bear interest at the rate of 12 percent per annum from the due date of the return until paid. An extension of time within which to fine a return shall not operate to extend the due date of the return for purposes of interest computation. Delinquent tax returns shall be subject to a late filing fee as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council. 
(Code 1973, § 22.27.090; Ord. No. 0012-18, 9-4-18; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 99, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 90-61. - Records; confidentiality. 
All tax returns, schedules exhibits, writings, or audit reports relating to such returns, on file with the treasurer, are deemed to be confidential, except the treasurer may divulge their contents to the following, and no others: 
(1)  The person who filed the return; 
(2)  Officers, agents, or employees of the Federal Internal Revenue Service or the State Department of Revenue; 
(3)  Officers, employees, or agents of the finance director; 
(4)  Such other public Officials of the City of Racine, when deemed necessary. 
(Ord. No. 0012-18, 9-4-18)  
Chapter 94 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— School traffic safety commission, § 2-261 et seq.; traffic commission, § 2-276 et seq.; department of transportation, § 2-346 et seq.; police department, § 2-401 et seq.; municipal judge, § 2-506 et seq.; motor vehicle recovery and towing businesses, § 22-831 et seq.; regulations regarding public passenger vehicles, § 22-1031 et seq.; hazardous spills and discharge prohibited, § 42-1; abandoned, nuisance, or junked vehicles, § 42-181 et seq.; traffic regulations in parks and recreation areas, § 70-76; parades, processions and open air meetings restricted and permit required, § 82-39; fire hydrants and other utilities located in streets restricted, § 82-40; repair or storage of motor vehicles in streets prohibited, § 82-42; vacating or temporarily closing streets, § 82-56 et seq.; excavations in streets, § 82-71 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 94-1. - State traffic laws adopted. 
Except as otherwise specifically provided in this Code, the provisions in Wis. Stats. chs. 340 to 348, describing and defining regulations with respect to vehicles and traffic, exclusive of any provisions therein relating to penalties to be imposed and exclusive of any regulations for which the statutory penalty is a fine or term of imprisonment, are adopted and by reference made a part of this Code as if fully set forth herein. Any act required to be performed or prohibited by any statute incorporated herein by reference is required or prohibited by this Code. Future amendments, revisions or modifications of the statutes incorporated herein are intended to be made a part of this Code in order to secure uniform statewide regulations of traffic on the highways, streets and alleys of the state. 
(Code 1973, § 27.01.010)  
Sec. 94-2. - State forfeitures adopted. 
Any forfeiture for violation of the state statutes adopted by reference in section 94-1 shall conform to the forfeiture permitted to be imposed for violation of such statutes, as set forth in the Uniform Deposit and Misdemeanor Bail Schedule of the Wisconsin Judicial Conference, including any variations or increases for subsequent offenses, which schedule is hereby adopted by reference. 
(Code 1973, § 27.01.020)  
Sec. 94-3. - State motor vehicle code adopted. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, the statutory provisions in Wis. Stats. §§ 110.06—110.075 and chapter TRANS 305, Wisconsin Administrative Code, describing and defining regulations with respect to motor vehicle equipment rules, regulations and inspections, are adopted and by reference made a part of this chapter as if fully set forth herein. Any act required to be performed or prohibited by any statute incorporated herein by reference is required or prohibited by this section. Any future amendments, revisions or modifications of the statutes incorporated in this section are intended to be made a part of this section. 
(b)  Any forfeiture for violation of the state statutes adopted by reference in subsection (a) of this section shall conform to the forfeiture permitted to be imposed for violation of such statutes, as set forth in the Uniform Deposit and Misdemeanor Bail Schedule of the Wisconsin Judicial Conference, including any variations or increases for subsequent offenses. Such schedule is hereby adopted by reference. 
(Code 1973, §§ 27.01.030, 27.01.031; Ord. No. 10-96, pt. 1, 7-2-96; Ord. No. 10-98, pt. 1, 7-21-98)  
Sec. 94-4. - Duties of police officers. 
It shall be the duty of the police department to enforce the provisions of this chapter. Officers of the police department are hereby authorized to direct all traffic either in person or by means of visible or audible signal in conformance with the provisions of this chapter; provided, that in the event of fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police or fire department may direct traffic as conditions may require, notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1973, § 27.03.010) 
State Law reference— Resisting or obstructing officer, Wis. Stats. § 946.41.  
Sec. 94-5. - General penalty for violation of chapter. 
The penalty for violation of any provision of this chapter shall be a forfeiture as provided in this chapter, together with the cost of prosecution imposed as provided in Wis. Stats. §§ 345.20—345.53. 
(Code 1973, § 27.39.010)  
Sec. 94-6. - Erecting and maintaining signs and signals. 
(a)  The traffic engineer is hereby authorized and directed to procure, erect and maintain appropriate standard traffic signs, signals and markings conforming to the rules of the state highway division, giving such notice of the provisions of this chapter as is required by state law. Signs shall be erected in such locations and manner as the traffic engineer shall determine will best effect the purposes of this chapter and give adequate warning to users of the street or highway. 
(b)  The traffic engineer shall have the authority granted by Wis. Stats. § 349.09, and is hereby directed, to order the removal of a sign, signal, marking or device placed, maintained or displayed in violation of this chapter or of Wis. Stats. § 346.41. 
(Code 1973, §§ 27.38.010, 27.38.020)  
Sec. 94-7. - Obedience to crossing guards. 
No operator of a vehicle shall fail or refuse to stop for a crossing guard or school crossing guard when, in the performance of his duties, he so directs by use of a sign or signal. 
(Code 1973, § 27.38.030)  
Sec. 94-8. - Authority of traffic engineer. 
The traffic engineer may make and implement any regulations necessary to effectively implement the provisions of this chapter. In addition, the traffic engineer may, notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, make and enforce any temporary traffic regulation necessary to handle or cover special conditions or emergency situations. 
(Code 1973, § 27.04.010)  
Sec. 94-9. - Temporary parking prohibitions. 
The commissioner of public works may, when necessary for the proper cleaning, maintenance, repair or construction of streets or alleys in the city, or when necessary for the handling or prevention of any emergency situation in the city, temporarily prohibit the parking of any vehicle upon any street or alley in the city. Such temporary prohibition of parking shall be implemented by the reasonable posting of signs in the affected area reading "Temporary no parking, City of Racine." Unless impracticable, the posting of signs shall be completed not less than four hours prior to the effective time and date of the parking prohibition. When the circumstances requiring the temporary prohibition of no parking cease, all such posted signs shall be removed and the temporary prohibition ended. 
(Code 1973, § 27.04.020)  
Sec. 94-10. - Snowmobiles. 
(a)  Definition. "Snowmobile" means any engine-driven vehicle of a type that utilizes sled type runners, or skis, or an endless belt tread, or any combination of these or other similar means of contact with the surface upon which it is operated, but does not include such vehicles that are either manually propelled or driven by a motor of four horsepower or less and that are operated in sanctioned races, derbies, competitions or exhibitions or only on private property. 
(b)  Operation on public streets, sidewalks, parkways and parks. Unless special permission is obtained from the common council, no person shall operate a snowmobile on any public street, sidewalk or parkway, or in any park owned by the city, whether such park lies within or without the city limits. 
(Code 1973, §§ 27.33.010, 27.33.020) 
State Law reference— Similar definition, Wis. Stats. § 34.01(58a).  
Sec. 94-11. - Operation of motor-driven cycles restricted. 
No person shall operate a motorcycle, motor bicycle, motor-driven cycle or power-driven cycle within any city park or upon any public beaches or upon any city-owned lands, except upon streets or alleys where such operation is specifically permitted either by statute or by ordinance. 
(Code 1973, § 27.37.010)  
Sec. 94-12. - Unattended vehicles. 
(a)  Prohibition. No person shall leave unattended any vehicle on any public highway or public property in violation of this chapter or in such a manner as to jeopardize public safety. 
(b)  Removal. Any vehicle left standing or unattended in violation of this section or in such a manner as to jeopardize public safety by either creating an unsafe condition or hindering the movement of traffic or in any tow away zone or in fire lanes under section 50-471 et seq. that have been posted as such, in the high peak traffic area noted in section 94-141, schedule F, no parking from 6:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. on Monday through Friday of each week, may be towed to a suitable place of impoundment, without prior notice or hearing, under the direction of the chief of police or his designee. Upon removal, the location of the vehicle shall be reported to the police department. 
(c)  Notice to owner. Within 48 hours of towing an illegally parked vehicle, the city shall send notice by regular mail to the owner. This notice shall contain the year, make, model and license number of the vehicle, the place where the vehicle is being held, and shall inform the owner of his right to reclaim the vehicle. If the owner does not appear within five days of mailing such notice, the procedure for notice and sale of unclaimed vehicles under section 42-190 shall apply. 
(d)  Hearing procedure. If the owner disputes the legality of the towing of his vehicle, the matter shall be processed into municipal court for trial. Pending disposition in municipal court, the owner may pay accrued storage and towing charges in order to obtain release of the vehicle. If the owner does not remove the vehicle from impoundment within 24 hours after disposition of the matter, storage charges shall accrue. If the owner disputes only the amount of storage and towing charges, the owner shall be entitled to an informal hearing at the police department. 
(e)  Owner's responsibility for costs. The owner of any vehicle which is removed according to this section is responsible for the costs of towing and storage of the vehicle. 
(f)  Penalty. Any person violating the provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall, upon conviction, forfeit not less than $5.00 nor more than $50.00, together with the costs of prosecution. 
(Code 1973, §§ 27.61.010—27.61.060)  
Sec. 94-13. - Uniform penalties for violation of state law. 
Except as provided in section 94-15 for nonmoving traffic offenses, forfeitures for violation of any provision of Wis. Stats. chs. 341 to 348 adopted by reference in section 94-1 shall conform to forfeitures for violation of the comparable state offense, including any variations or increases for second offenses. 
(Code 1973, § 27.39.020)  
Sec. 94-14. - Penalties for violations of chapter. 
(a)  Any person who violates any of the provisions of sections 94-176 through 94-178, 94-346, 94-350 and 94-351 shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not more than $40.00, together with the cost of prosecution. 
(b)  Any person who violates any of the provisions of section 94-7 or sections 94-68 or 94-91 through 94-95 shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not less than $20.00 nor more than $40.00, and not less than $50.00 nor more than $100.00 for the second or subsequent conviction within a year, together with the cost of prosecution. 
(c)  Any person who violates any of the provisions of sections 94-51 through 94-53, 94-81, 94-96 or 94-311 through 94-313 shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not less than $20.00 nor more than $200.00, together with the cost of prosecution. 
(d)  Any person violating any of the provisions of section 94-10 shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not less than $10.00 nor more than $50.00, together with the cost of prosecution. 
(e)  Any person violating any of the provisions of section 94-67 shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not less than $20.00 nor more than $50.00 for the first offense, and not less than $50.00 nor more than $100.00 for the second or subsequent conviction within one year, together with the cost of prosecution. 
(f)  Any person who violates any of the provisions of section 94-2 shall, upon conviction, forfeit not less than $25.00 nor more than $100.00, together with the cost of prosecution. 
(Code 1973, § 27.39.030)  
Sec. 94-15. - Penalties for parking violations. 
(a)  The forfeitures for offenses described in Wis. Stats. §§ 346.50—346.55, adopted by reference in section 94-1, shall be as follows: 
(1)  Wis. Stats. §§ 346.51 and 346.52: Not less than $5.00 nor more than $40.00. 
(2)  Wis. Stats. §§ 346.53, 346.54 and 346.55: Not less than $10.00 nor more than $40.00. 
(b)  The forfeiture for violation of parking regulations in sections 94-129, 94-141, 94-143, 94-145, 94-147(b), (c), 94-161, 94-241 through 94-251, 94-276, 94-280, or 94-282 shall be, upon conviction thereof, not more than $40.00, together with the cost of prosecution. 
(Code 1973, § 27.39.040)  
Sec. 94-16. - Traffic citations. 
(a)  Enforcement. This section shall be enforced in accordance with the provisions of Wis. Stats. §§ 66.12 and 345.20—345.54, ch. 799. 
(b)  Uniform citation for moving violations. The uniform traffic citation promulgated under Wis. Stats. § 345.11 shall be used for all moving traffic violations under this chapter. Stipulations of guilt or no contest may be made by persons arrested for moving traffic violations under this chapter. Such stipulations shall conform to the form contained on the uniform traffic citation and complaint under Wis. Stats. § 345.11, and may be accepted by the police department within five days of the alleged violation. 
(c)  Deposits. Any person stipulating guilt or no contest under this subsection (b) must make the deposit required under Wis. Stats. § 345.26 or, if the deposit is not established under such statute, shall deposit a forfeiture penalty as provided in the schedule established by the board of county judges of this county. Deposits may be brought or mailed to the office of the police department as directed by the arresting officer. 
(d)  Parking citations. Citations for all nonmoving traffic violations under this chapter shall conform to Wis. Stats. § 345.28, and shall be mailed or brought to the police department within five days of the issuance of the citation in lieu of court appearance. The issuing officer shall specify on such citation the amount of the applicable forfeiture as provided in this chapter. 
(e)  Notice of demerit points. Every officer accepting a stipulation under the provisions of this section shall comply with the provisions of Wis. Stats. §§ 343.28, 345.26(1)(a) and 345.27(2), and shall require the alleged violator to sign a statement of notice in substantially the form contained on the uniform traffic citation and complaint promulgated under Wis. Stats. § 345.11. 
(Code 1973, §§ 27.40.010—27.40.040)  
Sec. 94-17. - Traffic violation fine schedule. 
(a)  Payment of forfeiture in lieu of court appearance. Any person charged with a violation of the offenses listed under subsection (b) of this section may pay the amount enumerated therein at the police department in lieu of a court appearance. Persons wishing to contest charges contained in subsection (b) of this section may contact the police department to arrange a court appearance date. 
(b)  Schedule of forfeitable offenses. The following forfeitures for the offenses listed herein may be paid at the police department:

Sec. 94-18. - Late payment fees for traffic violations. 
In addition to the amount of forfeiture specified under section 94-17, the following fees shall be assessed when applicable: 
(1)  When payment is made more than five days after violation date, $5.00. 
(2)  When payment is made after issuance of a "First notice of past due ticket," $10.00. 
(3)  When payment is made after issuance of a "Final notice of past due ticket," $15.00. 
(4)  When payment is made following notification to the state department of transportation to suspend or refuse registration of vehicles under Wis. Stats. § 345.28(4)(a)2, $25.00. 
(Code 1973, § 27.60.030; Ord. No. 36-90, pt. 1, 10-2-90)  
Sec. 94-19. - Disposition of forfeitures. 
Any person accepting deposits or forfeited penalties under this chapter shall deliver them to the city treasurer within 20 days after receipt. Any person authorized to accept deposits under Wis. Stats. § 345.26 or this chapter shall qualify by taking the oath prescribed by Wis. Stats. § 19.01, and filing an official bond in the sum of $5,000.00, as described by Wis. Stats. § 19.01. 
(Code 1973, § 27.40.050) 
State Law reference— Citations for violations, cash deposits, failure to appear, Wis. Stats. § 66.119; fees in forfeiture actions, Wis. Stats. § 814.63.  
Sec. 94-20. - Parking on holidays. 
In this chapter, "holiday" means January 1, Memorial Day, July 4, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and December 25. 
(Ord. No. 35-95, pt. 1, 2-7-96)  
Sec. 94-21. - Neighborhood electric vehicles. 
(a)  Definitions. A neighborhood electric vehicle (NEV) means a self-propelled electrically-powered motor vehicle that has successfully completed the neighborhood electric vehicle America test program conducted by the federal Department of Energy and that conforms to the definition and requirements for low-speed vehicles, as adopted in the federal motor vehicle safety standards for "low-speed vehicles" under 49 CFR 571.3(b) and 571.500. 
A neighborhood electric vehicle shall be four-wheeled and have a speed range of at least 20 miles per hour and not more than 25 miles per hour on a paved surface and have a gross vehicle weight of less than 2,500 pounds. Neighborhood electric vehicle does not include an electric golf cart and shall have all of the following specifications: 
(1)  Headlamps; 
(2)  Front and rear turn signals; 
(3)  Stop lamps; 
(4)  Reflex reflectors; one red on each side as far to the rear as practicable and one red on the rear; 
(5)  An exterior mirror mounted on the driver's side and either an exterior mirror on the passenger side or an interior rearview mirror; 
(6)  Parking brake; 
(7)  A windshield that conforms to the requirements of the federal motor vehicle safety standard on glazing materials (49 CFR 571.205); 
(8)  A vehicle identification number (VIN) that complies with federal law as provided in 49 CFR 565; 
(9)  A type 1 or type 2 seatbelt assembly conforming to 49 CFR 571.209 and federal motor vehicle standard no. 209 for each designated seating position; and 
(10)  Meets the general test conditions under 49 CFR 571.50056. 
(b)  Use permitted on city streets. A licensed individual may operate a neighborhood electric vehicle on those city streets having a posted speed limit of 35 miles per hour or less, and headlamps must be on during operation. 
(c)  License. Neighborhood electric vehicles shall be registered, titled and licensed by the state. 
(d)  Permitted users. Any person who operates a neighborhood electric vehicle on any city street must hold a valid state operator's license. The operation of a neighborhood electric vehicle must in all respects comply with chapter 94 of the Racine Code of Ordinances. 
(e)  Penalty. Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall forfeit an amount as provided in section 1-15. 
(Ord. No. 05-08, pt. 1, 5-6-08)  
Sec. 94-22. - Disorderly conduct with a motor vehicle. 
No person shall, within the city, on public or private property, by or through the use of a motor vehicle, motorcycle, snowmobile, minibike, ATV or any other motorized vehicle, engage in violent, dangerous, abusive, unreasonably loud or otherwise disorderly conduct, including, but not limited to, unnecessary or deliberate or intentional: spinning of wheels, squealing of tires, revving of the engine, blowing of the horn, causing the engine to backfire, causing excessive or sudden veering or acceleration, causing the vehicle, while commencing to move or in motion, to raise one or more of its wheels off the ground, or causing the vehicle to otherwise be operated in an erratic or dangerous manner under circumstances which tend to cause or provoke a disturbance. 
(Ord. No. 2-10, pt. 1, 2-24-10)  
Secs. 94-23—94-40. - Reserved.

DIVISION 5. - TURNS[5]

State Law reference— Turning movements, Wis. Stats. §§ 346.31—346.36. 
 
Sec. 94-91. - Prohibited left turns—Generally. 
When signs are erected giving notice thereof, an operator of a vehicle shall not make a left turn at any of the following intersections when proceeding in the direction indicated: 
(1)  Durand Avenue, westerly at Elm Lane, at all times. 
(2)  South Memorial Drive, between Washington Avenue and 16th Street, southbound on the one-way section as it intersects with the main roadway. 
(3)  South Memorial Drive, northbound at the right turn cutoff onto Washington Avenue. 
(4)  Northerly on Mt. Pleasant Street, between the north line of Rapids Drive and the south line of Goold Street. 
(5)  Southwesterly on West Street at State Street, between 3:00 p.m. and 6:00 p.m. on weekdays. 
(6)  Southerly on Racine Street at 16th Street, between 3:00 p.m. and 6:00 p.m. on weekdays. 
(7)  Easterly on State Street at North Memorial Drive. 
(8)  Westerly on Sixth Street at Marquette Street, between 3:00 p.m. and 6:00 p.m. on weekdays. 
(9)  Marquette Street, southerly at Washington Avenue. 
(10)  Westerly on Dodge Street at North Main Street. 
(11)  Carmel Avenue, southeasterly at Columbia Street. 
(Code 1973, § 27.11.010; Ord. No. 22-92, pt. 1, 8-4-92; Ord. No. 26-92, pt. 1, 9-1-92; Ord. No. 3-93, pt. 1, 3-2-93; Ord. No. 9-93, pt. 1, 5-5-93; Ord. No. 14-97, pt. 1, 9-2-97; Ord. No. 22-00, pt. 2, 11-9-00; Ord. of 9-4-01, pt. 8.B.)  
Sec. 94-92. - Same—Entering or exiting private property. 
When signs are erected giving notice thereof, an operator of a motor vehicle shall not make a left turn at the areas designated below: 
(1)  On the 900 block of Washington Avenue: Left-hand turns to enter private property in the northerly 130 feet of the 900 block of Washington Avenue and left-hand turns out of driveways in the northerly 130 feet of the 900 block in the northeast side of Washington Avenue are prohibited. 
(2)  On the 4600 block of Washington Avenue: Left-hand turns to exit out of driveways in the westerly 100 feet of the 4600 block of the north side of Washington Avenue are prohibited. 
(3)  On the 2000 block of Douglas Avenue: Left-hand turns to enter driveways of private property located on the west side of Douglas Avenue and a distance of 160 feet north of Yout Street are prohibited; left-hand turns by operators of vehicles exiting from such driveways are likewise prohibited. 
(4)  On the 2100 block of Lathrop Avenue: lefthand turns to exit out of driveway of private property located on the west side of Lathrop Avenue, a distance of 100 feet south of 21st Street, are prohibited. 
(5)  On the 2100 block of Rapids Drive: Left-hand turns to enter private property by westbound vehicles in the westerly 850 feet of the 2100 block of Rapids Drive are prohibited. 
(6)  On the odd numbered side of State Street east of 1743 State Street, left hand turns to exit out of the driveways are prohibited. 
(Code 1973, § 27.11.020; Ord. No. 27-93, pt. 1, 12-7-93; Ord. No. 14-97, pt. 2, 9-2-97; Ord. No. 16-00, pt. 1, 9-6-00; Ord. No. 14-04, pt. 1, 6-1-04)  
Sec. 94-93. - Mandatory left turn. 
(a)  The operator of a vehicle proceeding easterly on Seventh Street and approaching Main Street in the lane farthest to the left shall turn left onto Main Street and shall not proceed in any other direction. 
(b)  The operator of a vehicle proceeding southerly on Washington Avenue and approaching Racine Street in the lane farthest to the left shall turn left onto Racine Street and shall not proceed in any other direction. 
(c)  The operator of a vehicle proceeding northerly on North Memorial Drive and approaching State Street in the lane furthest to the left shall turn left onto State Street and shall not proceed in any other direction. 
(d)  The operator of a vehicle proceeding westerly on South Street and approaching Mt. Pleasant Street in the lane farthest to the left shall turn left onto Mt. Pleasant Street and shall not proceed in any other direction. 
(e)  The operator of a vehicle proceeding southerly on Main Street and approaching Seventh Street in the lane farthest to the left shall turn left onto Seventh Street and shall not proceed in any other direction. 
(Code 1973, § 27.11.030; Ord. No. 12-92, pt. 1, 5-19-92; 6-6-95; Ord. No. 8-95, pt. 1, 7-5-95)  
Sec. 94-94. - Mandatory right turns. 
(a)  The operator of a vehicle proceeding southeasterly on State Street and approaching North Memorial Drive in the lane furthest to the right shall turn right onto North Memorial Drive and shall not proceed in any other direction. 
(b)  The operator of a vehicle proceeding westerly on Sam Johnson Parkway and approaching Main Street shall turn right onto Main Street and shall not proceed in any other direction. 
(c)  The operator of a vehicle proceeding southerly on Valley Drive and approaching Washington Avenue in the lane furthest to the right shall turn right onto Washington Avenue and shall not proceed in any other direction. 
(d)  The operator of a vehicle proceeding southerly on Taylor Avenue and approaching Durand Avenue in the lane furthest to the right shall turn right onto Durand Avenue and shall not proceed in any other direction. 
(e)  The operator of a vehicle proceeding northerly on Racine Street and approaching Washington Avenue shall turn right onto Washington Avenue and shall not proceed in any other direction. 
(f)  The operator of a vehicle proceeding northerly on Racine Street and approaching 11th Street in the lane furthest to the right shall turn right onto 11th Street and shall not proceed in any other direction. 
(Code 1973, § 27.11.035; Ord. of 12-3-02, pt. 4.B.; Ord. No. 42-04, pt. 1, 12-7-04; Ord. No. 5-05, pt. 1, 3-1-05; Ord. No. 8-07, pt. 1, 5-1-07)

ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Fire lane regulations, § 50-471 et seq.; streets, § 82-31 et seq.; repair or storage of motor vehicles in streets prohibited, § 82-42. 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate stopping, standing or parking of vehicles, Wis. Stats. § 349.13. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 94-126. - Angle parking, schedule E. 
Angle parking shall be allowed within the indicated spaces by signs or markings and at the locations specified as follows: 
Ontario Street, west side, from State Street south 235 feet. 
South side of alley area adjacent to Riverview Terrace. 
(Ord. No. 17-92, pt. 1, § 27.19.050, 6-16-92)  
Sec. 94-127. - Prohibited in places reserved for fire department vehicles; exceptions. 
(a)  No person may park, stop or leave standing any vehicle, whether attended or unattended and whether temporarily or otherwise, upon any portion of a street, highway or public parking facility reserved for fire department vehicles by official traffic signs, markers or parking meters indicating the restriction, except as provided in subsection (b) of this section. The areas reserved for fire department vehicles in the city are described in the following schedule: 
Eighth Street, north side, from Center Street west 330 feet. 
Eighth Street, south side, from 45 feet east of Washington Avenue east 225 feet. 
(b)  Any vehicle owned, operated or maintained by a fire department, as defined in Wis. Stats. §§ 213.08 and 213.095, may stop, stand or park in a place reserved for fire department vehicles as provided in this section. 
(Code 1973, §§ 27.49.010, 27.49.020; Ord. No. 41-04, pt. 1, 12-7-04)  
Sec. 94-128. - Large vehicle parking restrictions. 
(a)  Definitions. A large vehicle is defined as a vehicle, trailer or combination thereof which meets any of the following criteria: 
(1)  A combined weight of vehicle and load in excess of 10,000 pounds or registered in excess of 10,000 pounds. 
(2)  Has a length of greater than 30 feet. 
(3)  Is of such a width that when parked in accordance with the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 346.54, encroaches on the normal traveled way of the street upon which it is parked. 
(b)  Parking restrictions. No person shall park a large vehicle, as defined in this section, on any public street or alley for more than 30 minutes during any 24-hour period, excepting that school buses servicing public or private schools within the Racine Unified School District may park for no more than three hours during a 24-hour period. 
(c)  Exceptions to prohibition. Vehicles which are covered by the exceptions set forth in Wis. Stats. § 346.50 are also exempt from the prohibitions of this section. Vehicles engaged in construction work shall be exempt from the prohibitions of this section only when engaged directly in construction work. Vehicles actively engaged in loading and unloading are also exempted from this section. Vehicles owned by public utilities and which have been approved by the police department as necessary for on-call service in responding to police and fire emergencies are also exempt from the prohibition of this section. 
(d)  Payment of forfeiture in lieu of court appearance. Any person charged with a violation of the offense listed in subsection (a) of this section may pay the amount of $50.00 at the police department in lieu of a court appearance. 
(Code 1973, §§ 27.44.010—27.44.030; Ord. No. 27-90, pt. 1, 7-17-90; Ord. No. 27-95, pts. 1—4, 12-5-95; Ord. No. 14-99, pt. 1, 12-21-99; Ord. No. 6-00, pt. 1, 6-7-00; Ord. No. 0018-18, pt. 1, 1-15-19)  
Sec. 94-129. - Extended overtime parking. 
No person shall permit any vehicle to remain parked in any restricted parking area, as set out in this chapter, or in any parking meter zone, beyond the prescribed maximum legal parking time. To permit a vehicle, after a summons has been affixed to a permanent place on or within the vehicle or served upon the violator, to remain for a period of time equal to the prescribed maximum legal parking time for the area or zone shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1973, § 27.25.010)  
Sec. 94-130. - Parking junk collection vehicles. 
(a)  Prohibition. No person shall park or keep any vehicle operated or licensed for the collection of junk on any private property or public street, alley, sidewalk or other public property within the city, other than a licensed junkyard, for more than one hour unless such vehicle is in the active process of being loaded with junk, being unloaded at a licensed junkyard, or unless all junk has been removed therefrom at an authorized place. 
(b)  Penalty. Any person convicted of a violation of this section shall forfeit not less than $20.00 nor more than $150.00, plus the costs of prosecution. 
(Code 1973, §§ 27.51.010, 27.51.020) 
Cross reference— Nuisance vehicles, § 42-221 et seq.  
Sec. 94-131. - Parking in off-street areas other than conforming driveways or conforming off-street parking areas prohibited. 
No person shall park in any off-street area on public or private property which does not meet the requirements set forth in chapter 114, article XI, division 2 of the Municipal Code of the City of Racine. Whoever violates this section shall, upon conviction, forfeit not less than $1.00 nor more than $1,000.00, together with the costs of prosecution. Any person charged under this section may, in lieu of a court appearance, forfeit $50.00 at the police department. 
(Ord. No. 16-99, pt. 1, 2-1-00)  
Sec. 94-132. - Parking in the parkway-sidewalk area. 
No person shall park in the parkway or a driveway between a public sidewalk and the street pavement. A person may park in a driveway within the parkway where there is no sidewalk and where a minimum of two feet of space is maintained between the vehicle and the closest edge of street pavement. 
(Ord. No. 48-04, pt. 1, 12-21-04)  
Secs. 94-133—94-140. - Reserved.

State Law reference— Authority to regulate stopping, standing or parking of vehicles, Wis. Stats. § 349.13.  
Sec. 94-142. - No parking signs. 
There shall be no parking permitted upon any portion of a street when such portion is properly designated by an official no parking sign, erected pursuant to the authority and direction of the public works and services committee. 
(Code 1973, § 27.17.020; Ord. No. 0005-18, pt. 6, 8-6-18)  
Sec. 94-143. - Limited parking zones, schedule G. 
When signs are erected giving notice, no person shall park a vehicle upon any of the streets or parts of streets described in this section for a period of time longer than that set forth in the schedule set out in this section. If at any time or place on any such street parking is prohibited under the provisions of section 94-141, the no parking restriction shall take precedence over the limited parking restriction at such time and place.

Sec. 94-144. - Motorcycle parking zone. 
(a)  The zones designated as motorcycle parking zones are South Memorial Drive, west side, from 100 feet north of DeKoven Avenue north 75 feet. 
(b)  No person shall park, stop or leave standing any vehicle except a motorcycle in any zone established under this section. 
(Code 1973, §§ 27.19.020, 27.19.030; Ord. No. 17-94, pt. 1, 9-6-94; Ord. No. 43-04, pt. 1, 12-7-04)  
Sec. 94-145. - Parking prohibited between 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m.; exceptions. 
The operator or owner of any vehicle shall not park such vehicle between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on any street in the city, except that this prohibition shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Any Saturday or Sunday morning excepting from December 1 to April 1 of each year; 
(2)  Any holiday as designated in section 94-20; 
(3)  Those blocks where parking is prohibited along one entire side; 
(4)  The even-numbered side of any street on the morning of any even-numbered day; 
(5)  The odd-numbered side of any street on the morning of any odd-numbered day; 
(6)  Those blocks where parking is prohibited from 6:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m.; 
(7)  Those blocks designated as cul-de-sacs; and 
(8)  Those blocks within two blocks of a construction zone. 
(9)  Within an area bounded by and including State Street to Seventh Street from Main Street to Grand Avenue, parking shall be permitted from 2:00 a.m. to 3:00 a.m. 
(Code 1973, § 27.20.010; Ord. No. 4-92, pt. 1, 3-17-92; Ord. No. 13-94, pt. 1, 7-5-94; Ord. No. 34-95, pt. 2, 2-7-96; Ord. No. 18-09, pt. 1, 9-1-09; Ord. No. 03-16, pt. 1, 8-8-16; Ord. No. 03-16, pt. 1, 8-8-16)  
Sec. 94-146. - Parking time limit on streets. 
No person shall park or leave a vehicle upon any public street or alley in the city for a period longer than 48 hours. 
(Code 1973, § 27.20.020)  
Sec. 94-147. - Stopping, standing or parking prohibited in places reserved for law enforcement vehicles, schedule H; where permitted. 
(a)  No person may park, stop or leave standing any vehicle, whether attended or unattended and whether temporarily or otherwise, upon any portion of any street, highway or public parking facility reserved for law enforcement vehicles by official traffic signs, markers or parking meters indicating the restriction, except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section. The areas reserved for law enforcement vehicles in the city are described in the following schedule: 
Center Street, west side, from Eighth Street north 270 feet. 
Main Street, west side, from 90 feet south of Seventh Street south 160 feet. 
Wisconsin Avenue, west side, from 130 feet north of 14th Street north 70 feet. 
Eighth Street, north side, from 60 feet east of Wisconsin Avenue east 50 feet. 
Seventh Street, south side, from Wisconsin Avenue to Main Street. 
14th Street, north side, from 75 feet west of Wisconsin Avenue west 45 feet. 
Romayne Avenue, south side, from Anthony Lane east 80 feet. 
Geneva Street, west side, from Hamilton Street south 40 feet. 
(b)  The operator of a vehicle shall stop, stand or park such vehicle in compliance with the directions of a traffic control signal or sign. 
(c)  Any vehicle owned, operated or maintained by a law enforcement agency, as defined in Wis. Stats. § 165.83, may stop, stand or park in a place reserved for law enforcement vehicles as provided in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1973, §§ 27.48.010, 27.48.020; 11-4-97; Ord. of 2-5-08, § B.1.; Ord. of 12-22-08(1), § E.1.; Ord. of 7-5-16, § C.1., 7-5-16; Ord. of 4-15-19, § A.1)  
Sec. 94-148. - Notice. 
Notice of the requirements in this division shall be given by signs as required by Wis. Stats. § 349.13. 
(Code 1973, § 27.20.040)  
Secs. 94-149—94-160. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - LOADING AREAS 
 
Sec. 94-161. - Permit; types. 
Area privileges for setting aside curb space for loading zones in front of stores, theaters, hotels and other places of business may be granted to the owner or lessee of such property upon application therefor and proper cause for such loading zone or no parking area being shown to the common council. Area privileges shall be of two kinds, limited and unlimited. The limited type of area permitted shall be marked off by portable signs and the unlimited type of area permitted shall be marked off by stationary signs. The signs for limited area privileges shall be for a designated time and when not in use shall be removed. In the unlimited area privileges the signs may remain stationary. Any permit granted for area privileges under this division may be revoked by the common council at any time. 
(Code 1973, § 27.21.010; Ord. No. 19-96, pt. 1, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 94-162. - Application. 
Any owner or lessee requesting an area privilege under this division shall file a written application with the common council on forms provided by the city, setting forth the name of the person and, in the case of a corporation, the names of the principal officers thereof, together with the exact location, nature and extent of the use of such building and the reason or necessity for such area privilege. 
(Code 1973, § 27.21.020)  
Sec. 94-163. - Area privilege fees. 
The area privilege fee as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council for each lineal foot of curb space covered by the area privilege granted on or after January 1 of any year, excepting that if the area privilege is granted on or after July 1 of any year, the fee shall be as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council for each lineal foot of curb space covered by the area privilege granted for that year. If the common council finds that such loading and unloading zone should be established it shall direct the commissioner of public works to erect appropriate signs and collect the area privilege fee and sign installation costs. All area privileges shall expire on December 31. Area privileges may be renewed and shall remain in effect upon payment of the annual fee, unless revoked by the public works and services committee. The persons, groups or organizations which may receive an area privilege without payment of the annual fee are public or parochial schools, churches, hospitals, asylums or charitable institutions devoted to or which furnish free services to disabled persons. 
(Code 1973, § 27.21.030; Ord. No. 19-96, pt. 2, 11-6-96; Ord. No. 26-01, pt. 2, 10-2-01; Ord. No. 25-04, pt. 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 4-06, pt. 3, 2-23-06; Ord. No. 0005-18, pt. 7, 8-6-18; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 100, 11-12-19)  
Sec. 94-164. - Zones established; record; erection of signs. 
The commissioner of public works shall keep an accurate record of the size and location of all authorized area privilege zones. No person except the traffic engineer shall erect a loading zone or area privilege sign. 
(Code 1973, § 27.21.040; 3-21-95; Ord. No. 19-96, pt. 3, 11-6-96; Ord. No. 4-06, pt. 4, 2-23-06)  
Sec. 94-165. - Hours of restriction. 
No person may park any vehicle in any area privilege zones authorized under this division between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. of any day except Sundays and holidays. 
(Code 1973, § 27.21.050)  
Sec. 94-166. - Area privilege fee at all times. 
The annual fee for each lineal foot of curb space covered by an area privilege shall be as set forth in the fee schedule as established by the common council. No person may park any vehicle in any area privilege zones authorized under this division at any time. 
(Ord. No. 23-06, pt. 1, 6-28-06; Ord. No. 0028-19, pt. 101, 11-12-19)  
Secs. 94-167—94-175. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - TAXICABS 
 
Sec. 94-176. - Taxicab stands designated. 
The following locations are hereby designated as taxicab stands: 
(1)  Festival Hall. 
(2)  Elmwood Plaza. 
(3)  Regency Mall. 
(4)  Westgate Mall. 
(5)  Holiday Inn. 
(6)  Three Mile Road and North Main Street. 
(Code 1973, § 27.30.010; Ord. No. 24-90, pt. 1, 7-17-90; Ord. No. 29-90, pt. 1, 10-2-90; Ord. No. 3-92, pt. 1, 2-19-92)  
Sec. 94-177. - Other vehicles in taxicab stands. 
The operator of any vehicle other than a taxicab shall not stand or park in an officially designated taxicab stand except that the operator of any passenger vehicle may temporarily stop at any such stand for the purpose of and while actually engaged in the unloading and loading of passengers. 
(Code 1973, § 27.30.030)  
Sec. 94-178. - Taxicab parking. 
Taxicabs may park upon public streets and thoroughfares for 15-minute periods from 9:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. and for unlimited periods from 7:00 p.m. to 9:00 a.m., provided that the time of such parking shall not exceed the time allowed other vehicles at the particular location. No person operating a taxicab shall park such taxicab at such places for a period longer than that allowed by this section. 
(Code 1973, § 27.30.020)  
Secs. 94-179—94-190. - Reserved.

DIVISION 6. - PARKING FOR PHYSICALLY DISABLED[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note— Parts 4—6 of Ord. No. 19-96, adopted Nov. 6, 1996, repealed §§ 94-201—94-203 in their entirety. Formerly, §§ 94-201—94-203 pertained to parking for physically disabled and derived from §§ 27.47.010, 27.47.020 of the 1973 Code; pt. 1 of Ord. No. 14-92, adopted June 16, 1992; Feb. 7, 1995; Mar. 21, 1995; July 5, 1995; Aug. 1, 1995; Oct. 3, 1995; Nov. 7, 1995; Dec. 5, 1995; Feb. 7, 1996; Mar. 5, 1996; April 2, 1996; May 8, 1996; Aug. 5, 1996; Sept. 3, 1996. Parts 4—6 also added new §§ 94-201—94-203 to read as herein set out. 
State Law reference— Parking for disabled, Wis. Stats. §§ 346.503, 346.505. 
 
Sec. 94-201. - Permits. 
No person, except as provided in section 94-205, may park, stop or leave standing any vehicle, whether attended or unattended and whether temporarily or otherwise, upon any portion of a street, highway or public parking facility reserved for physically disabled persons by official traffic signs, markers or parking meters indicating the restriction. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, pt. 4, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 94-202. - Application; fees. 
Any owner or lessee requesting a disabled parking zone under this division shall file a written application with the traffic engineer on forms provided by the city, setting forth the name of the person or business, together with the exact location and reason or necessity for such a zone. If the traffic engineer finds that such zone should be established he shall erect appropriate signs and collect the sign installation costs from the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, pt. 5, 11-6-96; Ord. No. 15-03, pt. 1, 7-1-03)  
Sec. 94-203. - Zones established; record; erection of signs. 
The city engineer shall keep an accurate record of the location of all authorized disabled parking zones. No person except the city engineer shall erect a disabled parking zone sign. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, pt. 6, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 94-204. - Other restrictions. 
No person may park a vehicle in any disabled parking zone within an area which is designated as parking prohibited during certain hours of the day in accordance with pertinent sections of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, pt. 7, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 94-205. - Exceptions to section 94-201. 
(a)  A vehicle bearing special registration plates issued under Wis. Stats. § 341.14(1), (1a), (1m) or (1q) is exempt from section 94-201. 
(b)  Vehicles parked by or under the direction of a person to whom has been issued a special identification card by the state department of transportation under Wis. Stats. § 343.51 shall be exempt from section 94-201. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, pt. 8, 11-6-96)  
Sec. 94-206. - Display of registration. 
Any person or owner of a vehicle who parks, stops or leaves standing any vehicle, whether attended or unattended and whether temporarily or otherwise, upon any portion of a street, highway or public parking facility reserved for physically disabled persons by official traffic signs, markers or parking meters indicating the restriction, shall display in a prominent location on the driver's side of the vehicle the special registration authorized by Wis. Stats. § 341.14(1), (1a), (1m) or (1q) or by subject to the forfeiture as provided in section 94-51. 
(Ord. No. 19-96, pt. 9, 11-6-96)  
Secs. 94-207—94-215. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - SNOW EMERGENCIES[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference— Requirements regarding snow removal, § 82-109. 
 
Sec. 94-216. - Declaration; duration. 
There is hereby declared an emergency to exist in the city by reason of a heavy snowstorm whenever snow falls during any period of 24 hours or less to a depth of three inches or more, or has fallen in such manner as to produce a congestion of traffic, in that such storm constitutes a serious public hazard impairing transportation, the movement of food and fuel supplies, medical care, fire, health and police protection, and other vital facilities of the city. Such emergency is declared to continue for a period of 48 hours or until such earlier time as snowplowing operations have been declared completed by the commissioner of public works. 
(Code 1973, § 27.26.010)  
Sec. 94-217. - Parking prohibitions—Generally. 
(a)  Whenever a snow emergency exists and the commissioner of public works shall cause an announcement thereof to be made by a radio station and/or television station whose normal operating range covers the city or shall cause publication thereof in the newspaper in general circulation in the city, no person shall park or allow to be parked any vehicle of any kind or description while the snow emergency remains in effect upon any connecting highways (designated as state trunk highways) or upon any streets designated as arterial streets or collector streets as shown by the snow emergency map on file in the office of the city clerk, or upon any portion of a street that is in a parking meter zone. 
(b)  On all streets not designated in subsection (a) of this section, parking shall be prohibited on the odd-numbered side of the street from the time of declaration of the snow emergency on a day before an even-numbered day until 6:00 a.m. of the next day and on the even-numbered side of the street from the time of declaration of the snow emergency on a day before an odd-numbered day until 6:00 a.m. of the next day; provided, however, vehicles may be parked for a period of time not longer than three minutes for actual unloading or loading of passengers or not longer than 30 minutes for actual unloading or loading of property where no other regulation restricting parking as to place or time is violated thereby. 
(c)  The snow emergency map of the city may be revised by order of the commissioner of public works when the commissioner determines that a revision is in the public interest. Such revisions shall become effective upon publication in a newspaper as set forth in this section, and the commissioner shall file such revisions with the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1973, § 27.26.020; Ord. No. 9-94, pt. 1, 6-7-94; Ord. No. 45-04, pt. 1, 12-7-04; Ord. No. 18-13, pts. 1, 2, 11-27-13)  
Sec. 94-218. - Same—Temporary prohibition; notice. 
The commissioner of public works is hereby empowered to temporarily prohibit the parking of vehicles upon any city street from which snow is to be removed. Notice shall be posted along such streets not later than 4:00 p.m. on the day preceding snow removal and shall indicate the day of snow removal. No person shall park or suffer to be parked any vehicle of any kind or description upon any street so posted after 4:00 a.m. on the day indicated on such notice. Such notice shall be removed and the temporary prohibition ended by the commissioner of public works after the completion of snow removal. 
(Code 1973, § 27.26.030)  
Sec. 94-219. - Removal of vehicles. 
A vehicle of any kind or description parked in violation of snow removal or snow emergency regulations may be removed by towing to another area not a part of the snow removal or snow emergency area to an impound lot. Such removal shall be directed by the chief of police. 
(Code 1973, § 27.26.040)  
Sec. 94-220. - Owner's responsibility for removal costs. 
The owner of any vehicle removed from a snow removal or snow emergency area shall be responsible for all costs of towing, removal and storage. If the owner disputes the amount of these charges, the owner shall be entitled to an informal hearing at the police department. 
(Code 1973, § 27.26.050)  
Sec. 94-221. - Provisions superseded. 
Whenever a snow emergency is declared under this division, this division shall supersede and prevail over the provisions of section 94-145. 
(Code 1973, § 27.26.060)  
Sec. 94-222. - Enforcement of article. 
It should be the duty of the police department and the department of transportation to enforce the parking restrictions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 7-01, pt. 1, 3-6-01)  
Secs. 94-223—94-240. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - PARKING METERS 
 
Sec. 94-241. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Park or parking means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, upon a street otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of, and while actually engaged in, receiving or discharging passengers or loading or unloading merchandise or in obedience to traffic regulations, signs or signals or an involuntary stopping of the vehicle by reason of causes beyond the control of the operator of the vehicle. 
Parking meter means any device or meter not inconsistent with this article placed or erected for the regulation of parking by authority of this article. Each parking meter installed shall indicate by proper legend the legal parking time established by the city and when operated shall at all times indicate the balance of legal parking time, and at the expiration of such period shall indicate illegal, expired or overtime parking. 
Parking meter space means any space within a parking meter zone adjacent to a parking meter, and which is duly designated for the parking of a single vehicle by lines painted or otherwise durably marked on the curb or on the surface of the street adjacent to or adjoining the parking meters. 
Parking meter zone means any street upon which parking meters are installed and in operation. 
(Code 1973, § 27.22.010) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.
